This is not only just and characteristic, but it is satisfying. We have heard much of intrigues about the State and War Departments, to procure the imprisonment of suspected then, solely to indulge private malice or to serve a personal end. We have been told that Gen. MCCLELLAN [???] Gen. [???], to avoid the [???] of his own [???]. All this we now know to be thecoinage of fancy. Whatever has been done of this kind has been done by President LINCOLN himself, whose character is fortunately beyond all suspicion of partiality, injustice or oppression. When the time comes, we shall no doubt find that, whoever has been wrong, the President has been right.

abstract: GOTTSCHALK'S CONCERT AT NIBLO'S SALOON.  There can be little doubt that, whatever may be the opinion entertained by the professional musician respecting the merits of H.M. GOTTSCHALK, he is accepted by the public as one of the few artists who are...
lead_paragraph: GOTTSCHALK's CONCERT AT NIBLO's SALOON. -- There can be little doubt that, whatever may be the opinion entertained by the professional musician respecting the merits of H.M. GOTTSCHALK, he is accepted by the public as one of the few artists who are the greatest of modern pianists. while the critic heartily indorses its judgment. This is on the score, [???] alone of his brillancy of touch and execution, but, also, of the quaint originality of his invention, and the musical delight with which it would seem to be conceived. We have been more specially induced to remark on this last from hearing the new dance, "Reponds [???]," which he produced for the first time, and which was rendered by himself and Mr. H. SANDERSON. This was merely a [???], the idea of which was derived from some of the Spanish dances with which he has been conversant among the Havanese Creoles. But how splendidly has he embroidered the original theme he had seized upon, and wrought it, with its quaint time, into one of the most deliciously poetical of dances. As you listen to him, the nervous lightness of the Creole girl and her partner flashes before you, and you improvise the romance which the dream of the composer has suggested. This piece was wonderfully rendered by [???], who was most ably assisted by SANDERSON, and deserved the [???] applause which was awarded it. We may also warmly [???] the [???] on BEETHOVEN's Sonata Patherique -- or rather the manner in which it was translated by him. Perhaps, the German admirers of the master might somewhat except to its excessive brilliancy. But we ourselves see no reason for not accepting [???] transition, even if it verges upon being a new reading of the master, any more than we might decline recognizing the merit of [???], because it does not resemble the [???] JOHN [???] formerly gave the [???] world. The [???] a Seville, which is a charming and quiet bit of musical embroidery, in which his fingers [???] [???], was on this occasion exchanged by him for "The Funeral [???]." We may mention than in [???] serving the encore for the overture of "[???] Tell," arranged for two [???], Mr. [???], [???] spontaneous good feeling, responded to it by playing, with Mr. SANDERSON, who had performed the [???] [???] "The Bridal Eve Polka," composed by the [???] the vocal start of the evening, although the new tenor, TOMBESI, assisted in the [???] with [???]. The "Pardon de [???]." although not heard by us by any means for the first time, was a vocal gem well worth the setting which it had in the remainder of the concert. [???] in our opinion, not so good in the salon as on the stage. However, as we have, as yet, heard him but twice, it is hardly just to him, while it is certainly unjust to the public, to give a decided opinion in either case. The audience,at all events, seemed to share our opinion. We need not say that the Saloon was crowded by the fashion, while its entrance was overlaid with the criticism and musical taste of the City.

abstract: Editorial proposes policy for rebuilding Union when war is over
snippet: Editorial proposes policy for rebuilding Union when war is over
lead_paragraph: The time has come, in the rapid progress of events, for the Northern people to consider seriously their policy of reconstruction. Victories on the battle-field, capture of forts and batteries, the surrender of large cities and the military occupation of States as large as European kingdoms, are all very well -- they are indispensable, but they offer no solution of the final question, "How to reconstruct the Union?" We shall, it is true, conquer the South; we shall break up her armies and take possession of her cities; we can hold her as a conquered province, but it would be as Russia holds Poland, or as England held Ireland in the time of CROMWELL. It might, indeed, be a necessary state of things, but it would be one very repugnant to American feelings, very dangerous to our own liberties, and unsuited to our institutions and our Constitution. It is necessary for us, if possible, to have an American Union again. How shall we bring it about out of this chaos of contending forces, and this storm of civil wrath and mutual bitterness? This is the important question for us now. The answer we believe to be found in the very conditions of the problem - a solution, too, of the most hopeful nature - What is it, this war? We must never forget that it is not a war of sections, nor of parties. It in a class war. It is an ambitious insurrection of a powerful aristocracy for themselves. It is a war of the rich, in the interest of the rich, and is really against the poor and the middle class. It is the gentlemen's rebellion. It arose with the upper class, it is borne by them, it is forced upon others by their power. They are offering their wealth like water for it. The Southern aristocracy are now a compact, absolute military despotism - such as the world has seldom seen - able with the energy, ability and means of a few hundred thousand men to control the lives and destinies of millions who have no heart or interest in the struggle. It will be noticed that the aristocracies of the world everywhere sympathize with this powerful class. A large portion of the aristocratic interest of England knows instinctively that the struggle in the United States is only a type of the contest waging in Great Britain between the few and the many. Every day reveals some new proof of the nature of our civil war - that it is a war of classes. We find, as one battle after another occurs, that the rank and file in the Southern armies have little interest in the struggle. They surrender by the ten thousand - they yield strong position's at the first motion of a charge - they give up forts add islands which might hold out for months - they desert and mutiny. Even their own papers state that men are forced into the army at the point of the bayonet. The private soldiers invariably assure our men that they would gladly take the oath of allegiance; they are sick of the war, and sorry that they ever went into it. But with the officers - "the gentlemen," (so called) - it is quite another story. These are always determined and bitter. They hate the Yankee, they detest the Union. Whenever thay can, they burn their cotton, desert their homes, and abandon their estates. They have sworn an undying hostility to our Government, and neither peace nor pardon would mollify them.
headline: {'main': 'The War a War of the People against the Aristocracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War a War of the People against the Aristocracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The French war steamer Labradore, commander DE ATTEYNIE, arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, in six days. She has side wheels, mounts four guns, and carries a crew of 200 men; her engine is 250 horse-power. She reports that there was no American war vessel at Havana when she sailed.
lead_paragraph: The French war steamer Labradore, commander DE ATTEYNIE, arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, in six days. abstract: The rebel leaders count largely upon the aid they are presently to receive from the climate in repelling the Union armies. The occupation of New-Orleans cannot, they believe, continue longer than June, because of the Summer heat, malaria, and fevers, to which Northern troops will be exposed; and as last Fall they argued that if they could only hold out until Winter, Europe would come to their assistance, so they now persuade themselves that Summer will bring to their redemption that tremendous destroyer, the yellow fever.
lead_paragraph: The rebel leaders count largely upon the aid they are presently to receive from the climate in repelling the Union armies. abstract: -- The merit of capturing New-Orleanswill only be apportioned when we receive the official accounts. It is so common, however, to hear the achievement ascribed wholly for "PORTER's Mortar Flotilla," that it is well worth while to recall that the expedition was composed only partially of mortar-boats; a very powerful squadron of men-of-war, under command of Capt. THEODORUS BAILEY, constituting a very material portion. Of the entire naval expedition, composed of these two divisions, the command was in the hands of Capt. FARRAGUT. The details will probably show that the credit is to be divided equitably between FARRAGUT, BAILEY and PORTER.

abstract: The Toledo Commercial of Friday morning gives the particulars of the discovery, in that city, of several boxes of stolen hospital stores recently received there by express. For some time the suspicion had been entertained that something of the kind was going on, from the fact that packages had passed through the express office from some of the public hospitals. On Wednesday two boxes were received from Lebanon, Kentucky, and the express agent duly notified the police of their arrival. One of the boxes was permitted to be taken away by its apparent owner and carried to the lower part of the city. There the police seized it, as well as another box of a similar description, and they were found to contain hospital stores of one kind and another, evidently stolen. Still another box was seized at the express office, and found to contain similar goods. Still four other boxes and two trunks were seized at the Dayton and Michigan Depot, and a large and very suspicious variety of goods were discovered. One box was found filled with woolen shirts and drawers. Another was full of saddles, harnesses, &c. A variety of small stores -- tea, coffee, sugar, &c. --was found, the whole evidently stolen. One man, [???] W. HINDS, to whom one of the boxes was addressed, is the only person directly implicated. He has been arrested, and in default of ball has been sent to jail by the Mayor, to a waft examination on Monday next. HINDS had been connected with the hospital at Lebanon, Kr., as [???]. The Commercial says that it is reported there is now at [???] ten [???] of this stolen properly, which has been [???] about the State, until charges to the [???] of [???] have accumulated upon it. The Government agents have been notified of the discoveries at Toledo, and to look after the property, which at that place was [???] worth $500. Quite a large propertion of it was presumed to be the contributions of Soldiers Aid [???].  The rascals who engage in such a system of stealing, and of such goods, ought to be shot. No punishment could possibly be too severe for [???].

abstract: The report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the atrocities perpetrated by the rebels upon the bodies of our soldiers who have fallen in battle shows, in its ...
lead_paragraph: The report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the atrocities perpetrated by the rebels upon the bodies of our soldiers who have fallen in battle shows, in its true colors, the character of the parties to the contest we are waging. By the rules of modern warfare the moment a man has fallen he is entitled to all the care that an enemy is able to bestow upon its soldiers similarly situated; and if death ensues, to all the rites of Christian sepulture. The rule is based upon the fact that modern wars are waged, not to wreak personal hate or vengeance, but to vindicate a principle or alleged necessity of State. The moment a soldier, from any cause, ceases to be a combatant, his person is respected, according to well-established and humane laws. It is only savages that burn at the stake; tear out and devour the heart of a victim, as the highest manifestation of [???] prowess and [???]; display in ferocious triumph mutilated remains; convert skulls into goblets, human jaws into spurs for cavalry [???]; or strip the flesh from the bones, to crave on the latter ghastly devices and [???] of the fight. But many of these, and still greater outrages, are asserted by the present Committee to have been committed upon those of our soldiers who fell at Bull Run, and careful examination, it is stated, shows that in every important engagement gross outrages against humanity have been committed.

abstract: The news we receive from the rebels concerning New-Orleans is a remarkable medley, and the only fact that appears in it clear and certain is that the city is really in our possession.
lead_paragraph: The news we receive from the rebels concerning New-Orleans is a remarkable medley, and the only fact that appears in it clear and certain is that the city is really in our possession. The fleet passed Fort Jackson just a week ago this morning, and by noon of next day it appeared before the Crescent City. A demand for the surrender of the city was immediately made by the commander of the naval squadron, which the rebel General refused to comply with; but immediately after his refusal, he and his forces evacuated the city, and fled northward by railroad, nearly a hundred miles. Commodore FARRAGUT, instead of opening fire upon the rebellious city, then entered into a correspondence with the civil authorities, the result of which is not told; but the terms of the dispatch we give this morning, dated Mobile, Sunday, indicate that the city functionaries were trying to induce our naval commander to ask them to surrender the city; and the only thing they seemed to fear was that he would not renew his demand. It is said that "he promised the Mayor's Secretary, who visited the fleet by flag of truce, that he would make a renewed demand for the surrender of the city; but," alas ! "he has not done so up to this hour, 5 o'clock" (Sunday.) That certainly looks exceedingly like a parallel to the authentic tale of Capt. SCOTT's coon, whose anxiety to avoid the bullets of the huntsman led him to invite himself down from the tree -- a historical narrative, well known and much admired by all Orleanians. But if Commodore FARBAGUT had not repeated his demand for a capitulation by 5 o'clock, it is probable he did so by 5 1/2 o'clock; or, more likely still, the Mayor, waiving all needless ceremony in the matter, chivalrously took the initiative, and offered to give up what he knew he could not keep. For the Richmond papers, of Monday morning, definitely proclaimed to the startled rebels of the capital, and in the ears of JEFF. DAVIS himself, that "New-Orleans was in the possession of the enemy." The latest of our dispatches concerning the city is from Mobile, Monday, and that announces the evacuation of all the fortifications erected for the defence of New-Orleans on the lake in its rear -- so that, from the battered forte, sixty miles below the city, to the point to which LOVELL retreated, eighty miles above it, there was nowhere an enemy who offered any resistance. No mention is made in any of the dispatches of Gen. BEN. BUTLER, who was in chief command of the whole expedition, military and naval; and it is evident that he was not with the fleet when it appeared before the city, as, if he had been, the negotiations for capitulation would have been carried on by and with him, instead of Commodore FARRAGUT. It is very likely that FARRAGUT was waiting for his appearance from Friday, when the first demand for surrender was made, until Sunday night at five o'clock, when the second demand had not yet been sent to the anxious Mayor. It was understood, however, that Gen. BUTLER was to approach New-Orleans, with the Army of Occupation, by way of the Lakes, reduce the fortifications on their shores, and march to the possession of the City via the famous Shell Road; and this view is confirmed by our special dispatch from Washington this morning. If he reached his point of debarkation by Sunday or Monday of this week, however, as he must have done, be would find no hostile batteries or forts lining the shore, as the rebels themselves had destroyed them all; and the way would be clear for a triumphal march into the greatest city of rebeldom. By this route (i.e. by Lakes Borgne and Pontchartrain) our vessels could keep up free communication with the city; and if the forts on the Lower Mississippi were not reduced, they will now be cut off from supplies, and a speedy surrender is inevitable. They were only of value as defences to the city: and that being in our hands, it is better not to waste powder on their destruction, but to preserve as much of them as possible for our own uses. But we shall have authentic de[???] concerning the whole affair before many days as a steamer was doubtless dispatched North as soon as the work was completed. In the meantime, the rebel dispatches we already have, leave no doubt of the fact that our force in actual possession of the city.

abstract: Editorial on Union operations in Virginia Valley
snippet: Editorial on Union operations in Virginia Valley
lead_paragraph: -- The rapid advance of Gen. Banks down the Valley of Virginia has brought him near Staunton, the capital of the valley region. Situated as the place is on the Central Railroad, the control of that important line of communication is thus placed in Union hands, so that the progress of FREMONT on the west, parallel with Gen. BANKS' movement, will be secured from interruption. We are, of course, without knowledgeof the plans governing the course ofGen. BANKS, and equally, of course, can violate no rule in repeating the common impression, that the Southward march of this column will terminate at Staunton, and that following the line of the railroad through Rockfish Gap, Gen. BANKS will soon cooperate with the designs of Gen. McDOWELL in Eastern Virginia. The valley below Staunton is extremely broken by irregular spurs of the Alleghanies. There would be no profit in pursuing a long march through that difficult, country, on a path leading persistently away from the scene of active operations on the coast, without leading to the great battleground in the Southwest. The army, so misdirected, would a simply be so much strength lost, at a moment when all strength should be exerted in a decisive and final blow at the head of rebellion. A turn to the eastward may involve a contest for a passage over the Blue Ridge, where the rebel army will have capital natural advantage in making a stand; but this danger surmounted the whole of Eastern Virginia is at the feet of the Union General. From Charlottesville he may move directly on Richmond, simultaneously with McDOWELL: or, following the Orange and Alexandria road, he may seize Lynchburgh and the Tennessee Railroad. These temptations doubtless indicate the track to be taken by this enterprising Yankee General.

abstract: In other columns we give place to the manifesto addressed by the representatives of all parties in the State Legislature to their constituents. It recites a clear and comprehensive narrative of the events which have carried the country into the vortex of revolution ...
lead_paragraph: In other columns we give place to the manifesto addressed by the representatives of all parties in the State Legislature to their constituents. It recites a clear and comprehensive narrative of the events which have carried the country into the vortex of revolution with the comment necessary to give a true interpretation to a history so pregnant with results, and so directly bearing upon the reorganization of party, and the future political condition of the country. The authors of this paper place the responsibility of the war, not directly upon the slaveholders, but upon the political leaders of the South, reluctant to part with the control of the National Administration. The election of Mr. LINCOLN was the signal of rebellion, not because it endangered the interests of Slavery, but because it placed the Government in Northern hands, with the patronage needful to perpetuate the possession. Against the political leaders of the South, the address would have all the penalties of treason directed; it calls for a moderate scheme of confiscation applicable to the slaveholder, as a too willing accessory to rebellion, but has no punishment to urge against the ignorant and deluded rag-tag and bob-tail of Southern society, who have composed the heroic armies of the revolt. The Administration of Mr. LINCOLN, both in its conduct of domestic and foreign affairs, meets wills the entire approval of the signers. They find it their duty to support the President's plan of emancipation, the policy of abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia, and in general to lend their cordial concurrence to the conservative line of conduct which Mr. LINCOLN and his leading advisers have marked out for themselves. The restoration of the Union, the enforcement of the Constitution and laws, are the objects of the war. The President, in the view of these gentlemen, is laboring wisely and bravely to promote those objects, and the people of New-York are engaged to be his loyal and steadfast auxiliaries.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday a number of [???] for a General Bankrupt Law were [???]. A [???] was presented from JOAN [???]fering to build a city railroad in Washington in sixty days, and to pay $10,000 annually to the city. A resolution offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, relative to Kansas affairs, was laid over; also a resolution offered by Mr. DAVIS, declaring that the war shall be carried on for the restoration of the Union under the Constitution, and for no other purpose. Mr. WILSON's resolution, inquiring of the Military Committee whether any further legislation is necessary to prevent soldiers and officers from returning fugitive slaves, was debated until the expiration of the morning hour, when the Confiscation bill was taken up. Speeches were made by Messrs. WILSON, of Massachusetts, MORRILL, of Maine, HOWE, of Wisconsin, and DAVIS, of Kentucky, all in favor of confiscation in some shape. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: A large audience assembled at Continental Hall, on Monday evening, to listen to a lecture by Mr. THEODORE TILTON, on the latest questions of the war. Shortly after 8 o'clock, the Chairman received the following telegraphic dispatch from Mr. TILTON; "I am detained at Poekskill by a railroad accident, and cannot lecture, but propose to the audience three cheers in advance for the abolition of Slavery from every square inch of the Republic." The reading of this dispatch satisfied the assemblage that Mr. TILTON'S absence was no fault of his own, and the statement elicited three boisterous cheers. Mr. TILTON will deliver his lecture this evening, May 8, at the same place.
lead_paragraph: A large audience assembled at Continental Hall, on Monday evening, to listen to a lecture by Mr. THEODORE TILTON, on the latest questions of the war. Shortly after 8 o'clock, the Chairman received the following telegraphic dispatch from Mr. TILTON; "I am detained at Poekskill by a railroad accident, and cannot lecture, but propose to the audience three cheers in advance for the abolition of Slavery from every square inch of the Republic." The reading of this dispatch satisfied the assemblage that Mr. TILTON'S absence was no fault of his own, and the statement elicited three boisterous cheers. Mr. TILTON will deliver his lecture this evening, May 8, at the same place.

abstract: The new Postmaster is vindicating his claim to the good things we were pleased to say of him at the time of his appointment. In another column we print a programme for the reception and delivery of letters at the several City stations, which inaugurates a new era in that department of the service. Seven times daily will the letters be carried from the Post-office to the stations; and as often will the letters deposited at the stations be transmitted to the Post-office. From the lamp-post depositories, which now number a fraction less than six hundred, the letters will be gathered five times a day; and four times daily will the carriers deliver letters. While this increase of activity and efficiency is a capital omen for the future, we are gratified to know it is but an installment of the reforms and ameliorations which Mr. WAKEMAN contemplates. The City has at last an alive Postmaster.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax yesterday, we receive advices from Europe three days later than by the Bremen. She left Liverpool on the 10th and Queenstown on the 20th ult. There is very little news of interest. The London Times, speculating upon the importance of the then coming struggle for the possession of New-Orleans, says that its occupation by our forces would be "a [???] tightened over the great artery of the seceded States." The London Herald, is again urging interference in American affairs by the British Government. It was rumored in France that the police had arrested twelve hundred workmen on a charge of sedition. A dispatch from Madrid states that Spain will not, as has been asserted, withdraw her troops from Mexico, but will retain them there until the satisfaction demanded is obtained. Very little cotton was changing bands in the Liverpool market, but prices were firm. Bread-stuffs were advancing, and Provisions were generally unchanged. Consols were quoted at 93@ 94 for money. American Securities were dull.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax yesterday, we receive advices from Europe three days later than by the Bremen. A dispatch from Madrid states that Spain will not, as has been asserted, withdraw her troops from Mexico, but will retain them there until the satisfaction demanded is obtained. abstract: Fort Macon, North Carolina, the capture of which by Gen. BURNSIDE, is announced, commands the entrance to the harbor of Beaufort, North Carolina, and its guns have a full sweep over the main channel. It is the strongest regular fortification on the Atlantic coast between Fortress Monroe and Fort Sumter. As Beaufort was the only entrance to the North Carolina Sounds below Ocracoke Inlet, it really was a main mean of defence for the whole coast of North Carolina. From Beaufort, also, a railroad ran to Newbern and to Raleigh, the Capital of the State, and this road at Goldsborough intersectedthe main line running south from Virginia, As a defence to North Carolina against approaches from any direction, there was no work so important as Fort Macon, and no harbor so valuable as Beaufort. But the place was rendered practically valueless when Gen. BURNSIDE had seized Newbern, which cut it off from communication with the interior. We give herewith a view of the minute topography of the harbor and regions around Beaufort, by which its relations to Fort Macon and the adjoining sea islands and coast will be seen.
lead_paragraph: Fort Macon, North Carolina, the capture of which by Gen. abstract: -- To-day a work of great magnitude commences. Mr. TROW's canvassers commerce their work of collecting names for the new City Directory. Such a task it no easy one. Last year the total number of names collected amounted to 152,825, making it surprising that the Directory is so universally correct. Our citizens will of course afford all the facilities in their power to the canvassers.

abstract: A special dispatch to the Tribune from Cairo Says:  The packet Diligence, from Tiptonville, reports an alarming stage of water in the Mississippi River. Hundreds of houses on the banks of the river at that place and New-Madrid are submerged, and thousands of cattle, sheep and hogs have been washed away.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Thursday, May 1.

abstract: It would seem that the illustrious mosstrooper, Dr. JENNISON, has achieved a victory over his Kansas persecutors. Gens. abstract: TheExpress and the Staats Zeitung set all the glasses in Liquordom a-jingling by their announcement that the General Term of the Common Pleas had decided the old liquor cases against the People. They even put in the mouths of Judges DALY, HILTON and BRADY the arguments with which they justified the conclusion arrived at; and the Zeitung comments on the bearing of the decision on "the oppressors and tormentors of the tavern-keepers" -- meaning the Police -- and on "the much-abused MCCUNN," who is thus "gloriously vindicated" from the aspersions of "the Anglo-American organs of temperance fanaticism."

abstract: On the 24th inst., a company of cavalry from this place destroyed the extensive saltperte manufactory near Mellville Ark., and burned the building. Lieut. HICHOCK, of the Fourth Iowa Cavalry, was killed, and one private wounded in the skirmish with the rebels. A large quantity of supplies, hid, for the rebels' use, with deserters and Jayhawkers in the mountains, were captured by Gen. CURTIS' command.
lead_paragraph: FORSYTH, Mo., Tuesday, April 29.

abstract: I have just received a dispatch from Brig. Gen. MANSFIELD, to the effect that five negroes have arrived from Portsmouth. The contrabands report that Fort Macon was taken on Friday last. Eighteen rebels were killed and twenty-seven wounded.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, May 1.

abstract: An unusually large meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, both on account of the press of regular business, and the occasion of the presentation of medals to Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, of Fort Sumter, and Sergeant HART. The arrival of Gen. ANDERSON was noticed with universal applause. The reading of the minutes was dispensed with, and the Chairman, P. PERIT, Esq., proceeded to address Gen. ANDERSON. He reviewed the incidents of the memorable siege of Sumter, and depicted, in glowing terms, the popular appreciation of the heroism of Gen. ANDERSON and his associates, in conclusion presenting the medal, which had been struck by order of the Chamber.

abstract: HOME FOR SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDIERS. -- The opening ceremonies of the "Ladies' Home for Sick and Wounded Soldiers," will take place on Friday, May 2, at 3 o'clock, P.M., corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street. Addresses will be delivered by several distinguished gentlemen. Music by the Band of the Seventh Regiment, furnished gratuitously by the Eighth Company of that regiment. A flag will be presented to the "Home" by Commissary-Gen. WELCH. Col. SPICER and Staff, and the Seventy-first Regiment, will parade and take part in the ceremony. A collection will be taken up in aid of the "Home."
lead_paragraph: HOME FOR SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDIERS. -- The opening ceremonies of the "Ladies' Home for Sick and Wounded Soldiers," will take place on Friday, May 2, at 3 o'clock, P.M., corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street. Addresses will be delivered by several distinguished gentlemen. Music by the Band of the Seventh Regiment, furnished gratuitously by the Eighth Company of that regiment. A flag will be presented to the "Home" by Commissary-Gen. WELCH. Col. SPICER and Staff, and the Seventy-first Regiment, will parade and take part in the ceremony. A collection will be taken up in aid of the "Home."

abstract: We are at last authoritatively informed that this large and flourishing commercial emporium of the South has fallen into the hands of Yankee vandals, who, by means of gunboats and hay bales, accomplish on water what they never can do by land. We have thus far received very brief particulars; but they are enough to satisfy us that the city has been evacuated by our troops, and is now in possession of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: From the Petersburgh (Va.) Express, April 28.

abstract: From the rebels this morning we give the news that Fort Macon, near Beaufort, N.C., has surrendered to Gen. BURNSIDE. This nearly completes the work of recapturing from the rebels the forts and strongholds on the Southern seaboard. A short distance further down the coast, at Wilmington, are Forts Caswell and Johnson, still in rebel hands; and some distance southward still is Fort Sumter and the other forts in Charleston harbor. When these fall into our hands, we will have repossessed every fort of consequence on the Southern Atlantic coast. Our correspondent with Gen. BURNSIDE informed our readers a fortnight ago that Fort Macon had been invested, and that the work of reducing it had begun by slow bombardment. This is now the consummation of the work -- finished, as nearly all of Gen. BURNSIDE's operations are finished, with perfect success It was evident, when BURNSIDE had taken Newbern, that this fort must fall; and when, he moved a body of his troops down to Beaufort, assurance became doubly sure. But the rebels indulged in their ordinary bluster about its strength. They have been shut up in the fort now for over a month; and at last have succumbed either before hunger or hot shot -- at all events before BURNSIDE. It would be well for North Carolina now, if she would adopt the line of policy attributed to her of late, and voluntarily return to the Union. Her year of rebellion has been, indeed, a miserable and unfortunate year for her.
lead_paragraph: From the rebels this morning we give the news that Fort Macon, near Beaufort, N.C., has surrendered to Gen. BURNSIDE. This is now the consummation of the work -- finished, as nearly all of Gen. BURNSIDE's operations are finished, with perfect success It was evident, when BURNSIDE had taken Newbern, that this fort must fall; and when, he moved a body of his troops down to Beaufort, assurance became doubly sure. But the rebels indulged in their ordinary bluster about its strength. They have been shut up in the fort now for over a month; and at last have succumbed either before hunger or hot shot -- at all events before BURNSIDE. It would be well for North Carolina now, if she would adopt the line of policy attributed to her of late, and voluntarily return to the Union. Her year of rebellion has been, indeed, a miserable and unfortunate year for her.

abstract: The fall of fort Macon, commanding the harbor of Beaufort, N.C., is announced this morning. This news, as did that of the fall of New-Orleans, comes to us from the rebels, but, of course, its authenticity cannot be doubted. It is contained in a copy of the Richmond Enquirer, to which paper it is telegraphed. The report states that the surrender was conditional -- the officers being allowed to leave with their [???]. We shall soon have further details of this new triumph of the National arms, from our Special Correspondent, with Gen. BURNSIDE's command.

abstract: editorial compares Yorktown now and at time of Revolutionary War
snippet: editorial compares Yorktown now and at time of Revolutionary War
lead_paragraph: The army commanded by Gen. MCCLELLAN has now been before Yorktown precisely the period it took WASHINGTON to reduce that stronghold, in the memorable siege of '81. This period has been in both cases filled up in precisely the same manner -- the construction of lines of offensive works. To make the parallel complete, it only remains that the same result should follow the operations of Gen. MCCLELLAN as attended the preparations of Gen. WASHINGTON, namely, the surrender of the enemy's force. Three weeks WASHINGTON employed in weaving a web around CORNWALLIS at Yorktown. For three weeks has Gen.MCCLELLAN been doing the same thing for the present rebel force, on the grander scale and with the vastly more destructive enginery of modern warfare. When the British General saw what the American army had done, he realized that resistance was hopeless -- and surrendered. No general engagement took place between the two forces. WASHINGTON sacrificed no lives, except the few that were lost in the preliminary operations. His reduction of Yorktown was a triumph of pure military strategy. If it should turn out that Gen. MCCLELLAN designed to emulate his illostrious predecessor in this also? It would jump with that General's military method, and would certainly be a glorious triumph in the estimation of every right-minded man. And yet one scarcely ventures to desire that it should ho so; for malignity can go very far, and there are not wanting those who would make such, a bloodless victory the occasion for a renewed howl against a General whom they have determined at all hazards to defame. But whether it enters in to the plan of Gen. MCCLELLAN, that Yorktown shall fall into his hands as the ripe fruit of his strategic combinations, or whether he intends to had his vast force against the rebel line with a [???] that shall be the Atlantic coast to its foundations -- one thing is certain the crisis is impending; the gigantic preparations of the Commanding General are now complete, and any hour the electric wire may be freighted with intelligence that will be as decisive of the fate of the rebellion as the glorious tidings which WASHINGTON transmitted to the Continental Congress on the 18th of October, 1781, was decisive of American freedom and independence.

abstract: Following the laws of trade, by which the furnishing of supplies of small things for every-day consumption has crown from a petty business, embarked in by [???] producers of small dealers into great enterprises, in which large capital and commercial skill are employed, the supplying of milk to families in this City, in quantities of half a pint upward daily, has, under the improved order of enlarged commerce, become a branch of trade, conducted in accordance with the rules of strict honesty as the only means of insuring the permanancy and security of the large amounts of capital invested in it. With the change in dealing from irresponsibleto responsible parties, has come the guarantee of pure unadulterated milk, in whatever quantities it may be required. The producers, also, arc guaranteeda certain return for the milk furnished, which, under the old plan of selling to small dealers, they were often cheated out of. By means of the large sales and certainty of payment to the producer, the large milk establishment in New-York is enabled to dictate terms to the producer, as to perfect cleanliness in preparing the milk cans, the care essential to cooling the milk by placing the cans in running springs for several hours before the milk is shipped, and, above all, in enforcing the rule against watering the milk, the slightest infraction of which is readily detected by the hydrometer.

abstract: editorial reports treaty signed
snippet: editorial reports treaty signed
lead_paragraph: The Slave-trade has received its death-blow, in the treaty just concluded between the Governments of England and the United States. Disguise it as we may, we cannot escape the charge, before the civilized world, of having been, to a great extent, one prime cause of the immunity afforded, for many years past, to this accursed traffic. Under the pretence of our national dignity, and the consequent susceptibility respecting a right of search, the American flag has been the protection to the abandoned of all nations, who were bent upon making money in this unhallowed [???], against not only the feelings of all [???], but our own professions.
headline: {'main': 'The New Slave-trade Treaty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Slave-trade Treaty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There have been a greater numberof important events and actions during the month of April, just closed, than in any month of the war. It has been a month of great surrenders, battles and movements. It has been illustrated by the surrender of Island Number Ten and its six thousand rebel troops: by the surrender of Fort Pulaski and its rebel garrison; by the capitulation of New-Orleans, the New-York of the South, and all its rebels, excepting those who fled. It has been crimsoned by the bloody battle of Shiloh, and by a hundred minor engagements, fought along a line of fifteen hundred miles in extent, from Yorktown to Santa Fe. It has seen the splendid marc of [???] and the masterly movements of POPE. It has seen the advance of MCDOWELL to Fredericksbrugh, and the march of Gen. BANKS toward Staunton. CURTIS' column has been moving eastward through Missouri, STEELE preparing to descend the Arkansas, and FREMONT advancing southward through Virginia. BURNSIDE has been busy in North Carolina, and the capture of Fort Macon splendidly closes the month's work. HUNTER has been drawing in his strength, preparatory to a spring upon the enemy. But the greatest work of the month, greater than the surrenders, heavier than the engagements, more trying than the marches, has been the prodigious preparation going on for the two decisive battles of the war -- that under Gen. MCCLELLAN, on the York River, and that under Gen. HALLECK, on the Tennessee. The month which has just come in, the sweet month of May, will, in all human probability, be that in which the purpose and result of all these preparations will appear. So that, though the operations of April have been immeasurably important and splendid, they bid fair to be entirely overshadowed by the operations of May.

abstract: Washington is in a state glorious excitement to-night over the news received by the Government that Fort Macon has surrendered to Gen. Burnside, and New-Orleans has surrendered to Gen. Butler; and last, though not least, the statement of the Richmond Examiner, that Gen. Beauregard has evacuated Corinth. By this favor from rebeldom, it will be perceived that the calculation, made in this correspondence last night, that Gen. BUTLER was in New-Orleans,  was correct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 1.

abstract: ARRESTS FOR VIOLATION OF THE CONCERT-SALOON LAW. -- About 1 o'clock Wednesday morning, Officer BLAIR, of the Fourth Precinct, arrested MARGARET GIDDEN, WILHELMINA TOPPEN, and PHILLIPENA TOPPEN,all of whom were waiter-girls at a concert saloon, in the Shakespeare Hotel, situated on the corner of William and Duane streets. The policeman found the girls engaged in serving lager and other drinks to the numerous guests present, notwithstanding the law, and the order which has been recently issued by Superintendent KENNEDY. HENRY MONTZ, the bar-keeper, was also taken into custody, upon the charge of selling liquors in a concert saloon without a license. The prisoners were all taken before Justice BRENNAN Wednesday, and, in default of bail, committed for examination. The proprietor of the establishment alleges that he has had no theatrical performance of any kind in his house since the order was served upon him by the Police. The ordinary instrumental concert has, however, been carried on every night, as usual.

abstract: Proceedings
snippet: Proceedings
lead_paragraph: The United States Paymasters, in State-street, have been busy, for the last two days, paying off the various regular and volunteer officers on duty in and around New-York. The payrolls of the troops on Governor's Island are being made out in the Adjutant's office, and will be sent over to the Paymaster to be examined and checked as soon as possible, after which the men will receive their pay for the last four months. The men belonging to the Eighth and Twelfth Infantry, at Fort Hamilton, have already received their pay for the two months ending Feb. 28, and have thus had the advantage of the other troops in this vicinity.

abstract: -- The VAN WYCK Investigating Committee is realizing the truth that curses come home to roost. Having investigated for themselves, and been the cause of much investigation in others, they and themselves at last very curiously and unceremoniously inquired into by the House, whose delegated authority they have, it seems, been using more freely than prudently. The truth is, this Commission started for a fixed purpose, and that achieved, it should have subsided. It was raised with a view to making a case against FREMONT, to exposing the frauds in the War and the extortion in the Navy Department. Accordingly it visited St. Louis, and investigated, without calling before it either FREMONT or MCKINSTRY; it followed the unhappy CUMMINGS into the inkiest recesses of the World's press-room, and, as if bottled porter and chip bats for the army were not enough, charged him with vast balances which, alas! he had never handled; it overhauled the brokerages of the opulent MORGAN, and when found, made a note of some $75,000, to which that Dives was not entitled. But whatever merit and demerit there may have been in these partial and eccentric inquiries, the premature publication of so much of the testimony, strictly ex parte, which related to FREMONT, proved that the Committee conducted its inquest in no judicial spirit, but rather with the ardor and eagerness of detectives, thirsting for the magnificent popular reward of successful zeal. With this discovery the public, confidence, in the Committee vanished. Its usefulness ceased. Its bulky volume of evidence published at midwinter nobody read. The inquiry into the contracts for arms, the Secretary of War placed in better hands. For all practical purposes the Committee has been simply a source of useless [???] and popular annoyance.

abstract: Desertions from the rebel army here continue to be numerous. They are coming in daily, almost hourly, from various directions of their lines, and all agree in their statements of the rebel force, (about 100,000,) and of a very general depression of spirits among both officers and men. The news of our recent victories is kept sedulously from them. They  were first informed of the fall of Island No. 10 upon coming into our camp.
lead_paragraph: CAMP BEFORE YORKTOWN, Va., Monday, April 28, 1862.

abstract: GOTTSCHALK'S LAST CONCERT. - This concert is, after all, not to be the last which GOTTSCHALK will give in this City at present, as we were told upon entering the concert room, by one of the officials in attendance, that he is to give a positively last concert upon Monday next, a fact in which musical New-York, or the musical fashion of New-York, ought to rejoice; as from the character of the audiences he calls together, it is certain that he is the most fashionable, as he is the greatest, pianist now before the public. Seriously, indeed, in spite of the weather, he attracted such an audience last night, as in point of number, and musical quality and position, he ought to attract, and one which did full justice to the programme which he had provided for them. Among the most charming pieces which he gave was "Illusions Perdues," although it was one which is undoubtedly lost in a large saloon and to the general composition of modern concert rooms. "Repondi moi," which had been announced for repetition in consequence of its success when first produced, was, owing to the Illness of SANDERSON, performed with him by MUZIO. Under the circumstances, it was certainly as well rendered by him as could have been expected, and won for him the tangible honor of an encore with GOTTSCHALK. The Fantasia on the "Lucrezia Borgia" displayed all the originality of style that has always been so remarkable in the last-named artist - an originality so strikingly manifest that it is always as much a matter of uncertainty to himself as of doubt to those who are listening to him, what novelty of rendering he may choose to introduce in the pieces of his own composition which he may be singing to his hearers on the instrument. This renders them strikingly captivating to the audience, and will in some measure account for that singular sense of novelty which he invariably produces, even in those who are most accustomed to his manner and style of playing. It may be no more than matter of justice to say that in this concert, us in his preceding ones, he played upon a grand piano of GOTTSCHALK'S. CARLOTTI PATTI won applause for MUZIO by her singing of his "L'AMOUR Polka." We are unaware if this was the first time it has ever been given in this City or not, as the programme leaves it somewhat in doubt whether it is a novelty for the public or the lady. However, we certainly heard it for the first time. It is an excellent contribution to the stock of morceaux for the concert-room. She also sung with TOMBESI a duo from the "Ballo in Maschera," and with him and FERRI a terzetto from VERUTS "Attila." This last did not suit her voice so well as it did that of TOMBESI, who also gave a romanza by FLOTOW, in a style which may induce us to modify the opinion we had previously expressed respecting his superior qualifications for the operatic stage when contrasted with his capabilities for the concert-room. At any rate this romanza was ably and charmingly rendered by him, as if he had been determined to prove that he was as fit for the one as we had considered him for the other.

However, we certainly heard it for the first time. It is an excellent contribution to the stock of morceaux for the concert-room. She also sung with TOMBESI a duo from the "Ballo in Maschera," and with him and FERRI a terzetto from VERUTS "Attila." This last did not suit her voice so well as it did that of TOMBESI, who also gave a romanza by FLOTOW, in a style which may induce us to modify the opinion we had previously expressed respecting his superior qualifications for the operatic stage when contrasted with his capabilities for the concert-room. At any rate this romanza was ably and charmingly rendered by him, as if he had been determined to prove that he was as fit for the one as we had considered him for the other.

abstract: [???] -- The only accounts thus for received from Fort Macon trickle through rebel channels. There is enough, however, to discredit the statement that the surrender was conditional. When the rebel rag was healed down, the Fort, we are told, was wholly [???] and its garrison at the mercy of our forces. There was not the slightest ground for negotiation on the part of the National commander. It will require, therefore, something more than rebel authority to satisfy as that Gen [???] with his enemy entirely in his power, [???] so far from the fixed precedents of the war as to make terms with traitors. It will be only a day or two before our own accounts will be at hand, and we can afford to wait for the truth.

abstract: The attitude assumed by the American Government toward the allied movement in Mexico, is very clearly stated in a circular dispatch of Mr SEWARD, which we reproduce from our Paris files. The Allies are not only distinctly advised of the indisposition of our people to see a direct interposition of European influence in the domestic affairs of any State on this continent, but they are warned that the mere presence of their land and naval forces on the scene, while the Reactionists inaugurate and proseculo their revolution against the existing Government, is equivalent to active intervention, and must be regarded here with the utmost disfavor. The language of the Secretary amounts, in fact,to a vigorous protest against the policy of the Allies.
lead_paragraph: The attitude assumed by the American Government toward the allied movement in Mexico, is very clearly stated in a circular dispatch of Mr SEWARD, which we reproduce from our Paris files. The language of the Secretary amounts, in fact,to a vigorous protest against the policy of the Allies.

abstract: The official epistle of Mayor MONROE, of New-Orleans, in reply to Commodore FARRAGUT's demand for a surrender of the City, has no doubt set the whole country in a broad grin; and if rebellion has not dried up all the springs of mirth in the Southern nature, the rebels themselves must be moved to saturnine laughter by its farrago of bombast, impotence and conceit. It must have been a fine study of facial effect to see the plain, practical-minded sailor FARRAGUT, perusing, on board his flagship off the levee, the queer rigmarolehe received [???] to his pointed demand for the surrender of the city; and if he waits till he unravels this metaphysical puzzle before taking possession, the accumulations of Mississippi mud will have carried the delta ten miles further into the Gulf, FARRAGUT made a very definite demand, namely, "the unqualified surrender of the City, and that the emblem of the sovereignty of the United States be holsted over the City Hall, Mint and Custom-house, by meridian this day, and all flags and other emblems of sovereignty other than this of the. United States be removed from all the public buildings by that hour."

abstract: The formal opening of the Ladies' Home for sick and wounded soldiers, corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street, took place yesterday afternoon. A large audience, composed mainly of ladies, was present. Music was furnished by the Eighth Company, Seventh Regiment, who sent a detachment of GRAFULA's Seventh Regiment Band. The building has been some time completed, and is admirably adapted to the wants of a hospital. It was erected as a home for foundlings, and, together with the ground on which it stands, is the property of the City, and is worth about $150,000.

The building has been some time completed, and is admirably adapted to the wants of a hospital. abstract: A new state of things exists in this community, and important events seen to be rapidly approaching. The blessings of freedom are springing up in the path of a war of rebellion and treason. The contrabands in this District are already numerous, and their numbers are constantly increasing, as others come in from the adjacent rebel State of Virginia, some fleeing from rebel masters to avoid being sent further South; others escaping from the want and privation now being so severely felt on those portions of the country devastated by the rebels themselves, or by contending armies.
lead_paragraph: A new state of things exists in this community, and important events seen to be rapidly approaching. abstract: The Lexington Gazelle states that a [???] officer, who left JACKSON's headquarters on Saturday, 19th inst., states that he has taken a strong position at Swift Hun Gap. This is a gap in the Blue Ridge, cast of Harrisonburgh, and through which passes the turnpike leading to Gordonsville. His position cannot be flanked, and the Federals will not probably venture to pass him, in order to advance on Staunton, He is within reach of reinforcements.

abstract: Since we have had so much of weather and so little of food lately, the usual highly original question of "What do you think of the weather?" has been laid aside for a little while especially that the question is answered in the face of every man and the more interesting one of "How's your appetite?" is employed in its place, with a vigor truly tantalizing in the present state of food.

abstract: The new iron-clad steamer Ironsides, it is expected, will be launched from the yard of CRAMP   SON, Kensington, some day next week, though the exact time has not been fixed upon.
lead_paragraph: The new iron-clad steamer Ironsides, it is expected, will be launched from the yard of CRAMP SON, Kensington, some day next week, though the exact time has not been fixed upon. All the plating intended to be put on the vessel previous to launching is now in place, and workmen are now engaged in the interior of the vessel, arranging her for the reception of machinery, &c.

abstract: editorials on bill
snippet: editorials on bill
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a resolution was adopted requesting the Secretary of War to report the present condition of the Military Asylum. A bill introduced by Mr. GRIMES. of Iowa, to limit the number of Major and Brigadeir-Generals in the army, was referred to the Military Committee. The same Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of providing for appointments to the Marine Corps the same as to the Naval Academy. The Homestoad bill was debated briefly, and postponed until Monday. A Message was received from the President, assuming theresponsibility for the arrest of Gen. STONE, in the terms already stated in the TIMES. The Confiscation bill was then debated until the adjournment, which was until Monday.

abstract: This commodity was selling in the Richmond markets yesterday at very exaggerated prices. The reason assigned is that on Wednesday a requisition had been made for most of the beef cattle near the city for the use of the army on the Peninsula. If the prices which were demanded and paid yesterday shall be acted on as a precedent, it will very soon become necessary for Gen. WINDER to fix the price of beef at a reasonable standard. While the butchers may not be the only dealers in articles of prime necessity who are anxious to make all they can still in their case, as well as in that of others, a limit must be set to human cupidity. We are told by those who ought to know, that while man wants but little here below, he wants that little just as long as he can hold on to it. It is no less true that all men at anxious to make their "little all" as large as they conveniently [???], no matter at whose [???].

abstract: Editorial speculates on prospects for both sides in Southwest
snippet: Editorial speculates on prospects for both sides in Southwest
lead_paragraph: The rebel plan of campaign and line of operations in the Southwest was, until a brief time ago, sufficiently grand and comprehensive. Their lines swept from the Cumberland Mountains through Central Kentucky -- with "impregnable" works at all important points -- crossed the Mississippi at Columbus, from Athenes continued to the westernmost verge of Missouri, with outposts extending through the Indian and New-Mexican frontiers to the mountains of the Sierra Madre; and the whole east county south of this to the Gulf of Mexico, they were in undisputed possession. Now, their defensive line in the Southwest is contracted to a [???] of a hundred miles in the rear of Memphis. Here have been concentrated all the detachments of their army lately in Kentucky and Central Tennessee, those from Missouri and Arkansas, and those from the Gulf coast, magnified, too, by brigades and regiments from Virginia and the Atlantic States to its south. Here is likely any day now to be fought another great battle -- the decisive battle of the Mississippi Valley.
headline: {'main': 'The Prospect in the Southwest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prospect in the Southwest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our accounts from East Tennessee represent that the conscription act has occasioned an intense commotion among the milk-and-water patriots of East Tennessee. Whole counties are rising up and moving toward Kentucky. Such is the harvest that springs from the teachings of that double-dyed traitor, (well called Apollyon,) Brownlow. Gen. SMITH is doing what he can to arrest the stampede; but, as a correspondent informs us, it is like "lamming up the Nile with bulrushes."

abstract: Hon. Mr. PHELPS, when the bill for the fortification of the frontiers was introduced, addressed the House in a speech which, if it was not calculated to flatter the prejudices of his hearers, ought certainly to have approved itself to their reason. He first argued against the propriety of substituting a race of extravagance for the present economical inaction. If America armed. England would arm. If the New-Yorkshore of the Lakes were to bristle with cannon, the Canadian shore would soon present a similar aspect. A Sebastopol at Buffalo would merely call up another Sebastopol on the opposite border; and, asthe longest purse would win, it was probable that Great Britain might carry the day. But after this practical piece of reasoning, Mr. PHELPS proceeded to touch on a far more comprehensive and controvertible topic. He not only deprecated the angry spirit and abusive language in which it was customary with Americans to speak of us and our institutions, but he went a step farther, and declared, with a candor and boldness almost unexampled in such assemblies, that we did not deserve such treatment, in as much as in any international differences we for the most part had been clearly in the right and America in the wrong. He said that in the Trent affair we were proved to be in the right by the concurrent decisions of all European Governments, including those most cordially disposed toward America. Of our attitude during the civil war, he observed that it was certainly as friendly as that of France, to which no exception was taken, while of our general policy he spoke in terms of unreserved commendation. He remarked that in all recent treaties we had permitted America to gain the advantage; that we had overlooked in the San Juan affair a piece of conduct on the part of the Americans which they, if the decision had been theirs, would probably have resented by instant war; that we had eudured their protective and injurious tariffs without retaliating; and that it all such matters we had shown, a superior and enlightened liberality. For all there reasons, he thought it inexpedient to express any distrust of Graet Britain, or to encourage any idea's of hostility or war by the erection of the defences proposed.

He not only deprecated the angry spirit and abusive language in which it was customary with Americans to speak of us and our institutions, but he went a step farther, and declared, with a candor and boldness almost unexampled in such assemblies, that we did not deserve such treatment, in as much as in any international differences we for the most part had been clearly in the right and America in the wrong. He said that in the Trent affair we were proved to be in the right by the concurrent decisions of all European Governments, including those most cordially disposed toward America. Of our attitude during the civil war, he observed that it was certainly as friendly as that of France, to which no exception was taken, while of our general policy he spoke in terms of unreserved commendation. He remarked that in all recent treaties we had permitted America to gain the advantage; that we had overlooked in the San Juan affair a piece of conduct on the part of the Americans which they, if the decision had been theirs, would probably have resented by instant war; that we had eudured their protective and injurious tariffs without retaliating; and that it all such matters we had shown, a superior and enlightened liberality. abstract: doubts have surrounded the capture of Col. CROCKER, and Major CASSIDY, of a New-York regiment. The very general impression in the army at Yorktown has been that the two deliberately, and with treasonable purpose, went over to the enemy, endeavoring at the same time to leave behind the impression that they were involuntary prisoners. If this were so, they have certainly failed to convey that impression to the rebels. According to the Richmond papers, the two gentlemen have been kept in close confinement with other prisoners, and, conveyed to Richmond, have been placed in the common town jail. It is too evident, that while censurable for the grossest imprudence, the culprits are not the traitors they have been prematurely adjudged.

abstract: A MASONIC LODGE ROBBED OF ITS JEWELS. -- For several months past the Masonic Societies in this City, which meet at the Masonic Temple, corner of Broome and Crosby streets, have lost jewels, regalia and other valuable property worn by the, officers of the Lodge during their meetings. No one could be found to the thief until a day or two since, when a detective police officer was applied to, to work up the case. Soon after it was ascertained that the janitor was the guilty party. He had [???] false keys made to fit the locks of the chests where the jewels were kept, and by this means had successfully robbed the establishment of property to the amount of over $2,000. upon the person of the janitor were found nine pawn-tickets, representing nine separate parcels of jewels, &c., which had been stolen from the Montgomery, Clinton, Mystic, Enterprise and Davey Lodges. The janitor, whose name is JOSEPH BESCHAN, was committed to prison for trial.
lead_paragraph: A MASONIC LODGE ROBBED OF ITS JEWELS. -- For several months past the Masonic Societies in this City, which meet at the Masonic Temple, corner of Broome and Crosby streets, have lost jewels, regalia and other valuable property worn by the, officers of the Lodge during their meetings. No one could be found to the thief until a day or two since, when a detective police officer was applied to, to work up the case. Soon after it was ascertained that the janitor was the guilty party. The janitor, whose name is JOSEPH BESCHAN, was committed to prison for trial.

abstract: Rev. Mr. TAYLOR, of Ongar, in Essex, Eng., is too well known throughout this country and Canada, -- we may say, in all places where the English language is read, -- to require any extended comment from us. His works, entitled Ancient Christianity, the Natural History of Enthusiasm, the Physical Theory of Another Life, Loyola and Jesuitism, &c., &c., have obtained immense circulation and are standard, in their way. The present volume bears the title he gave to a series of lectures delivered in 1852, at Edinburgh and Glasgow, but its contents are greatlymodified from those of the lectures. Mr. TAYLOR's theme may briefly be stated as "The Historic Personality of God" -- the reality of Revelation, and the sublime certainty of the scheme of Man's Salvation, as deduced from the Hebrew Psalmists and Prophets from first to last. The erudite author makes war upon what he styles the "atheistic epilepsy" of our age, with a learning and skill that confirm his claim to a place among the theological classics of Protestantism. The beautiful binding, print and arrangement of this valuable volume reflect credit, not only upon the publisher, but upon the entire book-trade of New-York. It is the neatest piece of workmanship, in its range, that we have seen for some time.

abstract: The Americans in the North are on the tip-toe of expectation for news of the fall of New-Orleans. This is the next thrust of the swordfish into the whale. The Federals are so elated with their recent successes that they are impatient of any pause in the course of victory. They chafe under the delay in clearing the Mississippi, and at being checked at a point five hundred miles above its mouth; but they assure their "ignorant foreign critics" that they have, already, in all probability, gained possession of New-Orleans. The force at the mouth of the Mississippi is strong enough to strike terror wherever there is human life to be extinguished and property to be plundered. The American papers boast that it is the most formidable naval force sent on a hostile errand in modern times. In an age which remembers the fleet that spread itself over the Black Sea, the vaunt is sufficiently bombastic, but still it is a tremendous force when directed against an enemy which has no navy and can keep up no dock-yards, and depends upon smuggled supplies for its powder and its guns. It comprises a terrible mortar fleet of the heaviest ordnance which can be bought or made in the North, and more than 200 vessels, including the largest steam frigates in the Fedaral navy. "The world," we are told, "will be astonished at the force the [???] Government has sent against this rebellious city. and it will take even the American people by surprise when they learn its extent and importance."

abstract: The Memphis Argus, of the 29th of April, has the following dispatches:  CORINTH, MONDAY, April 28. Gen. BEAUREGAND is moving large bodies of troops southward; some go by railroad, and others afoot. A few have gone west. It is generally understood that he is evacuating the place, though he declines answering questions. He says that President DAVIS understands his movements.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Saturday, May 3.

abstract: editorial on report Beauregard is moving forces southward
snippet: editorial on report Beauregard is moving forces southward
lead_paragraph: The ominous and startling item of telegraphic news from Southern Tennessee, which was published here yesterday morning -- to the effect that events "of the highest importance" had taken place at Pittsburgh, but that the transmission of the facts was prohibited -- put people on the [???] all day to hear news from that quarter. The City retired to rest at night, however, no wiser, on this point, than it was after its breakfast of telegrams in the morning. From this day's paper, it will learn that whatever the event "of highest importance" that occurred out there might be, it was not a contest between the National and rebel armies; for the War Department has received dispatches dated as late as yesterday from Gen. HALLECK; and, if the intelligence which the Department chooses to give to the Press may be credited, the most important and noteworthy thing in the Southwest at this moment is, that "our army is well, in high spirits, and eager to meet the enemy." From the South, however, there comes an item of news of greater military significance, if it be not of more importance. A rebel dispatch, from Corinth to Memphis, announces that BEAUREGARD is "moving large bodies of troops southward, some by railroad, others afoot, while a few have gone West." "It is generally understood," continues the dispatch, "that he is evacuating the place, though he declines answering questions."

abstract: As the Yankees gave succeed in their purpose of making a demonstration up the Mississippi River, it is not at all unlikely that they may before very long make a similar attempt on [???], with a view to the capture of that city and the ascent of the Alabama River; and in the [???] of their success in passing the defences below Mobile, [???] may [???] us far up the Alabama River as it is [???] for their gunboats. Our authorities have [???] done all they could to render Mobile and the mouth of the river secure against attack; but [???] at New-Orleans and other points the fortifications were not sufficient to obstruct their passage, it is not impossible that the Yankees may succeed in forcing their way past the defences. Should they dothis, unless the river is so obstructed that they cannot navigate it, they would be quite likely to push on to Montgomery. We hope they may never be able to penetrate so far into the interior of our State, but the possibility of their doing so is [???] which should be unblenchingly contemplated, and preparations made to meet the emergency. There is here, as is well known, a considerable amount of [???], which the enemy are greatly interested in throwing on the market. We have a deeper interest, however, in preventing them from getting it, and if our people and the authorities do their duty, they will never obtain one bale of it. Not one ounce should be suffered to go abroad, upon any pretext, and if measures to secure the prompt destruction of the whole amount, if in danger of falling into the hands of the enemy, have not already been adopted, they should be at once. We have understood that an agent of the French Government is in this city, authorized to purchase an [???] amount of cotton.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate tobacco crop and demand for it
snippet: Editorial on Confederate tobacco crop and demand for it
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Dispatch of the 28th ult., in reply to a request that it would propitiate the good services of the planters, and invite them to "send in some of their tobacco, since there is room for it in the warehouse, and a moderate demand," gives rather positive advice the other way. It says: "In the present aspect of affairs, however, we are not prepared to advise them to this step. Better far that every particle of tobacco should be destroyed than sent where there is even a faint prospect of its contributing to the aid and comfort of the enemy."

abstract: Gen. MCCLELLAN, previous to this war, was known to be over partial to the South, and his father set the son a very good example by naming him in honor of a distinguished citizen of an adjoining State. Hence the appellation of the now much-talked of Gen. GEORGE BADGER MCCLELLAN, after the Hon GEORG E. BADGER, of Raleigh, N.C. And this same professed friend of the South in former times is now endeavoring to subjugate her people. He is cutting to pieces the soil of the Peninsular for the purpose of mounting 1,000 seige guns, thus hoping to accomplish, by his much vaunted long-range plan, what his faint heart prevents him from attempting by a more manly course God grant that he may be most signally discomfitted.

abstract: The whole country has been somewhat led astray by an item of news coming via Fortress Monroe, which was relied upon as correct because bearing the sanction of Government censorship. The Seminole, on arriving there from the South, was reported as authentically announcing that the garrison of Fort Pulaski had offered to surrender the fort if they could be allowed to retire with the honors of war, and that the proposal had been rejected by Gen. SHERMAN. It was further stated that the unconditional surrender of the fort was daily expected. Both these assertions prove to have been untrue. No such proposition was ever madeto Gen. SHERMAN - and, of course, not rejected; and no expectation was entertained of the surrender of the fort, on the part either of besiegers or besieged, till the day the capitulation took place.

abstract: We have been informed, says the Lynchburgh Virginian, that two cargoes of Yankees were [???] in the Shenandoah River last week. They were portion of BANKS' Division. A [???] of from 80 to 100 were attempting to cross on a [???] when they were swept away by the tide, and all of them went down to feed the fishes. Another lot of about 30, as our information runs, attempted the same thing about five miles below the point where they made their first fatal experiment, and they shared the fate of their comrades. We have not heard what their object was, whether they were a [???] party, or the advance of the army, designed to be thrown upon the opposite bank of the river with a view to cooperate in an effort to bridge the stream.

abstract: After a bombardment of eleven hours by two Batteries of mortars and one of Parroit guns, Fort Macon, with its garrison, armament, provisions and stores, was surrendered to Acting Major Gen. PARKI, commanding the Third Division of Gen. BURNSIDE'S army, on the 25th inst. The casualties on our side were one killed and two wounded; of the enemy, eight killed and twenty wounded.
lead_paragraph: After a bombardment of eleven hours by two Batteries of mortars and one of Parroit guns, Fort Macon, with its garrison, armament, provisions and stores, was surrendered to Acting Major Gen. PARKI, commanding the Third Division of Gen. BURNSIDE'S army, on the 25th inst. The casualties on our side were one killed and two wounded; of the enemy, eight killed and twenty wounded.

abstract: A dispatch, a few days ago, from Fortress Monroe, announced the death of this young and [???] officer from a wound received while engaged in making an important reconnoissance  at Yorktown Yesterday his body was received in this city, and under the charge of some personal friends was [???] to his father, who resides in Third, below [???] street. Very few officers of his years had seen [???] important and active service than young WAGNER, [???] had distinguished themselves with more ability. He was born in the southern part of this city, and was a graduate of the Philadelphia High School. [???] BACHE, perceiving in him marks of great merit, attached him to the Coast Survey, and while at Raleigh, engaged in the duties of the service, President PIERCE distinguished him by his appointment as cadet at large to the Military Academy at West Point. He graduated with high honors at that intitution, and was soon sent as a Lieutenant of that institution, and was soon sent as a Lieutenant of Topographical Engineers to New-Mexico, where his abilities obtain for him promotion to the rank of Assistant Adjutant-General. He was engaged in active service in the war with the Navajocs, and was with Col. McLEAN when that officer was killed. When the rebellion broke out, he came East and was attached to McCLELLAN's Staff in Western Virginia,being in ail the engagements in the campaign of 1861 in that region, where he  suffered an attack of illness from exposure. Subsequently, and before entirely restored, the went to Yorktown and was struck on the arm with a shell, while engaged in sketching some of the enemies' batteries. Notwithstanding the pain of the injury, his remark simply was: "That's bad, but I have executed the duty intrusted to me, and have a map of the works." This injury was such that amputation was necessary, which he cheerfully bore, but, owing to his previous ill health, his strength was not sufficient to support the operation, and he died  in a few days. At the time of his death he  was about to be made a Captain in the engineer service, an honor rarely reached by one so young, being only 25 years of age, one of the best evidences of the estimation in which he was held as an officer  of high scientific attainment. In speaking of his merits. Maj. HUMPHREYS, in a letter to his father, says. "By his death, the service has lost a well-instructed, intelligent and gallant officer, whose brief term of duty with the Army of the Potomac gave promise of rendering distinguished service to his country." The High School Alumni have adopted a series of resolutions in honor of the deceased, who was one of their number.

abstract: The Philadelphia Inquirer states that large cash investments in real estate have been made during the past week, by New-York capitalists, on South Broad-street. The distance from Jackson-street to Moyamensing Road, on the east side of Broad-street, consisting of some five or six squares, and taking in the whole of the Shetsline, West, and part of the Bond estates, have been thus purchased, and contracts are being made for the improvement of the two squares below Jackson-street, fronting Broad this present season, with beautiful dwellings. The boulevard parks and paying are to be extended south from its present terminus near Jackson-street, as the above improvements progress. This large purchase has beenmade for cash, after a careful investigation of several weeks, of the different localities of the city, on the part, of the purchasers, and further negotiations are in progress, by the same parties, for like investments below Federal-street.
