abstract: Editorial on proposed opera house to be built near Madison Square, NYC
snippet: Editorial on proposed opera house to be built near Madison Square, NYC
lead_paragraph: For some length of time, there has been movement on foot in this City, having a view toward the erection of a new Opera-House, and we believe that the arrangements with a view toward it have at length been definitely completed. The wishes of those who have been engaged in maturing this scheme were to build a theatre, and, in building it, to do away with two of the all abuses which has contributed, more than anything else, to the general failure of operatic managers. These were the free tickets held by the stockholders, and the immense extension of the deadhead branch of an operatic audience, which has, of late years, taken each an apparently firm root in the New-York Academy. For the last reason, as well as to reduce the current expenses of an operatic establishment to a more reasonable scale, it has been determined to erect the proposed Opera-House on a smaller scale than our present Academy. The site fixed upon is a very eligible one -- near Madison-square; and we apprehend that, unless difficulties arise in securing the ground, it will be almost immediately commenced; The proposed House will contain seats for about 1,000 or 1,600 persons, and it is understood that the auditorium will, with, of course, the exception of the parquet sad amphitheatre, be divided into boxes, containing four or six seats each. Two fine stores are to be under the theatre, on the ground-floor of the building, the rent of which will be reckoned on as a pert payment upon the capital invested -- the entire cost being calculated as averaging from $100,000 to $120,000. We need not point out that this house, when built, will be far more likely to pay the [???] as well as the proprietor or proprietors, from the mere fact that then will not be a large community of stockholders entitled to the best seats in the house, in that [???] class upon whom an opera manager has principally to rely for support. This fact alone, must give the lessee a far greater chance of success - we say this advisedly -- for in the term of year since the Academy of Music was first built, it would be difficult to point out a single tenant of that establishment, whose books would foot up at a positive gain. In truth, there can be no reason why [???] reasonably and economically managed, should not pay, and pay well, in such a wealthy City is New-York is, although it is here carried on without a subvention from the Government. But to effect such a result, the privileged classes who do not pay, must renounce their privileges or have them denied to them, and the house must be a size which will not allow it to appear empty when scantily filled by a merely paying audience, unless that audience is helped out by a large dead-head addition to it.

abstract: We have yet no explanation of the mystery attached to the dispatch from Cairo, published yesterday morning, announcing that important news had been received from Pittsburgh Landing, which was not allowed to be telegraphed. It probably, however, relates to the reported evacuation of Corinth by BEAUREGARI. The War Department has received dispatches from Gen. HALLECK, dated yesterday, but no intimation of their contents is given, except an assurance that our army is well, in high spirits, and eager to meet the enemy.

abstract: Editorial on Southerners' tendency to lie about their strength
snippet: Editorial on Southerners' tendency to lie about their strength
lead_paragraph: -- Oddly enough, the uniform success of all the expeditions directed by the National Government against the various rebel strongholds is, perhaps, in a considerable degree owing to the monstrous exaggerations indulged in by the rebels. No sooner is it conjectured that a certain point is aimed at by the National force than rebel report forth with endows the locality with every conceivable and inconceivable means of defensive and offensive warfare. Dark hints of untold resources of men, forts, ships and what not are given out: the spot is signalized as of all others the one they wish to have attempted, and the "Yankees" are gaily invited to hospitable graves. In consequence, the Government -- though of course perfectly aware of the rebel tendency to draw the long bow -- has yet proportioned the outfit of each important expedition just as though it would have actually to encounter the opposition intimated. The result is that our preparations have generally been overwhelming. The Fort Royal armada was on a scale out of all proportion to the task which really presented itself when it reached its destination -- namely, the reduction of a couple of imperfect earthworks, which yetwere sufficiently formidable to have seriously embarrassed a small fleet; while, at the same time, the presence of the powerful flotilla enabled us to take possession not only of Port Royal, but of the adjacent coast for a couple of hundred miles. Again, the Southern accounts of the enormous garrison at Fort Donelson led the Union commander to send thither a very powerful army, and when all was over, it turned out that the National force was really twice that of the rebels. Finally, there is every appearance that the capture of New-Orleans will prove a still more striking illustration of the same fact. The rebel imagination for months fairly exhausted itself in depicting the terrific character of the defences of that place. Nevertheless, if all they said had been true, their preparations would still have found more than a match in an expedition whose proportions may fairly be called gigantic. The rebels have to thank themselves that the Government has sent force enough not only to do up the New-Orleans business, but to clean rebellion out of the whole length of the Mississippi and its tributaries.

abstract: Union's iron-clad navy described; Union iron-clad navy described
snippet: Union's iron-clad navy described; Union iron-clad navy described
lead_paragraph: The inventive genius of our people has again become quickened under the presence of military excitement, and, as in the war of 1812, we are setting an example which other nations must hasten to follow. America, the youngest of sovereignties and the last to protect her coast with fleets, was and as the first to teach the world the true principles of maritime supremacy. Like Aphrodite, youngest son of Heaven, she is the Venus Genetrix on the domain of Ocean, first, in the era of the Winds, in that of Steam, and now in that of Iron.

abstract: The conditions on which Hon. JOHN M. BOTTS was released from his imprisonment in Castle Godwin, by the Court of Inquiry, that examinid the charge of disloyalty preferred against him, are: First, that after being permitted to go to his residence in Henrico, he shall, with all convenient speed, prepare to remove to a location further South; and when the same is Indicated by him, it must be approved by the War Department of the C.S. Government. It has already been intimated that, had not Mr. BOTTS, with his characteristic obstinacy, declared him elf a neutral in the present war, the Court of Inquiry would have recommended his charge. Of this we know nothing, but the conditions of his release, as specified above, may be relied on.

abstract: NEW ARMS FACTORY. -- The Association known as "Moore's Patent Arms Manufacturing Company," having completed their new works on First, near Hewes-street, opened them yesterday for the inspection of the public, and hundreds of citizens took advantage of the opportunity to examine the intricate machinery by which arms are made. The new factory is made of brick, 250 feet in length by 29 feet wide, and four stories high, besides a large basement. The lot upon which this building is located is 275 by 100 feet, and the whole of it is occupied by buildings used in the construction of the various weapons manufactured by this Company, cons sting of breechloading rifles, carbines, dragoon revolvers, pocket revolvers of various sizes, and Derringers. The Companyhas a capital of $75,1)00, and will, in the course of a few weeks, give employment to 500 men and boys. The capacity of the establishment is 2,000 rifles per month.

abstract: The pilot-boat Chase, from Nassan, N.P. for this port, says the Charleston Merchry, 29th was chased ashore by the Lincoln fleet, on Saturday last, and grounded on the Raccoon Keys, where she was burned by the officers and crew, to prevent her falling into the hands of the enemy. She had on board a cargo of sait,  The officers and men have serived here.

abstract: The remains of Gen. BEN. McCULLOCH, the hero of Oak Hills, the pride and boast of the army of the West, were, on Thursday, with all usual pomp and ceremony attending such occassions, laid by the side of BURLESON, HEMPHILL and McLEOD. The body lay in state, in Representative Hall, from 4 P.M. on Wednesday until 4 P.M. on Thursday last. At 11 o'clock, after prayer from Rev. Mr. PHILLIPS and Bishop GREGG, Capt. JOHN HENRY BROWN, who acted as Aid to Gen. McCULLOCH, in the action in which he lost his life, entertained the large concourse of citizens that crowded the large Representative Hall, with an address, narrating the thrilling incidents of the battle field, and portraying the military accomplishments, patriotism, heroism, and noble single-heartedness of our gallant Ranger General.

abstract: Our streets were enlivened on yesterday by the arrival of a large company of Cherokee warriors from the mountainous regions of North Carolina. These "children of the forest" have been enlisted in the Confederate service by Major MORGAN, Third Tennessee Regiment. The company here already numbers about one hundred and thirty, and we learn that Major MORGAN expects to raise a battalion composed partly of these Indians -- who we predict will do good service with their unerring rifles under the lead of the gallant Major. This officer, we must say, deserves the highest praise for his indefatigable zeal and energy as displayed in the enlistment of so many valuable recruits from the aboriginal population.

abstract: -- EZRA H. SPIER, ABRAM M. HAIGHT and NELSON EVANS were examined on Friday before United States Commissioner STILWELL on a charge of burning the Post-officer at New-Lebanon, Columbia County, N.Y., on the 5th of March last. The Post-office was kept in a storm which was burned, as is supposed, for the purpose of getting the insurance on the goods. The evidence against HAIGHT and EVANS was deemed by the Commissioner sufficiently strong to warrant their committal, which was accordingly done in default of bull. SPIER was discharged,

abstract: No one need be  No one need be surprised that President LINCOLN should have sent an astronomer to marshal the Union hosts southward. It is simply a bit of Old ABE's peculiar dry humor. MITCHEL is an astronomer and, by the way, he is a (West)...
lead_paragraph: -- No one need be surprised that President LINCOLN should have sent an astronomer to marshal the Union hosts southward. It is simply a bit of Old ABE's peculiar dry humor. MITCHEL is an astronomer -- and, by the way, he is a (West) Pointer also -- and was very property sent South to look after the lost stars. He has already succeeded in finding two or three -- having, as he himself some time ago remarked, "chased the rebels through three States without being able to come up with them." Kentucky and Tennessee, which an infamous rebellion put under temporary eclipse, again shine out in stellar splendor in the firmament of the Union; and he will doubtless push on and on, till the other stars appear in view -- down to the very verge of the Southern Cross. To the patriotic soul of the astronomer-soldier the restoration of the old starry glories must bring a rapture akin to hat which thrills --

abstract: The United States gunboat Santiago de Cuba, commander DANIEL B. abstract: During a passage through many, and a sojourn in a few of the towns on the line of the Rock Island, and Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana railways, during the past week, we have ascontained, by inquiries and personal inspection, that the growth of winter wheat never looked more promising. The extrem backwardness of the season must confine the
lead_paragraph: During a passage through many, and a sojourn in a few of the towns on the line of the Rock Island, and Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana railways, during the past week, we have ascontained, by inquiries and personal inspection, that the growth of winter wheat never looked more promising. The extrem backwardness of the season must confine the cultivation of spring wheat to a very small crop. Tho ground is as yet totally unfit to receive the seed, and the time is about past when it will be safe to sow it with any prospect of a successful crop. The time for corn planting has hardly yet arrived. If we shall be relieved within a couple of weeks of the present unpleasant state of weather, it will afford opportunity for successful corn planting, and farmers will undoubtedly put in as large a crop as their facilities for obtaining labor at the present and prospective scarcity for help will permit. We are not yet without hopes of a large crop of corn.

abstract: The Press in every part of the land is urging the organization of companies to engage in partisan warfare exclusively. As the enemy pushes his columns far into the interior, we must make it cost him so much that he will be deferred from continuing his operations. If he send a provision train from one point to another, he must send a small army to guard it, or lose the larger part. Instead of squads he will have to send brigades for foraging. Not knowing when a troop of cavalry will sweep down upon him, capturing horses and mules and destroying wagons, he will have to keep every point doubly guarded. But it will not do to wait for the enemy to get possession of the country before a few of these companies are organized. It is a fatal delusion to suppose thatthe unarmed, disorganized population will rise en masse and "get behind every tree, and under every bush." to fire upon a column marching upon the highway!
lead_paragraph: The Press in every part of the land is urging the organization of companies to engage in partisan warfare exclusively. abstract: This book might almost be called God's testimony given in one part of His word, and reiterated in other parts, in which essentially the same language that is in one part spoken of Jehovah and God, is in the other parts spoken of Christ, and of the Holy Spirit. Of such passages, in which the Bible abounds, fifty-one duplicates of corresponding passages are quoted which refer to Christ, and
lead_paragraph: This book might almost be called God's testimony given in one part of His word, and reiterated in other parts, in which essentially the same language that is in one part spoken of Jehovah and God, is in the other parts spoken of Christ, and of the Holy Spirit. Of such passages, in which the Bible abounds, fifty-one duplicates of corresponding passages are quoted which refer to Christ, and twenty-six duplicates of passages referring to the Holy Spirit. Then passages are quoted showing a trinity of persons; and passages showing a trinity in unity; with a summary view of the whole. Thus every candid reader has before him the Divine record, speaking for itself, irrespective of human theories, on a subject of pure revelation, before which it becomes human reason to bow down with humility, adoration and thanksgiving.

abstract: There is great briskness in the cotton market at present at this point. Loads are constantly passing through the city on their way to the river. One boat day before yesterday left with some two hundred bales. Buyers are scouring the country in all directions as far as the Federal lines extend, and sometimes even further. The planters are acting like men of practical sense, and are quick to trade. Good middling readily brings 16 and 17 cents in specie or United States Treasury Notes, and 22 and 25 in current Tennessee paper. There is no holding back on the part of the planters. They all fully appreciate the immense benefits which reviving trade will scatter over an almost bankrupt country. One thing has forced itself upon the minds of those even who were unwilling at first to admit the fact - imerference with private property which has not been included in the rebellion will not be made by Federal troops. All parties now feel secure in this respect. The Surveyor of this port has kindly consented to furnish us with the amount of bales shipped here. Our editorial friends abroad may hail this is a sign of reviving commerce in Nashville.

abstract: We judge from all we can learn that affairs in East Tennessee are in a most deplorable condition. The passage of the law by the legislature at Memphis, authorizing a draft has tested the greatest consideration a among the Union men who were willing to stay at home and quietly pursue their ordinary avoca-  tions, and reports reach here that thousands are flee-  ing into Kentucky, to avoid being forced into the Con-  federate army.
lead_paragraph: We judge from all we can learn that affairs in East Tennessee are in a most deplorable condition. The passage of the law by the legislature at Memphis, authorizing a draft has tested the greatest consideration a among the Union men who were willing to stay at home and quietly pursue their ordinary avoca- tions, and reports reach here that thousands are flee- ing into Kentucky, to avoid being forced into the Con- federate army. In Saturday's issue we copied a statement from the Knoxville Register, that a citizen of Knoxville, who had arrived there from Grainger County, on the 16th, had met, near Blair's Cross Roads, some 800 [???], on their way to Kentucky. They were said to be chiefly from Knox and Grainger Counties, and a few from Jefferson. The Register of the 30th announced the arrived there a large number of prisoners, arrested while attempting to escape into Kentucky, probably a portion of those referred to above. abstract: Before the Investigating Committee is disbanded, and Mr. CAMERON dismissed to his mission, there is an additional point or two in the transactions of last Spring that will bear inquiry. When Mr. CUMMINGS was appointed commission and forwarding agent for the Government in New-York, because of his "familiarity with the railroad system of Pennsylvania," it was because Washington was in imminent danger, and there was not a moment when railroad communication might not be severed. That communication was severed. The Seventh Regiment reached Philadelphia on the 20th of April, to find the bridges on both roads to Baltimore destroyed. It was actually embarked upon a large steamer, and carried to Annapolis around Cape Charles. Will it be credited that all this time there was a safe, expeditious and perfectly free thoroughfare to Washington, which the War Department never used? The Chesapeake and Delaware Canal is an artificial river which unites the two bays of those names. The channel is of unusual breadth and depth. The largest schooners, and propellers of considerable burden, pass through it daily. It is in a right line between Philadelphia and Baltimore. Along it all the troops and supplies wanted for the Capital could have been passed in an uninterrupted current to Annapolis. Fort McHenry could have been reinforced and victualled without a soldier passing through Baltimore. In short, the entire panic of the Northern people might have been saved. Why, it will be asked, was not the attention of the War Department called to this avenue? It was so called. The transportation agents here were assured that tugs and barges sufficient to move any number of troops, could be set in motion at once at Philadelphia. While the movement of regiments whose instant presence at Washington was most urgent, was wholly suspended, the agents of the Department were refusing to use a route upon which only thirteen and a half miles of canal navigation interposed between the waters of the Delaware and the Chesapeake, and over which an army can be passed with very little more delay than if it traveled over railroads in perfect order.

abstract: The news of the evacuation of Yorktown by the rebels produced a prodigious sensation in Washington, and before the full facts were obtained, the same wild clamor against Gen. McCLELLAN was raised that assailed him after the enemy's abandonment of Manassas. There were hundreds of heroes in political life who always knew the rebels never had thirty thousand men at Yorktown, and never intended to fight there.

abstract: The Twenty-eighth Anniversary of this institution was held at Dr. HAGUE's Church, Madison-avenue, last evening. A very large audience was in attendance, including about 200 children of the institution, who varied the exercises by singing. After prayer by Rev. Dr. HAGUE, an abstract of the Annual Report was read by Dr. L. RANNEY, of which the following is the substance: Receipts for the year ending Dec. 31, 1861, $21,068 50; disbursements, $20,927 35; leaving a balance in the treasury of $41 15. The receipts in the Publishing Department, for the same time, were $17,997 65; disbursements, $16 677 50; leaving a balance of $1,320 15. The number of young women and children who have received aid from the institution during the year is 2,335, as follows:

abstract: At an early hour on Sunday, under the profound darkness of the night, the entire rebel army in and near Yorktown, reckoned by common report at a hundred thousand men, evacuated their intrenched position, leaving their heavy guns, a vast amount of ammunition and medical stores, and the private property of their officers behind them.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour on Sunday, under the profound darkness of the night, the entire rebel army in and near Yorktown, reckoned by common report at a hundred thousand men, evacuated their intrenched position, leaving their heavy guns, a vast amount of ammunition and medical stores, and the private property of their officers behind them. A large portion of their ordnance stores is said to have been thrown into York river for the want of time and means to carry them off. Our first dispatch states that the heavy guns were left in position rather than risk an alarm to our army by the noise or confusion of their removal The whole extraordinary operation, which has startled the public by its unexpected occurrence -- to say nothing of its inexplicable motive -- appears to have been conducted with an expedition little short of a complete panic, from the fear of the consequences of remaining a single hour longer. It was scarcely probable that a general assault would have been made by Gen. MCCLELLAN on Sunday morning, but the rebel commanders were evidently unwilling to trust to the chance of another day's delay. Judging from the evidences of hasty flight which they left behind them, they stood not on the order of their going, but incontinently cleared out on the instant, as best they could.

abstract: Certain sympathizers with the slaveholding oligarchy of the South plume themselves much -- sorely lacking other occasion -- upon the defiant tone of the Mayor of New-Orleans in his letter of abdication to Commodore FARRAGUT, upon the like outbreathings of the Southern Press, and the attempt to drive the loyal East Tennesseeans from their homes.These incidents are pointed at as evidences that although the insurgents maybe beaten, they cannot be subdued; and that, although they fight for Slavery, they themselves "never, never, never will be slaves" to the Constitution and the laws. Perhaps it is not strange that a few weak-kneed people should be affected by this kind of talk, and shake their heads with doleful doubt over these malignant manifestations.
lead_paragraph: Certain sympathizers with the slaveholding oligarchy of the South plume themselves much -- sorely lacking other occasion -- upon the defiant tone of the Mayor of New-Orleans in his letter of abdication to Commodore FARRAGUT, upon the like outbreathings of the Southern Press, and the attempt to drive the loyal East Tennesseeans from their homes.These incidents are pointed at as evidences that although the insurgents maybe beaten, they cannot be subdued; and that, although they fight for Slavery, they themselves "never, never, never will be slaves" to the Constitution and the laws. Perhaps it is not strange that a few weak-kneed people should be affected by this kind of talk, and shake their heads with doleful doubt over these malignant manifestations.

abstract: A portion of our troops were ordered under arms this morning before light, indications leading one of the Generals to suppose that the enemy were preparing for an attack at daybreak. It was a false report, however, the enemy making no demonstration; nor are they likely to do so, being abundantly satisfied if they can make good their position where they are, without desiring to assume the offensive.

abstract: Rev. J. TODD, of Pittsfield, Mass., delivered the annual sermon of the Seamen's Friend Society, in the Lafayette-avenue Presbyterian Church, last evening. Every seat in the house was occupied, and the sermon was an impressive appeal for aid for seamen. The reverend speaker took for his text St. Luke, 5th chapter, and latter part of the fourth verse: "[???] out into the deep and let down your nets for a draught." He spoke of the lesson taught by the sea, as illustrating the power and goodness of God, in its productiveness, and of the dangers encountered by the 3,000,000 sailors who go down to the sea in ships -- 7,500 of whom die annually, of their hardships and privations, and expressed the belief that an appeal to aid these men would not be in vain. At the close of the [???] a liberal collection was taken up.

abstract: OUR WOUNDED. -- On Saturday evening a dispatch was received from the Surgeon-General at Washington, requesting that a number of surgeons should start at once to take charge of the wounded at Yorktown, and superintend their transportation to this city. In a few hours the following gentlemen left: Dr. James R. Wood, and his assistants; Messrs. Pray and Nolar; Drs. John V. Stone and Anderson; Dr. Daniel Ayres, of Brooklyn, and Dr. D.L. Rogers. Yesterday afternoon Dr. G. Buck, Dr. Watts, Dr. Peters and others also left for the same destination. The steamer Ocean Queen, which is to convey the wounded to New-York, will be in charge of the latter gentleman.
lead_paragraph: OUR WOUNDED. -- On Saturday evening a dispatch was received from the Surgeon-General at Washington, requesting that a number of surgeons should start at once to take charge of the wounded at Yorktown, and superintend their transportation to this city. In a few hours the following gentlemen left: Dr. James R. Wood, and his assistants; Messrs. Pray and Nolar; Drs. John V. Stone and Anderson; Dr. Daniel Ayres, of Brooklyn, and Dr. D.L. Rogers. Yesterday afternoon Dr. G. Buck, Dr. Watts, Dr. Peters and others also left for the same destination. The steamer Ocean Queen, which is to convey the wounded to New-York, will be in charge of the latter gentleman.

abstract: Yesterday evening, the annual sermon before the American and Foreign Christian Union was preached in St. George's Church, Dr. TYNG's by Rev. Dr. KINGSTON GODDARD. He took for his text the 19th verse of the 11th chapter of Revelations: "And I saw Heaven opened, and beheld to white horse; and he that sat upon him was called Faithful and True, and in righteousness be doth judge and make war." At the close of the discourse a collection was taken up in aid of the society.

abstract: Yorktown, which the rebels have repeatedly boasted could never be captured, is now in our possession, and the rebel army which lately occupied the intrenchments by which it was defended, are in full flight before the National army under Gen. MCCLELLAN. Various rumors have been in circulation during the past week, principals founded on the statements of deserters, that the rebels intended to evacuate the position, but it was hardly thought possible that the rebel leaders would risk such a movement. Evidence became very strong on Saturday, however, that they would do so, and on Saturday night, as will be seen from our dispatcher, the evacuation took place. Our troops immediately occupied the deserted works, and a large amount of camp equipage was found and guns, which the rebels dared not attempt to remove for fear of discovery. Gen. MCCLELLAN immediately threw forward all his cavalry and horse-artillery in pursuit, and took measures at once to embark troops on the York River, to be landed at West Point, on the railroad to Richmond -- Gloucester, in the meantime, having also been occupied by our forces. Everything inside the former rebel lines was found to be in the most confusion, indicating that the flight was hasty in the extreme. Seventy-one pieces of heavy artillery were found in their works, spiked, together with a large amount of ammunition, medical stores, camp equipage, tents, and the private property of the officers. Persons left in the town state that a large amount of ordnance stores was also thrown into the river, to prevent them falling into our hands. Our gunboats passed above Yorktown, and shelled the shore on the way up. The best information received led to the belief that the rebels fell back to Chickacoming Creek, beyond Williamsburgh, where it was expected they would make a stand. They are represented to be much demoralized, however, and whether they can now be brought to face our army, remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: Yorktown, which the rebels have repeatedly boasted could never be captured, is now in our possession, and the rebel army which lately occupied the intrenchments by which it was defended, are in full flight before the National army under Gen. Our troops immediately occupied the deserted works, and a large amount of camp equipage was found and guns, which the rebels dared not attempt to remove for fear of discovery. Gen. MCCLELLAN immediately threw forward all his cavalry and horse-artillery in pursuit, and took measures at once to embark troops on the York River, to be landed at West Point, on the railroad to Richmond -- Gloucester, in the meantime, having also been occupied by our forces. Everything inside the former rebel lines was found to be in the most confusion, indicating that the flight was hasty in the extreme. Seventy-one pieces of heavy artillery were found in their works, spiked, together with a large amount of ammunition, medical stores, camp equipage, tents, and the private property of the officers. Persons left in the town state that a large amount of ordnance stores was also thrown into the river, to prevent them falling into our hands. Our gunboats passed above Yorktown, and shelled the shore on the way up. The best information received led to the belief that the rebels fell back to Chickacoming Creek, beyond Williamsburgh, where it was expected they would make a stand. They are represented to be much demoralized, however, and whether they can now be brought to face our army, remains to be seen.

abstract: Yorktown was evacuated entirely by the rebels at 2  o'clock on the morning of the 4th. During all the preceding day and night they kept up a heavy firing on our batteries all along the lines to cover their retreat. Our pickets pressed their positions on the morning of the 4th, and entered their abandoned intrenchments.

abstract: The steamship Hammonia, from Southampton on the 23d ult., with advices from Europe three days later, arrived at this port late last night. The news is not specially important. The news of some of the recent great successes of the National arms had reached England, and created some excitement. The comments of the London Times on these events will be found elsewhere in this morning's TIMES.

abstract: The Police, last evening, made an attack upon Canterbury Hall; also, upon the concert saloon No. 444 Broadway, for a violation of the law relative to those places of amusement. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, the bill to limit the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals, was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment making the number of Major-Generals thirty instead of twenty. This amendment was adopted. A de- bate then occurred in reference to the number of Brigadier-Generals proper to appoint a point which was not decided.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, the bill to limit the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals, was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment making the number of Major-Generals thirty instead of twenty. This amendment was adopted. A de- bate then occurred in reference to the number of Brigadier-Generals proper to appoint -- a point which was not decided. The bill was laid over. A bill donating public taxes to States and Territories which provide colleges for the benefit of agricultural and mechanic arts, was introduced and referred. A resolution offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, to suspend all business under the act to secure pay, bounty, pensions, etc., to the officers and men employed in the Western Department, was referred. The Homestead bill was taken up, and Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, made a speech in opposition to it. The Confiscation bill was afterward considered until the Senate went into Executive Session. No other business was done in open session.

abstract: The object of the visit of M. MERCIER, the French Minister, to the rebel capital, is explained in a dispatch from our special Washington correspondent, published in this morning's TIMES. His mission, it will be seen, notwithstanding numerous denials, was a diplomatic one, and extremely important as bearing upon the pending struggle between the Government and the rebels. He carried assurances to the leaders in the rebellion that the Emperor of the French does not recognize them as a Power [???] the nations, that they must not [???] that the blockade is considered [???] that they are fairly beaten in arms, and that their independence as a nation is impossible. They were further assured that the destruction of cotton and tobacco, as threatened would [???] a most serious injury to the cause [???] a resort to guerrilla warfare could not [???], as it would be simply a return to [???], and that a [???] of hostilities is a duty they owe to themselves and to the world. At the same time, M. MERCIER carried assurances that Mr. LINCOLN's Administration would be held to a strict observance of the programme with which it started to combat the rebellion -- the restoration of the Union on the basis of the Constitution, with the inherent rights of all the States preserved. Of course, the object of the French Minister's visit was perfectly understood in Washington, and fully approved.

abstract: The flight from Yorktown of the main body of the army of the rebel Confederacy indicates, beyond dispute, the breaking-up of the great rebellion which has so long menaced the Nation's existence and defied its power. Neither in any part of Virginia nor in any one of the Southern States can the rebels find a position as favorable for them as that which they held on the peninsula on which to try the issue of arms. They could bring into action here not alone their army, but whatever they had of a navy. They had not only their line of works extended across the peninsula from river to river, but, by land batteries, they commanded both of the rivers from each of their banks. They had their transports carrying supplies and reinforcements directly into their camp, -- their gunboats to act as guards and supports, -- the Merrimac, whose guns and the fame of whose invulnerability have echoed round the world; they were close to Norfolk, the military and naval arsenal of the South; hey were within convenient distance of the whole Southern system of railroads; they had within call all the slaves of the densest Slave section of Virginia; in short, whatever there is in the South of men, munitions, supplies, labor, or facilities of conveyance, could be put to more efficient use at Yorktown than at any other point. The position could not be flanked, and the rear was entirely open. There can be no doubt, too, that here was the great bulk of the Confederated rebel army. Beside the levies from Virginia, we have certain knowledge that there were here troops from South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Louisiana and Texas, and, no doubt, also from all the other rebel States. The conscription law, which has been in operation in Virginia and throughout the South for over a month, has forced into service nearly the whole white population capable, of bearing arms; and as fast as regiments have been raised, they were sent post-haste, by rail and river, to Yorktown. To retreat from such a position, under such circumstances, is, in a military point of view, almost equivalent to giving up the campaign. At no other point is it possible for the rebels to bring into play one-half of the warlike agencies and facilities that were at their command here. Manassas itself was very far inferior as a defensive position to Yorktown. That drunken rebel and fop, MAGRUDER, spoke, for once, like an astute soldier when he said that "If they (the rebels) could not whip the Federals at Yorktown, there was no other place in Virginia where they could."

abstract: Our last intelligence from Mexico dissipates all doubt as to the fate of the coalition and the future policy of Spain. Gen. PRIM's nice sense of honor has rescued his adopted country from a very awkward position, and given the death-blow to a most unholy alliance. At the conference which took place between the representatives of the three Powers, to determine, if possible, on some common course of action, the Spanish Commander-in-Chief showed from the Treaty of London that the Allies had no right to impose on the Mexicans an obnoxious form of government; that to do so, in the manner contemplated by the French, would be not only to abandon the original idea of the coalition, but to break faith with the head of the Republic, and that, rather than become a party to such an outrage, he was resolved to withdraw the Spanish troops from the country. Gen. PRIM's arguments having produced no effect on the mind of the French Plenipotentiaries, that gallant soldier at once proceeded to make good his word, and, at the present moment, there is not, perhaps, a private of the Spanish contingent on Mexican soil. The Captain-General of Cuba, mortified at being withdrawn from the command of the expedition, was wroth, indeed, when he heard that the forced of Her Catholic Majesty were on their way to Havana, and, had he possessed the power, would doubtless have countermanded the retirement. The Spaniards in Cuba too, shared in the feelings of the Governor, and denounced Gen. PRIM as bitterly as if he had done something which reflected dishonor on Spain. But the die is now cast, the soldiers of Castille are fairly out of the dilemma in which they were involved, and no matter what view O'DONNEL may take of his officer's conduct, he will hardly send the troops a second time to Mexico.

abstract: Mercier reportedly went to Richmond to tell Confederates to cease fighting because their cause was lost
snippet: Mercier reportedly went to Richmond to tell Confederates to cease fighting because their cause was lost
lead_paragraph: When, three weeks ago, the Envoy of the French Government sought permission to visit the rebel capital, and having obtained it, left upon his mysterious errand, public curiosity was profoundly stirred. What at a moment so critical could be the business between the French Emperor and the rebel chief? Was it in the interest of France, or of mankind, or, more strictly, of the American people, that these impenetrable negotiations were to be conducted? There was no fact, of course, beyond the bare visit to go upon. On a foundation so narrow, optimists were content to build nothing broader than an attempt to release the tobacco crop, stores of which had been bought, paid for, and housed in Richmond, on account of the French Government, but which the rebels declined to release, and the National Government to pass, if released, through the blockade. The object was thought not to be unworthy of a Minister Plenipotentiary. Of tobacco the Imperial Government has a monopoly. If supplies were wanting to the smoking and snuffing subjects of Imperial rule, it would be impossible to foretell the political, to say nothing of the commercial consequences to the Empire; and in this view the dispatch of a Prince of the blood-royal would have been justified by the urgent need.

abstract: medical journal (La Sanidad) pays a high compliment to the American medical profession. Among our occulists and aurists it ranks Dr. LIGHTHILL of New-York, as one of the very first, and says that his treatment of diseases of the eye and ear is the most practical and philosophical yet known. It then goes into a lengthy description of the mode of treatment by the inhalation of certain chemical vapors, and quotes a number of the Doctor's most successful operations, illustrating its arguments. -- Albion.

abstract: -- A fantastic drama in four acts, called "Reason and Folly, or Life in Paris," was produced at this theatre last evening. It is stated that it has been adapted from the French especially for Miss KRENE; if we are not mistaken, Mr. CHARLES SELBY was the original translator, and the piece was produced in London some years ago, Madame CELESTE performing the principal part. No doubt Miss KRENY has curtailed and added to Mr. SELBY's translation, but has not improve it. Beyond this the piece is not worthy of mention.

abstract: Gov. MORGAN, attended by his Staff and a number of interested gentlemen, visited yesterday the various defences of the harbor. The result of the survey is represented as being in the highest degree satisfactory, the labors of Gen. BROWN, Gen. TOTTEN and Col. DELAFIELD having already armed and prepared for any contingency the principal works, while the remainder are rapidly approaching completion. The principal harbor defence, however, escaped the notice of the party. Three months of labor will finish the Stevens Battery, upon which the Naval Commission has reported favorably; and that, once finished, small use will there be in stone bastions and guns on terra firma. If one such vessel be placed in the Sound and another at Sandy Hook, the harbor of New-York will be as inaccessible in war time as that of Cronstadt. We are not aware that any wall in the harbor fortifications would resist such hammering as thegreat gun of Sir WM. ARMSTRONG inflicted upon the Shoeburyness target. Iron armor can readily be made to do so.

abstract: The following statement, dated yesterday, on five Rappahannock, has reached Washington.  A colored man came in to-day from the other side of the river, and represented himself as JEFF. DAVIS' coachman. From an examination of him, this is proba- bly the truth. He repeats scraps of conversations overheard while driving Mr. and Mrs. DAVIS in the carriage, and between Mr. DAVIS and those who came to see him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, May 5.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 6. The United States gunboat Huron captured, on  the 19th ultimo, off Charleston, the schooner Glide, of Charleston, while attempting to run the blockade. She was bound to Nassau, and was loaded with 100 bales of cotton and five fierces of rice. Her papers and logbook were thrown overboard during the cruise.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was offered by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and laid over, asking the Secretary of War for copies of all reports of the battles at Pittsburgh Landing. The Homestead bill was taken up and passed--33 to 7.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was offered by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and laid over, asking the Secretary of War for copies of all reports of the battles at Pittsburgh Landing. The Homestead bill was taken up and passed -- 33 to 7. The Confiscation bill was debated as the special order, and several Senators made speeches for or against it. A motion made by Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, that all the measures proposed on the subject be referred to a Special Committee of Seven, excited considerable discussion, but finally prevailed, with an amendment making the number of the Committee nine -- 24 to 14. During the debate on the Confiscation bill, Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, from the Finance Committee, obtained consent to report the House Tax bill with amendments. Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, said there had not been unanimity in the Committee regarding the proposed amendments, and submitted a substitute embodying the views of the Board of Trade of Boston and the Chamber of Commerce of New-York. The thousand extra copies of the bill and the amendments were ordered to be printed. After an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Of the partisan  rebel troopers who annoy the rear of our army in Tennessee, the most noted is a cavalry corps commanded by one MORGAN.
lead_paragraph: -- Of the partisan rebel troopers who annoy the rear of our army in Tennessee, the most noted is a cavalry corps commanded by one MORGAN. This fellow began to figure while our army was in Central Kentucky last Winter, and since it moved southward he has been particularly active. He and his men turn up everywhere. Now they are reported as killing a picket; now waylaying and entrapping small detachments of our troops; now burning bridges, tearing up railroad tracks, scouring the country in every direction, plundering houses, frightening women and children, and mingling, on general principles, the occupation of rebel mosstroopers with that of bandits and marauders. He is the first genuine specimen of those guerrillas with which, when all other means of waging war fall, the rebels threaten, to devastate their own section of the country. His field of operation is mainly a narrow strip of country running north and south from Nashville to either border of Tennessee, along the line of the railroad which our troops travel in going south or north by Nashville. He likes particularly to commit his depredations tantalizingly near to the Capital, and says that he will yet have ANDY JOHNSON and other large game among his prisoners of war. We have already published a good many tale. of the fellow's doings, and some others are reported this morning. Last Friday he and his men made a sudden swoop upon a detachment of National troops stationed in the village of Pulaski, Giles County, Southern Tennessee, and, after a skirmish, captured four Union Captains, nine Lieutenants, an Adjutant, and about 250 privates, whom he spiked by putting them all upon their parole of honor. Three days afterward he suddenly turned up at the town of Lebanon, Wilson County, Northern Tennessee, nearly a hundred miles by the traveled route from the scene of the previous exploit; but this time the tide of battle turned against him. A large number of his men were taken prisoners, the rest routed, and he himself is said to be slain. This is the first time MORGAN is reported to be killed; and, it he has half as many lives as some other rebel chieftains in the Southwest, it need not disappoint anybody if he turn up again -- in time, at least, to be hanged.

abstract: If evidence were wanting of the indomitable courage with which the country regards its future, it would be found in the fact that at this stage of the national struggle, and while the Treasury is still awaiting the revenue to be produced by a system of taxation still to ...
lead_paragraph: If evidence were wanting of the indomitable courage with which the country regards its future, it would be found in the fact that at this stage of the national struggle, and while the Treasury is still awaiting the revenue to be produced by a system of taxation still to be framed, Congress has nerve to enact a law providing for the completion of the most gigantic internal improvement the age has yet contemplated. The House of Representatives yesterday passed the Pacific Railroad bill, by a majority of thirty. Thus a measure which through years of popular prosperity and pecuniary opulence found no adequate support, is in a fair way to be put in practice at a period, which the outside world agrees to regard as that of the nation's extremity.

abstract: Prophesying has  proved rather a profitless business since the war began, yet the number of parties who have gone into it, and the amount of capital invested and sunk in it, both on this side of the water and abroad, was never greater.
lead_paragraph: -- Prophesying has proved rather a profitless business since the war began, yet the number of parties who have gone into it, and the amount of capital invested and sunk in it, both on this side of the water and abroad, was never greater. Thus far, it seems as if the foreign prophets had not succeeded as well in the business as our own, but this may be partly because, owing to their distance from us, we have in very many instances been able to place, right alongside of their prophecies, events which showed their utter falsity.

abstract: Proofs accumulate as to the correct  ness of our special Washington advices yesterday concerning the real object of the visit of M. MERCIER to the rebel Capital, and the nature and purport of his communications with the rebel leaders.
lead_paragraph: -- Proofs accumulate as to the correct ness of our special Washington advices yesterday concerning the real object of the visit of M. MERCIER to the rebel Capital, and the nature and purport of his communications with the rebel leaders. We have intelligence this morning from Richmond, by way of Fortress Monroe, which tallies, in almost every particular, with our intelligence already published from Washington. The French Minister is said in Richmond to have freely declared to the rebelleaders his belief that their rebellion was a failure, and must soon come to an end; that the Emperor was sincerely anxious that the contest should be terminated as speedily as possible by their relinquishment of it; and that he (the Emperor) would willingly proffer his good offices as a peacemaker upon the basis of their reacknowledgment of the General Government's authority intact. All this was expressed to the rebel Government unofficially, and without in any way recognizing its authoritative existence. We think there need no longer be any doubt that it was for the purpose of letting the rebel leaders know what is now the opinion of the monarch who, a year ago, extended to their "so-called Government" the rights of a belligerent power, that the Imperial representative visited Richmond. In the event of a rebel defeat on the peninsula, we shall probably at once have proof positive that this is the real truth of a matter which has been the subject of so much speculation. If so, the American Government and people, as well as the rebels, will have a very grave question for consideration.

abstract: It is almost bewildering to attempt to follow the campaign in the Virginia peninsula, as reported in the rapid throng of telegrams.
lead_paragraph: It is almost bewildering to attempt to follow the campaign in the Virginia peninsula, as reported in the rapid throng of telegrams. Not one, but half-a-dozen centres of action attract the eye in the complex though converging scheme of operations in front and flank and rear, adopted by Gen. MCCLELLAN for the capture of the enemy. If anything could be unlike the unity of action that has characterized the siege of Yorktown for the past month, it is the exciting and shifting spectacle now presented by the rebel force in mingled fight and flight, pressed and pursued by the Army of the Union.

abstract: PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, May 6. The remains of Gen. C.F. SMITH, the hero of  Fort Donelson, were removed from Independence Hall, to their last rosting-place at Laurel Hill, this afternoon. The ceremonies, which were of the most solemn character, were participated in by a large number of officers of the army, including Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, and the navy, together with all the civic dignitaries.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN to the Secretary of War, dated 10 o'clock on Monday night, announces that he had found the enemy in large force and strongly intrenched at Williamsburgh, under command of Gen. JOE JOHNSTON himself, and evidently intending to dispute his progress towards Richmond with all their power. There had been some brisk fighting, in which Gen. HANCOCK had taken two of the enemy's redoubts, and had repulsed EARLY's rebel brigade by a brilliant bayonet charge, in which our forces killed two rebel Colonels and two Lieutenant-Colonels, and captured one Colonel and one hundred and fifty other prisoners. Gen. HANCOCK's conduct in this affair is highly commended by Gen. MCCLELLAN. At the time of sending the dispatch our losses had not been ascertained, though they were thought to be heavy, as the fighting was very severe. Gen. MCCLELLAN expresses his belief in this dispatch that the rebel force is superior to his, and announces his determination to hold it in check while he resumed his original plan, temporarily suspended by the rebel flight from Yorktown.

abstract: The steamship Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 23d, and Queenstown on the 24th ult., arrived at this port last evening. The advices are one day later than were received by the Hammonia.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 23d, and Queenstown on the 24th ult., arrived at this port last evening. The advices are one day later than were received by the Hammonia. The most important news by this arrival is, that the rebel ship Ermile St. Pierre, which was captured some time ago by the blockading fleet, has arrived at Liverpool, having been recaptured from her prize crew by the Captain and two or three of the crew who were on board. The market news is unimportant.

abstract: A pleasant little story is told in our English files, of the way in which the British ship Emilie St. Pierre, a prize of our blockading squadron, made captive her captors, and sailed into Liverpool the other day with all sail bent and colors flying.
lead_paragraph: A pleasant little story is told in our English files, of the way in which the British ship Emilie St. Pierre, a prize of our blockading squadron, made captive her captors, and sailed into Liverpool the other day with all sail bent and colors flying. The vessel in question was seized under suspicious circumstances, off Charleston, on the 18th of March; and a portion of the crew having been removed, and a prize crew, numbering one Lieutenant and fifteen men substituted, the ship was ordered to Philadelphia for condemnation. Three of the original crew were left on board, the Captain, the steward, and cook. These three, before Cape Hatteras had been passed, executed a bold and ingenious scheme for recovering possession of the ship; and circumstances and the indifference of the prize crew favoring them, actually succeeded in overpowering and confining the officers, without alarming the crew, and in placing the hatches over the crew before any suspicion of the attempt had been excited. Enough of the captives to navigate the vessel and carry her safely to England were subsequently released upon parole. The heroism of the attempt, and still more its success, obtain the unqualified praise of the British Press, who are quite enraptured at the entire transaction. We, however, who remember what the colored steward, JOHN TILLMAN, did single-handed in the same line of business last July, when he brought the rebel prize S.J. Waring into New-York, must needs award the palm of superior gallantry to the American negro.

abstract: Judge  McCUNN has returned to the charge, his opportunity being the charge to the Grand Jury. We should-grieve profoundly to find ourselves classed with those who see no good in this magistrate.
lead_paragraph: -- Judge MCCUNN has returned to the charge, his opportunity being the charge to the Grand Jury. We should-grieve profoundly to find ourselves classed with those who see no good in this magistrate. The very address we allude to exhibits some of the Judge's better characteristics to the highest advantage. His points are well taken, and lucidly stated; and in learning the difficult duties of the Grand Juror, the wayfarer, after hearing this admirably digested summary, can by no possibility err. But these are not the only things brought to light by the charge. Another trait of Judge MCCUNN's character is his persistence, when by logic or sophism he has wrought himself into a state of dogmatic conviction in his opinions; and this peculiarity is finely displayed in the presentation to the Grand Jury of his favorite view of Sunday Liquor laws, "beverage, biberagium," and all. The Grand Jury has before it much work cut out for it by the rumsellers. The Judge was warranted in urging upon its attention not only the subject, but his legal prognosis thereof; and it now remains for Jury, Grand and Petit, to decide whether the Legislature meant to forbid the sale of rum of a Sunday, or to require it to be conducted in decency and secresy. If the latter dogma hold good, then does society owe reparation to the Justice and reprobation to the Legislature.

abstract: U.S.S. TUSCARORA, ALGESIRAS, Friday, April 11, 1862.  The merchants of New-York may at last regard the career of the Sumter as closed. We have managed to keep her closely blockaded in Gibraltar for two months, having the advantage of lying in hospitable Spanish waters, from which British impudence could not eject us, and finally the pirate appears to be giving up in despair.
lead_paragraph: U.S.S. TUSCARORA, ALGESIRAS, Friday, April 11, 1862.

abstract: The undersigned, being desirous of testifying practically their appreciation of the gallantry displayed by Lieut. WORDEN, United States Navy, commanding the United States gunboat Monitor, in her conflict with the rebel iron-clad steamer Merrimac, in Hampton Roads, Va., on March 9, and of the signal service rendered by him on that occasion to the commercial interest of New-York, and the UnitedStates at large, hereby agree to pay the sum set opposite their names toward a fund to be presented to Lieut. WORDEN. WM. H. ASPINWALL, Esq., has kindly consented to act as Treasurer of the fund, and subscriptions may be paid in at No. 68 Wall-street, office of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

abstract: editorial says battle cry "On to Richmond" is legitimate watchword now that McClellan is pursuing Confederates from Yorktown
snippet: editorial says battle cry "On to Richmond" is legitimate watchword now that McClellan is pursuing Confederates from Yorktown
lead_paragraph: The historic phrase which in the dark days of Midsummer was the despairing cry of a maddened and bewildered people, and afterward the insensate shibboleth of a political faction, is at last a living reality. The Army of the Potomac, led by its gallant commander, is now pressing on the heels of the routed regiments of the rebellion -- and its battle cry is "On to Richmond!" It is now a legitimate watchword, which any simple patriot may repeat and do naught to embarrass those who guide the Republic.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a number, of petitions were presented, among them one from citizens of Maryland, asking for the repeal of the act abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia. The House bill to provide for the deficiency in the appropriation for the payment of volunteers, and for the payment of troops in the Western Department, was reported.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a number, of petitions were presented, among them one from citizens of Maryland, asking for the repeal of the act abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia. The House bill to provide for the deficiency in the appropriation for the payment of volunteers, and for the payment of troops in the Western Department, was reported. It appropriates over $30,000,000. In answer to an inquiry as to how many men are in the army, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, stated that the number was not known exactly, but he thought from 500,000 to 520,000. After debate the bill was laid over. The House bill to provide increased revenue was passed. A resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on Commerce to inquire whether any legislation is necessary relative to vessels belonging to loyal citizens seized and confiscated by the rebels, and recaptured at New-Orleans and other places. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution for the expulsion of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, which was laid over. The House Committee, appointed to announce the impeachment of Judge HUMPHREYS, appeared at the bar of the Senate and fulfilled their mission. They received assurances that the Senate would take the proper steps in the matter. The bill to limit the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals was debated, but no conclusion was come to. Messrs. Clark of New-Hampshire, Collamer of Vermont, Harlan of Iowa, Cowan of Pennsylvania, Wilson of Massachusetts, Harris of New-York, Sherman of Ohio, Henderson of Missouri, and Willey of Virginia, were appointed the Special Committee on the Confiscation bill. The Senate then went into Executive Session, and afterward adjourned.

lead_paragraph: The friends of Hon. SIMON CAMERON, ExSecretary of War, gave him a public dinner, at Harrisburgh, Penn., on Saturday evening last, preliminary to his departure for Uurope. Mayor KEPNER presided, and, after the cloth was removed, Mr. CAMERON made a speech in response to a toast in his honor, which the Harrisburgh Telegraph reports at length. After reviewing some recollections of early life indicative of the vast progress made by Harrisburgh, Mr. CAMERON said:

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, a detachment of the Fifth New-York Cavalry made a reconnoissance toward Harrisonburgh. When five miles this side they encountered upwards of 200 of ASHBY'S Cavalry. They charged upon them and pursued them within two miles of town. Ten rebels were killed and six taken prisoners.
lead_paragraph: NEW MARKET, Va., Wednesday, May 7.

abstract: Last month was another busy one at the Cus- tom-house, the cash receipts for duties amounting to  $4,147,351, which sum is but little inferior to that re- ceived during the month preceding, the receipts for...
lead_paragraph: Last month was another busy one at the Cus- tom-house, the cash receipts for duties amounting to $4,147,351, which sum is but little inferior to that re- ceived during the month preceding, the receipts for the two months amounting to nearly $9,000,000. These two months have been the most busy ones for a long time. The duties have mostly been paid on sugar, of which large quantities have been imported, and on tea, coffee and dry goods. Of tea, some very large and valuable cargoes have been imported this year, and the duties realised therefrom have contributed largely to the revenue. But, as the Treasury regulations with reference to the levying of duty on tea now stand, the Government loses each year a large sum of money to which it is justly entitled, and the loss of which only serves to enrich the importer. In 1799 a law was passed regulating the amount of tare to be allowed importers of various article. According to that law, tea, as it is usually imported, is entitled to an allowance of eighteen pounds per chest. This law, regulating the matter of allowances, was reaffirmed by the Secretary of the Treasury last year, when the passage of a tariff, levying specific duties, rendered necessary some regulations on this subject. The fact was not taken into consideration that tea from China comes packed in chests which weigh much less than they formerly did, the Quantity of lead used in lining the chests, and the weight of the wood of which the chests are made, being less. By forgetting this fact, and, in consequence, not regulating the tare as it should be regulated, the Government loses on each chest imported about $1, a loss which, in the course of a year, amounts to a large sum.

abstract: Emanuel Giro et al. vs. The Cargo of the Brig Alexander Wise. -- This was an action upon a bottomry bond. The British brig Alexander Wise, while on a voyage from Marseilles to New-York, ran upon a reef and was injured so as to make it necessary for her to go to Gibraltar, discharge her cargo and obtain repairs and supplies. Her master, James Pill, ordered the repairs and supplies, and to secure the moneys advanced to pay the bills, amounting to Â£1,198, he executed a bottomry and respondentia bond, by which that sum, with 21 per cent. maritime interest, was declared to be secured "upon the said vessel, her hull, tackle, apparal, furniture, freight and appurtenances, and upon the cargo now laden on board." It declared that the obligees had consented to advance the money on such security, "and on the risk of the said voyage to New-York," and it provided that if the said vessel "do and shall proceed with all convenient dispatch from the port of Gibraltar to New-York aforesaid, (the damages and accidents of the seas and of navigation excepted,) and if the said James Pill, his heirs, executors and administrators, within two days next after the arrival of the said vessel at New-York aforesaid, do and shall, well and truly, pay, or cause to be paid," the said sum, &c., and interest; "or if, in the course of the voyage aforesaid, the utter loss of the aforesaid brig shall unavoidably happen," then the bond was to be void, otherwise of force.
lead_paragraph: Emanuel Giro et al. vs. The Cargo of the Brig Alexander Wise. -- This was an action upon a bottomry bond. The British brig Alexander Wise, while on a voyage from Marseilles to New-York, ran upon a reef and was injured so as to make it necessary for her to go to Gibraltar, discharge her cargo and obtain repairs and supplies. Her master, James Pill, ordered the repairs and supplies, and to secure the moneys advanced to pay the bills, amounting to £1,198, he executed a bottomry and respondentia bond, by which that sum, with 21 per cent. maritime interest, was declared to be secured "upon the said vessel, her hull, tackle, apparal, furniture, freight and appurtenances, and upon the cargo now laden on board." It declared that the obligees had consented to advance the money on such security, "and on the risk of the said voyage to New-York," and it provided that if the said vessel "do and shall proceed with all convenient dispatch from the port of Gibraltar to New-York aforesaid, (the damages and accidents of the seas and of navigation excepted,) and if the said James Pill, his heirs, executors and administrators, within two days next after the arrival of the said vessel at New-York aforesaid, do and shall, well and truly, pay, or cause to be paid," the said sum, &c., and interest; "or if, in the course of the voyage aforesaid, the utter loss of the aforesaid brig shall unavoidably happen," then the bond was to be void, otherwise of force.

abstract: Fort Jackson, which is by far the stronger work, is a regular pentagonal bastioned fortification, having two fronts bearing on the river, and three on the land side. The land fronts have each a glacis and covered way, and the channel is commanded by a battery of twenty-five guns.
lead_paragraph: Fort Jackson, which is by far the stronger work, is a regular pentagonal bastioned fortification, having two fronts bearing on the river, and three on the land side. The land fronts have each a glacis and covered way, and the channel is commanded by a battery of twenty-five guns. A wet ditch, from forty to seventy feet wide, and six feet deep, surrounds the main work on the river, and a similar ditch, one hundred and fifty feet wide, the land fronts. There is also a wet ditch, six feet deep, and thirty feet wide, around the channel-bearing battery. The two channel-bearing fronts have each eight casemate guns, which are the only casemated ones in the work. The ditches are defended by 24-pounder howitzers at either flank. The parapet is carried across the gorge of the bastion, so that there is no flank parapet defence. The bastions are only arranged for musketry fire from the walls. The main work of the lower battery mounts in the aggregate one hundred and twenty-five guns, of which one hundred bear on the channel. There was a one-story brick citadel within the fort, having two tiers of loop-holes for musketry defence, the walls of which are five feet thick. The entrance to the work is by a wooden bridge on the west side, connected with a draw-bridge ten feet wide.

abstract: For a naval battle of varied and thrilling interest, in which not only ship fights ship, and cannon thunders responsively to cannon, but in which ships fight forts, ships (wooden ships) fight iron-clad rams, fight chain barriers, masked batteries, fire-rafts, fire-eaters and whatever other warlike enginery Southern ingenuity may have devised, there is nothing equal to the one fought near the mouth of the Mississippi for the possession of the Southern metropolis.
lead_paragraph: For a naval battle of varied and thrilling interest, in which not only ship fights ship, and cannon thunders responsively to cannon, but in which ships fight forts, ships (wooden ships) fight iron-clad rams, fight chain barriers, masked batteries, fire-rafts, fire-eaters and whatever other warlike enginery Southern ingenuity may have devised, -- there is nothing equal to the one fought near the mouth of the Mississippi for the possession of the Southern metropolis. It seems, from the narrative of our correspondent, that all the wonderful and monstrous devices for the defence of the city, which had been so frequently and grandiloquently descanted upon by the New-Orleans press, were truly and actually in existence, and each of them in readiness for the ordeal of which they had been forewarned. The rebel mind had literally exhausted itself in its efforts to render the city impregnable. What other things could be thought or dreamed of, beside those which were provided? What could science, skill, or Confederate bonds do or procure, that was not done and procured? All that was thought to be necessary for the absolute security of the city, was to render the Mississippi River impassable, and the entrance to Lake Pontchartrain impossible for our fleet; -- and surely this had been thoroughly accomplished. Two of the means of defence and assaultwhich are particular favorites with the rebels -- stone blockades and torpedoes -- were impossible of application here. The deep and powerful volume of the Mississippi rendered vain any attempt or thought of such a thing. But during the fifteen months that had passed since Forts St. Philip and Jackson were seized by the rebel authority, and the rebel flag was raised over them and the Crescent City, all the foundries, ship-yards and workshops far and near had been busy providing every other conceivable means of defence.

abstract: As the magnitude and continuance of the rebellion have been greatly dependent upon the misrepresentations of the Southern papers, an inside view of the Press of New-Orleans has an especial interest at this moment. There are nowsix daily papers that have weathered the storm of the rebellion; there were still other dailies and several weeklies at the beginning of the war, but they were early swept away by the commercial disasters that overwhelmed the Crescent City. The excitements of the times, however, have had the local effect of increasing the daily circulation of the living representatives; but, save in this single and unimportant particular, their substantial interests have suffered, and probably, with one or two exceptions, they are kept from sinking because the publishers have capital at their command independent of their newspaper receipts. The price of a single paper in the streets since the war began has been an omnibus or car ticket, silver having early disappeared. These tickets are in turn bought from the newspaper offices by small grocers and hucksters, to enable them to make change. It should perhaps be stated, in this connection, that the scarcity of printing paper has not been felt in New-Orleans as much as in other parts of secessia -- the combined wealth and enterprise of the publishers having been equal to the establishment of a paper-mill.

abstract: It thus appears that, notwithstanding all that is said on behalf of the negro, his real position is very simple. He is the denizen of a country eight millions of the inhabitants of which are willing to allow him to exist there in the capacity of a slave,and eighteen millions are unwilling to allow him to exist there in any capacity at all.
lead_paragraph: It thus appears that, notwithstanding all that is said on behalf of the negro, his real position is very simple. He is the denizen of a country eight millions of the inhabitants of which are willing to allow him to exist there in the capacity of a slave,and eighteen millions are unwilling to allow him to exist there in any capacity at all. The South forces him to labor, but gives him food, clothing and a home. The North insists that he shall no longer be forced to labor, but refuses him a home in the land of his birth, and, while emancipating him from Slavery, denies him all the privileges of Freedom. The opinion of Russia has decided that the emancipation of the serfs carries with it the necessity of granting them a portion of the land for their subsistence. No such idea is maintained in America. The black must either be a slave or an outcast. He has no choice, no immediate state between forced labor and expulsion. The opinion that would protect him against the first is silent, and, could it speak, is powerless to defend him against the second. For him no middle state between the two is possible. The desperate precipitation of the South and the lust for dominion of the North have hurried on matters to a point which leaves no possibility of dealing gradually and temperately with this terrible question. Popular passions have been evoked and excited, and it may well turn out that the only point on which the two Confederacies, who are pouring forth each other's blood like water, may be able to agree will be in the destruction or expulsion of that unhappy race which has served as the pretext for their quarrel.

abstract: veyor ANDREWS and his Deputy, W. BROWN, in company with Officer O'KEEFE, boarded the Columbia, yesterday, upon her arrival from Havana, and took into custody a young man who gave his name as JOHN WM. HAMMOND, upon the charge of being an officer in the rebel army.
lead_paragraph: -- Surveyor ANDREWS and his Deputy, W. BROWN, in company with Officer O'KEEFE, boarded the Columbia, yesterday, upon her arrival from Havana, and took into custody a young man who gave his name as JOHN WM. HAMMOND, upon the charge of being an officer in the rebel army. The officers immediately searched his baggage and found several sword belts; also, a beltplate, upon which the letters "C.S.A." were very handsomely engraved. The Surveyor asked him where his sword was, to which question the accused answered he did not know. After some delay it was ascertained that he had given it in charge to one of the porters. The porter was then found. At first he denied all knowledge of the weapon, but finally produced it from a dark, out-of-the-way place in the hold of the vessel. When the sword was brought to light, the young rebel officer began to tremble very violently, and, in a low tone, remarked to some of the bystanders that he was afraid he was in a scrape. The articles seized were given in charge to Collector BARNEY, and the prisoner was conveyed to Police Headquarters. He says that he is 28 years of age, and a native of Sullivan County, in this State. Several of the passengers who came on from Havana in the same steamer, state that the prisoner was very zealous in the advocacy of the rebel cause during the entire passage. It is pretty well known that he left this City some weeks ago with the intention of going to Cuba, where he hoped to fall in with a vessel about to run the blockade, and by this means to gain the soil of "Secessia;" but failing in this, he concluded to return to New-York. Another party, who appeared to be a companion of HAMMOND, was also arrested and conveyed to Police headquarters.

abstract: The following is a concise statement of the famous drift of this ship on her voyage of 48 days from Boston to Port Royal.
lead_paragraph: The following is a concise statement of the famous drift of this ship on her voyage of 48 days from Boston to Port Royal. The Vermont left her anchorage at President Roads, in Boston Harbor, about 7 A.M., on the 24th of February, in tow of two steamtugs, and proceeded to sea in company with the steamer Kensington, it having been the intention of the Navy Department that the latter vessel should accompany the Vermont, and, when practicable, tow her on the route. The Kensington made fast to the Vermont outside of Boston Light, both ships steering E. S.E. by compass, and continued to tow her during the day, the weather thick and foggy, and wind from the eastward, with evident indications of a change in the weather for the worse. About 7 P.M. the wind hauled to the N.W., and increased so rapidly that the contingency of the Vermont forging ahead and running down the Kensington induced the latter to cut the hawsers, and she passed her, flying before the gale. The wind increased, in violence, the ship then being under double-reef topsails clewed down, mainsail and foresail hauled up, and mizzen-topsail furled. About 10 P.M. it blew a hurricane, with snow and hail. The ship became unmanageable, broached to, and every sail was blown from the yards in succession. Land -- Cape Cod -- was then said to be seen by the Commander and coast pilot, on the Ice how. This discovery we believed was confined to them alone. Orders were given to let go both anchors; the starboard one parted at 150 fathoms, and the [???] brought up with one hundred fathoms chain, and dragged for one hundred miles, when the anchor and chain were lost. The order was then given by the Commander to cut away the masts, and the carpenter's gang commenced the work, when it was countermanded. The morning of the 25th found the ship a glare of ice, and badly crippled for want of sails, &c.; the precise position undefined, and weather bad in the extreme. At 3 A.M. of the 26th, the iron tiller gave way, near the socket; the rudder soon after wrenched itself from the stern-post, and was lost, inflicting, however, no damage to the stern-frame of the ship.
headline: {'main': 'U.S. SHIP-OF-THE-LINE VERMONT.; Particulars of Her Voyage from Boston to Port Royal.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'U.S. SHIP-OF-THE-LINE VERMONT.; Particulars of Her Voyage from Boston to Port Royal.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
