abstract: The gallant fighting of the National soldiers under Gen. McCLELLAN on Monday was too much for the rebels, and on Tuesday night they evacuated their new position at Williamsburgh, and continued their retreat toward Richmond, followed on Tuesday morning by our victorious troops.
lead_paragraph: The gallant fighting of the National soldiers under Gen. McCLELLAN on Monday was too much for the rebels, and on Tuesday night they evacuated their new position at Williamsburgh, and continued their retreat toward Richmond, followed on Tuesday morning by our victorious troops. Gen. MCCLELLAN telegraphs to the War Department that the effect of Gen. HANCOCK's brilliant victory on Monday was to turn the left of the enemy's works, and our troops being reinforced the rebels were forced to leave with the utmost precipitation, leaving all their sick and wounded behind. We captured about three hundred uninjured prisoners and more than a thousand wounded -- proving the losses of the enemy to have been very severe. A subsequent dispatch from Gen. MCCELLAN, and the latest one from him, states that every hour proved our victory more complete, and that the enemy's loss was great, especially in officers. Our losses in HOOKER's Division on Monday are believed to be heavy, but are not yet known. Gen. HANCOCK gained his splendid success, however, with a loss of not over twenty killed and wounded. The latest we have from the Peninsula is a rumor received from Yorktown at Fortress Monroe, yesterday, to the effect that the rebels had left the direct line of retreat to Richmond, and had crossed the Chickahominy, destroying the bridges in their rear. This movement has been induced, probably, by the knowledge that Gen. MCCLELLAN has thrown a large force in their rear from West Point, at the head of navigation on the York River. This new line of retreat brings them near to the James River, on which our gunboats could do most effective service if allowed.

abstract: GRAMME. -- The news from Mexico confirms the previous announcement of a final rupture among the Allies. A portion of the Spanish contingent has already returned to Havana; the remainder, with Gen. PRIM, was to follow forthwith; and the British Marines had reembarked. The French were thus left alone to fight their way to the Capital. Of the progress of this enterprise, we have no information. We learn, however, from the interior, that the Mexicans were strengthening theirpositions and reinforcing the Eastern Division, thus interposing all possible obstacles to the French advance; and should the levy in mass ordered by the President meet with a patriotic response, it is quite possible the way may be effectually barred.

abstract: Gentlemen arrived in this city yesterday from Memphis and New-Orleans. They left Memphis Saturday evening, and brought a paper of that date, from which we make some extracts. The Argus alludes to mysterious rumors in circulation, and it is plain that there was something out, but they don't tell it. New-Orleans is alluded to mysteriously, and no one doubts that the point of anxiety was about the fate of that city. These gentlemen state that they had positive knowledge, before leaving Memphis, that New-Orleans was in the possession of the Federal troops, but the papers and the authorities were prohibited from publishing anything of the kind.

abstract: The enemy evacuated this place and their works in front last night, the rear guard passing through about 6 o'clock. At 9 o'clock Gen. McCLELLAN and escort entered the town and took possession. About one hundred and fifty of the enemy's wounded were left behind, without any rations, medicine or surgeons. They also left a number of their dead unburied. All of our wounded in yesterday's engagement who fell in their hands were left behind.

abstract: By the arrival of the Columbia from Havana we receive advices from Vera Cruz to the 24th ult. The news is important, and indicates immediate hostilities between the French and the Mexicans,  in fact, hostilities had already commenced.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Columbia from Havana we receive advices from Vera Cruz to the 24th ult. The news is important, and indicates immediate hostilities between the French and the Mexicans, -- in fact, hostilities had already commenced. The French, instead of retiring beyond the Passes of the Chiquihink to Paso Aucho, as they agreed to in the preliminaries of Soledad, had advanced from Cordova and occupied. Orizaba. They attacked some eighty men who were in a small fort, and though they defended themselves well, took 25 prisoners and 20 horses. The Mexicans appeared to have been much aroused. On the 19th. 3,000 reinforcements for ZARAGOZA arrived, and the 21st, 6,000 came from Puebla. CHARLES LENNOX WYKE was having a private conference with DOBLADO at Puebla, the end of which Gen. PRIM was awaiting at Vera Cruz. The causes given by the French Plenipotentiaries for not fulfilling what they had stipulated, are four, as follows:

abstract: William Donohue vs. John Kelly. Sheriff, et al.  This was an action to recover possession of certain personal property. The defence set up was that the sheriff seized the property, which consisted of about $1,200 worth of liquors, under an execution in favor of James Wallace, his codefendant, and against one Peter Murphy.
lead_paragraph: William Donohue vs. John Kelly. Sheriff, et al. -- This was an action to recover possession of certain personal property. The defence set up was that the sheriff seized the property, which consisted of about $1,200 worth of liquors, under an execution in favor of James Wallace, his codefendant, and against one Peter Murphy. It was claimed by the defendants that Murphy had kept a liquor store at the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty-second-street, previous to November, 1861, and on the 20th day of that month he sold the store to the plaintiff, who was his brother in-law, for the price of $1,500, and on the same day conveyed to his brother two lots at Harlem in payment for services; that between the 7th and 30th of November, 1861, Murphy bought of said William Walton and defendant Wallace, for his store, liquors to the amount of $2,000, and it was claimed by the defendants that, as against creditors, the sale was fraudulent, and that the plaintiff had notice of the fraudulent intent. Jury disagreed.

lead_paragraph: THE CONGREGATIONAL SOCIAL REUNION will take place at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this evening at 7 o'clock. Among the speakers announced are Dr. THOMPSON, Prof. HITCHCOOK, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Dr. EELLS and WM. ALLEN BUTLER, Esq. The plan of combining short, pithy addresses with sociability, singing and instrumental music, is an attractive feature of this meeting. Judging from the well-known character of these previous annual gatherings, and the recent brilliant victories of our armies, there will probably be a commingling of patriotism and religion on this occasion.

abstract: -- PUTNAM is bringing out a valuable accessory to the printed history of the war in FRANK MOORE's Companion to the Rebellion Record. This is intended to form a volume supplementary to the other, and of the same size and style. It consists entirely of documents relating to the history of the period. Of these, Part I. contains no less than 20, including "JOHN BRIGHT's speech at Rochdale, England, Dec. 4, 1861;" "The Rebellion, its Origin and Mainspring," by CHARLES SUMNER; "Gen. BEAREGARD's Report of the Battle of Manassas, or Bull Run," and others of like interest.
lead_paragraph: -- PUTNAM is bringing out a valuable accessory to the printed history of the war in FRANK MOORE's Companion to the Rebellion Record. This is intended to form a volume supplementary to the other, and of the same size and style. It consists entirely of documents relating to the history of the period. Of these, Part I. contains no less than 20, including "JOHN BRIGHT's speech at Rochdale, England, Dec. 4, 1861;" "The Rebellion, its Origin and Mainspring," by CHARLES SUMNER; "Gen. BEAREGARD's Report of the Battle of Manassas, or Bull Run," and others of like interest.

abstract: The work of reducing the rebel strongholds will be commenced this morning. How long the struggle will be prolonged no one is able to prophesy. We all know that a formidable task is before us; that desperate men, fighting for the last stake, are our opponents. But of our ultimate success every body is confident.
lead_paragraph: MISSISSIPPI RIVER, Friday, April 18, 1862.

abstract: Editorial sees end of blockade of Southern ports captured by Union forces
snippet: Editorial sees end of blockade of Southern ports captured by Union forces
lead_paragraph: Secretary SEWARD has addressed a circular to the Representatives of the Foreign Powers at Washington, which throws the proudest bulletin of victory into the shade, for it is itself the crown and fruition of a hundred victories. It announces the present purpose of the President of the United States to supersede the blockade at New-Orleans, and several other important seaports. For a year all the energies of the Government and the country have been absorbed in war measures. Here is the first measure of peace -- a peace possible, however, only by passage through the Red Sea of War. The announcement is notmore gratifying to us than it will be to foreign nations whose commerce has been shackled, whose industries have been paralyzed, and whose tempers have been tried by the bar which for twelve months it has been the duty of our Government to lay on all intercourse with the long line of insurgent coast.

abstract: The Sunday Schools connected with this Association -- 222 in number -- held their anniversaries on Tuesday, and, as usual, they were, for many reasons that might be named, the most pleasant of all the many anniversaries. They were all held at the same hour, 2 1/2 P.M., and at the following churches: Irving Hall, (Mission Schools,) Oliver-street Baptist Church, Allen-street Presbyterian Church, Sixth-street Baptist Church, Stanton-street Baptist Church, Central Presbyterian Church, Washington-square Reformed Dutch Church, Mercer-street Presbyterian Church, Laight-street Baptist Church, Second-avenue Baptist Tabernacle, St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Sixteenth-street Baptist Church, West Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church, North Presbyterian Church, Madison-avenue Presbyterian Church, Free Will Baptist Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, and Forty-second-street Presbyterian Church. The exercises were much the same in all, and consisted of singing by the children and addresses. Among the speakers at the various churches were Rev. S.H. Tyng, Jr., Rev. Alonzo R. Thompson, Rev. B.W. Chidlaw, Rev. N. Heston, Rev. I.M. Sprague, Rev. Dr. Newell, Rev. W. Sanderson, Rev. W. Hiscox, Rev. Mr. Zabriskie, Rev. W. Lowry, Rev. Mr. Hoaton, Rev. Dr. [???], Rev. Chas. Parker, of Kansas; Rev. Dr. Adams, Rev. Mr. Durvia, H.C. Trumbull, Wm. E. Dodge, W. Hasbrouck, H.A. Mott, S.M. Ostrander, and others. In the evening the officers and patrons of the Union acid a meeting at Irving Hall, at which Chancellor FURRIS, the President of the Union, presided being the forty-six in anniversary of the Association. Addresses were delivered by [???] of Rev. [???] CHILDLAW, and by H.C. TRUMBULL, Esq. The annual report of the Union was read by the Corresponding Secretary, J.N. MCELLIGOTT, Esq., from which we gather the following statistics; Number of schools connected with the Union, 222; additions during the year, 6; number of scholars registered, 48,000; whole number taught during the year, 70,000; number of scholars, 5,500; number of teachers in infant classes, 1,300; in Bible classes, 4,500; colored children in the Union, 1,200; total volumes in the libraries, 92,000; contributions from the scholars during the year for missionary and charitable purposes, $18,000; number of conversions reported from 16 schools, 200. The Union, as is generally known, comprises most of the Sunday Schools in this City and Brooklyn belonging to nearly all the different denominations except the Catholics, Episcopalians, Methodists and Universalists.

abstract: The Nashville Union publishes the following important call, which is signed by Gov. JOHNSON, BALLIE PEYTON, W.B. CAMPBELL, JORDAN STOKES, ALLEN A. HALL, W.B. STOKES, and a large number of other prominent citizens of Tennessee: "The undersigned respectfully request their fellow-citizens of the State of Tennessee, who are in favor of the restoration of the former relations of this State to the Federal Union, to be present at a public meeting to be held at the Capitol, in the City of Nashville, on Monday, the 12th day of May, 1862."

abstract: Owen J. Lakeman vs. Smith Barker et al.,Executors, &c., of Samuel Storm. -- This was an action to recover the sum of $1500, for work, labor and services performed by one Mary E. Storm, a daughter-in-law of Samuel Storm, as a nurse during the testator's last sickness. The plaintiff brines this action as the assignee of Mary E. Storm. The defence set up was, that the husband of Mary E. Storm rented a house of the testator, and that her work and labor was a consideration for the rent.

abstract: -- All who admire gallant conduct will be gratified to learn that Lieut. WORDEN is now convalescent. It is also gratifying that the responsive appreciation of our citizens has swelled the testimonial which it is proposed to present to this officer to a sum already very handsome. Others, however, will doubtless be glad to join in the subscription, and Mr. W.H. ASPINWALL will act as treasurer of the fund. No one who at all understands the object of this testimonial will make the mistake of supposing that it partakes in any degree of the nature of a charity. The design originated solely in the desire to give practical expression to a sense of gratitude for a signal National service, and had no reference to the pecuniary condition of the recipient. It will, however, take nothing from the gratification of the participators that the testimonial which it is proposed to present to the gallant officer will take a form that will make it an acceptable offering to him it honors.

abstract: THEATRE FRANCAIS, NIBLO's CONCERT ROOM. -- The remains of the French Company that were performing in this City, some two years since, gave last night one of their present series of representations. It was for the benefit of M. EDGARD. The staple of the evening's entertainment was, of course, adapted to the limited numbers of their company, consisting of one act comedy and vandeville. The company is, however, excellent in this class of piece, and attracted by that excellence a large audience, whose enjoyment of the entertainment provided for them must have been [???] satisfactory to  the beneficiare. Three pieces were given, the first of which was "Triolet a la Recherche of [???]." This was very crisply and neatly [???]. It was followed by "Marlon and [???]," placed upon the stage in this City, for the first time, and cleverly acted by Madame LAURETTI and M. EDGARD. We may hint to many of our own actors that it might be very possible to take a lesson from the closeness of style and clean finish of manner displayed by the few French artists forming the present troupe.

abstract: The Academy of Music was crowded to its very utmost capacity on Tuesday evening, on the occasion of the anniversary exercises of the "Howard Mission and Home for Little Wanderers," located at No. 26 New Bowery, when 200 performers made their first appearance on the stage of that temple of music. The occasion was one of unusual interest, and the exercises appropriate. The object of the Society, it is well known, is to provide homes for little wanderers, who are found running in the streets uncared for, or who are brought there for the purpose of having them sent to the Far West, where there is no trouble in finding good and permanent homes for them. From the annual report, a brief abstract of which is appended, it will be seen that the Society has accomplished much good, and deserves the encouragement and aid of all philanthropists.

abstract: The Annual Reunion of this Society took place in the Academy of Music last evening. The house by 7 o'clock, the hour announced for the exercises to commence, was filled from parquette to gallery, a major portion of the audience, as is usual on such occasions, being composed of ladies. The stage was occupied by a large number of clergymen and a num- ber of distinguished laymen, representing nearly if not every ecclesiastical denomination.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Reunion of this Society took place in the Academy of Music last evening. The house by 7 o'clock, the hour announced for the exercises to commence, was filled from parquette to gallery, a major portion of the audience, as is usual on such occasions, being composed of ladies. The stage was occupied by a large number of clergymen and a num- ber of distinguished laymen, representing nearly if not every ecclesiastical denomination. Punctually at 7 o'clock Rev. RUFUS W. CLARK, of Brooklyn, Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements, in his most felicitous manner, introduced the Chairman of the meeting in the person of Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, who, in a few happy remarks, following his induction into office before the footlights, soon made the audience feel at home, and prepared the way, in a measure, for the good things in store for them. But there was a something, which, to a certain extent, seemed to east a gloom over all present, and particularly the speakers if we can believe their own statements, for each one in turn alluded to it, more or less directly. This feeling was produced by the neglect of the committee to supply the refreshments heretofore furnished at the annual meetings of the Society; and flowers for the ladies. Notwithstanding this drawback, all present will have occasion to remember, for a long time, the meeting of last evening. The Chairman introduced the speakers in the following order: Prof. HITCHCOCK, of the Union Theological Seminary; Rev. Mr. FOSS, of the Fleet-street M.E. Church, Brooklyn; WM. ALLEN BUTLER; Rev. J. EELLS, of the Church of the Heights (Dutch Reformed); Rev. Mr. HOLMES, (Congregationalist,) of Jersey City; Rev. Dr. EDDY, Baptist, Boston; and in the absence of HENRY WARD BEECHER, an acceptable substitute was found in the person of the Rev. Dr. STONE, of the Park-street Presbyterian Church, Boston. The speeches were sandwiched with hymns, sung by the whole audience, accompanied by an excellent band of music. Rev. Mr. ANDERSON opened the exercises with prayer, and the meeting was closed with a benediction pronounced by Rev. Dr. BADGER.

abstract: The Forty-eighth Anniversary, of the American Tract Society of Boston was held on Wednesday afternoon, at the Academy of Music. The opening address was delivered by Rev. S.H. TYNG. President of the Society. Addresses were also delivered by Rev. T.L. CUYLER and Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. During the past year the receipts of the Society have been $88.054 72, exceeding those of the year preceding by nearly $14,000, and about $9,000 greater than any year since its organization. The expenditures of the year have been $88,115 77. The amount of donations specifically designated for the benefit of soldiers has been $17,793 77, and there has been disbursed in their behalf the sum of $22.196 89. The Secretaries report that "the general condition and prospects of this Society are highly encouraging. The list of its publications, though by no means equal to its necessities, is now sufficient to give it a large business, and is of such a character as to gain for it the confidence and favor of the Christian public. The demands for them are increasing, and from a very wide range of patronage in foreign countries, as well as at home. Several thousand dollars worth have been ordered from Australia and other parts of the British Colonies, and from England itself."
lead_paragraph: The Forty-eighth Anniversary, of the American Tract Society of Boston was held on Wednesday afternoon, at the Academy of Music. The opening address was delivered by Rev. S.H. TYNG. President of the Society. Addresses were also delivered by Rev. T.L. CUYLER and Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. During the past year the receipts of the Society have been $88.054 72, exceeding those of the year preceding by nearly $14,000, and about $9,000 greater than any year since its organization. The expenditures of the year have been $88,115 77. The amount of donations specifically designated for the benefit of soldiers has been $17,793 77, and there has been disbursed in their behalf the sum of $22.196 89. The Secretaries report that "the general condition and prospects of this Society are highly encouraging. The list of its publications, though by no means equal to its necessities, is now sufficient to give it a large business, and is of such a character as to gain for it the confidence and favor of the Christian public. The demands for them are increasing, and from a very wide range of patronage in foreign countries, as well as at home. Several thousand dollars worth have been ordered from Australia and other parts of the British Colonies, and from England itself."

abstract: AN AGGRAVATED CASE OF MALICIOUS MISCHIEF. -- Some very maliciously disposed person or persons, entered the marble-yard of Mr. RICHARD S. COOK, situated on the corner of Broadway and Twenty-second-street, on Wednesday night, and wantonly destroyed property of his, consisting of statuary, tombstones, vases, &c., to the amount of over $2,000. All of the tombstones in the yard were very badly defaced; the heads, hands, feet, &c., of the statues were broken off, and, in fact, the entire premises were one scene of ruin when they were entered yesterday morning by the proprietor. The facts of the case were immedaitely communicated to the Police, and a detective has been commissioned to ferret out the guilty party, if possible. There is little hope of success, however, for Mr. COOK has no idea who could wish to do him so great an injury.

abstract: Accounts from Yorktown to Wedne noon bring us reports that Gen. McCLELLAN was at that time some distance beyond Williamsburgh, in full pursuit of the flying rebel army, which was retreating in the greatest panic across the Chickaboundry River. Our forces came up with them the second time about eight miles from Williamsburgh, where they attempted to make another ...
lead_paragraph: Accounts from Yorktown to Wedne noon bring us reports that Gen. McCLELLAN was at that time some distance beyond Williamsburgh, in full pursuit of the flying rebel army, which was retreating in the greatest panic across the Chickaboundry River. Our forces came up with them the second time about eight miles from Williamsburgh, where they attempted to make another a bud, but after a brisk skirmish fled. A large additional number of prisoners were captured in this encounter, and a number of deserters had come into our lines, who gave the most deplorable account of the condition of the rebel army, as evidenced be their own condition of physical exhaustion, A later dispatch states that the main portion of the flying rebels had succeeded in crossing the Chickahominy, and had destroyed the bridges in their rear; and that Gen. MCCLELLAN was temporarily resting his victorious troops on the east back. It is stated to have seen the general impression at Yorkstown that Gen. MCCLELLAN had thus got the enemy precisely where he wanted men. Not less than fifty steamers were meantime engaged in transporting troops up the York River to West Point, from which, place they were expected to proceed across the Peninsula, to intercept the rebel retreat. But most important of all is the intelligence telegraphed from Fortress Monroe yesterday, that at 6 o'clock in the morning the iron-clad war-ship [???], accompanied by the gunboats Aroostook and Port Royal, proceeded up James River toward Richmond, to intercept the flight, of the rebels in that direction. They passed the Day's Point Battery without difficulty, and, at last accounts, were far up the river. Later in the day it was ascertained that Sewall's Point was being evacuated by the rebels, and the Monitor, the Naugatuck and several of our gunboats proceeded in that direction.

abstract: The Convention convened Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, President FARQUHER of Chicago, in the Chair, and a quorum present. The Convention listened to an address from the presiding officer, in which he briefly alluded to the progress made by the Typographical Union, which, not even the hated rebellion of the South had obstructed, and predicted greater success in the future than any enjoyed in the past.
lead_paragraph: The Convention convened Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, President FARQUHER of Chicago, in the Chair, and a quorum present. The Convention listened to an address from the presiding officer, in which he briefly alluded to the progress made by the Typographical Union, which, not even the hated rebellion of the South had obstructed, and predicted greater success in the future than any enjoyed in the past. The Secretary read his annual report, in which he says that subordinate Unions have been formed and charters approved in several localities in the States, but in consequence of the very depressed state of the trade a moderate progression in this respect is chronicled. He had received no response to the letters sent to the Typographical Societies in the Provinces of Canada, Nova Scotia and New-Brunswick, with a view of bringing them under the jurisdiction of the National Union, in accordance with the resolution of the Nashville Convention of 1860. Financially, the Union has not suffered. The receipts were $662 87, and expenditures $598 33, leaving a balance on hand of $74 54. Of the per capita tax received for 1860, $1 75 was paid from Grand Rapids, $27 from Baltimore, $39 from San Francisco, and $8 25 from Cleveland; total, $75. Of the per centage tax, $469 81 was received from 33 subordinate organizations. The report was adopted. The Convention then proceeded to the election of officers for the ensuing year, with the following result: President, John M. Farquher, of Chicago; First Vice-President, W. A. Montgomery, of Boston; Second Vice-President, Jas. H. Walker, of Detroit; Treasurer and Recording Secretary, Thomas J. Walsh, of the New-York TIMES; Corresponding Secretary, Theo. Nagle, of St. Louis. The President announced the following Standing Committees. On Appeals -- Messrs. Briggs, Keech, Cowles, Amsbury, Nagle. On Finance -- Messrs. Herrick, O'Connor, Wallace, Adams, Oakley. On Subordinate Unions -- Messrs. Choate, Squire, D. W. Flynn, Kenneard, Slump. On Unfinished Business -- Messrs. Smith, McDonald, F.M. Flynn. On New Business -- Messrs. Slawson, Browne, Vought, Santee, Gray. On Returns -- Messrs. Gorman, Kelvey, Morris, Bailey, Eaton. Some discussion ensued upon the propriety of retaining the name of George McKay Luken, of Memphis, on the permanent roll, which it was finally decided should be done. An invitation to visit the Public Charities of the City, to-day, at 2 1/2 o'clock P.M., and attend a printers' reception this evening, at the New-York Typographical Rooms, was accepted. The Committee on Unfinished Business reported in favor of diminishing the per capita tax from 15 cents to 10 cents, to apply to all the rolls of Unions. A proposition to establish the principle of paying 7 per cent, on all receipts, gave scope for considerable debate, which resulted in the postponement of the Committee's proposition for consideration to-day.

abstract: The Thirteenth Anniversary of the American and Foreign Christian Union was held on Tuesday morning, at Irving Hall. The Rev. Dr. DE WITT was called upon to preside. After the preliminary exercises, the annual report and the Treasurer's statement were read; from which it appears that the receipts of the Society during the past year, from voluntary contributions, collections, and legacies, exceeded the sum of $55,000. The expenditures were nearly equal to the receipts. The society has lost, during the past year, some of its warmest and most valued friends, among whom mention is made of the Hon. THEODORE FRELINGHUYSEN, Chief Justice WILLIAMS, and ELISHA TAYLOR, Esq. Since the last annual report, the Society has employed twenty-one missionaries in the Home Department including two women whose business it has been to distribute bibles. The Committee have in the last year established several new missions in New Granada, Brazil and Child. The missions established by this Society in Europe, have continued in a very prosperous condition. In France, the Committee have made appropriations to the Central Society for Evangelization, the Evangelical Society of France, and the Evangelical Church of Lyons. These three societies employ more than 180 missionaries, not including the students in Theology.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Messrs. lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Messrs. FOSTER, of Connecticut; DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, and DAVIS, of Kentucky, were appointed a Special Committee to consider the Humphreys impeachment case presented by the House. The House bill, to establish a port of entry and delivery at Hilton Head, S.C., was passed. A petition from citizens of Florida, asking the passage of a confiscation bill, was presented. The bill making an appropriation for the payment of volunteers was taken up, and, after some debate, was passed. The bill limiting the number of Major and Brigadier Generals was also passed. The number is fixed at 30 of the former and 200 of the latter. The bill to establish a Department of Agriculture was passed -- 25 to 13 -- after considerable debate. The bill for the appointment of medical storekeepers was passed, with an amendment authorizing the President to appoint Chaplains at hospitals. Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Winconsin, called up his bill to collect taxes on lands in insurrectionary districts; but after an explanation of its provisions it was postponed until to-day. The bill relative to the selection of jurors for the District of Columbia was passed. After some further business of no particular importance the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The thirty-ninth Aniversary of the American Home Missionary Society was celebrated at Irving Hall Wednesday evening, Rev. Dr. PETERS in chair. Prayer was offered up by Rev. Dr. ANDERSON, Rev. CHARLES R. ROBERTS, the secretary, then read the annual report which exhibited a favorable state of the Society's missionary progress and pecuniary prosperity. The receipts from various sources for the year have been $163,852,51: expenditures $158,336,33. There is a balance in the Treasury of $7,248,34. After the reading of the Report, addresses were made by Rev. F. MCGOWN and Rev. Dr. STONE. The proceedings closed with the usual election of officers.

abstract: The Sunday Schools connected with the six Universalist Churches in this City, held their anniversary on Wednesday afternoon at Rev. Dr. CHAPIN's Church in Broadway. Several hundred children were in attendance, who, together with their parents, friends and teachers, who joined in the celebration, completely filled the large church. The Stars and Stripes were unfurled in front of the pulpit, and on either side were arranged the beautiful side banners of the children, giving a very ornamental appearance to that end of the church. The exercises were of the usual character. Several songs and hymns were sung by the children, the concluding one being the "Star-spangled Banner," in which the whole audience joined. Appropriate addresses were made by Rev. MOSES BALLOU, Rev. Mr. CRAVENS, Rev. Mr. BROOKS, and Rev. Mr. FLANDERS.

abstract: In old age, habits are hard to alter. The Herald has tried in vain to become a decent sheet, properly admissible within the household circle; but its early and ingrained vulgarity and obscenity are irrepressible, and defeat the effort. So in youthful days it was accustomed to obtain the news at least as promptly as its rivals. Now, having abandoned the practice, it cannot rid itself of the habit, of complaint and depreciation with which it remarks the successes of its neighbor. Yesterday, the TIMES furnished the only detailed account, written with great skill and elaborate detail, of the tremendous engagement below New-Orleans. None of our cotemporarieshad a line of correspondence from the Mississippi; and those who cared to know the incidents of this most important event of the war were obliged to lay siege to the publication of this paper; or, our editions failing, buy the Express, which, with its usual instincts, stole the products of our enterprise bodily and without acknowledgment. Now, notwithstanding the Herald has had weekly experience in thus seeing itself outstripped by the TIMES, as the history of the Port Royal and the Burnside expedition, and of the expeditions down and up the Mississippi will thoroughly demonstrate, it cannot get accustomed to the sensation, and, while we may be at a loss to know what form the objurgation may take, the explosion of ill-natured scolding that follows each such mortifying defeat we have come to expect with positive certainty.

abstract: This Society held its twenty-fifth annual meeting Wednesday evening, in Dr. CHEEVER's Church, Union-square. In the absence of Gov. BUCKINGHAM, of Connecticut, Rev. Dr. TYNG, President of the Society, occupied the Chair. Dr. MARSH, the Secretary, read the report, from which it appeared that the Society has distributed a quarter of a million of tracts broadcast throughout the army, navy and hospitals; to enable them to do which, they had received, by way of public and private contributions, $1,373 75. The report states that laws prohibiting the traffic in liquors are observed in the rural districts, out have proved a failure here in the City; and it blames the Legislature for neglecting to refer a prohibitory amendment of the Constitution to the people. Resolutions of respect to the memory of Gov. BRIGGS, of Massachusetts; Chief Justice WILLIAMS, of Connecticut, and Hon. THEODORE FRELINGHUYSEN, of New-Jersey, were then passed. Addresses were subsequently made by JAMES A. BRIGGS, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER and others.

abstract: The important news which we publish this morning, that the iron-clad man-of-war Ga- lena, and two gunboats, started up the James River early yesterday morning, with the object of cutting off the retreat of the rebel army southward, indicates a speedy and decisive issue to the campaign in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The important news which we publish this morning, that the iron-clad man-of-war Ga- lena, and two gunboats, started up the James River early yesterday morning, with the object of cutting off the retreat of the rebel army southward, indicates a speedy and decisive issue to the campaign in Virginia. MCCLELLAN was pushing the rebels forward from point to point with such precipitate haste, that it was feared they might see that their safety depended upon an escape out of Virginia; and that, if they succeeded in effecting this, the campaign might be greatly prolonged, and transferred to a region where operations during the Summer would be exceedingly slow and difficult. It was desired by every one that the rebel army might be brought to bay at once, and compelled to try the issue of arms which it had first invited. -- Unless now it fly to the mountains as best it may, or effect a hocus-pocus retreat from Richmond over the railroad to Danville, and thence march into the Carolinas, it must fight on its present ground, and fight speedily. The gunboats will ascend the James River to Richmond, and probably capture the city, which would be nothing wonderful, since we have heard of the capture of New-Orleans. They can then go to Petersburgh, capture that place, seize the lines of railroad to Norfolk and to Weldon, and thereby completely isolate Norfolk, and control all the connecting lines of railway running South. If the rebel army be still between the Chickahominy and the James Rivers, they will hold it there until Gen. MCCLELLAN, who was on the right bank of the Chickahominy on Wednesday, can cross that stream, and, acting in conjunction with the large National force at New-Kent, on the line of the Richmond and West Point Railroad, can completely hem the rebels in, and compel a capitulation or a field fight. The Editor-in-chief of this journal, in a letter from the Peninsula, published on Wednesday, stated that if the rebel army crossed the Chickahominy, as he believed it would do, "the only way to prevent its escape was by an advance of our gunboats up the James River." In this morning's issue we publish the fact that the rebel army has actually crossed the Chickahominy; and it is pleasing also to announce, simultaneously with that fact, that the Navy Department has at last woke up to its duty, and put in operation the only means we had of preventing another rebel retreat.

abstract: The eighteenth anniversary of this excellent charity was celebrated, last evening, at the Academy of Music, the auditorium of the house being crowded. Some two hundred of the children belonging to the institution (ranging, in age from six to sixteen) were seated on tiers of railed seats at the back of the stage. The exercises engaged in by these promising scholars were interestingly varied, and showed a great deal of iintelligence, combined with patient training. One fine-looking boy, THOMAS H. GAUGHAN by name, gave special evidence of natural capacity and self-reliance. The opening prayer was offered by Rev. W.H. MILBURN; Rev. H.B. RIDGEWAY delivered an address, and Bishop JANES, who presided, pronounced the benediction. A collection wastaken up, and subscriptions announced to a total amount of $1,500, of which $500 was donated by DANIEL DREW, Esq. The financial statement of the Society exhibits an account of $8,157 32 disbursements, against $8,234 45 receipts, leaving a balance in hand of $76 83. There is, however, a debt of $3,000 due on the building at the Five Points.

abstract: It was inad-  vertently stated in the TIMES yesterday that Gen. SICKLES has remained in this City while his nomination has been pending in the Senate. The fact is otherwise.
lead_paragraph: It was inadvertently stated in the TIMES yesterday that Gen. SICKLES has remained in this City while his nomination has been pending in the Senate. The fact is otherwise. So eager has been Gen. SICKLES to place himself at the head of his brigade, to share its dangers and its glory, that he has spent every moment in Washington, where he still is, beseeching Senators for permission to serve his country, and urging action upon his appointment. It is certainly a hard case for the regiments raised by his indefatigable exertions, and who are malcontent at his displacement, to reap reluctantly a harvest of fame which he should justly share.

abstract: When operations began on the peninsula, by the retreat of the rebels from Yorktown, Gen. McCLELLAN announced that there should be no delay that he would follow up the enemy, and "push him to the wall." This promise was iterated and emphasized in his official dispatches, as though he felt that there was a certain amount of skepticism touching the army of the Potomac that needed to be overcome.

abstract: day, passed a bill organizing the Territory of Arizona, and providing for it a territorial government. About a month ago, JEFF. DAVIS' Congress Passed a bill for the same purpose. JEFF. DAVIS at present has the advantage, in that he actually holds and possesses the re-...
lead_paragraph: day, passed a bill organizing the Territory of Arizona, and providing for it a territorial government. About a month ago, JEFF. DAVIS' Congress Passed a bill for the same purpose. JEFF. DAVIS at present has the advantage, in that he actually holds and possesses the region of country over which he has extended jurisdiction. But his hold is a slender one. The country, in so far as it is roled at all, is mainly ruled by the Apache savages. The great anxiety of the rebels for the Territory was in vice of its value after they should have conquered a peace, and established their independence. Arizona runs along the northern line of Mexico for a good distance; it runs almost (and should run quite) to the Gulf of California, and it would be just the point from which to operate upon the rich but disorganized States of Northern Mexico. It is probable, however, that just at the present moment JEFF. DAVIS has something else to think about beside [???].

abstract: Our Teutonic contemporary, Dir. P. Mokrat, does not take our well-intended "Hint," as to its treatment of this country and its institutions amiably. We are sorry it is so, but hope to survive the disappointment. As it elects the style of Journalism and adopts even the cant terms of abuse of the Herald, there is no alternative but but to leave it in its chosen companionship, -- merely expressing our compassion for that portion of our German population whose language compels them to patronize such a vehicle of vulgarity and error.

abstract: Representatives appears to be exclusively composed of members from the rural districts, anxious to secure for their constituents every possible rural felicity. When the tax-bill passed that body the other day, great care was taken to strike out and exclude all imposts falling upon the agricultural interest, notwithstanding that interest is the only one which has been directly fostered by the war. But this partiality was not sufficiently marked to suit these one sided legislators. The House has determined that the farmer shall not only escape taxation himself, but shall appropriate to his own use a handsome portion of that raised from others. It passed on Thursday a bill creating another Executive Department of the National Government, to be known as the "Agricultural Department," the business of which shall be to take money from the National Treasury, and spend it upon the non-taxpaying farmer. We do not ask why not a Department of Manufactures, or a Department of Commerce; but, as a sequel to the Homestead bill, giving away the Nationtal domain, and the Agricultural bill, furnishing the new proprietors ideas, annuals, and seeds for cultivating it, we propose that Uncle Sam shall buy up the Southern negroes, and turn them in upon the Great West as apprentices, so that the untaxed agriculturist shall not only have land, and seed, and implements free, but shall be furnished with labor without cost. Can too much be done for this privileged class?

abstract: It was Mr.  THANKS TO GEN. McCLELLAN. It was Mr. LOVEJOY who yesterday moved the vote of thanks to Gen. McCLELLAN in the House of Representatives. The act was doubtless penitential, and certainly eminently becoming. For months the radicals, of whom LOVEJOY is the typical man, have delighted in denouncing the generalship, the fighting qualities, and who is now in pursuit of the flying enemy.
lead_paragraph: -- It was Mr. THANKS TO GEN. McCLELLAN. It was Mr. LOVEJOY who yesterday moved the vote of thanks to Gen. McCLELLAN in the House of Representatives. The act was doubtless penitential, and certainly eminently becoming. For months the radicals, of whom LOVEJOY is the typical man, have delighted in denouncing the generalship, the fighting qualities, and who is now in pursuit of the flying enemy. The events of a week have shown the utter falsity of these criminations. What better could LOVEJOY do -- presupposing grace granted him to do it -- than to make prompt and ample amend to the insulted patriot, even though the recantation convict them of envy, malice, and all uncharitableness?

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the petitions presented was one for a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River. The House bill for the better protection of the revenue was reported from the Committee on Commerce. The resolution presented by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, calling for the reports of the officers commanding in the two battles of Pittsburgh Landing, was taken up, and debated at considerable length. It was finally passed. The Select Committee on the Humphrey's impeachment case reported assurance that they would proceed with the case immediately. The bill for the education of colored children in the District of Columbia was passed, 28 to 7. After an executive session, the Senate adjourned until Monday.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, among the petitions presented was one for a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River. The bill for the education of colored children in the District of Columbia was passed, 28 to 7. After an executive session, the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The Convention held its final meeting yesterday. President FARQUHER presiding, and a full delegation present. Secretary WALSH announced that SAM. SLAWSON, President of the St. Louis Typographical Union, had refused to recognize a card of membership from Nashville, bearing the euphonious title of "Southern Confederacy Union, No. 1." The member of the latter Union had requested advice from the National body in regard to the matter, but this, it was claimed, is fully covered by the resolution of last Thursday, which expresses a desire to cooperate with the Subordinate Unions of the rebellious States, when they shall return to loyalty. The resolution requiring the possessor of a card of membership to present, as an additional qualification for fraternal favor, evidence of having served a regular apprenticeship, was defeated. The President announced the following Executive Committee for the year 1862-63:

snippet: editorial on situation
lead_paragraph: The Franco-Mexican war has commenced. No sooner did the Spaniards disappear from the scene than the French, without retiring to Paso Ancho, as they were bound in honor to do, advanced directly on Orizaba. Before they reached that city, a skirmish took place between a party of their chasseurs and a detachment of Mexican cavalry, led by an officer named AMELIANO, in which the latter were worsted. This was the first encounter of the belligerents, and the opening of the conflict.

abstract: Thursday was a day of excitement at Fortress Monroe. The latest dispatch from there which we had yesterday morning, announced that the Galena, accompanied by two gunboats, had gone up the James River to flank the rebels in their retreat across the Chickahominy toward Richmond, and that simultaneously with this movement the Monitor and the Naugatuck moved over toward Sewall's Point. It now appears that the two latter were accompanied by the Seminole, the Susquehannah, the Dacola' and the San Jacinto -- the whole being under command of Capt. LARDNER, of the San Jacinto. Fire was opened from these vessels upon the Sewall's Point batteries with the best effect; the Monitor running up to within a short distance, and delivering for fire with great precision. The guns on all our vessels were very effectively served, and seem to have been of superior range to those of the rebels, the shots from which nearly all fell short of our wooden ships. The fire of the rebels in reply to our bombardment was quite spirited for a time, but they seem after a while to have become discouraged, gradually slackened their efforts, and quickly ceased altogether. About 2 1/2 o'clock P.M., the Merrimac made her appearance on the scene, near Sewall's Point, but declined to take part in the action, though repeatedly dared to do so by the Monitor and the Naugatuck -- preferring rather to keep her place is a guard over the passage to Norfelk. It was said by the crew of the steamtug. already reported to have come over to Newport's News on Thursday, that the greatest excitement existed in that city, in regard to the appearance of Gen. BURNSIDE in its rear. He was said to be already within a few miles of Weldon, N.C., with a large force, and the rebel troops, in consequence, were evacuating Norfolk with all possible dispatch. Sewall's Point, and Pig Point were speedily abandoned, and preparations were being made to destroy the Navy-yard and all other public property.

abstract: A gradation of benches, extending nearly to the tops of the trees of the mimic forest which formed the background upon the stage, seated the three hundred little representatives of "Cow Bay," and associate localities of the Five Points. They were arranged in no striking uniforms of gauze or gay ribbons, but a costume as variegated as the features of one differed from another. The little girls were provided with snowy aprons, coarse though they were in fabric, while the boys sported their Sunday jackets, and, as a general thing, a shiny white collar, with, however, a noticeable absence of a corresponding cuff at the wrist. A contraband face and curled pate, here and there, of both sexes, lent effect to the pleture. The unassuming standard of the "Five Points" appeared hanging to branches of trees at the back, tanked to the dark foliage on either side by groupings of the Stars and Stripes. The uncomfortable seats of the Academy, (with the exception of these avoided as unavailable behind the massive columns,) were filled from parquette to third tier. The audience entered with hearty enthusiasm into the spirit of the exercises of their humble entertainers, and seemed deeply affected by several eloquent appeals made to them by the speakers of the evening, among whom were Rev. Dr. RICE, Rev. ASA D. SMITH, WM. DODGE, Esq., and Mr. BARLOW, the Superintendent of the House of Industry. The appeal to the pockets was so loudly applauded that the more practical response, as the bats went round, must have met every expectation, although no summing up could take place during the evening. Alter the collection an address was delivered by Rev. J. FALKNER BLAKE, and then followed the most peculiar feature of the performance to the uninitiated audience. It was the pantomimic exercises, which form a part of the daily school routine at the House of Industry. This concerted and speechless action on the part of so many little ones is really remarkable, and elicited repeated outbursts of applause from the highly-amused and interested spectators. After these came the "Bread Song" -- a very peculiar production, in which the children go through the motions of providing bread, from the taking of the grain to mill, to the giving of thanks to God in the eating of it. Each child wore a badge of loyalty, in the shape of a rude bright red, while and blue star, pinned to coat or apron. The lesser lights had to be taken from time to time into the Green-room, where they were revived by marching about and regaling upon peppermint drops, &c, &c. 18,000 persons have received partial or entire support from the institution during the past year. Nearly 3,000 meals have been given; 12,000 articles of clothing have been dispensed to encourage attendance at schools, prayer-meetings, &c., &c., and bounties too numerous to mention, have accrued to the wretched neighborhood where this society is fast transforming a den of debauchery into a respectable though poverty-stricken portion of our great City.
lead_paragraph: A gradation of benches, extending nearly to the tops of the trees of the mimic forest which formed the background upon the stage, seated the three hundred little representatives of "Cow Bay," and associate localities of the Five Points. They were arranged in no striking uniforms of gauze or gay ribbons, but a costume as variegated as the features of one differed from another. The little girls were provided with snowy aprons, coarse though they were in fabric, while the boys sported their Sunday jackets, and, as a general thing, a shiny white collar, with, however, a noticeable absence of a corresponding cuff at the wrist. A contraband face and curled pate, here and there, of both sexes, lent effect to the pleture. The unassuming standard of the "Five Points" appeared hanging to branches of trees at the back, tanked to the dark foliage on either side by groupings of the Stars and Stripes. The uncomfortable seats of the Academy, (with the exception of these avoided as unavailable behind the massive columns,) were filled from parquette to third tier. The audience entered with hearty enthusiasm into the spirit of the exercises of their humble entertainers, and seemed deeply affected by several eloquent appeals made to them by the speakers of the evening, among whom were Rev. Dr. RICE, Rev. ASA D. SMITH, WM. DODGE, Esq., and Mr. BARLOW, the Superintendent of the House of Industry. The appeal to the pockets was so loudly applauded that the more practical response, as the bats went round, must have met every expectation, although no summing up could take place during the evening. Alter the collection an address was delivered by Rev. J. FALKNER BLAKE, and then followed the most peculiar feature of the performance to the uninitiated audience. It was the pantomimic exercises, which form a part of the daily school routine at the House of Industry. This concerted and speechless action on the part of so many little ones is really remarkable, and elicited repeated outbursts of applause from the highly-amused and interested spectators. After these came the "Bread Song" -- a very peculiar production, in which the children go through the motions of providing bread, from the taking of the grain to mill, to the giving of thanks to God in the eating of it. Each child wore a badge of loyalty, in the shape of a rude bright red, while and blue star, pinned to coat or apron. The lesser lights had to be taken from time to time into the Green-room, where they were revived by marching about and regaling upon peppermint drops, &c, &c. 18,000 persons have received partial or entire support from the institution during the past year. Nearly 3,000 meals have been given; 12,000 articles of clothing have been dispensed to encourage attendance at schools, prayer-meetings, &c., &c., and bounties too numerous to mention, have accrued to the wretched neighborhood where this society is fast transforming a den of debauchery into a respectable though poverty-stricken portion of our great City.

abstract: events are moving on such rapidity and splendor in Virginia, things are evidently about ready in the Southwest for the opening of another campaign of equal magnitude and importance. Reports are very contradictory as to the presence of BEAUREGARD's army at Corinth. One day it has gone South, another West, and on the third it is still in its original position. But Gen. HALLECK is preparing for either event. The whole rebel army of the Southwest is in his [???], and his purpose evidently is not to let it escape from him too far. The various movement of the different columns, mentioned during the past few days, indicate clearly his purpose. And these movements are now so well advanced, that decisive action connot belong delayed. Movements in Virginia, if nothing else, must bring military affairs very soon to a headway all over the South. Gen. HALLECK has by far the largest number of troops under his command of any General in the field. When he shall deal the enemy a blow, it will be a blow which will settle the war in the West, and which will probably secure the peace in the Mississippi Valley for a thousand years.

abstract: the Territory of Arizona, known also as the "Gadsden Purchase"  has till now been nominally under the government of New-Mexico; but, as the delegate from the latter Territory said in Congress on Thursday, some parts of it were seven hundred miles distant from the Territorial capital, and of course all its interests were neglected. It is very rich in silver, and quite a number of miners from the Free States were working the mines successfully and profitably when the rebellion broke out. But a small gang of rebels from Texas want there; the military officers commanding the forts turned traitor; and the troops, as the fashion then was, surrendered. A number of loyal men were slaughtered; some were driven from the country; the Indians broke loose on the remainder; and finally the report was, that the mines had all been abandoned, and every white man driven out. The rebels, having thus finished their work, and given Arizona over to chaos, moved northward to repeat the same operation upon New-Mexico, where they have been quite successful until recently they were checked, and are now driven back again into Arizona. The New-Mexican delegate (Mr. WATT) said that there were 6,500 white men now in Arizona; but this means the Mexicans, half-breeds, peons, &c., all of them semi-civilized, if not worse. It is, of course, discreditable to us that any part of the National domain should be given over to barbarism, or that the rebels should be allowed to enjoy a triumph even at the most distant outpost of our country; and this bill, enforced, as it will be, by the National troops in New-Mexico, will extend the blessings of civilization, and permit and stimulate the progress of silver mining, which, a short time ago, was so hopeful. The United States purchased Arizona from Mexico at a cost often millions of dollars; and the rebel Congress but showed its usual audacity in quietly appropriating it, and providing for it a Government.

abstract: President LINCOLN reached Fortress Monroe on Wednesday morning. His presence at once set in motion the squadron of Secretary WELLES, which had so long lain "like painted ships upon a painted ocean." The Galena, Aroostook and Port Royal sailed the very next morning up the James River, to destroy rebel transportation, cut off retreat across that river, and in due time to attack Richmond, should the rebels attempt to hold the Virginian capital. The gunboats on the York River were also urged forward toward West Point, where their timely presence saved the army of Gen. FRANKLIN.
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN reached Fortress Monroe on Wednesday morning. His presence at once set in motion the squadron of Secretary WELLES, which had so long lain "like painted ships upon a painted ocean." The Galena, Aroostook and Port Royal sailed the very next morning up the James River, to destroy rebel transportation, cut off retreat across that river, and in due time to attack Richmond, should the rebels attempt to hold the Virginian capital. The gunboats on the York River were also urged forward toward West Point, where their timely presence saved the army of Gen. FRANKLIN.

abstract: Difficult as it is to catch the rebels, in their frequent flights from the battle-field, it is, per- haps, even more difficult to do so in argument. There is no way of cornering a rebel, even by the stern logic of facts.
lead_paragraph: Difficult as it is to catch the rebels, in their frequent flights from the battle-field, it is, per- haps, even more difficult to do so in argument. There is no way of cornering a rebel, even by the stern logic of facts. Like the celebrated Irish flea, when you put your finger upon him and have him. he isn't there! Drive their armies from stronghold to stronghold, -- from State to State, -- and they are only making victorious "retreats," in comparison to which, that of the 10,000 Greeks sinks to insignificance; -- whip them behind their own intrenchments, at the ratio of two to one against us, and we have only done so by means of "overwhelming numbers" on our side; repulse them on land, at the point of the bayonet, and it was not our soldiers, but gunboats, that gained the victory; -- let our gunboats range themselves before a traitor city and order it to supplant the Confederate rag by our National standard, -- and, straightway we find it was not the gunboats that compelled obedience; -- it was TREACHERY! Perhaps it was "treachery" that has made even Yorktown surrender. Says the Norfolk Day Book:

abstract: A marked change, every one must have observed, has come over the American Press during the last six months, indicative, like most general features of the Press, of a corresponding condition of the public mind.
lead_paragraph: A marked change, every one must have observed, has come over the American Press during the last six months, indicative, like most general features of the Press, of a corresponding condition of the public mind. In former years, and even in the beginning of this war, the columns of our leading journals were crowded with editorials copied from the British Press. An able leader of the London Times on American affairs, a letter from the distinguished "Special," articles from the Daily News or the Post, were scattered, by means of our Metropolitan Press, among millions of readers over the whole country. The London journals could be fairly said to have a nation of readers -- at least when treating of certain topics -- on this side of the Atlantic. Some of these articles were read from admiration of their literary cleverness, some as good specimens of English blundering on foreign topics, and many from a solid respect for the judgment of the nation, whose thoughts and sentiments they were supposed to represent. There was, too, a keen sensitiveness here as to the good opinion of the English people, and a certain want often of solid self-respect, so that we were extremely alive both to their praise and blame. All this had its advantages, as well as its disadvantages. If we showed rather too much youthful sensitiveness to foreign opinion, it was yet a fortunate thing for us that we heard of faults from a cool critic abroad, which we should never have heard from our own admirers at home. Besides, to the many in the Free States, laboring patiently to diminish and restrict a great wrong and abuse, it was a wonderful comfort and support to feel that the old heart of England beat manfully against Slavery, and that, whenever she had the opportunity, she would break over the barriers of national jealousy, and forget the profits of trade, in the noble cause of humanity.

abstract: The Congressional meeting held in the Capitol to-day, to organize an opposition to the ultra-Abolition measures proposed in Congress, was attended by about fifty members. abstract: The reader will perhaps recollect that we borrowed, last week, from the NEW-YORK TIMES, the outline of a very circumstantial charge against Monsieur DE SALIGNY, the Envoy of NAPOLEON III, to Mexico -- the gist of which was that the Envoy himself had an immense personal interest at stake. We watched therefore with no slight curiosity for the response that might be made to this allegation by our excellent neighbor, the Courrier des Etats Unis. And it was alter the lapse of a whole day that the answer appeared, in which, strange to say, the name of Monsieur DE SALIGNY does not once occur. The personal charge, specific and direct as evidence in a witness-box. is slurred over -- the "article" in the TIMES being pronounced in general terms an odious calumny against France and her Government, so at rocious in fact and so ridiculous, that the Courrier cannot sully its pen (query, paged) by reproducing it! Misplaced allusions to the long-sustained and intimate alliance between France and the United States follow. The TIMES is reminded of a period not very remote, when its columns were foremost among those of American journals in "doing justice" to everything French -- and it must be owned that the TIMES used to push its complaisance in this direction so far as to create an impression that it was inspired direct from the Tuilleries or by the French Legation at Washington. The whole concludes with a declaration that, wherever the French flag flies, it will be in a just cause, et coetera, as usual in such cases.

abstract: The hospitals here, to-day, present a sad sight, and one that brings home to the heart a painful realization of the horrors of war. By this hour most of the wounded brought up by the Commodore have found comfortable quarters at the Adams Hotel Hospital, and at the National Hospital, and many private houses in the vicinity, fitted up by the Government, are also occupied.

abstract: A PROBABLE SUICIDE. About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a man named WM. HOWES, of Boston, was found with his throat cut, in the rear of a lager-bier saloon, near the Coroner's office, in Centre-street.
lead_paragraph: A PROBABLE SUICIDE. -- About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a man named WM. HOWES, of Boston, was found with his throat cut, in the rear of a lager-bier saloon, near the Coroner's office, in Centre-street. The blood was flowing very freely from the wound at the time he was discovered, and the victim was wholly insensible through lose of blood. Officer LANNIGAN, who happened to be in the vicinity, was immediately summoned, and guarded the house and premises until the arrival of Coroner COLLIN and his Deputy, Dr. ROBINSON. An examination of the wound was made by the latter gentlemen, who pronounced the man to be in a dying condition. Large quantities of blood were found in different parts of the yard, but, after a diligent search, the instrument with which the injury was inflicted could not be found. He was removed to the New-York Hospital, where at a late hour last night he was lying in a state of insensibility, and it was believed that he could not survive till this morning. From all the evidence given thus far there can be no doubt that it is a case of suicide. But little is known about HOWES except the facts that he was a Boston school-teacher; that he had but little money about him, and that for several days past he had been quite low-spirited.

abstract: -- Gen. FREMONT is making a most excellent disposition of the forces under his command; and recent movements of his several divisions indicate speedy and important work in various sections of the Mountain Department. FREMONT has under him a number of the very best commanders in the field -- such men as the fighting MILROY; the discreet ROSECRANS; KELLY, the hero of Romney; the dashing Cox; the gallant BLENKER; CARTER, the indomitable East Tennesseean; and SCHENCK, every inch a hero Gen. KELLY has been serving along the line of the Grafton and Parkersburgh Railroad, in the Northern part of the State, repressing LETCHER's guerrillas, &c.; and a dispatch, this morning, announces that a detachment of his command has just defeated a rebel force of four hundred men at the town of Spencer. Gens. MILROY and Cox have been for some time on the east side of the Shenandoah Mountains, in Augusta County, driving the rebels from the mountain gaps, and advancing as rapidly as possible toward the railroad at Stanton. His position has been one of extraordinary hardship, the snow being still deep and the weather cold in the mountains, and he having almost daily encounters with detachments of Stone-wall JACKSON's rebels. A brisk affair with the enemy in this quarter also is reported this morning, in which four regiments were engaged, and in which SCHENCK, in one day, made a forced march of thirty-four miles, through mud and over mountains, to join MILROY. These two Generals were waiting for heavy reinforcements, which have probably reached them by this time; and it may easily be judged, from their present position, what is the point and which is the rebel force that is to be assaulted. The splendid German division of Gen. BLENKER is in FREMONT's command, and will doubtless soon be heard from. Gen. Cox has just made an exceedingly important movement up the New River, in the Western part of the State, or in the Kanawha Department, as it is termed. He has driven the rebels out of Greenbrier, Mercer and Giles Counties; and a dispatch from Gen. FREMONT, dated the 8th instant, announces that his advance had ascended the New River Valley as far as Giles Court-house, (now called Parisburgh,) in Giles County, which is only about twenty miles by turnpike from the line of the great East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad. It may not be Gen. Cox's purpose to cut this important rebel highway; but as the question of the necessity of cutting it has been discussed for over a year past, and as Cox's column is now nearer to it than any National force has yet been, it would certainly be a capital thing to do. By seizing this railroad a way would be opened up for our troops to penetrate into East Tennessee, and relieve the martyred Unionists of that section. In East Tennessee itself, (which as far as Knoxville is in Gen. FREMONT's Department,) there is a brigade of troops -- loyal East Tennesseeans -- under Gen. CARTER, who are not far from the line of the East Tennessee Railroad, near Knoxville, and who will undoubtedly be prepared to cooperate with Gen. Cox should be move westward in that direction. Taken altogether, the different columns under the command of FREMONT are moving with a rapidity and to a purpose which indicates a speedy relief to that part of Tennessee still under the rebel yoke, and which, perhaps, indicates also movements in the rear of Richmond, whose importance will be discovered ere long.

abstract: Deserters from the enemy report that the recent Union victories have caused the greatest depression of feeling among the rebel officers, who look upon their cause as hopeless. Their soldiers are very ragged, and without the means of getting new clothing. Hundreds would desert if it was generally known they would be kindly received by our officers. The enemy's ranks are daily becoming thinned by desertions.
lead_paragraph: NEW-MARKET, Va., Saturday, May 10.

abstract: Editorial on NYC accommodations for sick and wounded soldiers
snippet: Editorial on NYC accommodations for sick and wounded soldiers
lead_paragraph: Large numbersof disabled soldiers are now arriving inthis City from the Peninsula, from North Carolina, and from other places on the Southern seaboard where there have been battles and sieges. We are happy to state that ample quarters and every possible convenience and comfort have been provided for them. The supervision of affairs is in the hands of Gen. HARVEY BROWN, late commander at Fort Pickens, and now commander of the forts in this harbor. These have been special hospitals provided for the New-England troops, while the soldiers from this and other States are accommodated temporarily, or till convalescence, in the Broadway Hospital, in Bellevue, in Park Barracks, at the Ladies' Hospital, and elsewhere. Some of the men are permitted to go to private houses, and hundreds of homes are offered for every sick or wounded soldier who might need one. Dwellings and apartments, owned or occupied by people in all ranks of life, have been thrown open; thousands of ladies have volunteered their services as nurses; profuse quantities of delicacies and comforts are proffered; and the most skillful physicians and surgeons are anxious to furnish their services gratuitously. Some time ago, before any provision had been made, a boat load of sick and wounded heroes arrived here from Newbern; and we called attention to their case, and to the imperfect hospital accommodations then furnished, and made an appeal to the public, and particularly to the ladies, in their behalf. The immediate response to that appeal was extraordinary, though not unexpected; and the work of preparation and beneficence did not end then, but went on, till how beneficence can go no further. Although the Government dues all, perhaps, that is really necessary, there are still some things which official authorities are apt to overlook or neglect, while there are kindnesses that only loving hearts and delicate hands can administer. There will be no lack of these while the war lasts; for New-York City, which has sent fifty thousand of its sons to do battle for the Union and the Star Spangled Banner, has a hundred thousand daughters equally willing to give their lives and their all for the same holy cause. There will be a large number of these wounded heroes arriving now every day. On Friday they came from Newbern; yesterday came some of the wounded at the gallant fight at Williamsburgh, and to-day or to-morrow we may receive the disabled at West Point. The men who marched so erect and proud through our City a year ago, amid the plaudits and shouts of the citizens and the waving of white cambric by fair hands, now come back after having received the baptism of blood, and with the honorable and glorious scars of battle upon their persons. The same fair hands now minister to their wants and sooth their sufferings, and the manly shout gives place to the manly tear of sympathy and act of charity. It is not given to all to die or to bleed for their country; but all may take part in the equally noble work of suffering with those who suffer. There will be much to be done this Summer, and New-York will show how grandly she can do it.

abstract: It has been often said that the contempt which has been felt at the South for the peo-  ple of the Northern States, has been one cause of the present rebellion.
lead_paragraph: It has been often said that the contempt which has been felt at the South for the peo- ple of the Northern States, has been one cause of the present rebellion. This contempt had its foundation no doubt, in the views of Labor which prevailed in that region. Having once become general, there naturally sprung from it events whose tendency would be to increase that very contempt and hatred which had given them birth. Among these were prominent the very many instances of ill-usage or Northerners throughout the South, unredressed and unrebuked: the tarrings and featherings, and whippings and bullyings in general, which have so many times stirred the blood of those of us at the North who were not too deeply implicated in Southern trade or too dependent upon Southern politicians. But the effect of them has not been felt solely at the South, especially since the war began. There is many a man in the National army who bears burdens more readily, whose heart is made more bold, his blows more vigorous, his rifle more deadly by the remembrance of some such transaction, in which he was an unwilling participant. We are inclined to think that Gen. MITCHEL's march on Huntsville was not retarded at all by the memories of that railroad ride of his in Missippi a little more than a year ago, when, as our readers must recollect, he barely escaped being lynched as a Northern Abolitionist.

abstract: THE FIGHT IN HAMPTON ROADS. The fantas  tic tricks performed by the Censorship can find no happier illustration than in the dispatch of Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, printed in another column. For several weeks the fact that Government had turned into the waters of Hampton Roads a flock of steam-rams, destined to run down and destroy the Merrimac, has been known to half the loyal people at the North, and probably to every rebel at the South.
lead_paragraph: -- The fantastic tricks performed by the Censorship can find no happier illustration than in the dispatch of Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, printed in another column. For several weeks the fact that Government had turned into the waters of Hampton Roads a flock of steam-rams, destined to run down and destroy the Merrimac, has been known to half the loyal people at the North, and probably to every rebel at the South. Newspapers have been obliged, under the penalty of suppression, to withhold the most obscure reference to these vessels. And here suddenly we receive from the Government itself a formal publication of the existence of the flotilla, and the purpose of its creation, with a revelation of the blundering scheme which failed to decoy the Merrimac within reach of its fangs. And this dispatch is elicited by direct request of the Secretary of War, who is, of course, answerable for its publication.

abstract: FIRES. At about 12  o'clock yesterday morning, the paint manufactory of Messrs. HENRY WALDEN  Co., Nos. 189, 191, 193 and 195 Water-street, together with most of the contents, was destroyed by fire, involving a loss of $50,000, upon which there...
lead_paragraph: FIRES. -- At about 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, the paint manufactory of Messrs. HENRY WALDEN & CO., Nos. 189, 191, 193 and 195 Water-street, together with most of the contents, was destroyed by fire, involving a loss of $50,000, upon which there was an insurance amounting to $35,000 in the Lamar, Howard, Long Island, Mechanics, Standard and other insurance companies. The fire originated from accidental causes in the engine room, at the rear of the main building. The firemen were promptly on the spot, but owing to the inflammable character of a portion of the materials on the premises the fire spread so rapidly as to preclude the possibility of their accomplishing more than they did -- confining the fire to the establishment where it originated. At about the same hour, two frame buildings on Oakland-street, near Kent-street, seventeenth Ward, were destroyed, one owned and occupied by JAMES SMITH, whose loss a $500, and the other owned by H.R. SMITH, and occupied by a pedler named BLOOD, involving a loss of $500 more. Both buildings were insured in the Kinse County Insurance Company for nearly enough to cover the loss.

abstract: The prize-schooner Flash arrived here yesterday, she was captured off Price's Inlet, about fourteen miles to the northward of Charleston, while attempting to run the blockade, by the United States bark Restless, Lieut. CONROY, Commander. She stood in toward the land about 11 A.M., when the bark had covered her, and fired a Parrot shell through her mainsail. At daylight she was about three miles off, and when her crew found it was useless to try and escape, they ran her ashore, set fire to her, and abandoned her. The boats of the bark were immediately sent to her, got her afloat, and put out the fire. She was under English colors, and had cleared from Nassau for New-York. Her cargo consists of salt, kerosene oil, paper and box soap.

lead_paragraph: It was predicted and expected by the Southern Press, and Southern clergymen, even, that New-York would be deluged with vice, crime, and bloodshed, when the war for the Union should once begin. Our European friends have gone so far as to describe our condition to be that of lawless anarchy. The more timid among ourselves can hardly make themselves believe that we have not been on the verge of a "reign of terror." If we can trust our eyes and the ordinary inlets of evidence, we are constrained to say: "We don't see it."

abstract: A battle has been fought with the enemy's rear guard just outside of Williamsburgh, where light earthworks had been erected, beside other intrenchments. The Commanding General sets down the loss on either side to be about two thousand killed, wounded and missing one-third killed outright.
lead_paragraph: A battle has been fought with the enemy's rear guard just outside of Williamsburgh, where light earthworks had been erected, beside other intrenchments. The Commanding General sets down the loss on either side to be about two thousand killed, wounded and missing -- one-third killed outright. Yesterday and day before, we have been busily engaged in burying the dead and hunting up the wounded. Gen. HOOKER'S Division has suffered the must -- having held certain ground for five hours in front of a heavy [???] -- when Gen. PECK's Brigade came to his support, and Gen. HANCOCK charged the enemy, puttinghim to flight Bayonet wounds are plenty -- the rebels having stood firm until a charge was made, when they fled in the utmost confusion. Our cavalry and horse artillery are still in pursuit, but the roads are terrible, which impedes their progress much.
