abstract: It is refreshing, sometimes, to look over the records of old times and to uncover some of the hidden testimonies left by our predecessors to the cause of truth and freedom. The sentiments of the prominent men of Virginia, thirty years ago, in behalf of emancipation, are well known and frequently appealed to in our discussions.
lead_paragraph: It is refreshing, sometimes, to look over the records of old times and to uncover some of the hidden testimonies left by our predecessors to the cause of truth and freedom. The sentiments of the prominent men of Virginia, thirty years ago, in behalf of emancipation, are well known and frequently appealed to in our discussions. But we are favored with such a testimony from Tennessee, forty-five years ago, in the shape of an address by the Manumission Society of that State, in behalf of freedom, published in 1817, after two public deliveries of the same before the Society. We find it in "The Iron Platform," a series of political tracts for the people, published by WM. OLAND BOURNE, of this City. This address, for its length, is one of the most interesting, comprehensive and thorough discussions of the system of Slavery we have ever seen, and its powerful appeals for freedom gain new force, in view of the present condition of our political questions and the aspect of the emancipation proposal of President LINCOLN. Mr. BOURNE has presented the address in the handsomest and cheapest form for universal circulation, and the friends of the cause can hardly do a better thing than to place it in the hands of every voter in the Union as soon as possible. The low price of $1 a hundred, or $10 per thousand, should insure it a wide and speedy sale.

abstract: The Fifty-first Regiment New-York Volunteers have recently been presented with a splendid flag, from friends in New-York, as a graceful recognition of their brilliant services. This magnificent banner bears, on a dark blue field, the blended arms of the United States and New-York, and is throughout, in its design and workmanship, of the most rich and tasteful character. This splendid gift is worthy of its donors and of the noble regiment who are its recipients. Flags are soldiers' landmarks; they hold them sacred as their honor, around them their memories cluster, on them their histories are graven. Though this flag bears no memory of the scenes of wild danger and daring, of suffering and death on the bloodstained battle-fields of Roanoke and Newbern, it will yet be cherished with the same jealous care that shields that smoke-blackened one that was borne so bravely on those memorable fields; it will be guarded thus, because it is one other landmark placed by the pious love of friends at home on the glorious path that leads to the rescue of our country and the establishment of right.

abstract: Editorial hails good public credit situation at present time; Editorial lauds beneficial condition of public credit
snippet: Editorial hails good public credit situation at present time; Editorial lauds beneficial condition of public credit
lead_paragraph: The Public Credit has advanced rapidly on the Stock Exchange within the past fortnight. On Saturday week the sales of the Public Funds of 1881 at par at the Board of Brokers, was deemed an event so auspicious and gratifying as to induce an exchange of congratulations between the President of the Board and the Hon. Secretary of the Treasury. These Funds, in the darker days of the rebellion in the Summer of 1861, were awarded from the Treasury as low as 85 percent., and fell at one time on the Stock Exchange to 80 per cent., the accumulated interest being thrown out of the account. Another award was subsequently made to the Associated Banks of the three Atlantic Cities at 89.32 per cent, to the extent of fifty million of dollars, and so fearful were some of the Banks that this operation might prove a losing one that they accepted the first offers of the public, through the Stock Exchange, to relieve themselves at cost and interest. It was not until late in April that the market advanced materially above 92 or 93 per cent., and under all these circumstances the unexpected pleasure expressed at the first sales in May at the par value of the Stock is not to be wondered at. This pleasure is now increased by the circumstance that on Saturday last the same Stock sold at 100 per cent.

abstract: The rebel navy is being extinguished with amazing rapidity. A whole fleet, or flock, of iron rams, including the ram Manassas, was destroyed below New-Orleans. The great father of rams, the ram Merrimac, has just sank to rise no more. And in addition to these, we have also news from Fort Pillow, above Memphis, that Capt. Davis has blown up two rebel iron-clad gunboats -- rams, it would seem -- and sunk another, probably also a ram. This was on Saturday morning last, the morning before the world-famous Norfolk ram perished. What will the rebels now do, without rams? They have, we believe, the skeleton of one at Mobile, and the rebel women of Charleston are trying hard to raise means to create another there. But Commodore FARRAGUT has already announced that his next work after New-Orleans is to be the capture of Mobile; and Gen. HUNTER'S reconnoissances in Bull's Bay look as if Charleston was not likely to remain in rebel control much longer. When these places fall into our hands we will of course capture whatever rams, etc., may be in their harbors, and then the so-called Confederate States will be absolutely ramless.

abstract: At a late hour, last evening, the body of Mrs. SARAH LAVIN was found upon the floor of a room in her residence, at No. 176 East Twenty-fourth-street There were marks of violence upon her person and some wounds upon her head -- apparently made by some blunt instrument -- which it is believed were the immediate cause of her death. No one was present at the time of her death except her husband. The Police were called in immediately after the discovery of the body, and from all the facts and circumstances connected with the case, they conclude that it was their duty to arrest the husband upon the charge of murder. The only explanation which he saw fit to give concerning the death of his wife was that she fell on the floor in a fit, and in that way she bruised her head so as to render her insensible. Whilst she was in that state he says he did all in his power to bring her to, but without success. The prisoner, whose name is BARTLETT LAVIN, was conveyed to the the station-house, and locked up for the night. The Coroner was notified, and will investigate the case this afternoon at the late residence of the deceased.
lead_paragraph: At a late hour, last evening, the body of Mrs. SARAH LAVIN was found upon the floor of a room in her residence, at No. 176 East Twenty-fourth-street There were marks of violence upon her person and some wounds upon her head -- apparently made by some blunt instrument -- which it is believed were the immediate cause of her death. abstract: Norfolk, by last census, had a population of 14,609, about 3,300 of whom were slaves. But on account of the fearful state of perturbation in which the city has been kept for the last year, and also on account of the rebel conscription, it is now probably reduced to a half of that number. It is situated on the right bank of the Elizabeth River, just below the confluence of the two branches, 8 miles from Hampton Roads, 32 miles from the Ocean, and 100 by land and 160 by water southeast from Richmond. The situation is low; the streets are irregular and mostly wide, with good brick and stone buildings.

abstract: The news this morning is of the most glorious and exciting character. Within the last fortyeight hours great blows have been struck against the rebellion, which make it reel and totter to its very foundation.
lead_paragraph: The news this morning is of the most glorious and exciting character. Within the last fortyeight hours great blows have been struck against the rebellion, which make it reel and totter to its very foundation. Norfolk, Portsmouth and the Gosport Navy-yard have been captured, without bloodshed; the Merrimac -- the "Terror of the Roads," as the rebels were pleased to style her -- has been destroyed, and the triumphant march of MCCLELLAN's army has been continued almost to the threshold of the rebel Capital, while on the Mississippi, another is added to our numerous victories.

abstract: The Operatic and Concert-loving portion of our fashionable world is about at length to commence its annual repose, having terminated a musical season, which may fairly be considered one of the most singular we have for many years had in this City. Half a dozen of weeks of opera, scattered over the past six months, have been grudgingly given to the habitu s of the Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The Operatic and Concert-loving portion of our fashionable world is about at length to commence its annual repose, having terminated a musical season, which may fairly be considered one of the most singular we have for many years had in this City. Half a dozen of weeks of opera, scattered over the past six months, have been grudgingly given to the habitu s of the Academy of Music. GOTTSCHALK has vouchsafed his presence to us at the Academy, Irving Hall and Niblo's Saloon, In the same fitful and spasmodic manner; and we believe that Mr. GRAU, the manager in either instance, has no intention to return to us, musically, until the next Winter Season. There is, however, a prospect of Miss BROUGHTON, (who was to have appeared in Italian opera a few weeks since, and was prevented from doing so by serious illness, from which she has, we understand, now perfectly recovered,) making her appearance, for a short season of one week, at the Academy. This lady is an American, and is said to be a charming vocalist. If so, she will add another name to the list of our native prime donne, who count up favorably in the number of operatic reputations, at the present moment This appearance will, we presume, close opera for the years 1861-'62. The last concert of the season, of any mark, will be that announced by THEODORE THOMAS for to-morrow evening. We have already called attention to the amount of novelty which he offers the public. Frequently as we have in the last ten years had new "stars" culminating on our musical heaven, we have never before had so much musical novelty presented to us. MEYERBEER's Struensee alone ought to be a sufficient attraction, and combined as it is, with such plentiful instrumental music equally new to our musical world, under the capable conductorship of the young musician, must insure a crowded audience of the more critical as well as the more fashionable portion of our public.

abstract: The speed with which events are proceeding is steadily accelerated. The gap between great advantages and splendid victories is constantly less, while no reverse intervenes to retard the movement which, in so many days not months or years is to bring the rebellion to an end.
lead_paragraph: The speed with which events are proceeding is steadily accelerated. The gap between great advantages and splendid victories is constantly less, while no reverse intervenes to retard the movement which, in so many days -- not months or years -- is to bring the rebellion to an end. Norfolk is ours; "Onward to Richmond" will be an obsolete phrase before the week shall have closed. BURNSIDE has, by this time, placed himself in possession of the great line of Southern railroad through Weldon; COX, pushing forward from the Kanawha Valley, in Western Virginia, can hardly fail to have reached and cut off the Southwesterly outlet over the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad. Thus not only have the Union arms recovered all there is worth possessing on the Atlantic Coast, but it has in all probability so surrounded the main body of the rebel military force that it will never be able to make its way Southward. It need be no matter of surprise, if after Richmond shall have passed into the hands of Gen. MCCLELLAN, the rebel army should seek the alternative of surrender or dispersion. As a compact and organized body, it is hardly possible it can ever reach the Gulf States.

abstract: editorial on encounter of men from South Carolina and New England at battle
snippet: editorial on encounter of men from South Carolina and New England at battle
lead_paragraph: -- The red-mouthed South Carolina rebels have at last had what they have been so eager for these many years -- an encounter at arms with the men of Massachusetts and of Down-East generally; but it has not left the Palmetto braggarts in any such blaze of glory as they had always foretold for such an occasion. At the battle of Williamsburgh, on the peninsula, last Monday, there were no less than eight regiments of South Carolina troops engaged -- the Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, Eighth and Ninth -- some of which are the "crack" regiments of the "Gamecock" State. They were backed up, too, by eight regiments from Alabama, five from Virginia, and others from Mississippi, Louisiana and Florida, the whole force numbering twenty-six regiments; while among the commanders were some of the greatest Palmetto Generals. On the National side there were about as many soldiers from Massachusetts as South Carolina furnished to the rebel side, while there were other regiments from New-Hampshire, from Rhode Island, and from away down in Maine, not to speak of the gallant fellows from Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, Michigan and this State -- the whole of them, however, not forming a force equal in numbers to the rebels engaged with them. Did the South Carolina fire-eaters whip the Yankees ten to one? Did they fight till the last man of them was hacked to pieces? Did they stand their ground till the last rebel was engulphed in the ultimate ditch? Oh I tell it not in Gath nor in the streets of Charleston! whisper it not in the ear of Gen. QUATTLEBAUM, nor let RHETT proclaim it through his Mercury, nor GILMORE SIMMS in his romances! -- when the Yankees gave them cold steel, they skedaddled! And in their flight -- according to the interesting account of the battle we published yesterday -- the rebels threw away their blankets, their knapsacks, and their muskets; and even left the wounded behind to take care of themselves, or be taken care of by our surgeons. All along the wayside, for a long distance, were strewn the evidences of their haste and terror. Where they may have finally hauled up at, it is impossible to tell; but having had a taste of Yankee steel, it need not be wondered at if they do not stop until they get back again to South Carolina. Even there, however, they will find twenty thousand Yankees occupying the richest part of their State, anxious to meet them at any reasonable odds. The South Carolinian has long been wild with anxiety to meet and fight the Yankees. Nowhere now can he go without meeting and fighting them. They are in both the Carolinas, and in all the States of the Gulf. They are present everywhere, and there is no place where they are not. Unless, perhaps, it be in Fort Sumter; and 1862 will not be much older before that too is garrisoned by Yankees.

abstract: The commodious and delightfully-located dwell- ing and grounds at the foot of Sixty-fifth-street, to which the aged, and infirm, and poverty-stricken of our colored population look as a haven of rest and protection from the rude reminders which would constantly offend them in the outer world, contains at present 340 invalids.
lead_paragraph: The commodious and delightfully-located dwell- ing and grounds at the foot of Sixty-fifth-street, to which the aged, and infirm, and poverty-stricken of our colored population look as a haven of rest and protection from the rude reminders which would constantly offend them in the outer world, contains at present 340 invalids. As one approaches the inclosed domain, characteristic groups, or strollers thoughtfully and alone, are seen dotting the mounds and pretty slopes just now clothed in the first fresh green of Spring. Tottering dames in queer old-fashioned Methodist bonnets; remnants of what once was athletic manhood, now bent nearly double, making slow headway with smoothly-worn canes. Some again, younger in years, but laboring under one or another of the infirmities of our nature, are sunning themselves against the wall, or sleeping gently where the genial rays fall brightest. The aged gatekeeper takes his hat clear off as you pass his guarded threshold, and though the visitor never laid eyes upon his dusky visage before, he greets one pleasantly with, "How you been dis long time, honey?"

abstract: Portsmouth, directly opposite Norfolk, is a place of 9,500 inhabitants. It is built on level ground, has various institutions of learning, a military academy, five newspapers, and six churches. By the seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, and James River, it has extensive communications North and South, It, of course, falls with the fall of Norfolk. The Navy-yard is more properly said to be here than at Norfolk. It is half a mile from the central part of the town, or that part of it called Gosport.

abstract: The news which yesterday electrified the nation was second only in importance to that of the capture of New-Orleans. The capture of Norfolk was the event of all others most eagerly desired by the loyal population of the country.
lead_paragraph: The news which yesterday electrified the nation was second only in importance to that of the capture of New-Orleans. The capture of Norfolk was the event of all others most eagerly desired by the loyal population of the country. The splendor of the harbor, the inestimable value the rebels set upon it as the future Atlantic seaport of the Confederation, the worth of the National property concentrated there -- these were matters about which nobody cares a rush. If is only because the place was so ignominiously stolen from the Government; because the treachery engaged in its sequestration are of so much deeper tint than any other of that disgraceful period; and because it had spawned and harbored that terror of the American marine, the Merrimac, that the popular joy broke forth yesterday in expressions of unaccustomed satisfaction. It was an especially good thing that the President was there, "among the first to land;" it was also fortunate that the place was redeemed without the cost of life; but to have Norfolk, whatever the circumstances, and whatever the cost, is one of the most brilliant events of the war.

abstract: The truth is that the comments of a bystander on a contest still raging can never be [???] to the parties engaged in it. He [???] of inclining to one side or other, and it he be overheard to predict the result he will not escape the imputation of wishing to promote it. This is just the position in which we have been placed. We could not abstain from expressing opinions on events passing in America, and our estimate of the chances of the game happened to differ from that formed by one of the players. Time alone can show how far we were right. We were never among those who exulted over the alleged "breakdown of democratic institutions." We saw from the first that it was not so much Democracy as the principle of Federalism, under very peculiar conditions, that was on its trial. The strain produced by the antagonism of interests between North and South might undoubtedly have pro red fatal to a despotism or a constitutional monarchy, though it might possibly have been easier to bring back rebellious subjects to their allegiance than to break the spirit of free citizens accustomed to assume the name and exercise the chief attributes of sovereignty. If we fell into any mistake, it was in somewhat underra ing the determination and number of the Secessionists. So long as South Carolina was the only State in open revolt, we were unwilling to give up the belief that the Unionists, said to form a strong in the other Slave States, might bring about a compromise. That hope was disappointed, and from the moment that the Confederate standard was hoisted in every Southern capital, and "Independence" became the war-ery of the movement, we felt assured that any reunion worthy of the name was impossible. We think so still, and we are not shaken in that opinion by the recent Federal successes. They show that, by means of gunboats, troops can be conveyed into the heart of a country intersected with great rivers, that they can be supported by these gunboats in the assault of forts, and supplied with provisions in a way unexampled in European campaigns. Beyond this they prove nothing that we did not know before. No one supposed before the battle of Bull Run that the Confederates would be a match for the Federals in the open field; indeed, it was never expected that they would begin a defensive war by threatening the enemy's capital. Whether their late reverses will lend to a concentration of their forces, and whether their resources will hold out against the loans and taxation of the North, remains to be seen; but the real question is net to be settled by such calculations of chances as these. "The question is this, and this alone -- whether the heart of the county is set on separation?" Granted that the Confederate armies are ever so thoroughly beaten, will that make the planters more loyal members of the Union, and, if not, will the statesmen, whose work will begin where that of the Generals ends, seriously undertake to govern them as Austria governs Hungary, or Russia Poland? If we could think so, we should despair of peace on the American continent for many a year to come.

abstract: ting horses, which never yet competed with each other, will contend, on the Fashion Course to-day, for a purse, at mile heats, three in five. They are Gray Eddy, Native American and Sunnyside. The first two are well known here, and highly valued. As much as $5,000 was paid for each of them. The other is a black mare from Boston, which is valued at a still larger sum, and of whom fame trumpets loudly in advance. This is her first appearance on Long Island, and there is great curiosity to see her perform with the black and gray geldings. She is engaged with the latter and Widow Machree in several other purses and stakes, and hence the race to-day will be a sort of trial trot.

abstract: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in a Proclamation dated at Richmond on the 3d instant, commands that on Friday next prayer shall be offered up in all Richmond churches, that the Almighty will "strengthen and protect the hosts going forth to battle," and " restore...
lead_paragraph: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in a Proclamation dated at Richmond on the 3d instant, commands that on Friday next prayer shall be offered up in all Richmond churches, that the Almighty will "strengthen and protect the hosts going forth to battle," and " restore to the Confederacy the blessings of peace and security." JEFF. has frequently tried the "confidence game" with Providence without any visible success: but there is every likelihood that the proposed prayers will be answered in advance -- though not exactly in the way the pious man intended. The appointed day, if not an earlier one, will undoubtedly see the Union army in Richmond, carrying with it the "blessings of peace and security" to a distracted population, joy inexpressible to the loyal men now pining in rebel prisons, and wrath and vengeance to the guilty heads of the traitor crew that have too long been permitted to hold sway in that capital.

abstract: rebels, with that utter disregard of science that characterizes them, baulked, by the destruction of the Merrimac, a number of experiments in which the whole world is profoundly interested. We can, therefore, only fall back on the famous light in Hampton Roads, and, regarding this, there is an interesting point brought out in the TIMES editorial correspondence from Norfolk. It appears from the testimony of the Sailing Master of the Merrimac that no shots from the Monitor had penetrated her iron-sheathed sides, or injured her in any way, except by starting her timbers, and that the only shot which entered her was one from the Cumberland, which, striking her port-hole, split the gun and killed two men and wounded seventeen others. As the contest lasted over three hours, during which the Monitor rained several hundred shot on the mailed sides of the Merrimac, it may be taken as conclusive evidence that she carried no projectile of sufficient impact to penetrate the iron-plating. Since then, however, steel-pointed, square-headed projectiles have been made, which by experiment go through wrought-iron plates twice the thickness of the sheathing of the Merrimac. A supply of these was, we understand, sent to the Monitor, and they would have been tried on the rebel monster, had she given an opportunity to renew the contest. But this, and several other most important mechanical experiments, have been forever baulked, and are, with the Merrimac, "in the deep bosom of the ocean buried."

abstract: William H. Crommelin vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. -- This was an action of replevin to recover thirty pieces of South Dover marble, alleged to have been wrongfully detained by the defendants. The defence set up was a denial, and that the Company had a right to retain the marble until the plaintiff had paid them $1 per car for each day in which the marble had been stored in the car since its arrival in New-York. The amount claimed was $420, the value of the marble, and $250 damages for the detention. The defendants claimed that the detention was only to enforce payment at the rates charged for storage, for the time the plaintiff allowed the marble to remain in the cars, and in the custody of the Company, before taking it away.
lead_paragraph: William H. Crommelin vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. -- This was an action of replevin to recover thirty pieces of South Dover marble, alleged to have been wrongfully detained by the defendants. The defence set up was a denial, and that the Company had a right to retain the marble until the plaintiff had paid them $1 per car for each day in which the marble had been stored in the car since its arrival in New-York. The amount claimed was $420, the value of the marble, and $250 damages for the detention. The defendants claimed that the detention was only to enforce payment at the rates charged for storage, for the time the plaintiff allowed the marble to remain in the cars, and in the custody of the Company, before taking it away.

abstract: We give herewith a diagram, showing the iminute topography of the famous rebel Capital, upon which Gen. McCLELLAN, is now advancing with such rapid strikes.
lead_paragraph: We give herewith a diagram, showing the iminute topography of the famous rebel Capital, upon which Gen. McCLELLAN, is now advancing with such rapid strikes. The city, by last census, had a population of thirty-eight thousand souls; but the great influx of civil and military official and refugees from other parts of the State, has probably raised it, of late, to a much higher figure. It is situated at the head of tide-water, at the lower falls of James River, about one hundred and fifty miles from its mouth. The city occupies a most picturesque situation, being built on Richmond and Shockoe hills, which are separated by Shockoe Creek and surrounded by beautiful scenery. It is regularly laid out and well built, the streets, which are lighted with gas, crossing each other at right angles. On Shockoe Hill are the State Capitol and other public buildings. The Capitol is an imposing edifice, and contains in its central hall HONDON's celebrated statue of WASHINGTON. On the east of the square is the Governor's mansion, now occupied by the drunkard and traitor LETCHER, JEFF. DAVIS resides in a private mansion, which was purchased for him by the rebel Government. The city has many fine public buildings, six banks, thirteen newspapers and twenty-three churches. In one of the three Presbyterian churches JEFF. DAVIS worships.

abstract: Early yesterday morning the most extravagant rumors were in circulation with regard to an engagement which was represented to have taken place near Barhamsville, in New-Kent County, on Wednesday. One report stated that our arms had been crowned with a most signal and glorious success, and as a consequence of their impertinence and temerity, six thousand of the enemy had fallen into the hands of our victorious forces, together with an almost incalculable number of cannon and small arms. These rumors were so general and extensive that they obtained almost universal credence, and great was the gratification manifested on all sides at the supposed victory. About midday, however, these flattering reports received an official contradiction, and the following paragraph was found posted upon the bulletin boards of the different journals of the City:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after some business of no particular importance, the bill providing for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts, was taken up, debated at considerable length, and finally passed with only three dissenting votes, after being amended so as to provide for an additions tax to cover all the expenses of the collection and she salaries of officers appointed under the bill.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, after some business of no particular importance, the bill providing for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts, was taken up, debated at considerable length, and finally passed with only three dissenting votes, after being amended so as to provide for an additions tax to cover all the expenses of the collection and she salaries of officers appointed under the bill. The resolution from the House in regard to the adjournment of Congress, was taken up, and Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, moved to strike out the 19th of May, and insert the 2d of June. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, was opposed to filing any day for the adjournment, as was also Mr. [???], of Maine. Mr. DAVIS was in favor of an early adjournment, as there was danger of too much legislation. Already measures had passed which were unconstitutional and iniquitous, which would be resisted by the whole white population of Kentucky, and which he would counsel his people to resist by every made of resistance they could devise. Mr. WILSON immediately called Mr. DAVIS to order for uttering treasonable sentiments, and sent the substance of the words uttered to the clerk's desk to be read. Mr. DAVIS denied having uttered such words, and modified his language materially. Mr. WILSON did not care to press the matter under the circumstances, and it was dropped. The adjournment resolution was laid on the table. After some further business the Senate went into Executive Session -- during which the nomination of Gen. SICKLES was confirmed be one majority -- and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: seems to be incurable. They claim that even now success is everywhere crowning their arms in Virginia. By our Southern excerpts this morning, it will be seen that Gen. JOSEPH JOHNSTON states that the National troops were repulsed at Williamsburgh, on the Peninsula, and our advance in that direction altogether stopped; and the Richmond papers claim the battle there as a "most brilliant and successful affair" for the rebels. In the Department of Gen. FREMONT the rebels were in hot pursuit of Gen. MILROY, who was falling back before them, and they entertain a hope that they may be able to overtake and engage him. BANKS' corps, also, was retreating, and the rebels were taking large numbers of prisoners. In fact, if the Richmond rebels believe their own generals and journals, they will be greatly astonished when MCCLELLAN reaches the rebel capital to find that he has even a shred of an army left him.

abstract: The Trustees of the First Baptist Church of Brooklyn, et al., vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Co. -- This was an action to recover damages for the destruction by fire of plaintiffs' church, on the 10th day of September, 1848, which had been insured by defendants in 1845 for one year for a premium of $25. At the expiration of the policy in 1846, it was renewed for one year. It was claimed by the plaintiffs that there was an agreement before this renewal that the policy should be renewed from time to time without further notice, and one party or the other should give notice of an intention to discontinue the renewal. This the defendants denied. The evidence in regard to the renewal was very conflicting. The President of the Company and the Treasurer of the Church swearing to two conflicting statements. A verdict was given for the defendants, and a motion made for a new trial before Justice ALLEN on his minutes, which was denied and judgment entered for defendants -- from which the plaintiffs appealed to this Court, on the ground that the Court improperly excluded the answer of one A.N. Lewis to the question, "What is meant by a permanent policy," and also improperly excluded all evidence of contrast between other parties, and the mode in which they were carried out. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: The Trustees of the First Baptist Church of Brooklyn, et al., vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Co. -- This was an action to recover damages for the destruction by fire of plaintiffs' church, on the 10th day of September, 1848, which had been insured by defendants in 1845 for one year for a premium of $25. At the expiration of the policy in 1846, it was renewed for one year. It was claimed by the plaintiffs that there was an agreement before this renewal that the policy should be renewed from time to time without further notice, and one party or the other should give notice of an intention to discontinue the renewal. This the defendants denied. The evidence in regard to the renewal was very conflicting. The President of the Company and the Treasurer of the Church swearing to two conflicting statements. A verdict was given for the defendants, and a motion made for a new trial before Justice ALLEN on his minutes, which was denied and judgment entered for defendants -- from which the plaintiffs appealed to this Court, on the ground that the Court improperly excluded the answer of one A.N. Lewis to the question, "What is meant by a permanent policy," and also improperly excluded all evidence of contrast between other parties, and the mode in which they were carried out. Decision reserved.

abstract: which have placed Norfolk in the possession of the Government, the letter in another column gives an accurate narrative. The design and its success are due, it seems, to Gen. WOOL, whose expedition encountered no resistance, and who was able to return to Fortress Monroe the same day, carrying the news. Capt. FOOTE secured Island No. 10 without the loss of a man; the siege, however, lasted three weeks. Gen. WOOL was equally fortunate in winning a bloodless victory; but had a great advantage in the ease and rapidity with which his acquisition was made. Much of this commendable energy was due to the presence of Mr. LINCOLN. It seems almost desirable that the ample longitude of the Chief Magistrate might be divided, like JOHN ZISCA's skin, among all the divisions of the army and navy, so as to inspire like activity and beget similar success everywhere.

abstract: Elizabeth Reilly, Administratrix, &c., vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The plaintiff in this case sued as the Administratrix of her husband, who, as alleged, was killed by the negligence of the City in leaving a coal-hole open in the Bowery. The defence was that the City had never given permission that this coal-hole should be made under the sidewalk, and that it was not, therefore, responsible. The case was stated in the TIMES on Saturday, a sealed verdict being ordered.

abstract: The Court have ordered that at each May and November Terms a Committee of three shall be appointed to investigate the character of those applying for admission to practice, and that such Committee shall report before the third Monday. Each certificate submitted in respect to the character of an applicant shall state that the party making it is acquainted with the character of the applicant and knows it to be good.
lead_paragraph: The Court have ordered that at each May and November Terms a Committee of three shall be appointed to investigate the character of those applying for admission to practice, and that such Committee shall report before the third Monday. Each certificate submitted in respect to the character of an applicant shall state that the party making it is acquainted with the character of the applicant and knows it to be good.

abstract: Let those who accuse the North of ambition and severity be sincere; they would have overwhelmed the North with their contempt (and justly so,) if the North had resigned itself to the ruin of that vast empire without a struggle. "See," would they have said, "how [???] Those who were charged by a regular election with the heavy responsibility of the French Government [???] arms in their hands, rather than [???] of their country; they have [???] admitted the possibility at a [???] the Republic. They have [???] not only to the New World, but also to the Out, where their embarrassment was looked upon with pleasure, and where there was a disposition to triumph at their weakness, -They therefore decided on war, and organized it over an immense territory, against [???] better prepared and more warlike, and no check [???] their courage. They have at last brought things to the point at which we see them now, [???] that difficulty of distance when had been declared to be insurmountable, and seeking at the same time at Richmond, New-Orleans and Charleston, if not the immediate reestablishment of concord, at least the end of the revolt and the welfare of the country. And during the darkest days of this civil war, openly encouraged abroad, when their reverses were the severest, with the enemy at the gates of the capital, and treason within their walls, they did not act against a single suspected person, not put to death a [???] guilty one; they have only shed blood on the fields of battle, where volunteers, and volunteers alone, give their lives daily for this just cause. That is the spectacle which we Frenchmen, grandsons of the glorious founders of that Republic, now contemplate, not with a complete indifference, but with that relaxed attention and in that state between sleeping and waking, which renders us incapable of all great emotion. But posterity, which puts everything in its right place, will compare the defence of the soil of France, to 1792, with that [???] redemption of the American Republic, which appeared for an instant about to perish, to the great detriment of France, and to the joy of the enemies of free institutions over the entire universe.

They have at last brought things to the point at which we see them now, [???] that difficulty of distance when had been declared to be insurmountable, and seeking at the same time at Richmond, New-Orleans and Charleston, if not the immediate reestablishment of concord, at least the end of the revolt and the welfare of the country. And during the darkest days of this civil war, openly encouraged abroad, when their reverses were the severest, with the enemy at the gates of the capital, and treason within their walls, they did not act against a single suspected person, not put to death a [???] guilty one; they have only shed blood on the fields of battle, where volunteers, and volunteers alone, give their lives daily for this just cause. That is the spectacle which we Frenchmen, grandsons of the glorious founders of that Republic, now contemplate, not with a complete indifference, but with that relaxed attention and in that state between sleeping and waking, which renders us incapable of all great emotion. But posterity, which puts everything in its right place, will compare the defence of the soil of France, to 1792, with that [???] redemption of the American Republic, which appeared for an instant about to perish, to the great detriment of France, and to the joy of the enemies of free institutions over the entire universe.

abstract: There are only a few cities of importance on Southern seaboard remaining for our fleet now to capture. These are Wilmington, Charleston and Savannah on the Atlantic coast, and Mobile on the Gulf coast. The rebels say that Gen. BURNSIDE is about to attack Wilmington, which, when captured, will complete our possession of the
lead_paragraph: -- There are only a few cities of importance on Southern seaboard remaining for our fleet now to capture. These are Wilmington, Charleston and Savannah on the Atlantic coast, and Mobile on the Gulf coast. The rebels say that Gen. BURNSIDE is about to attack Wilmington, which, when captured, will complete our possession of the North Carolina shore. Gen. HUNTER, we learn from the South, is reconnoitering very close up to both Charleston and Savannah; and we shall doubtless soon have news of the fall of one or the other of these places. A telegraphic dispatch from Mobile, published in the Richmond papers, announces that "Commodore PORTER's fleet is advancing" upon that city, seventeen vessels strong, and that firing has already been heard in the vicinity. Mobile, it is known, was the point PORTER was to sail for after the fall of New-Orleans, and he had just about time to reach it by the close of last week, so that the news, though it be from rebel sources, is not at all unlikely. The Mobile rebels give forth the usual signs of a surrender when they end their telegram with the words: "The forces at the forts are confident." This is the precise formula which the rebels at every point have uttered just before caving in.

abstract: The colored people of this City and vicinity made a most enthusiastic demonstration yesterday in honor of the Abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. There was a prayer meeting at Shiloh Church, at 5 A.M., a flag, raising at the same place at 3 P.M., a grand mass meeting at Cooper Institute, and a ball at Metropolitian Hall, Prince-street, in the evening, The rejoicing among the colored population was most general and hearty.

lead_paragraph: The Paris letter-writer of the London Herald says the eagerness of the Emperor for an end to the American civil war has received a new fillip. The common sentiment in Paris, the correspondent says is despondency at the slow progress of the National arms; and a fear that at the present rate of progression the contest will last for years, to the incalculable detriment of French industry. These views, we are told, are common to the Emperor and the people. A hint is also thrown out that the heavy reinforcements just dispatched to Vera Cruz, are in reality destined to New-Orleans.

abstract: We have some very discouraging rumors again from Southwestern Virginia. The enemy is said to be advancing rapidly and in force on Dublin and Wytheville. We think these rumors exaggerated, and we advise the people not to be alarmed. It is the evident purpose, however, of the enemy, to cut to pieces our railroad, and destroy our resources of army supplies if he can. Our Government must prevent it at all hazards, and it ought at once to reinstate Gen. FLOYD to the command in that quarter.
lead_paragraph: We have some very discouraging rumors again from Southwestern Virginia. The enemy is said to be advancing rapidly and in force on Dublin and Wytheville. abstract: We give this morning a very full and special account of the advance upon and occupation of Norfolk, by our forces under Gen. WOOL, and all the circumstances which planned that important movement. Secretary STANTON, it appears, was mistaked, in announcing as he did, in his dispatch from Fortress Monroe, that the Gosport Navyyard bad not been barned by the rebels.
lead_paragraph: We give this morning a very full and special account of the advance upon and occupation of Norfolk, by our forces under Gen. WOOL, and all the circumstances which planned that important movement. Secretary STANTON, it appears, was mistaked, in announcing as he did, in his dispatch from Fortress Monroe, that the Gosport Navyyard bad not been barned by the rebels. All the property there was destroyed by them, with the exception of the great Naval Hospital. The destruction in steamboat property alone was immerse. Two iron-clad floating batteries in course of construction were partially burnt, but it is probable that they can yet be made available in service against the rebels. After the occupation of Norfolk by our forces. Gen. WOOL issued a proclamation assuring protection to the citizens in their legitimate avocations, and Gen. VIELE, as Military Governor, subsequently issued another to the same effect. The batteries on Craney Island, which were of course deserted by the rebels, were found to be very strong, and mounted fifty-two guns, principally rifled Dahlgrens. The Merrimac, before she was blown up, was run ashore on Craney Island.

abstract: of New-Orleans. He has now the more difficult task before him of overcoming the effects of defeat, wounded pride and mortification; in other words, of bringing the population, not merely into subjection to National authority, but into cheerful and willing subjection. Of the temper appropriate to this result, he appears to find little. The popular chagrin and disappointment are too acute to be readily cured. The citizens of New-Orleans had been confident of the practical inaccessibility of the place. What with forts and chains above, below and around the city; floating batteries, and gunboats without stint; and the presence of an army twice or thrice the strength of that which was approaching the town with hostile aim, they had every reason, they thought to laugh at the Yankees, and await patiently the annihilation of their leagues. The fates [???] otherwise; and prompt [???] of destiny is not classed [???]. New-Orleans, [???], insubordinate. The [???] and the Council decline to take theoath of allegiance to National authority, which saves them the consciousness of perjury, while it consigns them to the cool, though moist, seclusion of the calaboosc. And thus does Gen. BUTLER inaugurate his second campaign, which is directed against the moral rather than the martial recusancy of the rebels.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the Pacific Railroad bill was reported back from the Special Committee by Mr. McDOUGALL, who moved to make it the special order for Thursday next. The motion failed. The bill to protect the Indians who have adopted civilized habits was passed. A joint resolution to provide for the presentation of medals of honor to enlisted men and volunteers was reported from the Military Committee, and passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday the Pacific Railroad bill was reported back from the Special Committee by Mr. McDOUGALL, who moved to make it the special order for Thursday next. The motion failed. The bill to protect the Indians who have adopted civilized habits was passed. A joint resolution to provide for the presentation of medals of honor to enlisted men and volunteers was reported from the Military Committee, and passed. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, also offered a resolution authorizing regiments to inscribe the names of battles on their flags, and gave notice that he would call it up at an early day. The bill for the better protection of the revenue was passed. It confers upon the President and Secretary of the Treasury certain powers in regard to clearances and transportation. The Indian Appropriation bill was then considered until the adjournment.

abstract: The President has issued a proclamation declaring that the blockade of the ports of Beaufort, Port Royal and New-Orleans shall so far cease and determine from and after the 1st of June next, that commercial intercourse with those ports, except as to persons and things and information contraband of war, may from that time be carried on, subject to the laws of the United States, and to the limitations and in pursuance of the regulations which are prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury. In accordance with this proclamation,  Secretary CHASE has issued a circular prescribing the rules by which the trade with these reopened ports must be regulated. The proclamation and the circular will be found in our columns this morning.

abstract: Capt. D S Porter lr. outlines survey services in capture of New Orleans

lead_paragraph: When the attack on New-Orleans was in preparation, the Superintendent of the Coast Survey detailed a surveying party under the command of Assistant T.H. GERDES, to join the attacking forces and render them all the assistance in their power. The other officers of the party were Messrs. J.S. HARRIS, (also of the United States Boundary Commission corps,) J.G. OLTMANS, R.E. HALTER and T.C. BOWIE. Mr. HALTER had previously joined the fleet and had rendered efficient service in sounding out the Passes of the Mississippi and placing buoys. Com. PORTER acknowledges the important services rendered by this Coast Survey party in a letter to Prof. BACHE, from which we make the following extracts:

abstract: -- We would call attention to the testimony which, in another column, Capt. PORTER bears to the important services rendered him by the Coast Survey. At every stage of his progress he was indebted to the personal and professional counsels of the officer detached by Superintendent BACHE to accompany him. Channels were retraced, soundings verified, secure anchorage and advantageous positions pointed out; in a word, a volume of information and assistance furnished, the want of which must have seriously retarded, if not defeated, the operations of the flotilla. The aid rendered this single expedition were cheaply bought with the entire yearly appropriation for the Survey.

abstract: We continue to receive assurances that the rebel army intends to make a final stand, a desperate, determined effort at resistance in front of Richmond. Advices from Norfolk assert that this is the universal opinion there. Of course it is. This is the pretext on which Gen. HUGER justified to the citizens of that place his abandonment of them.
lead_paragraph: We continue to receive assurances that the rebel army intends to make a final stand, -- a desperate, determined effort at resistance in front of Richmond. Advices from Norfolk assert that this is the universal opinion there. Of course it is. This is the pretext on which Gen. HUGER justified to the citizens of that place his abandonment of them. He told them that great strategical reasons demanded his evacuation of Norfolk, -- that his army was needed at Richmond, -- and that there they intend to fight to the last man. The same story induced the evacuation of Yorktown. Indeed, it is precisely what the rebel officers have said at every point. They have found it necessary to say it in order to keep up the confidence of their men. If it had been generally supposed that their withdrawal from these strong points was merely a retreat and nothing more, the rebel army could not have been held together an hour.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, James Frederick Howell, an Englishman, 38 years of age, was tried on a charge of grand larceny, in stealing a pawnbroker's stop-ticket, representing about $40 worth of silver-ware, from Mrs. John Hines. The jury convicted him of petit larceny, and he will be sentenced on Saturday. Catharine Travers, Irish, jointly indicted with three other women who were acquitted, on Monday, for robbing a sailor named Wm. H. Showan, of several dollars, was tried and acquitted.

abstract: There must presently be either a great battle or a grand retreat in the Southwest. The immense army of Gen. HALLECK the largest column under any one commander in the field-is so close upon the rebel works and army, and his movements are now so menacing and dangerous, that it will be impossible for BEAUREGARD to remain inactive in his present position for many days longer.
lead_paragraph: There must presently be either a great battle or a grand retreat in the Southwest. The immense army of Gen. HALLECK -- the largest column under any one commander in the field -- is so close upon the rebel works and army, and his movements are now so menacing and dangerous, that it will be impossible for BEAUREGARD to remain inactive in his present position for many days longer. The daily reports of skirmishes which reach us, are indicative of the steady advance of ourlines; of the constant occupation of new points of value, and of the progress of a system of strategy similar to that which has been so destructive to the rebel army in Virginia -- namely, rendering the rebel situation untenable, and making success morally certain before the assault is begun. The heavy skirmish which was reported in our yesterday's issue, as having taken place three miles from Corinth, when the enemy found it necessary to move against our advance with a force twenty thousand strong, indicates the perilous proximity to our troops of the right wing of the enemy's main body. If he means to maintain his present position for any length of time, or to keep open his western line of communication, or his southward line of retreat, it is essential to him that our troops be prevented from advancing another inch in any direction But while it is necessary for him to do all he can to accomplish this, it is quite impossible for him to succeed in it; for the troops of Gen. HALLECK are now so disposed that he can completely outflank him whenever it shall be found advisable to do so.

abstract: By the arrival off Farther Point of the steamship Jura, on her way to Quebec, we have advices from Europe to the 2d of May one day later. It is again asserted by the Paris correspondent of the Independmece Belge that France and England intend to interfere in the af- fairs of the United States. The foundation for the statement is not given.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival off Farther Point of the steamship Jura, on her way to Quebec, we have advices from Europe to the 2d of May -- one day later. It is again asserted by the Paris correspondent of the Independmece Belge that France and England intend to interfere in the af- fairs of the United States. The foundation for the statement is not given. One of the terms of intervention is stated to be a requirement that the South shall guarantee the emancipation of the slaves. The Great Exhibition was opened on the 1st inst., and the affair is represented to have been a decided success. The Liverpool Cotton market was dull and lower. Breadstuffs were also dull, and Provisions heavy. Consols were 93 3/4@93 7/8.

abstract: The President's proclamation declaring the supersession of the blockade at certain Southern ports, of which we took notice when first officially resolved, is now published. It abolishes, from the first of June next, the blockade at the ports of Beaufort, N.C., Port Royal, S.C., (a port opened by Northern enterprise, and likely to supplant Charleston, as it well deserves to,) and New-Orleans, and throws them open to the commerce of the world, subject to the laws of the United States, and to the limitations and regulations prescribed by the Treasury Department. These limitations and regulations, both as regards foreign vessels and coastwise traders, are expressly stated in a circular issued by Secretary CHASE.
lead_paragraph: The President's proclamation declaring the supersession of the blockade at certain Southern ports, of which we took notice when first officially resolved, is now published. These limitations and regulations, both as regards foreign vessels and coastwise traders, are expressly stated in a circular issued by Secretary CHASE.

abstract: -- The reception accorded yesterday to Parson BROWNLOW, he will have the goodness to consider a very imperfect expression of the feeling heartily entertained toward him by our people. We have learned here to regard him as the true type of what the Southerner ought to be, and of what in tale and tradition he is represented to be. Daring, self-reliant, earnest, truthful, gentle, in the right cause eloquent, and against the wrong unsparing; patient and unconquerable in persecution and adversity; the soul of honor, with the heart of a woman -- these are the elements of genuine chivalry, and all these are the possession of BROWNLOW. A loyalty like his, which has braved death, how shall we measure with the standard of GARRET DAVIS, or POWELL, or CRITTENDEN! BROWNLOW sets his country and the Union above all else -- oven above Slavery. Loyalists of the Kentucky school hedge their fidelity about with infinite conditions, and the reservation of numberless selfish interests, enshrined higher than the Union and the Constitution; talking of State rights in language borrowed from the lips of Rebellion. By as much as we despise and reject these men, do we honor the Tennessee hero, who is so worthily the guest of our people. All honor to PARSON BROWNLOW!
lead_paragraph: -- The reception accorded yesterday to Parson BROWNLOW, he will have the goodness to consider a very imperfect expression of the feeling heartily entertained toward him by our people. abstract: Memphis is now the city round which centres all the movements of the Southwestern campaign. FOOTE's fleet (now commanded by Capt. DAVIS) is trying to force its way to it down the Mississippi River; another fleet is gradually advancing to it up the same stream, and HALLECK's great army threatens it from the West. It was mainly with a view to its defence, and therewith the defence of the Mississippi Valley, that BEAUREGARD took up his position at Corinth, and immense preparations have also been made for its defence in front and rear. It is now, next to Richmond, (of which we gave a diagram yesterday, the rebel city of greatest interest, and until it is captured by our troops, public attention will be fixed upon it, and upon the operations on the great military lines leading to it. So well are the rebels satisfied of its speedy fall, that the military authorities have already begun to burn the cotton there stored, and to roll the sugar and molasses into the river. For a whole year, the city has been kept perpetually in the wildest state of excitement by the dread of capture and destruction; and the Memphian rebels must by this time be absolutely crazy. Its capture now cannot be delayed; for the discomfiture last Saturday of the rebel iron-clad gunboats and rams, upon which reliance was placed to keep our fleet from the city, shows that there is nothing now to prevent our bomb-ketches from anchoring in front of the city, and bringing it to terms as New-Orleans was brought to terms. We give this morning a diagram of the city which is the centre of so much importance and interest. Many interesting points will be found noted; among others the property of BEAUREGARD. The fact that he is a property holder here may account in part for his taking up his position as where did, and his anxiety to defend the city.

abstract: Brownlow gives pro-Union speech at reception, NYC
snippet: Brownlow gives pro-Union speech at reception, NYC
lead_paragraph: Our readers are familiar with the more notable facts in the recent history of Rev. W.G. BROWNLOW, of Knoxville, Tenn., better known by the sobriquet of the "Fighting Parson." Concerning his earlier career, not so much is known, and the public impression is, that the redoubtable preacher is a rough-and-ready fighter, an effective speaker, a good hater, and a mixture of strong elements, good and bad. The truth is, that Mr. BROWNLOW is original in his way of thinking, and eccentric in his manner of acting, and being of invincible determination, never gives up an opinion once entertained. He has fought often with his hands, but oftener with his tongue, and yet more frequently and with as much effect, with his pen. For more than twenty years he edited and sustained the Jonesborough Whig, in the midst of a fighting community -- a paper which regularly scored some political or personal opponent, and a community which believed in pistols, bowie-knives, and the use of them.

abstract: body of the President's nominations to high commands in the army, the Senate has made a few exceptions, apparently without any adequate motive. The case of Gen. W.F. SMITH has already been noticed. Another is that of Gen. MARCY, who is the Chief of Gen. MCCLELLAN's Staff, and who has rendered most important service to the army under his command. An idea seems to be very prevalent that those Generals only merit favor who distinguish themselves by actual fighting. This would dovery well it all Generals had an equal chance to engage in fighting. But ninety-nine hundredths of the duty of an army -- officers and soldiers -- is to prepare for fighting; and when the critical moment arrives, it is a matter of accident, depending upon the movements of the enemy, and not at all upon the will of any particular officer, whether he will have a chance for distinction or not. One of the ablast, most pains-taking and meritorious officers in our army is FITZ JOHN PORTER. Though laboring under a disease which renders exposure almost certainly fatal and severe labor next to impossible, he has labored with intense and inexlinustible enthusiasm to prepare the army for the advance it is now making upon Richmond. Night after night, in darkness, rain and mud, without food, rest or comfort of any kind, has he passed in exploring and surveying the work in progress, and in perfecting the arrangements for the grand assault. His reward would have been complete if he could have had a chance for the distinction which a soldier most covets, when the moment for the charge arrived.

abstract: VEXED QUESTION SETTLED. -- We surrender much of our space, this morning, to an important admiralty decision of the United States Supreme Court, settling what has been a vexed and doubtful question. Under the twelfth Admiralty rule, adopted by the Supreme Court in 1844, and several decisions of the Court both preceding and following it, it had been generally understood that the Admiralty Courts of the country had jurisdiction to enforce liens upon vessels for supplies, as well under the State lien laws, where the vessel was a domestic one, as under the maritime law, where the vessel was foreign; and under this view of the case very many suits were entertained by the District Courts to enforce these liens.But, some years ago, the Supreme Court seemed to have adopted different views of the law, and to have come to the conclusion that there was no jurisdiction in an Admiralty Court to enforce a lien upon a domestic vessel.
lead_paragraph: VEXED QUESTION SETTLED. -- We surrender much of our space, this morning, to an important admiralty decision of the United States Supreme Court, settling what has been a vexed and doubtful question. Under the twelfth Admiralty rule, adopted by the Supreme Court in 1844, and several decisions of the Court both preceding and following it, it had been generally understood that the Admiralty Courts of the country had jurisdiction to enforce liens upon vessels for supplies, as well under the State lien laws, where the vessel was a domestic one, as under the maritime law, where the vessel was foreign; and under this view of the case very many suits were entertained by the District Courts to enforce these liens.But, some years ago, the Supreme Court seemed to have adopted different views of the law, and to have come to the conclusion that there was no jurisdiction in an Admiralty Court to enforce a lien upon a domestic vessel.

abstract: A large and influential meeting of merchants and other citizens of New-York was held at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday noon, in response to a call for pecuniary aid to the sufferers by the Troy fire. Mayor [???] was called to the Chair, and in opening the meeting, said the object of the gathering was to devise some means for the relief of the sufferers by the conflagration in our sister city of Troy -- a conflagration which, in proportion to the size of the city, is as great an affliction as the great fire of 1835 was to New-York, which would be recollected by many present. The citizens of Troy at that time responded with great liberality for our relief, and it was, therefore, most fitting that we should respond with even greater liberality in this their hour of need.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition from citizens of Indiana was presented by Mr. WRIGHT, of that State, asking Congress to stop the agitation of the negro question, and attend to the business of putting down the rebellion. The resolution to suspend the payment of the troops actually employed in the Department of the West, until certain charges of fraud could be investigated, was considered, but laid over without action.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition from citizens of Indiana was presented by Mr. WRIGHT, of that State, asking Congress to stop the agitation of the negro question, and attend to the business of putting down the rebellion. The resolution to suspend the payment of the troops actually employed in the Department of the West, until certain charges of fraud could be investigated, was considered, but laid over without action. Mr. POWELL's resolution, asking information of the Secretary of War relative to the arrest and imprisonment of citizens of Kentucky, was taken up, and Mr. SUMNER's amendment, calling upon the President for the information, if compatible with the public interests, was adopted. The resolution as thus amended was adopted. A bill was reported from the Special Committee on Confiscation, and was laid over. A resolution calling upon the President to inform the Senate whether any foreign Power had proposed to interfere in our National affairs, was introduced by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, but, was laid over. The Indian Appropriation bill was then debated until the Senate went into Executive session. No other business was done in open session.

abstract: Editorial on pending bill on confiscation of property of secessionists in captured areas
snippet: Editorial on pending bill on confiscation of property of secessionists in captured areas
lead_paragraph: The conferences between the Select Committees of senate and House on the Confiscation bills have resulted in the submission of two measures, quite different in scope, butboth exceedingly stringent. The first provides for the forfeiture of all property belonging to those who hold offices of honor, trust or profit in the rebel services, and to those bearing arms in that service who, within sixty daysafter the President has issued a warning proclamation, shall not return to their allegiance. In the absence of the recusant, theproceedings may be had in rem, or against the property itself, as in case of seizures under the law of customs. The second bill simply affects property in the labor of slaves, the slaves of all rebels being liberated by the act, and when suit shall be brought to reclaim them, the claimant will have to establish the fact of his undeviating loyalty.

abstract: the policy of relaxing the blockade of our Southern coast will be extended as speedily as possible to Norfolk. The inhabitants of that section of Virginia, and of the whole Peninsula between the James and York rivers, are actually suffering for the necessaries of life.
lead_paragraph: the policy of relaxing the blockade of our Southern coast will be extended as speedily as possible to Norfolk. The inhabitants of that section of Virginia, and of the whole Peninsula between the James and York rivers, are actually suffering for the necessaries of life. The rebel armies quartered among them for the Winter consumed nearly all their grain and other provisions, and the subsequent passage of the Union troops completed their exhaustion. They need trade more than anything else. They have little money, it is true, that would be available here, but they have valuable property, and could doubtless obtain credit to an amount that would afford them very great relief. Nothing will strengthen the Union feeling more rapidly than a brisk and active trade with the North.

abstract: Benjamin Blossom et al. vs. Edward Champion et al. -- This was an action to recover for detention of personal property. The plaintiff contracted to sell to F.A. Blossom, 843 barrels of spirits of turpentine, for cash on delivery. F.A. Blossom sold to Albert Woodhull. Defendant, Champion, was the master of the ship Victoria. Plaintiffs sent the spirits of turpentine on board the ship, about the 13th to 16th January, 1855, and took receipts from the mate. The plaintiffs retained the receipts. Offered to perform their contract with F.A. Blossom. He was unable to pay. The name of the plaintiffs was on the back of the receipts. The receipts were in the usual form. Before the spirits of turpentine was all on board the vessel and without the production of the receipts, the defendant Champion gave to Woodhull bills of lading for if, taking from his son a guarantee that it should be put on board. The plaintiffs went to defendant Champion; demanded bills of lading on showing receipts; offered to pay freight. Champion refused. Plaintiffs then demanded the goods. Plaintiffs proved by a large number of witnesses the existence at this port of a uniform and well-known usage to deliver bills of lading to the person holding the ship's receipts. The defendants did not dispute this usage. Plaintiffs then replevied the goods. the cause was tried by a Jury in February, 1859. Verdict for plaintiffs. Defendant appeals. The exceptions during the trial were to the charge and proof of custom.

abstract: period when for months all eyes were direcred to Charleston, and the intense desire and passionate cry of the whole country was that the traitor city that inaugurated rebellion should be assailed, captured and punished. But we think very little about Charleston now, and the country is quite willing patiently to await the pleasure of the Government in regard to its capture.
lead_paragraph: period when for months all eyes were direcred to Charleston, and the intense desire and passionate cry of the whole country was that the traitor city that inaugurated rebellion should be assailed, captured and punished. But we think very little about Charleston now, and the country is quite willing patiently to await the pleasure of the Government in regard to its capture. The reason is that everybody knows we can take Charleston any moment we please. The Monitor and Galena can coolly steam into the harbor, past Sumter and up to the city, while all the shot the fort can rain on them fall from off their mailed sides like the peas of a pop-gun. It would have been a formidable and a hazardous business to have attempted to run with wooden vessels the gauntlet of the rebel batteries and the fire from Fort Sumter. But with the iron-clads cela ca sans dire: and we presume that just as soon as they are relieved from the important mission they now have to fill in the James River, this will be the very next duty they will be sent on. When Richmond falls, "On to Charleston" will probably be the substitute for the old battle-cry. But even if the Government shall see fit to reserve the capture of Charleston for the termination of a war [???] in that guilty city, the country will be perfectly satisfied knowing that the fruit is [???] and ready at any moment for [???].

abstract: Editorial on lies spread by Confederates about themselves and about Union
snippet: Editorial on lies spread by Confederates about themselves and about Union
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship [???] at Halifax last evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later than by the Jura. The most notable feature of the news is the reiteration of the rumors that France and England intend to interfere in the affairs of this country. The rumors, however, are very vague, somewhat contradictory, and probably have no foundation. The announcement is made in the London Times that the British Government has gradually withdrawn even its originally small stake in the military part of the enterprise in Mexico, and has now little beyond a moral participation in the matter.The Times adds: "We shall have to get such redress for the past and guarantees for the future as are found to be obtainable, and we want nothing more." The papers of London were filled with glowing accounts of the opening of the Great Exhibition. The number of persons present was 33.000 -- all season ticket holders. There is no change to note in the condition of the markets.

lead_paragraph: pression given by the announcement that Suffolk had been captured by the Union forces, was that BURNSIDE had done too late what he should have done long ago. It is a relief to find this charge unfounded. Sufflok is in the hands of Gen. WOOL'S Division; white BURNSIDE is doubtless carrying out with entire success his movement toward the interior of North Carolina. The other day the seizure of Suffolk would have been hailed as a most important event, because it severed the connection between Norfolk and Richmond. The event is still important, if it is to be followed by an active advance of Gen. WOOL's army upon Petereburgh, reaching the rear of JOHNSTON's force, and cutting off its retreat. It is twelve months since we pointed out in the TIMES the eminent advisability of reaching Richmond by a simultaneous movement up both banks of the James.

abstract: Joachim F. Gulick, Executor, &c., vs. The New-York Balance Dry-Dock Company, -- The case was reported in the TIMES of Feb. 8, when a verdict was given to the plaintiff for the amount claimed, $5,000. The Court, at General Term, granted a new trial. The plaintiff brings this action to recover of the defendants for causing the death of John Coulter, Feb. 1, 1860. The complaint alleges that Coulter was in the employ of the defendants as night watchman, and that he was killed by the explosion of a steam boiler belonging to the company, and that the boiler was dangerous and unsafe, and that the engineer of the company had given them notice of that fact several times previous to the explosion.

abstract: "ALBERT CARDOZA, SAMUEL JONES, and HENRY A. CRAM have been appointed examiners of the appoints for admission to the Bar. These gentlemen are skillful practitioners, and the aspirants for legal fame must be up to their work, or they will be compelled to wait for a more auspicious opportunity. By the way, we observe that several promising students from 'the New-York University' have been admitted to practice on the application cf Prof. WEDGWOOD. Among the number, we notice SMITH ELY, Jr., JOHN QUACKENBUSH, WILDES P. WALKER, representative from 'Maine.' and other precocious juveniles. The doors of the University swing wide open, and all who desire to put out their shingles must hurry up and make it all right with the 'Professor.'

abstract: Tunis S. Waring vs. Eleazar Ayres. -- This was an action to compel the specific performance of a contract respecting the conveyance of certain real estate. The defence set up was that the contract was a nullity so far as any obligations to convey lands were concerned, and that its provisions were too indefinite to be enforced. The action was tried before a referee, and judgment rendered for plaintiff. The defendant appealed on the ground that to entitle a party to a specific performance of contract, the contract itself must be show to be legal and valid in all respects, and the equity must be clear and unembarrassed. That no contract concerning lands can be enforced unless it is in writing, and so specific in its terms as to enable the Court to direct what shall be done without extrinsic aid. That the contract did not show that the plaintiff had any interest in the property which he could sell. It was not a couveyance in present, nor a covenant to convey, there was no covenant on the part of defendant to convey real estate to the plaintiff. The agreement was to dinner the lots, which clearly meant nothing but possession. The description was so indefinite and uncertain, and was consequently defective. A written contract could not be helped out by parole evidence, and the Referee erred in admitting evidence of conversations and parole agreements prior to the written contract.

abstract: The People ex rel. Wm. Mictchell vs. Robert T. Haws. -- This is the case which has been so often reported, in respect to the question whether or not the law of April 18, 1852, allowing the Board of Supervisors of the First District to raise by tax "such additional annual compensation as they may deem proper," for Justices resident in said District, is constitutional. The money was raised, but the Comptroller refused to pay it, relying upon that section of the Constitution which prohibits such increase of salary "during continuance in office," which provision was made the substance of his return to the alternative mandamus in the case. The Court, at Special Term, overruled the relator's demurrer to that return, and this was an appeal from that judgment.

abstract: BOROUGH. In the present situtation of affairs on the Peninusule, infinite interest attaches to the movements of the gunboats and ironclads that are pushing their way up James River toward Richmond. For whether the rebel force between the Chickahominy and the James awaits and gives battle to the army of Gen. McCLELLAN, or makes another, and this...
lead_paragraph: BOROUGH. -- In the present situtation of affairs on the Peninusule, infinite interest attaches to the movements of the gunboats and ironclads that are pushing their way up James River toward Richmond. For whether the rebel force between the Chickahominy and the James awaits and gives battle to the army of Gen. McCLELLAN, or makes another, and this time the last, of its masterly retreats, it will depend on the gunboats to cut off its retreat and enable Gen. McClellan to capture the whole force. When last heard from, the gunboats were pushing vigorously "on to Richmond," having silenced two rebel batteries by the way, and three days ago they were within little more than as many hours run of the Capital. Now there are but two or three possible points at which the rebels can retreat southward across the James -- and these are between City Point, opposite Petersburgh, and at Richmond. We take it for granted that our gunboats will destroy the floating means of transport the enemy may have prepared to avail himself of in case of flight. All that will then need to be done will be to either destroy or simply command by our guns the railroad bridge (of the Richmond and Danville Railroad) at Richmond, at the same time that another gunboat makes a detour into the Appomattox and up to Petersburgh, (but a dozen miles from its embouchure into the James,) and doing the same for the bridges there. Since the suicide of the Merrimac has relieved our fleet from police duty, we presume a portion of it, including the Monitor and Naugatuck, has been sent up to reinforce the gunboats that went up last week, and that we now have sufficient naval force to secure, beyond a doubt, the important objects indicated. There is no reason why the whole vast rebel army on the Peninsula should not, in this way, be captured; and the country expects that it will be so. Here is a splendid opening for Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH to carry off the richest laurels of the war. We presume he means to avail himself of it.
