abstract: veals fresh evidence of his sterling judgment and firmness in snubbing that fellow FOSTER, whose name has so suggestive a rhyme, FOSTER has been the bete noir of North Carolina. His career in both functions was brought to a termination at once appropriate and prompt; but resolute, to make a good thing out of his adopted State,...
lead_paragraph: veals fresh evidence of his sterling judgment and firmness in snubbing that fellow FOSTER, whose name has so suggestive a rhyme, FOSTER has been the bete noir of North Carolina. He figured for a while as Provisional Governor of the State, self-appointed; then as a Congressman, self-elected. His career in both functions was brought to a termination at once appropriate and prompt; but resolute, to make a good thing out of his adopted State, he has since hovered about the union camps, awaiting the chance for a fresh demonstration. At Newborn the other day he announced his purpose to deliver a stump speech to the free and independent electors of that city. Now the city is under martial law, a circumstance in itself prohibiting popular political gatherings; and, besides, FOSTER is a humbug, and it behooves the military police to put down alike all quack doctoring and doctrine. So Gen. BURNSIDE forbade the speech, and the orator was unheard. Perseverance in this judicious course will entitle the General to the gratitude of the entire people of the State. The popular horror of FOSTER is represented as something worse than the nightmare.

abstract: John McGrane vs. The Mayor, &c. -- On the 28th day of November, 1853, the parties to this action entered into an agreement in writing for regulating and grading Fifty-third-street, in this City, between Third and Sixth avenues, by which plaintiff agreed to perform the work at a certain price. It is claimed by the plaintiff, that he proceeded in the performance of the work in a manner satisfactory to the defendants, and according to certain plans and specifications, and that the defendants prevented and hindered him from completing the work, and would not allow him to dig through Fifth-avenue in a line, according to the specification. By reason of such hindrance he was compelled to carry the dirt a long way around, and to bale the water out of the street, which would otherwise have run off -- and he now brings this action to recover for the extra labor.

abstract: establishing a Department of Agriculture has passed both Houses of Congress. lead_paragraph: establishing a Department of Agriculture has passed both Houses of Congress. The President, having no constitutional objections to offer, will unquestionably sign it; and out of the overtasked Treasury will be taken, at the lowest estimate, some $30,000 a-year, to affect what might have been effected for tithe of the sum. The only advantage, indeed, we ran discover in giving this interest a department instead of that more economical machine, a bureau, consists in the presence at the Cabinet councils, debating grave questions of war and foreign policy, of a member deeply versed in [???], at home among cereals, and profound in the mysteries of mangel-wurzel, and the best remedies for the rot. We trust the Commissioner will have a seat in the Cabinet.

abstract: Hon. EDWARD STANLEY arrived here yesterday, from California, on his way to North Carolina. With him came the San Francisco papers announcing his resignation of an important civil position in that city and his determina- tion to accept the post of temporary Governor of North Carolina, tendered him by the President. The news is in all respects gratifying.
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. EDWARD STANLEY arrived here yesterday, from California, on his way to North Carolina. With him came the San Francisco papers announcing his resignation of an important civil position in that city and his determina- tion to accept the post of temporary Governor of North Carolina, tendered him by the President. The news is in all respects gratifying. A native of North Carolina himself, one of a family profoundly respected throughout the State, a steady and conservative Whig, exceeding popular, personally and politically, he must be less objectionable to the population he is sent to govern than any other possible selection. The war will have done good service to the Border States should it do nothing more than substitute ANDY JOHNSON, EDWARD STANLEY and JOHN M. BOTTS, for HARRIS, ELLIS and LETCHER.

abstract: Daniel H. Craig vs. Francis O.J. Smith. -- The plaintiff in this action was the Agent of the Associated Press, and transmitted the news from England via Halifax, from the latter place to New-York. This action is brought to recover damages for an alleged libel, claimed to have been published in the Boston Daily Courier, in which the defendant charged the plaintiff with cutting the telegraph wire of the Boston and New-York line, in order to give a cypher dispatch to Jacob Little the advantage of time; and also that Mr. Craig was assisted in cutting the wire by a woman. The complaint gives the exact language as copied from the Boston Daily Courier, of Feb. 25, 1859. The defence denies, on information and belief, that plaintiff was the agent of the Associated Press, and sets up that the defendant was called before the Committee of the Legislature of Massachusetts, known as the Committee on Mercantile Affairs and Insurance, and gave his testimony before that Committee relative to the matter of Mr. Craig and the telegraph wires. It also sets up that Craig caused to be published an attack upon Smith in the Boston Daily Transcript of Feb. 16, 1859. Also that the allegations in the article published by the defendant are true. Damages claimed $25,000. Case still on.

The advance guard of the army, under Gen. STONEMAN, Still remains at White House, within sight of the enemy's position.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon the remains of Surgeon NATHAN S. JARVIS, of the Regular Army, were buried with military honors. A troop of infantry, from Governor's Island, accompanied by the garrison band, proceeded to the residence of the deceased, up town, whence they escorted the corpse to Greenwood Cemetery. Dr. JARVIS, who was a Major by rank, was a native of New-York, and entered the United States Army 29 years ago. He died in Philadelphia on Monday last. The deceased gentleman was warmly esteemed by all who knew him, and bore an excellent character. Bad health necessitated his withdrawal from active duty some time since.

abstract: Parson BROWNLOW received last night, at the Academy of Music, such a reception as only New-York can give to those whom it delights to honor. The Parson's courage has been amply tested on many a field, but it must have needed some nerve to face such a sympathetic demonstration as greeted him. He stood the test, however, and confronted the brilliant auditory, the same rough, untameable, irrepressible fighting Parson in propria persona, whom all who appreciate pluck have learned to love and admire. His experiences of life in rebeldom, told with all his peculiar pungency, gave a new idea of what loyalty costs, and could not but stimulate the patriotism of his hearers. Parson BROWNLOW means to return to East Tennessee, to continue the good fight. He is himself a legion, and might safely be pitted against the whole Confederacy.

abstract: Gen. HUNTER evidently thinks that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points. He does not see, moreover, why mathematical axioms should not be applicable to political problems, and is quite inclined to solve the Slavery question according to Euclid. He has issued a proclamation intended to extinguish the institution in the States of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, by the shortest possible process, -- namely, a stroke of the pen. The proclamation is a noteworthy document, and runs thus:

abstract: Haskins vs. Kelly, Sheriff, and Murphy. -- This suit was commenced about the 1st of November, 1861, to recover the value of printing presses and fixtures, valued at $12,000. The property was taken by the defendants, the one being Sheriff and the other his Deputy, under claim and delivery proceedings instituted on the 27th of March, 1861, in a suit in which William Hays was plaintiff and John Miller was defendant. It was claimed on the part of the plaintiff that he had bought and was in possession of the property at the time it was taken by the Deputy. The defendants, on the other hand, maintain that the property was in the possession of Miller, defendant in the claim and delivery proceedings.

abstract: The closing soiree of Mrs. E. SEGUIN's musical "season" was given on Wednesday evening, at her residence, in Twenty-first-street, before an assemblage as select as it was appreciative. The performance of the evening was the Grand Mass of CHAS. WELS, and it was given as it was never before, and never will be again, in this City. The composer, who was present, acknowledged that he had never before appreciated its merits, and was as happy as a composer ought to be to whose music the most ample justice bad been done.

abstract: The late decision of Mr. Justice SWAYNE, the recently appointed Justice of the United States Supreme Court, quashing indictments found against various parties for treason, takes somewhat different views of the law from those which have been presented in some other quarters. The indictments charged the offence to have been committed contrary to that provision of the Statute of 1790, which affixes the penalty of death to the crime of "adhering to the enemies" of the United States, "giving them aid and comfort" -- and they are quashed on the broad ground that this provision of the Statute is inapplicable to the present state of things, because the rebels are not enemies of the United States within the meaning of the Statute.
lead_paragraph: The late decision of Mr. Justice SWAYNE, the recently appointed Justice of the United States Supreme Court, quashing indictments found against various parties for treason, takes somewhat different views of the law from those which have been presented in some other quarters. abstract: In the Senate, the House Bill to provide a temporary Government for Arizona was reported back from the Committee on Territories. It was not acted upon. The House bid, to secure freedom to the people of the Territories, was also reported back from the same Committee, with an amendment changing the language of the bill to that of the Ordinance of 1787. The report of the Committee, of Conference on the Washington and Georgetown Railroad bill was agreed to. A message was received from he President, recommending a vote of thanks to Capt. FARRAGUT and the other officers commanding the expedition against New-Orleans. A report from the Committee of Conference on the Homestead bill was agreed to. The Indian Appropriation bill was considered until a message was received from the House announcing the death of Mr. BAILEY, of Massachusetts, when [???] the customary eulogies, the Senate [???].

abstract: Recorder HOFFMAN yesterday filed his decision in the case of the parties arrested under the late act for the suppression of the concert saloons, declaring the law constitutional and the arrests properly made. It will be recollected that the question came before the Recorder on writs of habeas corpus granted by himself in the cases of Robert M. Butler and John Lea, proprietor and bartender of Canterbury Hall, who were arrested for violation of the law. The cases were argued before His Honor on Saturday last by James T. Brady and Frank Byrne, Esqrs., for the defendants, and by the Assistant District-Attorney, Mr. Whitehead, for the people. The Recorder accompanies his decision by a written opinion, in which, after recapitulating the circumstances of the arrests, and quoting the sections of the law applicable to the case, he says:

abstract: Since Mr. RUSSELL's return to England, his experience in America has been utilized by the managers of the London Times in elaborate articles, analytic of events in America. MCCLELLAN, and his animosity toward Secretary STANTON, are unconcealed. The following paragraph, which refers to a matter of much public moment, in regard to which Mr. RUSSELL had opportunities to inform himself, will be read with interest:

abstract: We publish elsewhere the proceedings of the Republican State Central Committee, and also of the Committee appointed by the Legislative Caucus, at meetings held on Tuesday, with reference to the coming Fall campaign. The object of the movement in the Legislature was to lay a basis of principle for the union of men of all parties in support of the National Administration, and against those who would cripple its efforts to supress the rebellion. The Union movement of last Fall was a matter simply of patrioticimpulse. It sprang from the intense desire and determination of the whole community to crush the military power arrayed against the Government. It ignored all political principles, all differences of opinion upon topics of public concern, and all distinctions of sentiment and purpose on the subject of Slavery.

abstract: Gen. MCCLELLAN's headquarters, we learn from a dispatch dated the 14th, are now established at Cumberland, on the Pamunky River, while the advance, under Gen. STONEMAN, is still at White House, and the main body of the army is concentrating at a point designated by Gen. MCCLELLAN, but for obvious reason not made public. It is stated by a fugitive from Richmond, that between that city and the Chickahominy, a distance of some seventeen miles, the rebels are encamped in large force, awaiting the forward movement of our army, which will probably be not much longer delayed, as our command of the York and Pamunky Rivers has given us facilities for forwarding supplies in ample quantities. The rebels are believed to have blown up the railroad bridges across the Chickahominy. Our gunboats on the James River have not been heard from since Monday last, and whether they have succeeded in passing the obstructions sunk by the rebels, between City Point and Richmond, is of course unknown.

abstract: The National Arms would achieve a very great and permanent advantage in the Southwest, if, while the rebel force is massed at Cerinth, and the Cotton States are drained of fighting men to swell it, a few detachments of our great army could be spared to advance upon and occupy these States their forts, strategic positions and capitals. Louisiana is now clear of rebel sol-...
lead_paragraph: The National Arms would achieve a very great and permanent advantage in the Southwest, if, while the rebel force is massed at Cerinth, and the Cotton States are drained of fighting men to swell it, a few detachments of our great army could be spared to advance upon and occupy these States -- their forts, strategic positions and capitals. Louisiana is now clear of rebel soldiers; and so also is Arkansas and Mississippi (excepting its northeastern corner,) and Alabama. Either, or all of these States, could now be taken and held by a small military and naval force, and then the whole work in the Southwest would be finished as soon as Gen. HALLECK has disposed of BEAUREGARD's army at Corinth. If the rebel army is broken up, it would be rendered incapable of doing further damage or of prolonging the war; and, if, after defeat, it attempted a retreat southward or westward, it would find all the ground already occupied.

abstract: LAW. Recorder HOFFMAN has done the cause of public morality good service by his deflaitive decision in the matter of the Concert-Saloon "Pretty-Waiter-Girl" nuisance.
lead_paragraph: LAW. -- Recorder HOFFMAN has done the cause of public morality good service by his deflaitive decision in the matter of the Concert-Saloon "Pretty-Waiter-Girl" nuisance. It is well known that when the legislative enactment took effect, and those dens were closed by the Police, the chief proprietors banded together to test the constitutionality of the law. Able talent was found ready to do the work of Devil's Attorney, and it was not doubted that they would be able to drive a coach-and-four, or at least several pretty waiter girls, through the enactment, and that, after a brief season of eclipse, the concert saloons would shine forth more brilliant and more bawdy than ever. Two or three of the more courageous Broadway proprietors have even ventured to keep their establishments open -- though in a sickly, half-mourning condition. Meanwhile, all their strength and all their hopes were concentrated on the test-cases of Lee and Butler, which have been fully argued before the Recorder. Yesterday, Judge HOFFMAN filed his opinion, deciding that the arrests were properly made, that the law is constitutional, and that the prisoners must be remanded to custody.

abstract: Among the passengers by the steamer [???], which sailed yesterday for Port Royal, was Capt. RUFUS SAXTON, U.S.A., now a Brigadier-General of Volunteers, the new Military Governor of South Carolina, and the Department of the South, which includes the whole district of Maj.-Gen. HUNTER's command. His Aids accompanied him on the steamer. Gen. SAXTON has already obtained an intimate acquaintance with his assigned field of service, having acted as Quartermaster-General under SHERMAN, during his entire command at Port Royal. His headquarters for the present will be at Beaufort, S.C., until Charleston is taken, when he will move to that city.

abstract: Editorial on European attitudes and rumors of their intervention
snippet: Editorial on European attitudes and rumors of their intervention
lead_paragraph: The very common currency in Europe of the story of an allied intervention in the American struggle has excited an unreasonable degree of attention in this country. There was no atom of foundation for the rumor beyond an anonymous correspondent of the Belgian Independance, a paper which has for several years past traded in a fallacious way upon an old, but now exceedingly tattered, character for accuracy; and which, in relation to our American troubles, has set flying a larger flock of canards than any other European fancier in that line. The Independance found a cheerful echo in the London Herald, the elect vehicle of rebel falsehood in England. The Emperor, this veracious and purely disinterested couple averred, had determined to end the American contest by the offer of mediation, England cooperating; and, this offer declined, to throw the weight of the allied strength in the scale against the recusant combatant. In other words, the fact being assumed that the National Government would repel and resent mediation, while the rebels would grasp it at any price, it was asserted that France and England were about to espouse the cause of the latter, acknowledge their independence, open the blockade, and make war upon the Northern people.

abstract: $20,000. -- The fire which occurred in the five-story building, No. 321 Pearl-street, at 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, resulted in a loss of about $20,000. The fire originated on the third floor, in premises occupied by THORNE & WALKER, book-binders. Their damage is $5,000. They are insured in the Excelsior Insurance Company for $3,000: in the Columbia for $2,000, and in the Market for $500. The fourth floor was occupied by JAMES EGBERT, printer, whose loss is about $7,000. He is insured in the Market Insurance Company for $2,500; in the St. Nicholas for $1,500, Security for $1,500, and in the Park Insurance Company for $1,500. The Fifth-floor was occupied by Mrs. ELLIS, as a book-bindery. Her loss is about $1,000; she is insured for the same amount in the Lorrillard Insurance Company. The second floor, occupied by G.F. BUNCE & Co., printers, was damaged to the extent of $1,500. The stock of BUNCE & Co., was insured in the Relief and Kings County Insurance Companies for $1,000 each. Messrs. LUBLEE & STIHER, occupied the first floor, as a leather and shoemaker's finding store. Their stock was damaged about $1,500, by fire and water. They are insured for $5,000 in the Greenwich and Security Insurance Companies. The building was owned by SAMUEL VERPLANCK. All of the upper stories were destroyed. The damage is estimated at $4,000, and is fully insured in City companies. The origin of the fire is at present unknown.

abstract: OF NEW-YORK, 1862 -- BY D.T. VALENTINE. -- This is the very unpretending title of a volume which has reached its twenty-first birth-day, and which speaks well for the indefatigable industry of the worthy clerk of the Common Council, the compiler. Mr. VALENTINE's volume of this year, in addition to the great amount of local information it contains, is replete with reminiscences of our City which go back far beyond the memory of the "oldest inhabitant," and evidences that he has either some authorities at hand unknown to histrographers of the present day, or that he inserts pleasant fictions to tickle the fancies of the New-Yorkers of 1862. The compiler has, in fact, in this volume presented New-York in an aspect scarcely to be realized by its present denizens, and has furnished information of its early founders, which is worthy a more exalted place in our public records than is given to them by the valuable, but ephemeral volume which he annually issues under the direction of the common Council. Some few years since, Mr. Valentine commenced a history of New-York, but only one volume was issued, and now that the Manual has reached years of discretion, we really hope that the valuable and instructive material at his command will be turned into some more permanent shape, and rendered accessible to all who take an interest in that which concerns our City's history.

abstract: Jarris N. Lake vs. The Artisans' Bank. -- This was an action to recover the value of a certain promissory note. The plaintiff claimed that he had a bank account with the defendants, and that the note in question was discounted by them, at their bank, in July, 1857. The indorsers on the note were Lebbeus Stetson, Daniel C. Bates and the plaintiff. The plaintiff also claimed that the defendants represented that they had protested the note, they being the holders, and that he paid the note out of moneys which he had in the bank at the time, and that he had afterward ascertained that the note was not protested. The defence set up was that it was understood at the time the note was discounted that it should be charged to the plaintiff. On the trial, the only question in issue was whether the defendants, they having discounted the note for the benefit of the plaintiff, were legally bound to protest the note for non-payment.

abstract: -- Parson BROWNLOW, in his speech in the Academy of Music the other evening, proposed, after the rebellion was crushed, and we had "a few weeks rest to rucruit," to "lick England and [???] both, if they wish it; and" (he added) [???] not certain but we will have to do it -- particularly old England." The Parson is a splendid hater, and is privileged to say what would be both ungracious and impolitic from other lips. But he will probably find out, if he stays long enough in New-York, that there is no present call for the proposed "licking." The good-natured laughter and applause that followed this utterance, had a purely ideal reference -- very far from an actual indorsement of the Parson's belligerent sentiment.

abstract: ORPHAN ASYLUM. -- The 12th of May will long be conspicuous in the annals of our colored population. Besides the emancipation [???], commemorative of the set in the District of Columbia, which drew self-congratulating crowds to a prayer-meeting in the early morning, a flag raising in the afternoon, and a grand demonstration at Cooper Union in the evening, a [???], forming a collection of varied and attractive specimens of art, was opened in Mozart Hall. These fairs are only hold once in two or three years, and are usually very successful -- the benefits accruing to the colored orphans. The tables are, as a general thing, presided over by young girls of color; but it is sometimes the case that a paler face than even the richly-complexioned octoroon is to be met -- as, for instance, at the stand called the "Orphan's Table" is always to be found such a one, so great a friend to the cause and the class, that upon each occasion of this kind she feels impelled to leave her home in Troy and adjourn for a week behind this identicaltable. Upon the "Orphan's Table" are placed all the articles prepared by the children, who here snow how much have been appreciated the little scraps, odds and ends, &c., which kind friends have given them. Other tables, too, are distinguished by tasteful arrangement. Upon one is an embroidered cloak of white merino, which will no doubt pass into the hands of some doating mother for her babe. Behind another is hung a white bed-spread, knit by an aged dame of eighty years; its beauty almost equaling its durability, for it cannot easily be worn out. The Brooklyn and Williamsburgh tables each do great credit to their respective localities -- the former being loaded with underlinen, in all the wealth of embroidery and stitching, while above the latter, a lovely Canary carols to the passer by. The "Utility Table," most appropriately so termed, is covered with piles of muslins, laces and linen under-wear, as well as outer garments for children -- as slips, bibs, aprons, &c., and even comprising in its long list of useful articles, the time-honored check-apron, to tie round the waist of good cook or housewife. An indescribable curiosity and study which the most delicate taste must love to linger over, exists in a collection of artificial flowers, leaves and birds, which are a donation from Brazil. One box contains a wreath of soft, white roses, which, upon inspection, are found to be wholly composed of fish-scales. Another has a brilliant collection of leaves, the beautiful sprigs being formed of the wings of tropical insects. Groupings of larger flowers in constantly varying shades, as the glancing light falls upon them, are made up entirely of humming-birds wings, pressed with all the leathers attached. These Brazilian rarities are not to be met with often, and are worthy of examination.

abstract: The United States vs. the brig Delta and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured by the Santee, on Oct. 28, 1861, in the Gulf of Mexico, and was sent to this port and libeled as prize on Nov. 27. On Dec. 17, Isaac and Seth Adams, citizens of loyal States of the United States, intervened and claimed "the brig, her guns, boats, ammunition, small arms and appurtenances," as assignees of Charles W. Adams, alleging that he was the mortgagee, of the vessel to the value of Â£1,900, and had also chartered the vessel of the mortgagor. The claim was supported by the test oath of Isaac Adams.

lead_paragraph: The Sons of New-England met at the Fifthavenue Hotel, past evening, Hon. BENJ. W. BONNEY, Esq., in the Chair, and CEARLES GOULD, Esq., Secretary, for the purpose of making proper arrangements for the reception of Commodore FOOTE, and appointed a committee for that purpose, consisting of the following thirteen gentlemen, with power to add to their number. Connecticut, Gen. P.M. Wetmore and Mr. John Wadsworth; Rhode Island, Rev. Francis Vinton, D.D., Mr. Nehemiah Knight; Massachussetts, Mr. Wm M. Evarts, Rev. S. Osgood, D.D., and Mr. J. Green Pearson; Vermont, Maj. J.A. Pullen, Mr. John Paine; New-Hampshire, Hon. Chas. A. Peabody, Jeremiah Burns; Maine, Rev. R.D. Hitchcock, D.D., Mr. Wm. H. Fogg. On motion of Gen. WETMORE, the Chairman and Secretary were added; as also the three State Agents, Col. J.H. Almy, Col. Frank A. [???], and Mr. Dexter A. Hawkins, Messrs. STETSON & Co. informed the meeting, by letter, that they had tendered the hospitalities of the Astor House to the Commodore during his stay in the City. Gen. P.M. WETMORE, during a glowing [???] on the Commodore, suggested a supper as the most appropriate method of meeting and conversing with him. Rev. Dr. OSGOOD thought that a series of junketings was not the most appropriate method of receiving a hero. There ought to be symbolism more than anything else on such occasions; for his own part he thought late suppers demoralizing, and believed that every man should be in his bed after 11 o'clock. FOOTE was one of the old Puritan stock, with a dash of NELSON and CROMWELL in him, and he thought that some testimonial should be offered, in which all citizens could take a part. Rev. Dr. HITCHCOCK, in suggesting a reception at the Academy of Music, and a supper also, hoped that the speech of Parson BROWNLOW, on Thursday evening, would be [???] and circulated among the [???] States, which would leave JEFF. DAVIS' [???] not worth a pin. Prof. LARNED thought that the Commodore's modesty would prevent him accepting any demonstration. He suggested, however, that Capts. BAILEY and BOGGS be included in the demonstration, and Dr. HITCHCOCK wished to add Commodore STRINGHAM to the list, defending that gentleman from the statements made that he came here to get an ovation. That was not true; he had merely obeyed orders. Mr. ELLIOTT SHEPPARD remarked that the receipts at the Academy of Music had amounted to a nice sum for Parson BROWNLOW, but as Commodore FOOTE was not in want of money, he might be induced to accept a demonstration if the proceeds would go to some charitable object. The Chair. at the motion of Gen. WETMORE, agreed with the suggestion that the Commodore should be [???] some public place, where the citizens generally [???] him. He also agreed with the suggestion that the receipts of such demonstration be made available for some charitable purpose. The meeting then adjourned, and the Committee went into session, and appointed Judge Bonney, Mr. Gould, Gen. Wetmore, Prof. Hitchcock and Rev. Dr. Osgood, a Committee to invite Commodore FOOTE to a reception, and learn from him what attentions can be rendered to him, and report to the Committee in what manner the demonstration could be made. Adjourned subject to the call of the Chairman and Secretary. The Sub-Committee subsequently agreed to write to the Commodore at Cleveland, in accordance with the resolution.

abstract: The death of Charles Jared Ingersoll is announced, in his eightieth year. Mr. Ingersoll, besides being one of the most distinguished members of the Philadelphia Bar, has been prominent as a politician and statesman. At a very early age he was connected with the embassy to France, and as early as in 1812 represented Philadelphia in Congress. President Madison appointed him United States District Attorney, President Polk Minister to France, though the Senate did not confirm the latter appointment. In the Politics of Pennsylvania he was equally active and distinguished, and served in several important Conventions for the improvement of the internal communications of the State, and Reform Constitution. He was an eloquent speaker, argumentative, close and convincing in his reasoning. He espoused the Democratic side in most political questions, and was esteemed one of the best speakers in Congress. Mr. INGERSOLL was also an author of some distinction, and his productions show a wide range of talent as well as of learning and literally taste. He has contributed a poem, a tragedy, and a history to the literature of the country, and it was quite recently announced that he was engaged in a political history connected with the [???] acquisitions of this country. The father of Mr. INGERSOLL was a member of the Convention which trained the United States Constitution, and was a very distinguished [???] and politician in the Revolutionary [???].

abstract: We are  glad to learn that the Naval Committee of the House has acted favorably on a bill to establish new grades of rank in the navy. Ten orders are provided for by the bill, including Admirals, Commodores,  The measure is one greatly needed, and its adoption has often been urged in these columns. It cannot be doubted that favorable action will at once be taken upon it by both the ...
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to learn that the Naval Committee of the House has acted favorably on a bill to establish new grades of rank in the navy. Ten orders are provided for by the bill, including Admirals, Commodores, &c. The measure is one greatly needed, and its adoption has often been urged in these columns. It cannot be doubted that favorable action will at once be taken upon it by both the House and Senate. The man who took New-Orleans is still but a Captain; FOOTE is only Captain FOOTE; and so with DUPONT. All these gallant sailors should be Admirals; as, had their operations been conducted on land, they would certainly all have been Major-Generals. The highest grade, however, should be limited to a small number, and should be conferred as an honor only upon those who have performed the most glorious deeds.

abstract: It would be an exceedingly easy thing just now for a column of our army to advance southward via Norfolk and Suffolk, and seize and possess the State of North Carolina. Suffolk has already been occupied by our troops; from there to Weldon (N.C.) is but sixty miles by the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, and from Weldon railroads diverge to ...
lead_paragraph: -- It would be an exceedingly easy thing just now for a column of our army to advance southward via Norfolk and Suffolk, and seize and possess the State of North Carolina. Suffolk has already been occupied by our troops; from there to Weldon (N.C.) is but sixty miles by the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, and from Weldon railroads diverge to Goldsboro, Raleigh, (the capital,) and Greensboro. With these places in our hands, in addition to the coast line and the rivers already held by BURNSIDE, there would be little else needed to restore the Old North State to the Union, but to install the new Military Governor, STANLEY, at the capital. Nearly all the rebel troops that have been raised in North Carolina are now in Virginia; and a rapid movement from Suffolk would forestall any attempt the rebels might make to throw troops into the State from Richmond. The rebels, it is true, boast that they have an immense number of soldiers stationed at various points in North Carolina; and the organ of the rebels in this City yesterday stated that they had thirty thousand men at Edenton -- a very likely place, by the way, for the rebels to station thirty thousand troops, when a couple of our gunboats in Albemarle Sound, could at any moment isolate and capture them. We do not believe that North Carolina contributed thirty thousand men altogether to the service of JEFF. DAVIS. At the various points we have captured in the State -- at Roanoke Island, at Newbern, at Beaufort, &c., we have encountered but small bodies of troops; and a good part of these have been from other rebel States. At the present time especially, the State is very bare of troops, and would undoubtedly be easily enough occupied. By seizing the three points we have named, also, the main lines of retreat over which the Richmond rebels expect to escape into the Cotton States would be in our control.

abstract: MERCY THAT SHOULD ATONE FOR TARBY JUSTICE.  --The painful rumor comes to us from Port Royal that a mutinous spirit has developed it  self in the ranks of Col. SERRELL'S Engineer  Regiment, and that forty-five malcontents have been sentenced to hard labor on the Dry Tortugas. The fact seems to be that this admirable corps. composed of picked men, drawn ...
lead_paragraph: MERCY THAT SHOULD ATONE FOR TARBY JUSTICE. -- The painful rumor comes to us from Port Royal that a mutinous spirit has developed it self in the ranks of Col. SERRELL'S Engineer Regiment, and that forty-five malcontents have been sentenced to hard labor on the Dry Tortugas. The fact seems to be that this admirable corps. composed of picked men, drawn from every class of our artisans, enlisted and were mustered into service as a corps of engineers -- a department of service in which the pay is about one-third greater than that of the line. The Paymasters declined to recognize the regiment in the character of Engineers; and officers and men refused to take pay tendered them as infantry. The matter was referred to the War Department, where Col. SERRELL, and one officer of the corps after another, endeavored to have justice done, but wholly without success. It is remarkable, indeed, that never has business so dragged in the Department, as since it passed under the control of its actual chief. For eight months without pay, their families without means of support, Government deaf to their crying claim for justice, and obliged under an ardent sun to do the heavy labor of engineers, while receiving no compensation whatever: permission to disband and return to the aid of their dependents denied them, is it any wonder these victims of red tape tyranny should rise in a desperate spirit of mutiny?

abstract: Daniel H. Craig vs. Francis O.J. Smith. -- This case was reported in the TIMES of yesterday. Mr. Craig was called as a witness, and testified that he never cut the wire; that he never told one Greenleaf Howe that he cut the wire, as claimed by that gentleman, and that he never transmitted messages over Smith's line. Evidence was also offered to impeach Mr. Howe, whose testimony before the Committee of the Legislature of Massachusetts was to the effect that Craig had told him that he (Craig) had cut the wire. Case still on.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from merchants and others of New-York was presented, asking for the speedy passage of the Pacific Railroad bill. The Indian Appropriation bill was debated, and an amendment was adopted, authorizing the President to discriminate against those tribes which have taken up arms against the Government. The Confiscation bill, reported from the Special Committee, was taken up and debated until the adjournment.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from merchants and others of New-York was presented, asking for the speedy passage of the Pacific Railroad bill. The Indian Appropriation bill was debated, and an amendment was adopted, authorizing the President to discriminate against those tribes which have taken up arms against the Government. The Confiscation bill, reported from the Special Committee, was taken up and debated until the adjournment. Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, explained that the bill had been carefully prepared by the Committee, who had tried to harmonize the different opinions. Attempts were made to kill it by voting it down section by section, but they failed by decided votes. The Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: We do  not understand that the new Military Governor, which the Military Board of Kentucky ask for that State, is intended to supersede Gov. MAGOFFIN, or in any way to interfere with his legitimate functions. The late Legislature of Kentucky--as loyal a body as ever was convened in any State--did not think ...
lead_paragraph: -- We do not understand that the new Military Governor, which the Military Board of Kentucky ask for that State, is intended to supersede Gov. MAGOFFIN, or in any way to interfere with his legitimate functions. The late Legislature of Kentucky -- as loyal a body as ever was convened in any State -- did not think proper to impeach or remove him; and there is no necessity for any interference with him now -- even if the Government had power in the premises. The duties of the new functionary will relate purely to the military interests of the State -- to the suppression of guerrillas, to the prevention of rebel enlistments, and to watching over any demonstrations which the latent but powerful secession element in the State might at any time attempt. These duties have been utterly neglected by Gov. MAGOFFIN; and some sections of the State -- the extreme west and the extreme east -- have, in consequence, been threatened with outbreaks. There must be no tampering with the rebel brigands -- no doubts as to the propriety of "coercing" them, or hanging them; and, particularly, there must be no secret encouragement given to them by any of the men invested with power. The purpose of the State Board in requesting a Military Supervisor is, that he may look after these interests, and thereby secure the peace of Kentucky, so long disturbed by the rebels.

abstract: The report of the Committee of the Law Institute, in respect to the admission to the Bar of Edwin James, which was now formally submitted, is to the effect, that the Committee find that some of the facts connected with his professional position in England were not disclosed to the Court at the time of his application; and that, for such reason, the order so admitting him should be revoked. It is, however, recommended that Mr. James have an opportunity to be heard, in reply to the report of the Committee, and in opposition to the motion for revocation.

abstract: the surrender of Richmond go about the streets. These anticipations of events sure to happen, are always repeated and exaggerated, and find always a class of people furnished with exhaustless reasons why they may be true.  The New-York Times, Saturday, May 17, 1862.
lead_paragraph: the surrender of Richmond go about the streets. These anticipations of events sure to happen, are always repeated and exaggerated, and find always a class of people furnished with exhaustless reasons why they may be true. Of one thing an impatient public may be assured -- the capture of Richmond will be known to the authorities at Washington as soon as possible after it shall occur; and as it is not a fact that "tends to retard the movements of our army," it will very certainly be sent by the War Department on the wings of lightning to the uttermost corners of the land. It is only when we have suffered a reverse that intelligence is withheld and manipulated, day after day, until the public is maddened with doubt and impatience.

abstract: Congress  has put an extinguisher upon the Metropolitan Railroad Bill, one of the pleasantest little jobs of the session. With swelling promise of opening a much-needed Military and Post Road between Washington and New-York, upon which the time of transit might be reduced by ...
lead_paragraph: -- Congress has put an extinguisher upon the Metropolitan Railroad Bill, one of the pleasantest little jobs of the session. With swelling promise of opening a much-needed Military and Post Road between Washington and New-York, upon which the time of transit might be reduced by several hours, and the fares curtailed several dollars, the bill simply contemplated a new railroad between Baltimore and Washington, with no mentionable advantages over the one now in existence. And this enterprise was to be aided by a loan of Government credit. It required but a first reading of the bill to put it upon the table, where it will lie till the Greek Kalends.

abstract: Editorial on British press views
snippet: Editorial on British press views
lead_paragraph: We copied the other day an article of the London Times, expository of the reasons why the Northern States can never subdue the rebellion of the South. The topic is as stale as the argument; but it is worth while to record this latest of the Times oracles, in order that it may be fresh in the mind of the reader when events shall occur to disprove it. Here indeed the disproof is already perfect. The pillars of the rebellion are crumbling perceptibly as we look at them. The main supports it had to stand upon have already disappeared. New-Orleans and the navigation of the Mississippi; Norfolk and the traffic brought to its doors by the internal improvements of the Border States; the possession of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts; foreign sympathy, to assume in due time a practical shape; the ability of their rams and plated batteries to break the blockade and invade Yankee seaports; all these have come to naught. The manufacturers of Europe have given up all hope of the cotton crop. The pressure of the National armies is such that the chances of protracting resistance and provoking the mediatorial offices of the European Powers, by weariness of a long and apparently interminable war, have wholly disappeared. In fact, the rebels have practically given up the fight, and are only seeking that last ditch in which they stand pledged to die, to leave the substantial fruits of triumph in the hands of National authority.

abstract: Human sorrow is contagious. Few hearts are so steeled to suffering that even the sight of a bear robbed of her whelps will not moisten the eye of pity. Weeping Rachels always awaken sympathy--whatever doubts there may be as to the virtue of mother or children. It is enough to know that the children "are not" to open the fountains of compassion.

abstract: Not a day passes without engagements of a triffing nature, in which, not unirequently, several hundred are engaged. The division of the army under Gen. But in the action twenty of our men were killed and wounded.

abstract: The most important news this morning is unwelcome. A dispatch from Williamsburgh, authorized by Gen. MCCLELLAN, states that the gunboats Galena, Monitor, Naugatuck, Aroostook and Port Royal have made an attack upon Fort Darling, seven miles below Richmond, and have been repulsed with considerable loss. A portion of the fleet had returned to Jamestown Island, opposite Williamsburgh, where seventeen of our men had been interred. The 100-pounder gun on board the Naugatuck explored at the first fire. No particulars of the engagement are given, but they will probably reach us in time for to-morrow's paper.
lead_paragraph: The most important news this morning is unwelcome. A dispatch from Williamsburgh, authorized by Gen. MCCLELLAN, states that the gunboats Galena, Monitor, Naugatuck, Aroostook and Port Royal have made an attack upon Fort Darling, seven miles below Richmond, and have been repulsed with considerable loss. A portion of the fleet had returned to Jamestown Island, opposite Williamsburgh, where seventeen of our men had been interred. The 100-pounder gun on board the Naugatuck explored at the first fire. No particulars of the engagement are given, but they will probably reach us in time for to-morrow's paper.

abstract: How AVOID IT. -- We very much doubt the truth of the statement which comes from that foundry of falsehoods, Memphis, that the yellow fever has made its appearance at New-Orleans. It is probably thrown out as an attempt to terrify and demoralize the small National force occupying New-Orleans, to prevent the sending of reinforcements there, and to operate upon the mind of the North generally. It is between two and three months yet before the season for yellow fever, as an epidemic, will arrive in the South; and it may very well be doubted whether the malign agencies of nature will deviate from their ordinary course to forward the schemes of the rebels, or to sustain the tottering throne of Jeff. Davis.

abstract: -A Washington tolegram states that the Secessionists there claim that the blowing up of the Merrimac is a hoax and assert that she is still afloat. This is certainly a desperate attempt to bolster up their courage. If the testimony to the reality of the destruction -- now fortified by that of several of her officers who were on board when, in a drunken spree, as now appears, it was resolved to blow her up -- be not convincing to even the most skeptical Secessionist, mind, then would they not believe, though the Merrimac herself rose from the dead. Besides, if not destroyed, where is she? Every nook and corner of all the contiguous waters has been explored, and she is not an object one hides in his waistcoat pocket. The Merrimac will never more appear, save, perchance, as a phantom ship painted on a canvas of cloud, seen by some Prester John about the period of the Greek Kalends.

abstract: The tenor of our foreign advices renders it quite conclusive that no intervention in our affairs is contemplated by the French Government, and that Great Britain is irrevocably committed to neutrality. The Paris Patrie certainly admits that the mission of M. MERCIER was political, adding that its purport was previously made known to President LINCOLN. But the Patrie, notwithstanding its semi-official character, has been wholly committed to the interests of the South, and, if it had anything to tell adverse to the Government of the United States, or tending to discourage the projects of the North, would have told it greedily. There is every reason to believe that the facts were of another character, and were, accordingly, withheld.

abstract: We have definite  advices from Washington that the action of the President in the matter of Gen. HUNTER'S order, liberating the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, will be in harmony with the prudent and conservative course he has heretofore taken on this question of Slavery, whenever it has come up for his practical action, in any form. Gen. HUNTER, in the issuing of the order, acted entirely upon his own...
lead_paragraph: -- We have definite advices from Washington that the action of the President in the matter of Gen. HUNTER's order, liberating the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, will be in harmony with the prudent and conservative course he has heretofore taken on this question of Slavery, whenever it has come up for his practical action, in any form. Gen. HUNTER, in the issuing of the order, acted entirely upon his own responsibility, without authorization by the President, and without consultation with him. The course he took was antagonistic to the line marked out for him by the President, both by precedent and by instructions. It was not given to him, nor to any other General in the field, to decide a question of such momentous and enduring importance. The treatment of Slavery in the rebel States is a political problem, and not a military one; and while a commander may use all legitimate means to deprive the rebels of slaves used for military purposes, just as he may deprive them of warlike implements or stores, he cannot step beyond that and declare Slavery itself at an end. Gen. HUNTER was a subordinate of, and acting with, Gen. FREMONT, when the latter declared the slaves of rebels in Missouri emancipated; and he is acquainted with the action of the President upon that order. The policy of the Government has undergone no change since then, but, on the contrary, has been confirmed and illustrated by numerous examples.
headline: {'main': "GEN. HUNTER'S ORDER.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "GEN. HUNTER'S ORDER.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on lessons that may be learned from war
snippet: Editorial on lessons that may be learned from war
lead_paragraph: We hear a good deal said about the evil effects of the war, and no one can deny that such ill effects are to be anticipated. Not only are they to be found in the lives lost, in the sorrow which invades so many homes, in the destruction of property and the heavy load of debt with which the country will be burdened for long years, but they will also be seen in the demoralization of very many of our soldiers, the evil habits contracted in the moral miasma which pervades the camp, and all the bad influences which necessarily spring from war, and especially from such a war as the present.
headline: {'main': 'The War and Its Lessons The Uses of Adversity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War and Its Lessons The Uses of Adversity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on 300th anniversary of slaughter of Huguenots in Toulouse
snippet: Editorial on 300th anniversary of slaughter of Huguenots in Toulouse
lead_paragraph: The 17th of May was the three hundredth anniversary of one of those sad and terrible events which deface the records of humanity. At this late period, notwithstanding the distressing scenes which the conflict of unruly human passions still evokes, civilized nations, by common and tacit consent, agree to let the recollection of mutual wrongs and outrages inflicted in past times slumber. Weakness and wickedness are, or have been, too universal to be charged on any one race or people alone, and, in the general progress of mankind, individual cases of atrocity are, finally, overborne and blotted out of the account.
headline: {'main': 'An Anniversary of Bigotry and Blood.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Anniversary of Bigotry and Blood.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Great Eastern arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left [???]-Haven on the 6th inst. Her advices are two days later than were received by the America. The news is of very little importance The principal item is the assertion of the Paris Patrie, of the 4th inst., that M. MERCIER, the French Minister to this country, had a long conference with JEFF. DAVIS, on the occasion of his late visit to Richmond, and that his visit was entirely of a political character, and understood by President LINCOLN. The Captain of the Emily St. Pierre, who recently recovered his ship from a prize crew and took her to Liverpool, has been the recipient of marked honors, a service of plate and a gold chronometer having been presented him by merchants of Liverpool and others, together with other marks of appreciation of his conduct. The owners of the Emily St. Pierre had made him a present of L2,000, and intended to provide handsomely for his companions. There had been a decline in the Liverpool Cotton Market, and American Securities were strong.

abstract: PORT LEWIS, Mauritius, April 5. -- The bark Cheshire (previously reported) has been sold for $5.000 -- the cargo reshipped per Mercury, which vessel sailed on the 24th ult. A part of the cargo, say some 700 bags, was so badly damaged that it could not he reshipped, and they would not allow it to be landed here; it was therefore taken outside and thrown into the sea. The schr. James Lawrence, from New-York, arrived on the 16th ult. On the passage she lost head of foremast.

abstract: Press observations from North and South
snippet: Press observations from North and South
lead_paragraph: The [???] the [???] and the Revue des Deux Mondes are highly [???] at the prevailing report of a joint intervention of England and France in America. The continuance of useless strife and fearful loss of life seems to [???] papers, whose views on the subject, one would have supposed, from their general tone, to be more enlightened, preferable to any conciliatory steps taken by the great Western Powers to put an end to the calamities of civil war accros the Atlantic, and at the same time relieve a large portion of their subjects from the distress which this hepless struggle is inflicting upon them. Their great ar-gument is that any foreign interference to restore peace between the North and South isan encouragement to Slavery -- argument which is the more curious from the fact of the "peculiar Institution" having survived in the French Colonies until 1848. It is not doubted here that M. MERCIER's journey to Richmond is strictly political, and has direct reference to the war, and it is far from impossible that it may lead to the recognition of the Southern States as a separate nation. I subjoin some remarks on the subject from the new number of the Revue des Deux Mondes, published this day; you will observe that the Revue adopts as beyond question all the news given from a Federal source, although its correctness has been disproved by later intelligence. It says:

abstract: A main reliance of the rebels, during the whole course of the rebellion, as it was during their preliminary labors, has been incessant lying about themselves and us. The lies which they have told about us we have of course been able to contradict as they were uttered. Those which they have told about themselves, in many cases we have not been able to show up, because we could not get at the facts. It has been about as difficult to get accurate statements from the interior of rebeldom as from the polar regions. Their newspapers lied so persistently about us that we could never believe what they said aboutthemselves, unless it told against them, and even then we were quite sure that the half was not told. And thus behind this close-drawn curtain they have built refuges of lies which have helped their cause very much both here and abroad, until they were found out. But now, as our forces are working their way behind this curtain, and getting at the secrets of the prison-house, many a thing is overthrown and made ridiculous which has for a while held forth as fierce and formidable a front as the pretended Quaker guns at Manassas.

abstract: The telegraph announces the withdrawal into the interior from Yorktown, of the Confederate army, and also the ascent of Federal gunboats to West Point, on York River, 20 miles below its formation by the junction of the Pamunkey and Mattapony. The only direction by which our army could reach the interior was up the Peninsula, between the York and James Rivers, through Charles City and New Kent Counties.

abstract: At a public meeting of the citizens of New-York, a Committee was appointed to collect and apply the means of aiding the many thousands of deserving persons, made destitute by the late fire in the City of Troy. The case is one which addresses itself strongly to the benevolent and the generous. Hundreds of families, mostly of the industrial classes, are homeless and without necessary clothing or food, save what charity bestows upon them. Timely assistance will not only relieve present destitution, out will enable the afflicted to recover speedily from the effects of the disaster, by resuming their accustomed labors.

abstract: This magnificent vessel, in command of Capt. WALTER PATON, again visited our harbor yesterday morning, after a splendld run across the Atlantic  having satled from Milford Haven at 2 P. M. of the 7th inst., and arriving off Sandy Hook at 6 A.M., 17th, thus making the passage in much less than ten days. She brings a large number of passengers, a mail and considerable cargo.

abstract: On the 30 inst., the rooms of the Liverpool Mercantile Marine Association were crowded almost to suffocation by the merchan' and mercantile marine officers of Liverpool, to witness the presentation of a magnificent testimonial to Capt. WILLIAM WILSON, of the British ship Emily St. Pierre, for his pluck and gallantry in recapturing his ship, which had been seized by the United States cruiser, James Adger, off Charleston. The occasion was also availed of to present the cook and steward of the ship with a substantial acknowledgment of their bravery, in assisting Capt. WILSON in his deed of daring.

abstract: THE LAST MOMENTS or CANTERBURY MUSIC HALL. -- It would have been impossible for the action of the State Legislature, with regard to the sale of liquors in places of public amusement, to have been more speedy in its operations. Several of the smaller pustules upon the social condition of New-York, it effaced immediately, and on Thursday last, the most prominent of the plague-blotches in our daily life was forever, as we sincerely trust, obliterated. We of course allude to the Canterbury Music Hall. Those luxurious embellishments of the saloon which had been provided to heighten its temptations to the younger and laxer portion of our citizens were on Thursday finally dispersed by the auctioneer's hammer. Surgeons had been of no benefit to the patient. Its constitution had been so rapidly broken up, that the last official had been summoned by its friends to "lay it out," as deenetly as possible. We are happy to say that the mourners were few, with the exception of those more immediately concerned. In other words, the auction was scantily attended. Large plate mirrors -- these surrounded the walls of the saloon -- fetchedfabulously low prices. The smaller minors, on the exterior of the boxes, averaged fifty to seventy-five cents apiece. Chairs went for a mere song. Everything exposed for sale, tempting as its appearance and actual value might be, brought in a merely nominal amount. For the first time since these social ulcers sprung into existence, we looked upon one of them. Let us hope that its extinction was final and complete.

Large plate mirrors -- these surrounded the walls of the saloon -- fetchedfabulously low prices. The smaller minors, on the exterior of the boxes, averaged fifty to seventy-five cents apiece. abstract: -- Six months ago, or a year ago, the capture of Pensacola and the adjoining forts held by the rebels, would have created a sensation North and South. In these days, however, when every week brings us a first-class event, such as the rout of the rebels from Yorktown, or the capture of New-Orleans, or the occupation of Norfolk, things which formerly seemed highly [???] now sink to the level of mere incidental circumstances. Still the anxiety and [???] that for so long a time centred around this region of Western Florida cannot soon be forgotten, and the importance of the capture of Pensacola Forts Barrancas and McRae, and the Warrington Navy-yard, which at one time seemed so great, is not a whit less now than at any previous time.

abstract: SIR: The rear divisions of the army under my command, which had been delayed a considerable time in rebuilding the Duck River bridge, left Columbia on the 21st inst. I left on the evening of that day, and arrived at Savanna on the evening of the 5th. Gen. NELSON, with his division, which formed the advance, arrived the same day. The other divisions marched with intervals of about six miles.

abstract: The Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives have reported favorably on the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs for this port. We find in the Evening Post an abstract of their report, and assuming that it sets forth the document correctly, we are at a loss whether most to wonder at the old errors of fact or the new ones, or the errors in the conclusions drawn from them.

abstract: The record of last week will demand no very gorgeous blazon in the calendar of war. Upon it no victories figure. The Union arms made no advance, by sea or land, tributary to the great result of the contest. In the Southwest Gen. HALLECK continued to press in cautiously but closely upon the lines of BEAUREGARD, apparently rating the strength, position
lead_paragraph: The record of last week will demand no very gorgeous blazon in the calendar of war. Upon it no victories figure. The Union arms made no advance, by sea or land, tributary to the great result of the contest. In the Southwest Gen. HALLECK continued to press in cautiously but closely upon the lines of BEAUREGARD, apparently rating the strength, position and resources of the adversary at their full value, and resolute to afford him no other advantage than that of his elaborate works. In regard to relative numbers of the combatants at Corinth, accounts continue to disagree with more than ordinary pertinacity. On the one hand the superiority is assigned to the rebels, and the dreariest apprehensions are suggested as to the event of a struggle wherein the former is not only admirably posted and defended, and commanded by his ablest Generals, but has the odds of strength in his favor. At Corinth, also, the last ditch of the Southwestern rebels has been located, in order that we may be taught to anticipate there a vigor and tenacity of resistance not herefore encountered. The truth, however, appears to be that HALLECK has a force by one-third greater than BEAUREGARD, and of this greater number the main body have seen active service, stood fire gallantly, and have the utmost confidence in their ability to whip the rebels one to five. Of BEAUREGARD's force the majority are of new levies. When SIDNEY JOHNSTON's command reached the line of the Memphis and Charleston Road, after its retreat from Bowling Green, it is known to have dwindled away to a mere handful. It simply served as the nucleus of an army, alarmingly unsound at the core. BRAGG has reinforced it with ten thousand men from Pensacola. LOVELL is there with the detachment which deserted New-Orleans without striking a blow: the fugitives FLOYD extricated from Fort Donelson and the relies of Pea Ridge are also there. The rest is the ragtag and bobtail of the Southern mob driven into the ranks at the point of the bayonet, and eager for any calamity which shall release them and send them homeward. As to the morale, as of the numerical strength of such an army, we may fairly entertain doubts. No tropical people exhibits the fortitude and persistence under reverse, which stimulate to new efforts, and more desperate exhibitions of courage and daring. There is none of that real elasticity under disaster, which adds ferocity to each fresh encounter. The Southern army has no motive to new endeavors. Nothing but [???] and [???] fill the diary of the last three months, the few incidents of a contrary character being too insignificant to produce any [???] confidence. The misconceptions [???] at Bull Run have been cured effectually. Panic no longer fights on the side of the rebels, who, from the first, have counted more confidently upon panic than upon more [???] agencies -- panic in the cotton market, panic among European manufacturers upon the loss of Southern custom, panic among Yankee soldiery, wherever it should encounter the half-horse, half-alligator braves of the Southwest. Wiser and sadder men, they come to each new conflict with less arrogance and resolution; and of desperation they have little, for the reason that as much is to be hoped, among rank and file, from National as from rebel success. There is nothing either in the force or the spirit of the rebels to excite the fears of Gen. HALLECK. It is only their position which requires his extreme circumspection.

abstract: The steamship Great Eastern arrived at this port Saturday morning, having left Millord-Haven on the 6th inst. Her advices are two days later than were received by the America. The news is of very little importance. The principal item is the assertion of the Paris Patric of the 4th inst., that M. MERCIER, the French Minister to this country, had a long conference with JEFF DAVIS,
lead_paragraph: The steamship Great Eastern arrived at this port Saturday morning, having left Millord-Haven on the 6th inst. Her advices are two days later than were received by the America. The news is of very little importance. The principal item is the assertion of the Paris Patric of the 4th inst., that M. MERCIER, the French Minister to this country, had a long conference with JEFF DAVIS, on the occasion of his late visit to Richmond, and that his visit was entirely of a political character, and understood by President LINCOLN. The Captain of the Emily St. Pierre, who recently recovered his ship from a prize crew and took her to Liverpool, has been the recipient of marked honors, a service of plate and a gold chronometer having been presented him by merchants of Liverpool and others, together with other marks of appreciation of his conduct. The owners of the Emily St. Pierre had made him a present of £2,000, and intended to provide handsomely for his companions. There had been a decline in the Liverpool Cotton Market, and American Securities were steady.

abstract: THE SATURDAY REVIEW ON MR. RUSSELL's CONGE. -- That priggish organ of English intellectual snobbery, the Saturday Review, after throwing weekly ridicule on Mr. RUSSELL during his entire stay in the United States, has, since his return, taken to be slavering him with praise. In its latest issues it has an article on "Mr. RUSSELL's Conge," in which it attributes the prohibition which was put on the Special Correspondent's accompanying the army of the Potomac, to the "envy, hatred and malice of the rowdy New-York newspapers," and asserts that the "New-York [???]" actually compelled Secretary [???] to shut down on Mr. RUSSEL's following [???] campaign in Virginia! Now, as Mr. RUSSELL has already given a full explanation of both the ostensible, and what he regarded the [???] reasons of his conge, the theory of the Review is, to say the least, courageous. Mr. RUSSELL knows -- the Saturday Review, doubtless, also knows -- that the New-York journals (leaving out, always, the one "rowdy sheet" which nobody mistakes for either a type of New-York journalism or a representative of New-York opinion) not only did not "instigate," but deeply regretted Mr. RUSSELL's departure, and that, during his twelve months' stay in the United States, he received from the New-York Press far more courtesy and appreciation than he met at the hands of the Review, which does not hesitate to found a spiteful paragraph on a palpable untruth.
lead_paragraph: THE SATURDAY REVIEW ON MR. RUSSELL's CONGE. -- That priggish organ of English intellectual snobbery, the Saturday Review, after throwing weekly ridicule on Mr. RUSSELL during his entire stay in the United States, has, since his return, taken to be slavering him with praise. In its latest issues it has an article on "Mr. RUSSELL's Conge," in which it attributes the prohibition which was put on the Special Correspondent's accompanying the army of the Potomac, to the "envy, hatred and malice of the rowdy New-York newspapers," and asserts that the "New-York [???]" actually compelled Secretary [???] to shut down on Mr. RUSSEL's following [???] campaign in Virginia! Now, as Mr. RUSSELL has already given a full explanation of both the ostensible, and what he regarded the [???] reasons of his conge, the theory of the Review is, to say the least, courageous. Mr. RUSSELL knows -- the Saturday Review, doubtless, also knows -- that the New-York journals (leaving out, always, the one "rowdy sheet" which nobody mistakes for either a type of New-York journalism or a representative of New-York opinion) not only did not "instigate," but deeply regretted Mr. RUSSELL's departure, and that, during his twelve months' stay in the United States, he received from the New-York Press far more courtesy and appreciation than he met at the hands of the Review, which does not hesitate to found a spiteful paragraph on a palpable untruth.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the cowstables attached to the distillery of S.L. HUSTED  SON, made famous a few years ago by the exposures in LESLIE'S illustrated Newspaper and the investigations which followed these exposures. The distillery is located on the block bounded by Flushing, Park and Franklin avenues and Ryerson-street.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the cowstables attached to the distillery of S.L. HUSTED & SON, made famous a few years ago by the exposures in LESLIE's illustrated Newspaper and the investigations which followed these exposures. The distillery is located on the block bounded by Flushing, Park and Franklin avenues and Ryerson-street. The fire was first discovered in some hay for horses that had been stored in the loft of one of the buildings, and before the progress of the fire could be stayed the stables occupied by ALBERT FREEMAN, PETER CLARK and GEORGE MESHENDORF, capable of accommodating (in the [???] cows are usually packed in swill-milk stables) about two hundred cows, were destroyed. The manufacturers of the swill in these establishments own the stables and let them out to other parties, who manufacture the milk. When the alarm was given, there was great consternation among the employes of the place, for they experienced the almost difficulty in getting the live stock beyond reach of the fire. Many of the cows were in such a weak condition that they were thrown down and trampled upon by the more recent additions to the stock, and several will have to be braced up before they can undergo the process of milking again. The miserable condition of the cows generally, thus summarily turned into the street for public inspection, excited the commisseration of all classes of citizens -- always excepting the "milkmaids." engaged about the distillery, who affected to consider the cows of the best kind, and were disposed to deny the right of any one to express a contrary opinion. One cow in particular, owing to her deformed feet, being unable to stand, attracted considerable attention, and yet the lookers-on were assured that she gave the best milk of any animal in the whole country. There were all kinds of apologies for cows in the lot, turned loose -- long tails, short tails, stub tails, and some with no tails at all. Their appendages were in every conceivable condition, from a sound stump down to stumps in every degree of decomposition -- some in rags and others without. It was a most pitiable and disgusting spectacle. Messrs. HEUSTED & SON estimate their loss at $1,000. The occupants of the cow stables refused to make any estimate of their loss, but it could not have been very heavy, except what may result from the incontinental exposure of their animals.

abstract: A NEW AND DANGEROUS COUNTERFEIT. An attempt was made on Saturday evening to put in circulation counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of America, of this City. Quite a number of the up-town shopkeepers were swindled by the rogues before the fraud was detected. It seems that the counterfeiters had formed a plan to circulate these spurious notes simultaneously in New-York, Brooklyn and Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: A NEW AND DANGEROUS COUNTERFEIT. -- An attempt was made on Saturday evening to put in circulation counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of America, of this City. Quite a number of the up-town shopkeepers were swindled by the rogues before the fraud was detected. It seems that the counterfeiters had formed a plan to circulate these spurious notes simultaneously in New-York, Brooklyn and Jersey City, and had it not been for the telegraph and the Police, they would doubtless have succeeded in defrauding the community of thousands of dollars. The notes are finely engraved, or photographed, so as to resemble very closely the genuine $5 bills of this Bank, and but for the fact that the paper is coarse and poor, the best of judges would be deceived by them. JAMES SMITH was arrested for passing one upon Mr. ELLERY DENISON, of No. 403 Hudson-street. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed the accused for examination. Several other parties, who are known to the Police, will probably be arrested to-day for the same offence.

abstract: -- It gives us much pleasure to be able to state that the Ocean House, in this City, has been re-leased by Messrs. KERNER & BIRCH, the well-known and popular proprietors of the Clarendon, New-York. The superior style in which this celebrated Summer hotel has been kept for several years past, by these most competent and gentlemanly landlords, commends the house to travelers in the strongest manner. We, therefore, have no doubt but that the Ocean House, notwithstanding the disastrous war in which the country is engaged, will be the resort of very many health and pleasure seeking visitors during the coming watering season. -- Newport Advertises.

abstract: A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN to the War Department, dated 10 o'clock P. M. of the 17th, states that a combined naval and army expedition had proceeded some twenty-five miles up the Pamunkey River, from White House, and forced the rebels to destroy two steamers and some twenty schooners. The expedition, Gen. McCLELLAN says, was admirably managed.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN to the War Department, dated 10 1/2 o'clock P.M. of the 17th, states that a combined naval and army expedition had proceeded some twenty-five miles up the Pamunkey River, from White House, and forced the rebels to destroy two steamers and some twenty schooners. The expedition, Gen. MCCLELLAN says, was admirably managed. The dispatch closes with the announcement that the roads were improving, and that the army had advanced considerably on Saturday. An indication of how far it had advanced will be found in our other dispatches. It is now within fifteen miles of Richmond -- at Bottom Bridge, on the Chickahominy River, across which the rebels have now been driven. It is expected that our troops will experience considerable difficulty in crossing, as the country is low and swampy, and the enemy will probably do all in their power to prevent it.

abstract: Next to successes that are utterly incomprehensible, the grandest efforts of Official Intelligence are in reporting defeats that are equally beyond the power of mere human wit to fathom. There is this about the former, however that people soon learn to allow a certain amount in these announcements of exaggerated triumphs.
lead_paragraph: Next to successes that are utterly incomprehensible, the grandest efforts of Official Intelligence are in reporting defeats that are equally beyond the power of mere human wit to fathom. There is this about the former, however -- that people soon learn to allow a certain amount in these announcements of exaggerated triumphs. Men know that there is generally a correspondence between means and end, that prestidigitatorial effects are the exception rather than the rule in real war; and when a preternatural success is achieved with supernaturally small force and loss, the public quietly sets down in its own mind either that the object attained was really of less magnitude than was reported, or that the means employed to effect it was greater, and the price paid correspondingly large. It is not so easy to apply the same process to announcements of defeats, for the very reason that official dispatches are generally too good rather than too bad, and there is no end to the suspense, anxiety and torture to which the public may be put by a stupid employe of the War Department. We have had a good many illustrations of this; but they are all thrown completely into the shade by his astounding report of the repulse of our iron-clad fleet near Richmond, transmitted from Washington with the official imprimatur, and printed in the TIMES.

abstract: Lieut.-Gov. Salomon, who succeeds to the Gubernatorial Chair of the State of Wisconsin by the tragical death of Louis P. Harvey, was born at Halberstadt, in Prussia, in 1828; was educated at the University of Berlin, but came to the United States before his 20th year was completed. Here he began the study of the law -- first at Manitowoc and then at Milwaukee, and in a short time was admitted to the bar. In 1856 he voted for James Buchanan, though in local politics he has always favored the election of the best man, regardless of political questions. At the last Presidential election he supported Mr. Lincoln, and he is to-day a supporter of the most vigorous war measures. Gov. Salomon is not a professional politician; and has been claimed by both the Democratic and the Republican Parties in his State. He was nominated to the Lieutenant-Governorship by the Republicans, and elected on the Republican ticket by a plurality, over the straight Democratic candidate, of 5,471. Gov. Salomon has three brothers in the army, and all have seen service and taken part in battles in this war. Two were in the battle of Wilson's Creek, where Lyon fell, one as Colonel and the other as Captain of the Fifth Missouri. He who was then captain is now Colonel of the Ninth Missouri. The third brother is a private in the ranks.
