abstract: of our iron-clad fleet on the James River was very temporary. By the tenor of the dispatches yesterday, it appeared almost as if our entire fleet had been annihilated. But this morning the news will satisfy the most sanguine. Our gunboats are still within eight miles of Richmond, and the banks of the James to that point have now been entirely cleared of rebel batteries, so that bombketches and other aids can be sent up, as well as supplies. The river being clear and navigable to Fort Darling, it only remains now that that work be reduced, and our gunboats will then probably be able at once to steam up within cannon-shot of JEFF. DAVIS. There is no reason to doubt that they will be able to do this; and if the rebel army has not yet fled across the James, they will also be able to prevent that great rebel "strategic movement." It is altgether likely that the naval force will be the first force to reach the rebel capital.

abstract: George W.M. Silver et al. vs. Kellogg H. Loomis. -- This was an action to recover the value of goods claimed to have been obtained by false pretences. The plaintiff is the master of the barge Susquehanna, and alleged that the defendant obtained a large quantity of flour by representing that he belonged to the firm of Fowle, Hewitt & Co. The defence set up a general denial. The only question submitted to the jury was whether there really was such a firm as Fowle, Hewitt & Co., or whether it was a bogus concern. The jury gave a verdict for the plaintiff for $170 72, the amount claimed.

abstract: -- A letter from a Special Correspondent, in another column, throws instructive light upon the condition of military affairs about Richmond. It may be safe, however, to receive with caution his estimate of the rebel strength. This has so uniformly been exaggerated, too often, we fear,to enhance the value and merit of the anticipated Union victory, as to put the public well on its guard; and at Richmond, as at Corinth, it will be reasonable to deduct twenty per cent, from the rebel numbers, and then to make a fresh deduction for raw levies, the sick, and the disaffected. But, even then, the public certainly shares the wonder of this letter-writer, why the troops of MCDOWELL and BANKS, of WOOL and BURNSIDE, are not advancing with forced marches upon Richmond, to surround, cut off and capture the insurgent army.
lead_paragraph: -- A letter from a Special Correspondent, in another column, throws instructive light upon the condition of military affairs about Richmond. But, even then, the public certainly shares the wonder of this letter-writer, why the troops of MCDOWELL and BANKS, of WOOL and BURNSIDE, are not advancing with forced marches upon Richmond, to surround, cut off and capture the insurgent army.

abstract: Robert Rogers vs. C.W. Ford et al. -- This was an action against the defendants as indorsers in the firm name of "Ford, Stannard & Co," of six promissory notes, made 17th December, 1650, at Fredericktown, Penn., by Z. & C. Donogho, and payable to the order of the defendants. The firm name of Ford, Stannard & Co. was indorsed by one of the firm, and the notes transferred to the plaintiff. The defence of defendant Stannard set up a general denial. The only point which arose on the trial, was whether Stannard was liable, since the firm of Ford, Stannard & Co. was dissolved in July, 1850, and no notice of the dissolution had been given to the plaintiff, who had previously purchased only one bill of goods of Ford, Stannard & Co., for cash. The Court, in delivering its opinion in favor of the defendants, said that Rogers having only purchased one bill of goods of the defendants, and that for cash, and not having been a regular customer of theirs, was not entitled to notice of the dissolution.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rogers vs. C.W. Ford et al. -- This was an action against the defendants as indorsers in the firm name of "Ford, Stannard & Co," of six promissory notes, made 17th December, 1650, at Fredericktown, Penn., by Z. & C. The Court, in delivering its opinion in favor of the defendants, said that Rogers having only purchased one bill of goods of the defendants, and that for cash, and not having been a regular customer of theirs, was not entitled to notice of the dissolution.

abstract: In another column will be found a letter from Col. CROCKER whose capture, with Major CASSIDY, by the rebels on the 22d of April, occasioned a good deal of comment at the time. The peculiar circumstances of the case prompted the suspicion that they must have intended to desert, a suspicion which we freely shared and expressed at the time. Col. CROCKER protests against this as cruelly unjust, and states that they were engaged in the performance of an ordinary camp [???] and neither saw any picket-guard nor had any reason to suppose that they had passed beyond the lines. The first indication of danger that met them was finding themselves in presence of twenty or thirty of the enemy's riflemen.

abstract: Our knowledge of iron-clad vessels is really yet so limited that every lesson is valuable, even though purchased at the cost of vexatious or disastrous experiences. The action at Fort Darling, on the James River, will doubtless, when we receive the full details, furnish some important contributions, and already it has brought out one fact very sharply. The Monitor was struck in her sides several times by shot from rifled cannon of the heaviest caliber, but was wholly uninjured. The Galena, however, was, we learn, severely damaged in her deck and upper works by the shot of the; rebel batteries, -- Fort Darling being situated upon a bluff two hundred feet above the river, high enough to direct a plunging fire upon attacking boats, which could not use their guns in response. Now the so-called "bomb-proof" deck of the Galena is but half an inch (possibly five-eighths) in thickness; of course, altogether too thin to withstand the impact of heavy rifled shot. While she was in process of construction we repeatedly urged in these columns the imperative necessity of adding to the thickness of metal both of her bows and deck. The admonition was heeded with respect to the former -- the half-inch plating being stripped off, and two and a half inch bars substituted, making her bows of equal thickness with her sides. But it was not heeded with respect of the deck, and she was put in service in a condition certain to result just as it has resulted. Our other iron-clads have inch plating on their decks -- butthis is also quite too thin. It may safely be stated as an "acquired fact," that the vulnerable part of our iron-clad gunboats is their deck-plating. Let the Navy Department make a note of it.

abstract: The People ex rel. Ralph Noble vs. The Pilot Commissioners. -- This was an appeal from a judgment at Special Term of the Court, superseding the relator's writ of certiorari, upon which the proceedings of the Commissioners revoking the relator's license as a pilot, were taken up for review. The case has been several times stated in this paper, -- latterly Jan. 23 and Feb. 19.

abstract: With reference to the expected exchange of Col. CORCORAN, the Philadelphia North American, of yesterday, says: "We were, on Saturday, shown a letter from a reliable quarter, by which it now appears probable that Col. CORCORAN will be again with his friends in a few days. The proposed exchange for him has been accepted by the rebel Government. He will arrive in Washington, it is said, early next week. The Councils of the Capital will welcome him in person. A bill for his reception in this city passed the Councils some time ago, when he was expected during the same week. When he does come there will be an excitement among the shamrocks."

abstract: GOTTACHALK's LAST CONCERT. -- The final concert of the great planist takes place this evening at Niblo's Saloon, where he will be assisted by Messrs. MASON and MILLS, upon the piano. He will also be supported by D'ANGRI, BRIGNOLI, SUSINI and MANCUSI. It will be crowded, and there can be no necessity for us to ask the attention of our readers to either the artists or the programme.
lead_paragraph: GOTTACHALK's LAST CONCERT. -- The final concert of the great planist takes place this evening at Niblo's Saloon, where he will be assisted by Messrs. MASON and MILLS, upon the piano. He will also be supported by D'ANGRI, BRIGNOLI, SUSINI and MANCUSI. It will be crowded, and there can be no necessity for us to ask the attention of our readers to either the artists or the programme.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from New-York merchants, in favor of a General Bankrupt law, was presented. M. WILSON, of Massachusettes, offered a resolution asking the Secretary of the Interior for information relative to New-York vessels engaged in the save-trade. The Secretary of War was called upon for information relative to the appointment of staff officers. A bill was passed for the relief of ROBERT SMALL and others, who recently delivered he rebel steamer Planter to Commodore DUPONT. It provides that one-half the value of the vessel and her appurtenances shall go to SMALL and his associates, with the provision that the Secretary of the Navy may invest the same in United States Stocks, the interest to be paid to SMALL and the others, or their heirs. The resolution providing for the presentation of medals of honor to enlisted men was passed. The Confiscation bill was taken up, and Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, made a speech in favor of the principle of confiscation and the emancipation of the slaves of rebels, and urging the adoption of his substitute for the bill reported by the Special Committee. Messrs. DAVIS and POWELL, of Kentucky, offered several amendments, which were rejected. The bill was discussed until the adjournment.

abstract: So great has been the demand of late upon the resources of this Society, that now since the sick and wounded are daily arriving, they have felt it their duty to redouble their efforts. To this end they last night called a meeting of their members, and Messrs. GROVER and BAKER, who have for a whole year afforded them the gratuitous use of their fine rooms, entered into the plan of the meeting by brilliantly lighting up the elegant saloon just above their store. The scene as one entered from the broad [???] case and beheld the gathering of the noble mothers and daughters of our patriotic City busily plying the needle, or working to the hum of the neat sewing-machine, was one rarely to be seen now-a-days. While some were sewing others were laying the [???] together to plan still greater deeds, and the [???] erations proved that nothing would [???] ing out of their [???] lack of material, for with the [???] is manifest to dispose of every fibre that can be made up for use to the soldier, the dry goods must soon be-com exhausted. The past is promise for the future, and the ladies trust those friends who have never yet been found wanting. Now is their time of need. The country societies will not forget those whom their donation so much assisted last Summer. The liberal New-York merchant will remember them when he unpacks his new invoices of flannels and calicoes. The Secretary's annual report shows that one year ago the Society was organized in the church of the Puritans, and that at that time there were five hundred members. That the advancing warm weather caused their number to dwindle down, but that during the Winter they have not only sustained themselves, but assisted other societies, who, knowing of their superior facilities, have asked their aid. They have sent off, for field and hospital use, some six thousand garments. Much has been given away at the rooms, to military men who applied for themselves or for a company. Latterly they have confined their benefits to the hospitals, and their attention has, in various ways, been directed to the sick.

abstract: It would have been difficult to predict, at the beginning of the rebellion, when the theory of "State Rights" was used as the lever with which to precipitate the Southern States out of the Union, that the self-same doctrine might eventually become one of the instruments in bringing those States back into the Union. But there are already several unmistakable tokens that the bane is also to prove the antidote, and none more markedthan the military interpretation which the doctrine of "State Rights" has just received in North Carolina. The facts of this interesting development are related in an article from the Newbern newspaper, which will be found in another column. It appears that when that place was captured by Gen. BURNSIDE, it was reported that Mayor RESPESS, of Washington, N.C, went to see the General. Mr. RESPESS was hereupon arrested by agents of DAVIS in the night; hurried off to Richmond in irons, and thrust into a dungeon. The outrage created intense excitement throughout the State. Gov. CLARK (who is not yet in prison) accordingly sent an imperative demand to the Richmond authorities that the person of the Mayor must be delivered up forthwith, otherwise North Carolina would send a force to back up the demand of the Convention. This effected his release. But the matter does not end here. It seems that the rebel "President" a few days since ordered Gov. CLARK to furnish all the means of transportation and defence possible to aid him in the passage to and through the Cotton States, and also for additional troops. Gov. CLARK backed by the Convention, informed him that he "had received all the aid from North Carolina that he could expect, and that hereafter no more troops would be permitted to leave the State," and has ordered all the North Carolina State troops home. He further informed the Richmond authorities that they could use the railroads in retreating homewards, but they would run their own risk of being intercepted by a Union force at any part of the State. The source through which this intelligence comes leaves no doubt of the substantial accuracy of the whole transaction.
lead_paragraph: It would have been difficult to predict, at the beginning of the rebellion, when the theory of "State Rights" was used as the lever with which to precipitate the Southern States out of the Union, that the self-same doctrine might eventually become one of the instruments in bringing those States back into the Union. But there are already several unmistakable tokens that the bane is also to prove the antidote, and none more markedthan the military interpretation which the doctrine of "State Rights" has just received in North Carolina. The facts of this interesting development are related in an article from the Newbern newspaper, which will be found in another column. It appears that when that place was captured by Gen. BURNSIDE, it was reported that Mayor RESPESS, of Washington, N.C, went to see the General. Mr. RESPESS was hereupon arrested by agents of DAVIS in the night; hurried off to Richmond in irons, and thrust into a dungeon. The outrage created intense excitement throughout the State. Gov. CLARK (who is not yet in prison) accordingly sent an imperative demand to the Richmond authorities that the person of the Mayor must be delivered up forthwith, otherwise North Carolina would send a force to back up the demand of the Convention. This effected his release. But the matter does not end here. It seems that the rebel "President" a few days since ordered Gov. CLARK to furnish all the means of transportation and defence possible to aid him in the passage to and through the Cotton States, and also for additional troops. Gov. He further informed the Richmond authorities that they could use the railroads in retreating homewards, but they would run their own risk of being intercepted by a Union force at any part of the State. The source through which this intelligence comes leaves no doubt of the substantial accuracy of the whole transaction.

abstract: The Macon Telegraph condemns in severe language the conduct of the rebel troops at Bridgeport, by which the most important gateway to our State was opened to the enemy, and the possession of all our rich mines of deposits of coal, iron and saitpetre placed in imminent danger. Martial law has been proclaimed over Charleston and for ten miles surrounding.

abstract: -- What does the militaryexpedition which has received marching orders from Leavenworth for New-Mexico, propose to accomplish? It is not needed now for any purpose in New-Mexico; for the few rebels who have been ravaging and ruling that Territory for a year past have been driven out of it pell-mell, and have fled through Arizona into Mexico or Texas. The expedition cannot be needed for Arizona; for there are National troops enough out of duty in New-Mexico to take care of that region, and to sustain its newly erected Government. It cannot possibly be intended to operate against Western Texas in this way, by a prodigious march of a thousand miles across deserts and plains and over mountains, and amid savages; for there is a short, direct, and easy route from Fort Leavenworth to Texas. Beside, the force composing the expedition, though large, is altogether too small to attempt any operation in Texas; and will probably not get there before next Fall -- if ever.
lead_paragraph: -- What does the militaryexpedition which has received marching orders from Leavenworth for New-Mexico, propose to accomplish? abstract: The United States vs. The schooner Aigburth. -- The Same vs. The brig Sarah Starr. -- NELSON, C.J. -- These two vessels, which have been seized us prizes by the Government, and were condemned in the Court below, are in this Court on appeal. An order has heretofore been made, at the instance of the claimants, for bonding them: they have been appraised for that purpose -- the Aigburth at $900, and the Sarah Starr at $2,000 -- and the bonds tendered. The Marshal has intervened and claims the payment of his fees and disbursements on the seizure and subsequent safe-keeping of the vessels; and, also, for wharfage, towage, &c.; or, at least, that the claimants pay into Court a sum of money to cover these fees and expenses.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The schooner Aigburth. -- The Same vs. The brig Sarah Starr. -- NELSON, C.J. -- These two vessels, which have been seized us prizes by the Government, and were condemned in the Court below, are in this Court on appeal. An order has heretofore been made, at the instance of the claimants, for bonding them: they have been appraised for that purpose -- the Aigburth at $900, and the Sarah Starr at $2,000 -- and the bonds tendered. The Marshal has intervened and claims the payment of his fees and disbursements on the seizure and subsequent safe-keeping of the vessels; and, also, for wharfage, towage, &c.; or, at least, that the claimants pay into Court a sum of money to cover these fees and expenses.

lead_paragraph: No one can be surprised by the announcement that Gen. HUNTER'S military order, emancipating all the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, on the absurd pretext that "martial law and Slavery are incompatible in a free country," is repudiated by President LINCOLN. Gen. HUNTER will be largely indebted to the President's forbearance if he is not recalled. His order involved a very gross departure from his official duty, was utterly unjustifiable in itself, and was calculated very greatly to embarrass the General Government in its great task of dealing with the rebellion.

abstract: In his address to the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER was eminently successful in clearing up doubts attending the right of the National Government to confiscate the property of rebels. There was little difficulty in proving them to be criminals, and consequently amenable to constitutional penalties; and it was no loss easy to prove them public enemies, and therefore exposed to the extra-constitutional penalties imposed by the laws of war.
lead_paragraph: In his address to the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER was eminently successful in clearing up doubts attending the right of the National Government to confiscate the property of rebels. There was little difficulty in proving them to be criminals, and consequently amenable to constitutional penalties; and it was no loss easy to prove them public enemies, and therefore exposed to the extra-constitutional penalties imposed by the laws of war. These points secured, the power of Congress to confiscate, which might prove insufficient under the one, becomes perfect under the other. Some such reasoning as this, it is more than probable, has underlain the general sentiment that the rebels have exposed themselves to the most rigorous visitation of law. It has been the good fortune of Mr. SUMNER, who has brought his skill as a jurist-consult to bear on the point, to make the subject logically distinct.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Sumner on Confiscation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Sumner on Confiscation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The corner-stone of the new Kings County Court-house was laid at 4 o'clock last evening, with appropriate exercises. The Court-house is being erected on Joralemon, directly opposite the bend of Fulton-street, at the City Hall, and will extend through to Livingston-street. The building will have a front...
lead_paragraph: The corner-stone of the new Kings County Court-house was laid at 4 o'clock last evening, with appropriate exercises. The Court-house is being erected on Joralemon, directly opposite the bend of Fulton-street, at the City Hall, and will extend through to Livingston-street. The building will have a front width of 140 feet, and a mean depth of 316 feet. The front will be of the Corinthian order, of Westchester marble, 60 feet high, with a dome rising from the centre to the height of 104 feet. The whole structure will be made in the most thorough and substantial manner, with all modern improvements, and is intended to accommodate all of the county officers and Courts for the next century at least. The whole cost will be about $300,000, and it is estimated that by building at this time -- by reason of the low price of labor and material -- $100,000 has been saved upon the contracts. The work was commenced last Fall, and the building will be ready for use in 1863.

abstract: In re Alansen Nash.--This was a motion to strike from the roll of attorneys of this Court the name of Alanson Nash. The matter was stated in the TIMES of July 20, 1860. The proceeding is based...
lead_paragraph: In re Alansen Nash. -- This was a motion to strike from the roll of attorneys of this Court the name of Alanson Nash. The matter was stated in the TIMES of July 20, 1860. The proceeding is based upon the allegation that in 1852, Nash, who was at the time a judgment debtor of one Caroline Donaldson, made an assignment to her of his interest in an action against the Hudson River Railroad Company, in which one Frederick Ritter was plaintiff, and Nash his attorney. Nash, as alleged at the time, owed Miss Donaldson $700, and this assignment was taken by her in payment thereof. Upon the recovery of the judgment by Nash against the Railroad Company, he failed, as alleged, to pay over to Miss Donaldson the $700 which he had received, and which he had promised her to collect for her. The affidavit of Miss Donaldson was corroborated by that of Wm. B. Leeds, Esq. The defence set up was, that Nash's interest in the suit against the Company was derived from an assignment from Ritter, and that subsequently he ascertained that Ritter had made an assignment previously to a Mr. Haugh, who had made an assignment to Ritter's wife, and that he (Nash) prosecuted the suit for the benefit of Mrs. Ritter. Decision reserved.

abstract: In his official report of the fight at Williamsburgh, Brig.-Gen. BIRNEY says: "The Thirty-eighth New-York, or 'Scott Life Guard,' preserved well the high reputation for gallantry it gained at Bull Run, and although in that engagement and this it has lost fifteen officers and one-third of its numbers, it is still ready to devote the balance to support our flag, I ask that Congress will by special resolution authorize this regiment to place upon its flag 'Bull Run and Williamsburgh'; and the Fortieth New-York, or Mozart Regiment, 'Williamsburgh.'"

abstract: We  We have repeatedly urged upon Government the necessity of establishing a loyal and legitimate Government for the State of Florida. It is now more imperative than ever; and its authority might now at once be extended over the whole surface of the State. Since the evacuation of Pensacola there is not a rebel force in Florida except here and there a few hundred local rebel militia, or some scattered bands of marauders.
lead_paragraph: We have repeatedly urged upon Government the necessity of establishing a loyal and legitimate Government for the State of Florida. It is now more imperative than ever; and its authority might now at once be extended over the whole surface of the State. Since the evacuation of Pensacola there is not a rebel force in Florida except here and there a few hundred local rebel militia, or some scattered bands of marauders. A short term of martial law would soon put an end to these and would restore the State to order, and to the operations of trade and commerce. There is a large amount of cotton on the plantations -- the pick of last year -- that might be brought out. It has not been burned there, and there is no likelihood or possibility of its being burnt.

abstract: The army commenced moving at an early hour this morning in the direction of Richmond, and will oncamp some miles in advance of this place. The advance, under Gen. abstract: MRS. HOEY'S BENEFIT.--Wallack's Theatre will be filled this evening by the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season. The statement may be made advisedly, for the simple reason that Mrs. HOEY this evening takes her annual benefit, on which occasion the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season always does assemble. "A Romance of a Poor Young Man" will be played, though it is a matter of indifference what the entertainment may be.
lead_paragraph: MRS. HOEY's BENEFIT. -- Wallack's Theatre will be filled this evening by the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season. The statement may be made advisedly, for the simple reason that Mrs. HOEY this evening takes her annual benefit, on which occasion the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season always does assemble. "A Romance of a Poor Young Man" will be played, though it is a matter of indifference what the entertainment may be. It is ever gratification enough for Mrs. HOEY's friends and the general public to have a share in celebrating the particular personal triumph which she yearly enjoys under the conventional name of benefit.

abstract: In the Matter of Frederick J. Conant, a Bankrupt. -- NELSON C.J. -- A petition was filed in this case in the District Court, by M.T. Taggard and others, for the purpose of vacating an order of sale, made on behalf of the general assignee of a certain lot of land in the State of Illinois, as belonging to the estate of Conant, the bankrupt, on the ground that it was made through inadvertence, and misapprehension of a true statement of the facts, without notice to the petitioners, or to the persons whom they represent, and to his and their prejudice. The purchaser of the lot under the sale by the assignee appears, and opposes the petition. The petitioners claim title to the lot under a prior sale, by an order of the Chancellor of this State upon a creditor's bill.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Frederick J. Conant, a Bankrupt. -- NELSON C.J. -- A petition was filed in this case in the District Court, by M.T. abstract: is becoming disgusted with the Confederate habit of "lying." In due time it may come to dislike their kindred practice of stealing. But the whole Confederacy rests on these twin supports. But for FLOYD's original thefts they could have fought no battles, and then there would have been nothing to lie about. The Whig says, that when they see it asserted in a Southern newspaper, that the whole National army has been annihilated, they at once know that the Confederate army is to be defeated the next day. The Whig learns slowly, but it is pleasant to perceive that it does learn after all.

abstract: Few subjects now  engross more thought and solicitude at home and abroad than the question concerning the best system of National defence. Each passing month gives some new fillip to public and professional opinion. One by one old faiths are rudely shaken, trampled down, revived, and again slain. The public mind will persist in regarding the public safety as everybody's affair.
lead_paragraph: Few subjects now engross more thought and solicitude at home and abroad than the question concerning the best system of National defence. Each passing month gives some new fillip to public and professional opinion. One by one old faiths are rudely shaken, trampled down, revived, and again slain. The public mind will persist in regarding the public safety as everybody's affair. But the public mind is little furnished with the technical knowledge needed for any conclusive studies on subjects so thoroughly material as that of National defences. Hence we have seen Congress, which mainly expounds this opinion, pursuing a most fluctuating policy, in which, however, our friends across the water have out-shuffled us.

The statement may be made advisedly, for the simple reason that Mrs. HOEY this evening takes her annual benefit, on which occasion the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season always does assemble. "A Romance of a Poor Young Man" will be played, though it is a matter of indifference what the entertainment may be. It is ever gratification, enough for Mrs. HOEY's friends and the general public to have a share in celebrating the particular personal triumph which she yearly enjoys under the conventional name of benefit.

abstract: "A courier from Col. SCOTT's Cavalry, arrived last night, reports that in evacuating Decaturm the enemy battered down the pillars and burnt the bridge over the Tennessee. SCOTT crossed the river on the 30th, and next day attacked the Federals at Athens, on the Tennessee and Alabama Railroad, capturing tents, camp equipage, a number of wagons, and losing only one man. Capt. FENELON, with cannon, proceeded to the next station on Indian Creek. A train from Nashville, with Gen. MITCHELL on board, passed up only half an hour before. Hearing a down train coming, loaded with supplies, logs were put on the track, which produced a 'smash up,' killing several Federal troops and destroying the locomotive. The Confederates, on returning, were pursued by the enemy's cavalry, who overtook them on Friday at Elk River, when a skirmish ensued. The enemy lost twelve men killed, and their Colonel morality wounded. Our loss in the skirmish was only, two killed."

abstract: An arrival at Fortress Monroe from the Gulf brings advices from New-Orleans to the 8th inst., and from Pensacola to the 11th. The, news from...
lead_paragraph: An arrival at Fortress Monroe from the Gulf brings advices from New-Orleans to the 8th inst., and from Pensacola to the 11th. The, news from New-Orleans corroborates to a certain extent what has reached us through rebel channels. Gen. BUTLER landed on the 1st inst., and at first occupied the Custom-house as his headquarters, but subsequently removed to the St. Charles Hotel. Affairs were beginning to assume a more satisfactory appearance in the city. The Opelousas and Jackson Railroad had been taken possession of, and all the approaches to the city had been cut off. Gen. PHELPS had occupied Carrollton, five miles up the river. PORTER's mortarfleet had reconnoitered the approaches to the harbor of Mobile, and had taken soundings preparatory to an attack. Pensacola was evacuated on the night of the 9th inst., as before stated. Gen. ARNOLD, in command at Fort Pickens, had succeeded in saving a portion of the public property. The city and forts had been occupied by our forces, and Gen. ARNOLD was expected to establish his headquarters on shore. The steamer Rhode Island, which brings this intelligence to Fortress Monroe, has on board a number of prisoners taken in the naval battle below New-Orleans.

abstract: Daily News subsided and vanished, its manager has been at a loss to express his secession dogmas with any degree of comfort and safety. Ingenuity at length suggested the veil of romance. Mr. BEN. WOOD became a novelist, and gave to the Press a one-volume story, entitled Love and Secession, which we presume has been read more or less by somebody. Taking courage at the security of this flight in the realms of fancy, Mr. WOOD determined upon a fresh and more daring assault upon the loyal sentiment of the country. A few days ago he sought of the House of Representatives' leave to print a speech, which the House did not care to hear read. Leave was granted; and this speech, which might not unfairly be termed a labor of "love and legislation," appears at great length in the official Globe. And thus, with Congressional sanction, has the honorable member spread before the world opinions which he dared not publish in the News for fear of punishment, and the effectual tendency of which is to lend as much aid and comfort to the enemy as the slaughter of ten Union regiments.

abstract: At a public sale of the property of Rev. H.H. DURANT deceased, on sales day last, the prices which the negroes and land brought clearly show that neither have suffered depreciation by the action of LINCOLN and his minions. House and lot (six acres) brought the sum of $3,510. Woman and two children -- one two years old, the other four months -- $1,219. One man, fifty years old, $355. The major part of the estate was sold previously at equally fair prices. On the same day several lots were contracted for and purchased privately by citizens of Charleston. Among them the beautiful house and lot of Mrs. BOWIE, by Mr. NICKERSON. Others are unless negotiation, and will, no doubt, result in a change of titles.

abstract: Philadelphia are suffering from another of their periodical attacks of Mint-phobia. They are again in consternation over a proposition to create a Mint in New-York. They evidently suppose that Philadelphia would collapse instantly if we should get a Mint. On the whole, considering the wretchedness this business occasions our neighbors, we wish Congress would stop talking about it. The matter is of very little consequence to New-York, but to Philadelphia it is clearly a matter of life and death. Let us cart our gold thither a while longer; it hurts us but little and it helps them a great deal.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions from merchants of New-York for a General Bankrupt law, were presented. He had not concluded whon the Senate adjourned.

abstract: President LINCOLN'S Proclamation, which we published yesterday, is in every respect a remarkable document. It repudiates, in the...
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN's Proclamation, which we published yesterday, is in every respect a remarkable document. It repudiates, in the most explicit and emphatic manner, Gen. HUNTER's order emancipating the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, and puts at rest forever all questions that may be raised hereafter concerning the powers and rights of Commanding Generals in the field to deal with the subject of Slavery on alleged grounds of military necessity. If it ever does become necessary so to deal with it, Mr. LINCOLN says the duty and responsibility of so treating it belong to him. He is the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, and in that capacity will take cognizance, in his own discretion and upon his own responsibility, of all such grave and important topics. The declaration is just and timely. We hope it will have the effect of checking the mania, which seems to have become infectious among our Generals, of issuing political proclamations, -- of settling the political future of the country according to their own ideas. We have had too much of this already. Mr. LINCOLN's proclamation will, we presume, put an end to it.

abstract: Various rumors continued to float about relative to the political significance of M. MERCIER'S visit to Richmond, but they are all apparently disposed of by an announcement made in the House of Commons by Mr. LAYARD, on the 9th inst., to the effect that M. MESOIER went to Richmond without any instructions from his own Government, and that his visit was attended with no political result whatever.
lead_paragraph: Various rumors continued to float about relative to the political significance of M. MERCIER'S visit to Richmond, but they are all apparently disposed of by an announcement made in the House of Commons by Mr. LAYARD, on the 9th inst., to the effect that M. MESOIER went to Richmond without any instructions from his own Government, and that his visit was attended with no political result whatever.

abstract: The corner-stone of the new Kings County Court-house was laid at 4 o'clock last evening, with appropriate exercises. The Court-house is being erected on Joralemon, directly opposite the bend of Fulton-street, at the City Hall, and will extend through to Livingston-street.
lead_paragraph: The corner-stone of the new Kings County Court-house was laid at 4 o'clock last evening, with appropriate exercises. The Court-house is being erected on Joralemon, directly opposite the bend of Fulton-street, at the City Hall, and will extend through to Livingston-street. The building will have a front width of 140 feet, and a mean depth of 316 feet. The front will be of the Corinthian order, of Westchester marble, 60 feet high, with a dome rising from the centre to the height of 104 feet. The whole structure will be made in the most thorough and substantial manner, with all modern improvements, and is intended to accommodate all of the county officers and Courts for the next century at least. The whole cost will be about $300,000, and it is estimated that by building at this time -- by reason of the low price of labor and material -- $100,000 has been saved upon the contracts. The work was commenced last Fall, and the building will be ready for use in 1863.

abstract: Davis vs. Hackley et al. -- This case, which has been so frequently reported in the TIMES, came before this Court yesterday, on the appeal from the order of Judge Barnard, entered at Special Term, granting an injunction and appointing a receiver. Mr. Edwin James stated to the Court that his client, Mr. Davis, had sold his interest in the contract since the injunction was granted, and not having received further instruction from the purchasers, he would not occupy the attention of the Court in arguing the case. Whereupon the decision was reversed.

abstract: DAVIS was going to abandon Richmond. The rebel Legislature of Virginia, seeing the army retire from one after another of the defences of the Capital, began to get terrified that both, the Capital and the State were about to be forsaken by the protecting angels of the rebel army; and demanded of JEFF. DAVIS his intentions in the matter. He replied that he had never entertained a thought of withdrawing from Virginia; but, said he, "if in the course of events, the capital should fall," etc., etc., "the war could still be successfully waged on Virginia soil for twenty years." This is a remarkable change from the assured and defiant notes heretofore given forth from Richmond. JEFF. DAVIS admits the possibility of its evacuation -- as well he may, since the National army has pushed his whole army from Yorktown up to within ten or fifteen miles of the city, and the Monitor is within eight miles of it. But the fall of Richmond does not imply the abandonment of Virginia. It would not do, of course, to admit such a thing at present, when Virginia troops are one of the mainstays of the rebel army. Whether it does or not, however, depends greatly upon the "course of events," of which the rebel chief appears not to have much control at present. It is a preposterous falsehood, worthy only of JEFF. DAVIS, that his army could maintain a contest twenty years after the fall of Richmond, or even twenty weeks. The different columns of our army, those of MCDOWELL, BANKS, FREMONT, WOOL and BURNSIDE, are now so placed that the fall of Richmond would be the signal for a simultaneous advance upon every railroad, city, and position of value in the State. He cannot, of course, flee northward; he cannot flee to the mountains, for it would be impossible to subsist his army there; he cannot attempt to hold Petersburgh or Lynchburgh, while Suffolk is in our hands, and Weldon soon will be. If he thinks to escape from Richmond with his army, and carry on a war for twenty years between Petersburgh and the North Carolina line, he must be as great a fool as he has proved himself a traitor. But this whole talk is evidently intended as a counteractive to the depressing effect upon the rebels of the projected evacuation of Richmond.

abstract: The Journal de St. Petersburgh publishes an Imperial ukase, ordering the State Bank to exchange notes for gold and silver, on and after the 13th inst. The price of specie in exchange of bank notes is to be gradually reduced until it reaches the nominal value. For the present gold half imperials are to be exchanged for 670 copecks, and the silver rouble for 110 copecks paper currency: In the month of August, the price of gold is to be 560 copecks, and that of silver 108 copecks, Further reductions in the price of bullion are to be announced by an imperial decree.

abstract: submits, in another column, a highly ingenious and satisfactory view of the practical working of the President's emancipation policy. He reasons that in the substitution of free for slave labor the State is infinitely a gainer; and it is only because of the temporary inconvenience to be suffered by individuals in losing their slaves that compensation by the National Government becomes just and proper. The beneficial as well as magnanimous character of the President's plan could not be more, effectively stated.

abstract: We saw it stateda day or two since that the sale and circulation of Northern newspapers at Norfolk had been forbidden by Gen. WOOL. There may be valid reasons for such prohibition, but we don't see them. On the contrary, it would seem to us eminently desirable that the people the South should have every opportunity  to become acquainted with public sentiment and the progress of events in the Northern States. The more they learn of movements and opinion here the more rapidly will they become loyal to the Government of the United States. Nothing has done more to alienate them from it hitherto than the lying of their own newspapers; and the sooner this is corrected the better.

abstract: observations from Great Britain reveal rumors of French intervention because Mercier visited Richmond
snippet: observations from Great Britain reveal rumors of French intervention because Mercier visited Richmond
lead_paragraph: We have been agitated for the past few days by continued rumors of French intervention in America, partly based on the visit of M. MERCIER to Richmond, and partly an the tone of the French Press. As to the visit to Richmond, nothing appears to be known about it. M. THOUVENEL declares that he has given no directions in the matter, and the inference is that M. MERCIER's instructions were from the Emperor. Another supposition is, that M. MERCIER went to Richmond at the request of the American Government.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Census report was received from the Department of the Interior, and a motion to print a hundred thousand copies was referred to the Committee on Printing.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the Census report was received from the Department of the Interior, and a motion to print a hundred thousand copies was referred to the Committee on Printing. A joint resolution was reported from the Naval Committee, thanking Capt. FARRAGUT and his officers and men. It was passed. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing suitable bounty for soldiers enlisted for three months and one year. The bill donating lands for the benefit of Agricultural colleges and mechanic arts, was discussed until the expiration of the morning hour. The Senate adopted a resolution to take up to-day the Humphreys impeachment case. The Confiscation bill was then considered briefly, but was postponed to make way for the Tax bill, which the Senate decided to take up by a vote of 33 to 9. Several amendments of the Financial Committee were adopted, including one to reduce the salary of the Commissioners from [???] to [???]. The Senate them went into Executive Session and afterward adjourned.

abstract: The forty-fourth anniversary of The Society for Promoting the Gospel amongst Seamen commonly called the Port Society was last night celebrated in the Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The forty-fourth anniversary of The Society for Promoting the Gospel amongst Seamen -- commonly called the Port Society -- was last night celebrated in the Academy of Music. The auditorium was handsomely filled by an appreciative gathering of the Society's friends, and on the stage were a number of well-known citizens, as also convenient accommodations for the instrumental performers of the North Carolina's marine band, and for the vocalists belonging to the choir of the Mariner's Church -- the latter a bevy of comely girls, sustained by the needful base and tenor elements of the other sex. The order of services was as follows: Music by the band; prayer; anthem by the choir; address by Rev. C.J. JONES, pastor of the Mariners' Church the reading of the annual report; a psalm by the choir; selections by the band; address by Capt. SAMUEL ELLIOTT, Missionary of the Port Society; address by Dr. HITCHCOCK; a collection; "The Star-Spangled Banner," by the choir; remarks by naval officers and seamen, (Capt. BOGGS, of the Varuna, and FERDINAND LUCAS, a seaman of the frigate Congress, responding to this part of the programme;) national hymn, "America," by the choir; the benediction.

abstract: Review says that "the perpetual stoppage of the export of cotton will be averted by those who are concerned, even if it should afterward become necessary to alter future editions of VATTEL. In other words, England will have cotton bye and bye, even if she has to disregard every principle of the law of nations in order to get it. When Mr. SEWARD said that MASON and SLIDELL would have been held in spite of the demand of England for their surrender, if the salvation of the Union had required it, this same Review was horror-stricken at the flagrant immorality of such a declaration.

abstract: NO ONE INJURED. -- The late accident on board the gunboat Naugatuck -- the bursting of her 100-pound Parrot gun, without injuring a single man out of a crew of thirty -- is the first practical demonstration of the correctness of Mr. STEVENS' new principle of mounting and loading ordnance. By this plan, the crew load the gun from beneath the deck, and below the water line, which not only protects them from the enemies' shot, but from injury by accidents like this. The bursting of a gun mounted and used in the ordinary way, with the crow all around it, must have sacrificed a large number of lives. The injury of two men on the Naugatuck during this action was from other causes, after the bursting of the gun.
lead_paragraph: NO ONE INJURED. -- The late accident on board the gunboat Naugatuck -- the bursting of her 100-pound Parrot gun, without injuring a single man out of a crew of thirty -- is the first practical demonstration of the correctness of Mr. STEVENS' new principle of mounting and loading ordnance. By this plan, the crew load the gun from beneath the deck, and below the water line, which not only protects them from the enemies' shot, but from injury by accidents like this. The bursting of a gun mounted and used in the ordinary way, with the crow all around it, must have sacrificed a large number of lives. The injury of two men on the Naugatuck during this action was from other causes, after the bursting of the gun.

abstract: is evidently embarrassed in its advocacy of the rebellion, by the steady success of the Union arms. It adopts the usual resort of persons in that condition: it ignores everything unpleasant. "The Federal Government," it says, "has so effectually suppressed all information concerning the progress of the war," that nothing is known! To remedy this defect, and supply this lack of intelligence, "the friends or agents of the Confederate Government have judiciously established a weekly paper in London called the Index, -- and from this reservoir of Confederate lies, the Saturday Review draw its meagre supply of consolation. "All accounts, however, coincide," says the Review, "in representing the resolution of the South to be immutably fixed, and if the statement can be trusted, no further proof is necessary of the impossibility of subjugation." This is good. It is delightful to find so pretentious and so able a journal as the Saturday Review thus reasoning in a style which would disgrace an idiot. "If we can believe what the agents of the South say of their intentions, no further proof is needed that they will carry them out." Was not the resolution of the South "immutably fixed" not to abandon Pittsburgh Landing, not to surrender New-Orleans, not to give up Nashville, to defend Yorktown to the last extremity, and to hold Norfolk until the last man had perished in its defence? Yet, what became of this immutable resolution at last?
lead_paragraph: is evidently embarrassed in its advocacy of the rebellion, by the steady success of the Union arms. It adopts the usual resort of persons in that condition: it ignores everything unpleasant. "The Federal Government," it says, "has so effectually suppressed all information concerning the progress of the war," that nothing is known! To remedy this defect, and supply this lack of intelligence, "the friends or agents of the Confederate Government have judiciously established a weekly paper in London called the Index, -- and from this reservoir of Confederate lies, the Saturday Review draw its meagre supply of consolation. "All accounts, however, coincide," says the Review, "in representing the resolution of the South to be immutably fixed, and if the statement can be trusted, no further proof is necessary of the impossibility of subjugation." This is good. It is delightful to find so pretentious and so able a journal as the Saturday Review thus reasoning in a style which would disgrace an idiot. "If we can believe what the agents of the South say of their intentions, no further proof is needed that they will carry them out." Was not the resolution of the South "immutably fixed" not to abandon Pittsburgh Landing, not to surrender New-Orleans, not to give up Nashville, to defend Yorktown to the last extremity, and to hold Norfolk until the last man had perished in its defence? Yet, what became of this immutable resolution at last?

abstract: A few months ago the English public was convulsed and outraged by an unfounded story that an American spy had been placed upon the track of a noted British sympathizer with JEFF. DAVIS. Not until the falsehood had been exposed was the heat of John Bull's wrath attempered. It forms a curious contrast with this excessive sensitiveness to-usward, the docility of our venerable ancestor toward the despotisms of Europe. A few years ago, at the bidding of the Austrian Minister, the British Government permitted the Post-office officials in London to examine and suppress correspondence passing between KOSSUTH and other supposed conspirators against the Hapsburgs. And it is notorious that the secret police of NAPOLEON swarms in England, dogs the footsteps of every one supposed to be hostile to the French autocracy; and in the case of refugees from Imperial punishments, hunts them to desperation, and often to suicide. Only the other day Dr. BERNARD, the accomplice of ORSINI, resorted to the latter fearful alternative to escape persecution of this sort. And it is stated that a visit of one of the Orleans Princes to the International Exhibition, the other day, was attended by so undisguised a display of the surveillance as to attract general attention and indignation. It becomes a matter of curious inquiry to know at what period the subjugation of the British Government to the French will be completed. It certainly makes active progress.

abstract: A POPULARERROR CORRECTED. -- An impression has obtained general circulation that the garrison of Fort Macon surrendered with the honors of war. An examination of the Articles of Capitulation, we are authorized to say, will show this not to be the case. The garrison surrendered as prisoners of war, and as such were paroled. Col. WHITE delivered up his sword, which was returned to him by Gen. BURNSIDE; and if the officers were permitted to retain their side arms, it was by the special favor of the General, and not by virtue of any stipulation. The explanation is due to the credit of our gallant and successful commander.

abstract: It is understood that the Great Eastern will be open to public inspection during next week. Some fears are expressed lest the vessel should fall to obtain a sufficiently large passenger list to authorize a repetition of its American trip. The apprehension is, we understand, groundless. Not only has there been a lively demand for passage, but so great is the current just now setting toward Europe, and to so large an extent have the accommodations of other vessels been secured in advance, that the Great Eastern's ample room is likely to be entirely occupied. It is one advantage of the monster that its exhaustless quarters are so nearly equal in comfort and convenience throughout, that the last applicant for a state room stands very nearly as good a chance as the first.

abstract: Roe et al. vs. New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company. -- This is one of six cases to recover certificates of stock of the defendant's Company. The several plaintiffs hold certificates of stock of the defendant's Company, alleged by it to be invalid. In July, 1854, the Company refused to recognize the stock in question, or to permit transfers thereof, and the plaintiffs' cause of action then accrued, and the statute of limitations began than to run. The actions were commenced in July. 1860, just in time to save the statute. The omnibus suit was commenced in January, 1855, and judgment at special term therein rendered in November, 1860. By such judgment the stock in question was declared invalid, and the present plaintiffs were thereby enjoined from taking any proceedings to establish the validity of the said stock, or their claims as stockholders. From the judgment, appeals have been taken by both parties, and such appeals are pending. The company have undertaken the preparation of the bill of exceptions, but the same has not yet been settled. The plaintiffs in the above action moved, at Special Term, for an order that the time to serve the complaints be extended until the decision by the General Term of the said appeal in the omnibus suit, and Judge Leonard granted the application, and the defendants appealed, on the ground that the Court had no authority according to adjudicated cases to extend the time to serve the complaint.

abstract: editorial on question of emancipation in slave states
snippet: editorial on question of emancipation in slave states
lead_paragraph: The telegraph apprises us that a Mass Convention of the "friends of the Administration and those favorable to emancipation of the slaves of Missouri, under the plan submitted to Congress by the President," is to be held at Jefferson City on the 16th of next month, to nominate State officers. We have no means of judging what degree of support this movement will meet in the public sentiment of Missouri. There are thousands and tens of thousands of persons in that State who know perfectly well that Slavery is a blight and a curse to it, and who would be zealous advocates of its abolition if they could free themselves from the prejudices, the fears and the resentments to which the discussion of this subject has given rise. Whether they will act upon their own judgments now, or allow themselves to be overborne by the false and wicked clamor which has led them to the verge of ruin hitherto, remains to be seen.

abstract: editorial lauds speeches
snippet: editorial lauds speeches
lead_paragraph: Parson BROWNLOW is a man of mark. Few men in any position, or at any time, have shown more courage, more endurance, more heroic devotion to principle than he has evinced in his contest with secession in his own neighborhood. Few men in any age are called upon to endure greater tortures, or to pay more terrible penalties in the maintenance of what they believe to be the cause of justice and of right, than the Union men of the Southern States. And while thousands of them have proved themselves worthy to stand side by side with the best martyrs of the worst days the world has over seen, Parson BROWNLOW stands foremost among them in the highest qualities of such a character. No threats, no privations, no tortures, neither imprisonment, nor starvation, nor the instant prospect of death, have induced him even to conceal for a moment his utter hatred and detestation of the infamous rebellion against the Government.

abstract: Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: It will have been noticed as a singular feature of the American quarrel that no intervention is thought probable or practicable, except in favor of the South. Mediation, in whatever form or under whatever name it is to be offered, is universally taken to imply some movement behalf of the Confederates. So completely, indeed, are the belligerents themselves impressed with this idea, that the South casts it in our teeth as a scandal and a blunder that no European arbitration has been yet interposed; while the President of the Northern States actually proclaims a day of thanksgiving for the deliverance of the country from "foreign intervention," which he identifies with nothing less than "invasion." The instincts of the combatants have undoubtedly led them to correct decisions on this point, but the fact is not a little curious.

abstract: We understand that Miss KELLOGG, GOTTSCHALK, the great pianist, BRIGNOLI, SUSINI and Muzio have combined together in an Artistic Committee for the purpose of giving the New-York public one more concert. Seriously, these artists have determined upon appealing to public taste, independent of managerial intervention, and their first concert takes place on Saturday next at Niblo's Saloon. As we always do, when artists work for themselves, and no one interferes with the possibility of either their profit or loss, we sincerely hope that they will be thoroughly successful.

abstract: For two weeks past there has been no little confusion in the political circles of Washington. For a time the most skillful pilots seemed to have lost their charts, and no one could give an intelligible opinion of the actual stage of the war, or of the purposes of the Administration, or of the probability of serious dissensions among our own people, or of intervention in our affairs by foreign nations.

abstract: On the 9thinst., Mr. EDWIN P. CHRISTY, of this City, threw himself from a third story window of his residence, No. 78 East Eighteenth-street, while laboring under temporary insanity. He struck upon the paving stones in the rear yard, and injured himself by the fall so seriously that he died of the injuries about 3 o'clock, yesterday morning: A post mortem examination way held upon the body by the physicians who have attended him since the occurrence. Coloner WILDEY held an inquest, and a verdict was rendered in accordance with the above facts. The post-mortem showed that the fall broke the right fore-arm of the deceased, fractured his right knee-cap, caused a severe wound on his head, and fractured the sixth cervical vertebra, causing a compound compression of the spinal coal. Paralysis ensued immediately after the accident, and continued to the time of his death. For several days previous to his demise he was able to converse quite freely and rationally for a few minutes at a time. About 15 years ago, Mr. CHRISTY started the celebrated "Christy's Minstrels" in this City. During the greater portion of the time since then, he and GEORGE CHRISTY have conducted the business of "Negro Minstrelsy" with great pecuniary success. The deceased was reported to be very wealthy. He was about 40 years of age, and a native of this State.
lead_paragraph: On the 9thinst., Mr. EDWIN P. CHRISTY, of this City, threw himself from a third story window of his residence, No. 78 East Eighteenth-street, while laboring under temporary insanity. He struck upon the paving stones in the rear yard, and injured himself by the fall so seriously that he died of the injuries about 3 o'clock, yesterday morning: A post mortem examination way held upon the body by the physicians who have attended him since the occurrence. Coloner WILDEY held an inquest, and a verdict was rendered in accordance with the above facts. The post-mortem showed that the fall broke the right fore-arm of the deceased, fractured his right knee-cap, caused a severe wound on his head, and fractured the sixth cervical vertebra, causing a compound compression of the spinal coal. Paralysis ensued immediately after the accident, and continued to the time of his death. For several days previous to his demise he was able to converse quite freely and rationally for a few minutes at a time. About 15 years ago, Mr. CHRISTY started the celebrated "Christy's Minstrels" in this City. During the greater portion of the time since then, he and GEORGE CHRISTY have conducted the business of "Negro Minstrelsy" with great pecuniary success. The deceased was reported to be very wealthy. He was about 40 years of age, and a native of this State.

abstract: The new steamship Scotia arrived at this port early yesterday morning, and a full summary of her news appeared in a large portion of our morning paper. We give, this morning, in addition, a variety of extracts from our foreign files, together with the first letter from our special correspondent at the Great Exhibition. This letter will be found to convey a better impression of exactly what the Exhibition is, than can be gathered from the verbose and grandiloquent accounts of the London journals.

abstract: The news from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army is highly important. The headquarters yesterday were but a short distance from Richmond, before which city the main body of the rebel force was supposed to be encamped.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army is highly important. The headquarters yesterday were but a short distance from Richmond, before which city the main body of the rebel force was supposed to be encamped. Their pickets were driven across Bottom's Bridge on Tuesday, by our troops advancing in that direction, while Gen. STONEMAN had arrived at New-Bridge, only about eight miles from the city. At that point the Chickahominy is but a small creek, and can be crossed without much difficulty when the proper time arrives. The rebels had six pieces of artillery posted on the opposite bank, but no crossing was attempted, it not being intended to bring on an engagement at that time. Our whole army, however, moved early yesterday morning, with the view, our dispatch states, of making a long march. To-day may bring us the news of the commencement of the expected great battle.

abstract: Martin vs. Butler et al. -- This was an action against the defendants as indorsers of promissory notes to the amount of $5,000. The notes were made by the Chicago and Fon du Lac Railroad Company, in June, 1857. The answer set up usury, and that the defendants were Directors of the Company, and indorsed as accommodation indorsers. Plaintiff's counsel contended that the defendants were principals. The Court, however, directed a verdict for defendants, to which plaintiff excepted.

abstract: -- The plot thickens around the rebel capital. Our army is now literally before the city; and the public will not be surprised to hear, at any moment, that it has been actually occupied by our forces, or that a great battle has been fought in front of it. If the main body of the rebel army is still on this side of the James -- and here is no reason to believe that it has cross-[???] that river -- it must be concentrated quite close to Richmond, probably on the hills immediately around the city, and in the city itself. It is impossible, situated as our army now is, that it should delay a day in its forward march; while a glance at the map, and a comprehension of the positions held by our forces, and of the nature of the country, will show the almost insuperable obstacles in the way of a rebel retreat -- even if there were not political and moral considerations which make a resolute stand for the capital an imperative necessity. Gen. MAGRUDER's army, we learn, passed over the New Bridge, only a few miles northeast of Richmond, on its way into the city, on Sunday last; and our own cavalry reached the same point, for the same destination, about forty-eight hours later. It appears, by the route MAGRUDER took to enter the city, that it is either his purpose to fight there, or else that he desires to convey such an impression. A very short time, however, must now decide the fact.

abstract: It is an essential ingredient of panic that it should be groundless. The excitement about French intervention displays this characteristic in a marked degree, so distinctly, indeed, that it is a wonder that what we are accustomed to call cool-headed people have yielded so unreservedly to the outcry.
lead_paragraph: It is an essential ingredient of panic that it should be groundless. The excitement about French intervention displays this characteristic in a marked degree, so distinctly, indeed, that it is a wonder that what we are accustomed to call cool-headed people have yielded so unreservedly to the outcry. Never, indeed, was a statement founded upon a narrower basis, or accepted from less credible witnesses. The foundation was the simple fact that M. MERCIER, the French Minister, paid a visit to Richmond; the witnesses to the malign purpose of his errand, were certain covert sympathizers with the cause of treason in this country, and the open advocates of that cause in Europe. Abstract from the business the fact of the visit, or the interpretation arbitrarily affixed to it by the devil's advocates, and there is clearly no more reason to believe in the story of French intervention now than there was three months ago. There is, it is needless to say, the profoundest suffering among the laboring classes of Europe. In France the looms are at rest, and the shops deserted, while the work-people live meagrely at the cost of the Government. In England whole communities, deprived of business, are dependent upon charity; while in both England and France, the manufacturing capitalists are frightfully near bankruptcy. But whatever of this was not true four months since, was foreseen a year ago by the Governments concerned, who believed to the contrary of what was believed here, that the war was to be exceedingly protracted, and that all thought of dependence upon American supply and demand might be at once and for a long time abandoned. No new element has figured in the business to strengthen this established and current European conviction. The only fresh element is the fact of the rapid progress and uniform success of the American arms; the certainty that the rebels are in their supreme struggle; and the strong probability of the war, contrary to all transatlantic preestimates, will terminate with the Summer. And these additional bits of evidence are not of a kind to encourage a departure from that patient attitude of neutrality which the prophets of evil rashly predict.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. It is always a difficult thing to speak fairly of a debutante, and this the more especially when she exhibits so much of promise as as Miss EMELIE BOUGHTON has done in "La Traviata." Her Violetta was most certainly an unconventional rendering of the part, yet it must be confessed that her method wants certainty, precision and finish.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- It is always a difficult thing to speak fairly of a debutante, and this the more especially when she exhibits so much of promise as as Miss EMELIE BOUGHTON has done in "La Traviata." Her Violetta was most certainly an unconventional rendering of the part, yet it must be confessed that her method wants certainty, precision and finish. She has, however, a pleasant and sympathetic voice, and developed in its use far more feeling than ninetenths of our modern vocalists. She emphatically needs study, and without it will never be able to take the role of leading soprano in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. However, while we can deal gently and at the same time justly with the lady, we must seriously remonstrate with the paternal BOUGHTON. Upon what pretence he has ventured before the public, it would be hard to say. A tenure with a "remarkably" small voice, and as "remarkably" small an amount of skill, dressed in a quaintly absurd manner, and moving in a singularly automatic fashion, we might perhaps have said nothing about him but that "harsh justice" may in this case "prove sweet mercy," and possibly induce them to terminate his own operatic career forthwith, and give Miss BOUGHTON that course of study which she absolutely needs before she ran be fairly fitted for the profession which she has adopted.

abstract: A prominent topic  THE SUPPLY OF FOOD. A prominent topic  in the Southern and especially the New-Orleans journals just now is the prospective lack of food, not only fur the armies but for the people of the Southern States. Mr. W.T. PALFREY, who is spoken of as one of the oldest inhabitants of Louisiana, writes to the Planter's Banner on this subject, reminding them ...
lead_paragraph: -- A prominent topic in the Southern and especially the New-Orleans journals just now is the prospective lack of food, not only fur the armies but for the people of the Southern States. Mr. W.T. PALFREY, who is spoken of as one of the oldest inhabitants of Louisiana, writes to the Planter's Banner on this subject, -- reminding them that hitherto the South has been largely supplied with corn from the West, and that not only is this now cut off, but that the Union armies have possession also of large portions of the corn-growing Southern States. The planters, as a general thing, he thinks, have been very neglectful in not providing for this contingency. Instead of devoting their lands to corn, they go on planting cane as usual, "although at the outset they were in favor of the most ultra measures." Even those with whom he has personally remonstrated, Mr. P. says, only profess their willingness to raise as much corn as will supply their own wants. He thinks they ought to consider, and provide for the wants of the Southern States in general, for "a week's lack of food would disband the whole Southern army." Is it not barely possible that these same planters foresee the end of the rebellion, and the time when their sugar crop will again be in demand?
headline: {'main': 'THE SUPPLY OF FOOD.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE SUPPLY OF FOOD.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. W.H. KEIM, whose death at Harrisburgh, on Sunday, is announced, had reached that place from the seat of war, in Virginia, a few days before, and had been laboring under an attack of typhoid fever, and dysentery. He was 49 years of age, a native of Reading, Penn., where his remains are to be interred. He was not a West Pointer, but was for a long time one of the Brigadier Generals in the Pennsylvania Militia, and was well known to the Militia of the State, almost invariably officiating at the inauguration of Governors and other State ceremonies. In the early part of the war he received a Major-General's commission from Gov. CURTIN, and served in PATTERSON's Division, retaining the office of Surveyor-General of the State, to which he had been elected in 1849. Last Fall he resigned his civic office, and was appointed a Brigadier-General of Volunteers by the President, and he commanded a brigade in MCCLELLAN's army. He was present at the evacuation of Yorktown and at the battle of Williamsburgh, but was too ill to participate in the latter conflict. He was looked upon as a good disciplinarian, and a man of good judgment and ability, while his experience in military matters previous to this war served him well in the stead of a West Point training.

abstract: Vicksburgh, (Miss.,) which, according to the rebel telegram, has been reached by Commodore PORTER's fleet, is situated about midway between New-Orleans and Memphis -- its distance from New-Orleans being four hundred miles, and from Memphis three hundred and fifty. It is forty-five miles west from Jackson, the capital of Mississippi, with which it is connected by a railroad. It is located just below the Walnut Hills, in a bend of the river, and occupies an elevated position on the side of a hill, whose highest point is three hundred feet above the river; opposite the city the river is three hundred feet deep. The cotton country around is very fertile, and the most important article of export from Vicksburgh is cotton, of which it ships about 200,000 bales annually. The population of the city was, by last census, 4,600. From Vicksburgh to Memphis the rebels have no defences of importance.

abstract: Our latest advices from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army are to Wednesday afternoon. Gen. STONEMAN's advance was still about eight miles from Richmond, and near Chickahominy Creek, on the opposite banks of which were the pickets of the opposing forces. A balloon reconnaissance had revealed the fact that the enemy was present in heavy force. A good view of Richmond and the surrounding country was obtained with a glass. Heavy firing was heard on Tuesday afternoon, supposed to proceed from our gunboats on the James River.

Heavy firing was heard on Tuesday afternoon, supposed to proceed from our gunboats on the James River.

abstract: The purport of that journey to Richmond, which is to hand Count MERCIER down to posterity, as a more wonderful traveler than MARCO POLO, threatens to elude research as if it were a recipe for compounding potable gold. From Washington we were favored yesterday with information, pretentiously throwing glowing light upon the entire transaction. The French Minister, we were told, acted without express instructions from Count THOUVENEL, but in obedience to impulses, which our Government was prepared to respect, and was accordingly vouchsafed permission to make the progress. The visit, the Administration is satisfied, was wholly without political results.

abstract: The United States steam gunboat Penguin Lieut.-Commanding J.C. WILLIAMSON, arrived at this port last evening from the blockading fleet, leaving Mosquito Inlet, Fla., 16th inst., Port Royal 18th inst., and St. Helena Sound 19th inst. She brings no intelligence of any importance. The health of the fleet was good.

abstract: The Fifty-sixth Anniversary of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of New-York took place Wednesday morning at the Asylum, Seventy-fourthstreet, near the Bloomingdale Road. The day was quite propitious, and a very large audience assembled to witness the most interesting exercises of the children. The large hall of the Institution was quite filled, and the major portion of those present was composed of the gentler sex.

abstract: The accommodations which are being prepared at the hospital in Twenty-eighth-street are of the best possible kind. An application from Government was received last week to provide immediately two wards for the returning sick and wounded soldiers. The singularity of these wards consists of the ample distance between the beds, and the provision of a table and sick chair for each. The wards are very spacious, one being situated upon the third floor, the other on the fourth, or uppermost. They are cool and well ventilated. They will be divided into surgical and medical departments, and will be attended by the regular house staff of physicians. The beds are of good quality, consisting of a straw mattress overlaid with one of hair. Government provides the bedding of the soldiers, which may be of courser quality than that in use at the hospital, but as is always the case, it will be suited to the comfort of the invalids. The hospital provides the linen for sheets, &c., &c.

abstract: It is now just five weeks since a few patriotic women of this City met together to form a plan whereby material comfort could be tendered the returning sick and wounded volunteers, and a temporary rest afforded, where those whose homes lay further on, might recuperate their strength under most careful auspices. The benevolent design was gradually carried out, first by gaining a partial promise of the use of a suitable building, and after a delay of two weeks taking possession of one selected, or rather a portion of it, the Northeastern Dispensary, occupying several rooms upon the first floor. It is situated on the corner of Fifty-first-street and Lexington-avenue, and was built for a Foundling Hospital, to which use it has never yet been put, and probably will not now, so long as a necessity exists for an institution such as it at present represents.
lead_paragraph: It is now just five weeks since a few patriotic women of this City met together to form a plan whereby material comfort could be tendered the returning sick and wounded volunteers, and a temporary rest afforded, where those whose homes lay further on, might recuperate their strength under most careful auspices.
