abstract: The teachers of Ward School No. 45, in 24th-st., between 7th and 8th avenues, have hit upon a method of furnishing relief for the wounded soldiers, which is at once quiet, thorough, prompt and effectual, and, if followed by the other schools of the City, will obviate the necessity of any further public appeals to our citizens in this behalf. The Principal of the school, Mr. JOHN G. MCNARY, after consultation with the Trustees, decided to make an appeal for contributions through the children of his school, who number about 2,200. The appeal was made a week ago by himself, and the female principals, Miss ADELAIDE HAWLEY and Miss EMILY KENNEDY, who simply told the children the nature and object of the contributions desired, and instructed them not to urge the matter upon their parents in any way in case objections were made. The result of this simple and quiet appeal has been that five cartloads of goods, comprising every variety of articles needed for the suffering soldiers, have already been brought in by the children and their parents, and sent off to the Sanitary Commission, to the Home for wounded soldiers in Fifty-fourth-street, to the Park Barracks, to the City Hospital, and to other places where they were needed. The contributions of the first four days after the appeal was made comprised 239 bottles of brandies, wines, &.; 58 bottles of cologne, bay rum and liniments; 753 packages of farina, corn starch and the like; 40 packages of tea, cocoa and sugar; 40 boxes of lint, bandages, old linen, &c.; 240 jars of jelly and preserves; 145 dozen oranges; 51 dozen lemons; 704 shirts; 153 pairs of drawers; 917 other articles of wearing apparel; 155 sheets and quilts, and 223 articles of sundry kinds. In addition to these, were contributions in money, amounting to $[???], which is to be expended in purchasing materials for the girls of the school to make up-the female teachers having kindly consented to stay after school hours and cut out the goods ready for making. The total number of articles contributed, up to yesterday, amounted to 3,664. There are about 75,000 children attending the public schools of this City, and should the example of No. 45 be followed by the others, the subject of relief for our wounded soldiers would be thus brought home in a quiet way to almost every family in the community, and the contributions would far exceed those obtained in any mode hitherto suggested. It deserves to be stated that the Knickerbocker Stage Company voluntarily sent teams around to the school-house and carted away the goods to their places of destination free of expense. They also took, without charge, several stage loads of teachers and children of the school down to the City Hospital and the Park Barracks, to give them an opportunity of seeing the wounded soldiers, and witnessing the good work effected by their exertions.

abstract: Hon. EDWARD STANLY, whom President LINCOLN has chosen to be Governor of North Carolina, leaves New-York to-day for Newbern, the old Capital of the State, and which will be the seat of its Provisional Government. It is  agreed On all hands that Mr. STANLY is the very best man that could have been selected to fill this delicate and responsible mission.
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. EDWARD STANLY, whom President LINCOLN has chosen to be Governor of North Carolina, leaves New-York to-day for Newbern, the old Capital of the State, and which will be the seat of its Provisional Government. It is agreed On all hands that Mr. STANLY is the very best man that could have been selected to fill this delicate and responsible mission. Not less than in the case of Gov. JOHNSON do all the qualities conspire to make Mr. STANLY the fit guide of his native State out of the slough of secession. Born in the Old North State (the house in Newbern occupied by Gen. BURNSIDE as headquarters is that in which Gov. STANLY was born, and his distinguished father died,) he has that instinctive, sympathetic apprehension of the feelings, traditions, principles and prejudices of the people, which is the first condition of successfully dealing with a community in a period of revolution. Having formerly represented North Carolina in the National Legislature, and exercised high legal functions in the State, he is, of course, most intimately acquainted with the Constitution and practical working of the State Government, and will do the least possible violence to the habits and views of that conservative people. Finally, while his instincts and interests will be a guaranty of his sympathy and sincere friendship for the people, he is a man whose popularity and demeanor will conciliate, while his steady patriotism will insure his faithful administration. How Gov. STANLY understands his mission may be inferred from the following words, contained in a farewell letter to his friends in California, written on the eve of his departure for the East to assume his duties:

abstract: editorial on naval operations on Mississippi
snippet: editorial on naval operations on Mississippi
lead_paragraph: -- We have been for a long time in great darkness as to what our fleet really was doing in the Mississippi above New-Orleans. Shortly after the capture of the latter city, we a learned from a rebels that some of our vessels had appeared before and had taken Baton Rouge; then that they were at Tunica Bend; then at Fort Adams; then at Natchez; and now we learn from the same source that that they had appeared before Vicksburgh, meeting nowhere with successful resistance. As all the points successively named are in regular order in the progress up the river, and as the rebels would not be likely to chronicle our successes, if it could be avoided, or if the facts could be misrepresented, it is more than likely that our fleet has actually captured or reduced every town or fortification on the river up to Vicksburgh which is four hundred miles above New-Orleans; and this view is confirmed by the telegram published yesterday from Washington, which announced that part of our fleet had gone up "as far as Vicksburgh, for a purpose which it would be improper to state." It is earnestly to be hoped that Gen. BUTLER did not let this improper purpose out of the bag when he stated in his official report of the capture of New-Orleans, that the fleet was going "to pass up the river as far as the mouth of the Red River, so as to cut off their supplies, and make a landing and a demonstration in their rear, as a diversion in favor of Gen. BUELL." That certainly would be an incorrect thing to do, particularly when it is considered that railroads run from Vicksburgh directly to BEAUREGARD's "rear."

abstract: the name of FAY, residing near the National Road, about five miles east of the city, who has recently excited the wonder of those who have heretofore entertained a horror of snakes. He spends the most of his time in hunting for and playing with reptiles of various kinds, and goes about with his hat and pantaloons pockets filled with them. A day or two ago, a party of gentlemen, who were fishing along Wheeling Creek, met FAY, and one of them, in a sportive manner, took off his (FAY's) hat, when seven water-snakes jumped off his head and ran in different directions. FAY then proposed, for a consideration, to go and bring another lot, which he did in an incredible short space of time, and upon being paid an additional sum of money, actually put the heads of the forked tongued reptiles in his mouth, and bit them off one after another, and throw their bodies away. On his upper jaw the fellow has but one tooth, so that he is compelled to tear and chew the necks of the snakes before he can separate the heads from the bodies. He has made himself so familiar with the habits and hiding places of the water-snake, that he can go out, and in a few moments return with a hat full -- Wheeling Intelligencer.

abstract: The public  has already been made familiar with the fact that previous to leaving Yorktown the rebels planted torpedoes and other explosive articles in the tents, paths, , which our officers would be most likely to frequent. Several lives of Union men were lost in this way.
lead_paragraph: -- The public has already been made familiar with the fact that previous to leaving Yorktown the rebels planted torpedoes and other explosive articles in the tents, paths, &c., which our officers would be most likely to frequent. Several lives of Union men were lost in this way. It was stated, in an affidavit made by a rebel prisoner named GROVER, that these murderous weapons were prepared and distributed under the immediate personal supervision of Brig.-Gen. RAINS, of Georgia, who took great interest in their manufacture and in designating the spots where they were to be planted.

abstract: editorial on Lincoln policy on slavery and on attitude taken by NY Tribune
snippet: editorial on Lincoln policy on slavery and on attitude taken by NY Tribune
lead_paragraph: We have no intention of questioning the loyalty of the Tribune, but we cannot help doubting the efficiency of the support which it seeks to give the Government in its contest with the rebellion. It sustains the War, but qualifies its support by the most damaging drawbacks. The general drift of its comments is that there is only one way of preserving the Union, and that is by abolishing Slavery; and everything done by the Government which falls short of this, or proceeds upon a different basis, is condemned either directly or by necessary implication. In yesterday's issue alone, there are half a dozen instances of this. Thus in a leading editorial, the Tribune says that "if this Union should be destroyed, history will write on its tomb-stone, -- Died miserably of official deference and democratic subserviency to traitorous Slavery." Its Washington correspondence gives expression to grave doubts "whether the several States will promptly furnish their respective quotas of men under the forthcoming call of the President," unless in effect it shall first be decided that negroes may be enlisted. "Some say," writes this correspondent, "that their citizens will demand an Anti-Slavery policy before they will fill up the regiments."

abstract: We are rejoiced to  A FIT APPOINTMENT. We are rejoiced to learn that FLOYD(the thief) has been appointed Major-General of the Virginia troops, with authority to raise 20,000 men to act in Western Virginia. We noticed some time ago that the rebel Legislature of Virginia had passed resolutions urging his appointment upon the Confederate authorities, and we ...
lead_paragraph: We are rejoiced to learn that FLOYD(the thief) has been appointed Major-General of the Virginia troops, with authority to raise 20,000 men to act in Western Virginia. We noticed some time ago that the rebel Legislature of Virginia had passed resolutions urging his appointment upon the Confederate authorities, and we should have added our recommendation to theirs, if we had supposed that it would have added any weight to it in JEFF. DAVIS's mind. But we cannot refrain, now that FLOYD has got the appointment, from characterizing it as one eminently "fit to be [???]," and can only regret that he had not 40,000 instead of 20,000 troops put under him.

abstract: When Mr. LINCOLN said that "the Union could not exist half free and half slave," he ultered a truth perfectly demonstrable, and which was nowhere better understood than in the South. But Mr. LINCOLN did not, as I recollect, give the reason why the Union cannot continue half free and half slave. It has existed for seventy years, with States having both free and slave institutions.

abstract: A large number of wounded soldiers arrived here last night, some by the Daniel Webster, and others by railroad from Philadelphia. These latter left Baltimore at 7 o'clock on Wednesday night; were there crowded on a freight train and dragged along for sixteen hours before reaching Philadelphia. Many of them were terribly exhausted before the end of the journey. All these invalids belong to the army of the Peninsula, and are chiefly soldiers who have dropped, from disease or fatigue, on the march from Yorktown on to Richmond. We append a list of their names:

abstract: To Hon. Ira Harris, United States Senate.  DEAR SIR The Newspapers have informed us that the House of Representatives, with little debate and in great haste, refused to consider the Bankrupt bill, and postponed all action upon it until next December. The manner "of its taking off" was so strange, that the great debtor and creditor interests through our country are all amazement.

abstract: A rather remarkable circumstance was yesterday brought to the notice of Judge NELSON, in the United States Circuit Court, in relation to the cargo of the bark Hiawatha. This vessel was among the first, if not the very first, of the vessels captured as prizes. She was brought into this port on May 24, 1861, and was taken charge of by the Prize Commissioners, who sealed up her hatches and kept her until she was taken by the Marshal under the process issued in the cause. Since that time she has remained in the custody of the Marshal, with her cargo, except a small portion of the latter, which, by a special order, was directed to be delivered up a short time since.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for a General Bankrupt law were presented; also, a petition from citizens of Maryland, asking for the better enfocement of the Fugitive Slave law in the District of Columbia. A. resolution calling upon the secretary of the Navy for official reports of the late naval battle on the Mississippi was adopted.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for a General Bankrupt law were presented; also, a petition from citizens of Maryland, asking for the better enfocement of the Fugitive Slave law in the District of Columbia. A. resolution calling upon the secretary of the Navy for official reports of the late naval battle on the Mississippi was adopted. A resolution was offered by Mr. SUMNER, but laid over, directing the Committee on the District of Columbia to inquire what legislation is necessary to protect colored people from unconstitutional seizure as fugitive slaves. The bill donating lands for the benefit of agricultural colleges and mechanic arts was discussed until the expiration of the morning hour, when the Senate resulted itself into a Court for the trial of the Humphreys impeachment case. The Managers of the case on the part of the House, Messrs. BINGHAM, PENDLETON, DUNLOP and TRAIN, appeared and read to the Senate the articles of impeachment. They received assurances that the Senate would take the proper order in the case, and that due notice would be given to the House of the same. The Court was then adjourned, and the Senate resumed its regular proceedings. The Tax bill was then considered until the adjournment -- the sixty-third section having been reached.

abstract: It is rather a grim  subject for the New-Orleans Press to make merry over, the advent of yellow fever.
lead_paragraph: -- It is rather a grim subject for the New-Orleans Press to make merry over, the advent of yellow fever. They personify it as "Yellow Jack," and represent him as tripping around the streets, slaying his thousands and grinning as he says; they characterize it as "Bronze John," and figure him as stalking around the city, felling his foes who vainly fly before him; they shadow it out as "His Saffron Majesty," with a cadaverous countenance and withering breath, waving his sceptre over universal desolation. And they jocularly announce that it will likely soon make its appearance in the Crescent City and give brief dispatch to the Northern soldiers who have [???] to invade its domain.
headline: {'main': 'THE YELLOW FEVER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE YELLOW FEVER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: REBEL SOLDIERS IN NEW-YORK.?Yesterday fifteen rebel prisoners (formerly belonging to the First Regiment North Carolina Cavalry, and captured about three months since in Virginia,) were permitted to return home in the steamer General Burnside?the vessel in which Gov. STANLEY proceeds to the sphere of his coming duties.
lead_paragraph: REBEL SOLDIERS IN NEW-YORK. -- Yesterday fifteen rebel prisoners (formerly belonging to the First Regiment North Carolina Cavalry, and captured about three months since in Virginia,) were permitted to return home in the steamer General Burnside -- the vessel in which Gov. STANLEY proceeds to the sphere of his coming duties. These men arrived here from Washington very early in the morning, and after refreshment in the Park Barracks, were marched through the streets down to the pier, exciting only occasional attention on the way, for the fact of their being rebels was almost unknown. They were dressed in the usual secession grey, of poor color and quality, but many of them sported Excelsior (SICKLE's) Brigade buttons, which they had obtained by way of exchange with some of SICKLE's men whilst in captivity at Washington. The names of the prisoners are as follows: John Dugg, Wm. Gunns, S. Dillon, Wm. B. Lane, F.A. Jones, W.S. Harttman, I. Phillips, I.W. Barden, W.T. Hughes, G.S. Elliot, J.A. Buggett, H.W. Hare, E.H. Abbott, H. Chesman and J.H. Everett. They all of them still adhere pertenaciously to the failing cause of re-rebellion, and resolutely refused, both here and in Washington, to take the oath of allegiance. They were set at liberty on parole not to take up arms against the United States.

abstract: Nothing in this war is  more conspicuous than the kind treatment extended by our troops to the rebel wounded who have fallen into our hands.
lead_paragraph: -- Nothing in this war is more conspicuous than the kind treatment extended by our troops to the rebel wounded who have fallen into our hands. At Williamsburgh after the battle this was especially noticeable. When our army entered the town, they found it full of sick and wounded, whom the rebels in their retreat had been forced to leave. They were at once attended to by our surgeons, -- cared for by our nurses, and everything possible done for their comfort. We heard from scores and hundreds of them the most grateful acknowledgments for the kindness they had received, coupled always with the remark that they been taught to expect very different treatment.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER. -- A man named JOHN FAY was sent to the Penitentiary Thursday for six months, by Justice ADAMS, for beating his wife with the leg of a chair. The prisoner resides at No. 4 Franklin-place, and the attention of Capt. JACOBS and Sergeant CRAFT, of the Forty-second Precinct, was called to the house on Tuesday night, by the cries of a woman in distress. They forced open the door leading to the apartments occupied by FAY, and discovered him beating his wife with a heavy chair leg, and had injured her seriously if not fatally. FAY was secured, and upon examining the room they found a daughter of the prisoner 6 years old, who had been scalded a few days before by her father throwing a pot of hot soup upon her. The upper part of her person was covered with blisters. It is supposed she cannot recover. The mother and daughter were sent to the Hospital at Flatbush yesterday.

abstract: A statement from the War Department is to the effect that no dispatches have been received from the vicinity of Richmond since Thursday, up to which time no engagement had taken place. More definite intelligence is contained in a dispatch to the Baltimore American from Fortress Monroe ...
lead_paragraph: A statement from the War Department is to the effect that no dispatches have been received from the vicinity of Richmond since Thursday, up to which time no engagement had taken place. More definite intelligence is contained in a dispatch to the Baltimore American from Fortress Monroe reproduced in our columns. The First Grand Division of the army had already commenced crossing Bottom's Bridge, and the Second Division was crossing the Chickahominy at New-Bridge -- the advance being already within five miles of Richmond, to which point the entire rebel army appears to have fallen back, with very little effort to check our onward movement. There was a rumor that a proposition for an armistice of ten days had been made by the rebels. There is probably no more foundation for this rumor than there was for a similar one relative to the rebels at Corinth. At any rate, such a proposition could not for a moment be entertained. There appears to be no doubt that the condition of the rebels at Richmond is becoming more and more desperate. The scarcity of provisions is represented by refugees to be very great, even the rebel soldiers being on half rations. Notwithstanding the fact that JEFF. DAVIS and the military authorities declared their intention to fight to the last in defence of the city, it was strongly suspected that it would be abandoned after a show of fight over the defences surrounding it, -- in which case fears were entertained that the soldiers from the Gulf States would fire the city, threats to that effect having been freely uttered. It is asserted that BEAUREGARD arrived at Richmond on Tuesday last; but it is doubtful if even he can make anything out of the partially armed mob of which the rebel army now seems to be composed. Its numbers are estimated at about 200,000, including the recent levies under the conscription law, which is still being rigorously enforced.

abstract: NIBLO's SALOON -- THE GALA MATINEE. -- This morning Miss KELLOGG, with GOTTSCHALK and BRIGNOLI, give a matinee under the above festive soubriquet, at Niblo's Saloon. They will be assisted by SUSINI. The body of the entertainment will be opera ("La Figlia del Reggimento,") conducted by the baton of MUZIO, and GOTTSCHALK will perform in the entre-acte. We have little doubt that the female fashable world of New-York will be fully represented at this artistic matinee, of which we understand that BRIGNOLI is the principal manager.

abstract: We attach no importance to the report that the rebels at Richmond have asked an armistice for five days. It rests upon no better authority than the conjecture of a newspaper correspondent, who gives it as the explanation ...
lead_paragraph: We attach no importance to the report that the rebels at Richmond have asked an armistice for five days. It rests upon no better authority than the conjecture of a newspaper correspondent, who gives it as the explanation of a flag of truce which had reached headquarters. We do not believe that any such request has been made. The rebels could have had no object in making it which would not be defeated by the very fact of making it. If they intend to fight, the only motive of an armistice would be to gain time for preparation. If they intend to retreat, the only motive of an armistice would be to secure the removal of their stores and the safe withdrawal of their army. The very fact of asking time for the accomplishment of either object would stimulate Gen. MCCLELLAN to press forward with increased rapidity in order to defeat them both.

abstract: To-day Gen. STONEMAN'S Brigade advanced to within 14 miles of Richmond. They left their encampment near the White House at daybreak this morning, and, preceded by the Signal Corps, pushed on to a point six miles above Tunstalt's Station. Here they halted for about an hour, and leaving the wagons, and a small force to guard them, proceeded onward.

abstract: The offi  cers and agents of the Army Sanitary Commission are doing most excellent work on the peninsula.
lead_paragraph: -- The officers and agents of the Army Sanitary Commission are doing most excellent work on the peninsula. The Commission is now working in perfect harmony with the regular medical authorities of the army; and it not only relieves these authorities of a large part of their overwhelming labors, but performs duties toward the sick and wounded soldiers which would otherwise be neglected. The work which it did for a long time in the camp is now changed to, or rather has added to it, work in the field. Since active operations began before Yorktown, these labors have been immense. The disabled at the different battles, those sick from exposure, from the malaria of the peninsula, and other causes, have been put almost entirely in its charge. The very excellent plan has now been adopted of removing all patients as soon as possible from the insalubrious vicinity of the battle-fields, and taking them where their wants can be better ministered to, and where the climate will be more agreeable to their enfeebled constitutions. Within the last fortnight, two thousand patients have arrived in this City alone from the military hospitals at Yorktown and Newbern, nearly all of them on board the hospital transports of the Sanitary Commission, and under its care. In a single day of the present month, twenty-five hundred patients, it is reported, were made over to the Commission by the military authorities, and by it were provided for. This involved an amount of labor which it would require actual observation to properly estimate or to appreciate. We give in our present issue an interesting report of some of the recent operations of the body on the peninsula, from the pen of Mr. OLMSTED, its General Secretary.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER'S resolution, inquiring of the Judiciary Committee whether any further legislation is necessary to protect persons of African desert in the District of Columbia, was adopted. A bill for the reorganization of the Courts of the District was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER's resolution, inquiring of the Judiciary Committee whether any further legislation is necessary to protect persons of African desert in the District of Columbia, was adopted. A bill for the reorganization of the Courts of the District was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill requiring that the nominations of staff officers shall be sent to the Senate for confirmation, was passed. The Tax bill was then taken up, and gone through with to the seventy-fifth section, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Probably no man in the country has been subjected to more steady and vehement vitup nation that Mr. D.H. CRAIG, the New-York agent of the Associated Press. The delicate nature of his duties, the number of persons whom he is required to serve, and the number, almost as great, of those with whose supposed interests his offices interfere, expose him to assaults and aspersions of every kind. One of his oldest, most violent and determined opponents is F.O.J. SMITH, Esq., of Portland, who has endeavored in every possible way to destroy Mr. CRAIG's business by destroying his character. His assertions at last became so definite that Mr. CRAIG held him to a legal responsibility, and required him to prove them. The trial was closed on Thursday and resulted in a verdict of $750 for Mr. CRAIG. Mr. SMITH failed to substantiate a single one of the damaging aspersions he had made upon Mr. CRAIG. We consider this a result in which the public has a decided interest. As the Telegraphic Agent of the whole Press, Mr. CRAIG's position is one of great public responsibility, and it is highly important that the public should have confidence in the good faith and integrity with which its duties are performed. The verdict of the Jury in this case, pronounced after a laborious and very careful investigation of the charges brought against him, is unequivocally in his favor.

abstract: The  call for an additional supply of volunteers, to the number of fifty thousand, meets with the quick unquestioning response that might have been anticipated.
lead_paragraph: -- The call for an additional supply of volunteers, to the number of fifty thousand, meets with the quick unquestioning response that might have been anticipated. Many of the States have already expressed their readiness to immediately put their quota on foot, and to-day an order will be issued from the Adjutant-General's Department for additional volunteers from the State of New-York. The order of the War Department, a couple of months ago, commanding that recruiting should cease, was received with disappointment; the present opening, accordingly, will be gladly embraced, and there is no doubt that in a week the full number will be under marching orders. An official telegram from Washington volunteers the information that the present recruiting is simply for the purpose of filling up regiments in the field, and organizing a small reserve. But there was no need of the explanation. Not a whisper of reluctance is heard, nor is there any holding back that the purpose of the Government in the conduct of the war may be criticised or questioned. The people have confidence that the programme these troops will aid in carrying out is a legitimate and a worthy one; and the President may depend on it that all the force needed shall be forthcoming.

abstract: Editorial on Journal of Commerce ideas of peaceful settlement of war
snippet: Editorial on Journal of Commerce ideas of peaceful settlement of war
lead_paragraph: The Journal of Commerce is calling for "conservative" demonstrations at the North, and from the Administration, as essential to the development of a Union sentiment in the Southern States. If we understood better what the Journal means, we should be better prepared to judge of the justice and wisdom of its demand. The end it professes to seek -- the development of Unionism at the South -- is infinitely, desirable. Anything fair and just, which will bring about that end, without sacrificing other objects still more important, deserves the most favorable consideration.

abstract: Another bad affair has occurred on the James River, resulting in the loss of a whole boat's crew and several of the officers of the gunboat Wachusett. It appears that on Saturday last, when the fleet, consisting of the Wachusett, Capt. SMITH, the Monitor, the Galena, the Port Royal and Aroostook, anchored off City Point, the people came down with flags of truce, and suspended white flags at every prominent point. Capt. SMITH accordingly landed, and found the inhabitants of the little town to consist largely of women and children, who made the most earnest protestations of opposition to the war, and that they were suffering for many of the necessaries of life. In fact, the desire for peace among them was so great that many of them professed Union sentiments, and Capt. SMITH returned to the vessel highly pleased with the people, and deeply commiserating their condition. Arrangements were made to receive from them vegetables, and some assistance was given to the most destitute.

abstract: In the early days of Abolition the evangelists of that ilk were used to achieve pathetic pictorial effects by delineating a leash of some dozen negroes, old and young, driven along in their bonds by the lash of a truculent overseer, while in the background stood the ...
lead_paragraph: In the early days of Abolition the evangelists of that ilk were used to achieve pathetic pictorial effects by delineating a leash of some dozen negroes, old and young, driven along in their bonds by the lash of a truculent overseer, while in the background stood the National Capitol, with the flag flying from the dome. The author of this telling antithesis would be unequal to realize the spectacle presented to-day in the District of Columbia. Slavery has just been abolished by an act, the intention of which met the cordial approval of the loyal people of the country. No longer was the seat of National Government to be the theatre of systematized outrage upon the rights of a race. The Slave-trade was brushed away long ago; Slavery had followed. So far as the National Government was concerned, the vexed and vexations question had been laid to rest. And what, now proves to be the fact? The District, so far from being freed from the horrors of Slavery, has now become exhibition grounds of their most repulsive forms. The streets of the City, and the shaded walks about the capitol, ring with the clamor of slave hunts. The negroes in Maryland have heard that slaves in the District are free. They see the serfs of the other day reveling in all the delight and dignity of self-ownership. They note the negroes of Virginia pouring over the Potomac, and unmolested urging their quest of a millennial North. They, too, seek freedom in the District. Their masters pursue them. The Marshal of the District, one LAMON, eagerly anticipates all legal doubts and decisions, by lending the civil energies of National authority to the chase. The negroes are caught, and then steps in another claimant. The Military Governor of Washington has explicit orders to look after the blacks. None of them is to go back, unless to a master of undoubted loyalty; and the schemes of the professional kidnapper have to be baulked. Here is apparently a quite sufficient conflict of powers. But this is not all. The people, impatient at the tardiness of their servants, now and then take a hand in person -- as the other day, when a regiment of Union-saving soldiers, passing through the Capital, resolved itself into a mob for the rescue of a hapless runaway from his hunters. Conflicts between the myrmidons of LAMON and the troopers of Gen. WADSWORTH are of daily occurrence, but are insignificant beside this wild outbreak of an indignant soldiery.

abstract: In another part of our journal we quote some interesting items, received via California, relative to the intrigues of the Secessionists in Sonora and Chihuahua.
lead_paragraph: -- In another part of our journal we quote some interesting items, received via California, relative to the intrigues of the Secessionists in Sonora and Chihuahua. We anticipate small results from the movements of Gen. SIBLEY or Col. REILY, with their great force, in that part of the country. The more men they have, the sooner they will be obliged to move off or starve. The country produces nothing at present, and they have no money with which to purchase supplies from Mexico. The danger on that frontier is not, we believe, so much from large bodies of regular organized forces, immediately under the direction of the Southern Confederacy, but is from small and irresponsible bands of fillibustering, plundering Secessionists, who care but for little more than will supply them for the moment.

abstract: which we published in yesterday's TIMES, says that if the South only "rises, Actaeon-like, with renewed vigor from every fall, she will yet be rewarded with success." If we recollect aright, Actaeon was an ardent young gentleman, who, for some impropriety, was turned into a stag and devoured by his own dogs. The South is not unlikely to encounter the same fate. Possibly Gen. LOVELL alluded toAntaeus, who, in his fight with Hercules, did gain strength by touching the earth at every fall. But his enemy kept him from the ground and strangled him in the air. Possibly our gunboats may be rendering a similar service to Gen. LOVELL and his friends.

abstract: The Richmond papers  are discussing the question whether they shall surrender the city on the approach of the National gunboats alone, or wait until they are backed up by a respectable army.
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond papers are discussing the question whether they shall surrender the city on the approach of the National gunboats alone, -- or wait until they are backed up by a respectable army. The Dispatch is decidedly in favor of the latter course. "People and Government," it is quite certain, are united on this point. They do not intend to "incur the disgrace of submitting to two or three National gunboats." On the contrary, they are determined to "resist until" -- the last man is dead, -- the last shot fired -- the last ditch filled with the defenders of their hearths and homes? -- not at all -- "until the demand can be backed by such force and circumstances as, at least, to make the surrender an act not to crimson the cheek with shame."

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: The third annual commencement exercises of the Cooper Institute took place in the large hall of the building on last Friday evening, in the presence of a fine audience. The literary exercises consisted of orations by ALEX, THAIRE, MARSHALL, LONG, EWING M. FOX, J.F. CHAPMAN and FRANCIS J. TUCKER, and a very meritorious poem on "The Progress of Learning." by ALFRED E. PARKS, of the Chemistry Class. The singing, by about three hundred of the pupils, who were present on the stage, and led by Mr. BRISTOW, elicited deserved applause, especial merit being attached to Miss G. HARTSHORNE, and Miss M. MCINTYRE, M.J.A. KEANE, and R.J. JOHNSTON, who each sang solos.

abstract: editorial on Front Royal defeat
snippet: editorial on Front Royal defeat
lead_paragraph: -- The movements of Gen. BANKS' corps d'armce, and of detachments of it, have been rather remarkable of late. When, about three months ago, he crossed the Potomac, and marched up the Valley of the Shenandoah, the rapidity of his movements was admirable, and his success everywhere complete. He drove the "Stonewall" rebels before him from point to point, defeated them at Winchester, and also in numerous cavalry skirmishes, pursued them to and from Strasburgh, from Woodstock, beyond the line of the Valley Railroad, as far as Harrisonburgh, and, it was believed, to Stanton, till finally it was announced that the Shenandoah Valley was entirely cleared of the rebels, who had held it for a full year. It was given out that his splendid march and pursuit of the rebels, was to terminate in his seizure of the railroad at Staunton, and from thence he would cross the Blue Ridge and operate somewhere in the rear or on the flank of the Richmond rebel army. Suddenly, however, the corps d'armee of Gen. BANKS was wheeled about, marched back to the railroad, (the Stone-wall Jackson rebels apparently following -- they say pursuing -- our troops,) and from thence to Strasburgh, where the railroad from Manassas Junction intersects the line running up the Shenandoah Valley. After he had made this retrograde movement, our forces in the mountains of Highland County, under MILROY and SCHENCK, who had been expecting support and cooperation from Gen. BANKS, were left isolated and were at, once attacked near the town of Macdowell by the rebels, and after a hard-fought battle and a heavy loss, had to fall back to Franklin, in Pendleton County. There they were opportunely met by reinforcements under Gen. FREMONT, and the rebels were in turn driven back. After halting for a time at Strasburgh, Gen. BANKS began to move his forces, in detachments, eastward over the Manassas Gap railroad, to join, it was said, the corps d'armee of Gen. MCDOWELL. Gen. SHIELDS' Division was moved first, and has probably by this time reached Fredericksburgh. Subsequently other columns were sent in the same direction; and it was while moving over this road that the detachment under Col. KENLY were surprised and repulsed by the rebels at Front Royal, some ten miles east of Strasburgh, after having suffered, according to Gen. BANKS' official report, "considerable loss in killed and wounded and prisoners." The rebels hold Front Royal, breaking BANKS' communication with Manassas Junction, and will probably, by burning bridges and tearing up the track, altogether destroy the connection, and prevent the union of the two corps d'armee, which was needed for their efficient action. This mishap is an unfortunate one at the present moment. If Gen. BANKS was going to move his whole force, piecemeal, over the railroad, he should certainly have held the lines open at all hazards, and with the large force under his command was abundantly competent to do so. It will be quite easy for him to move forward with his whole force and drive the rebels from Front Royal, but unless he also capture or totally destroy them, they will, with the facility of movement which has characterized rebel operations in that vicinity, return again to the Shenandoah Valley, and there resume their sway and their ravages.

abstract: Presuming that you have received the full details of the skirmish of yesterday from antoher source, I will simply state here that our forces engaged consisted of the Third Confederate States Infantry, Ninth Arkansas, Twenty fifth, Twenty-ninth and Thirtyseventh Tennessee, Capt. SWEET'S Mississippi Battery, and Capt. RODDY'S Alabama Cavalry, composing Gen. MARMADUKE'S Brigade, numbering not over sixteen hundred men, while the enemy's force was at least seven thousand.

abstract: It is a striking evidence of the spirit of the age that in the coming Summer, by the side of the Grand Exhibition of the Works of Art and Industry of all Nations, will meet a Convention of men from various countries, interested in the welfare of the poor, the criminal, and the uncared for. In one quarter of London will be an imposing and gorgeous show of all the richest products and the most ingenious manufactures of Europe and Asia -- the porcelain, the shawls, the silks, the gold and silver ware, the rich embroideries and tapestries, the machinery, the inventions, the implements for war and peace, the comforts and luxuries which the wealth and ingenuity of the most civilized countries have produced. In another will be assembled a Congress, where will be exhibited what may be even higher indications of the civilization of Europe than the machinery or the splendid manufactures of the Exhibition -- the models for improved prisons; the plans for the best almshouses and public schools; the most valuable books for public instruction; reports of charity and reformatory schools; plans for the best drainage and the preservation of the health of cities; statistics of crime and poverty; and general reports of the education of all countries. There, will be discussed the great social and moral problems of all nations, the questions of the treatment of vice, of intemperance, of education for the masses, of the best prison system, of the regulation of marriage by the Government, of the relation of wages and capital, of the associations of laborers and of the condition of the laboring classes. "The Congress of Benefaction," says its programme, addressed in French by its Secretary, T. TWINING, (NO. 12 Old Bond-street,) to all interested, "has for its object the well-considered and progressive amelioration of the physical, moral and intellectual condition of the laboring and indigent classes. It collects authentic information in regard to their present state and the means which have been employed with more or less of success to cultivate it; it brings to light the opinions of men who have devoted themselves in a practical manner to the well-being of their kind, and reunites thus the results of the experience of every country for the common advantage of all. Disavowing all spirit of party or sect, it adopts 'Benefaction' as a neutral ground, where all opinions and all beliefs can give one another the hand and work in concert."

abstract: The Kennebec from Yorktown arrived last night, with 230 sick and wounded New-York and New-England soldiers. Cols. BLISS, HOWE and ALMY took on board hot coffee and food for the men, and the ladies of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association went down to render all the aid they could. Col. BURGESS, of Gov. SPRAGUE's Staff, wounded in the advance of Gen. STONEMAN, was removed from the Kennebec to the Astor House, where he is doing well.
lead_paragraph: The Kennebec from Yorktown arrived last night, with 230 sick and wounded New-York and New-England soldiers. Cols. abstract: We are receiving full proof of Southern hospitality as we advance toward Richmond. The doors of the most comfortable mansions along the way are thrown wide open to receive us, and not content with sharing with us alike, their inhabitants leave everything in our possession; forsaking their own homes that we may find shelter. Their houses are left at our disposal, their servants wait to do our bidding ...
lead_paragraph: ROSE COTTAGE, NEAR BOTTON's BRIDGE, Va., Monday, May 13, 1862.

abstract: We all know that the Southern slaves are the happiest of laborers; that they are utterly unable to take care of themselves, and are or ought to be profoundly grateful to those superior beings who have taken upon themselves the labor and care of watching over them, and seeing to it that they are preserved from those mischiefs which "Satan finds for idle hands to do."
lead_paragraph: -- We all know that the Southern slaves are the happiest of laborers; that they are utterly unable to take care of themselves, and are or ought to be profoundly grateful to those superior beings who have taken upon themselves the labor and care of watching over them, and seeing to it that they are preserved from those mischiefs which "Satan finds for idle hands to do." At least, if we do not know these facts, it is our own fault. Have we not been told them often enough, and by those who ought to know best, namely, by these very superior whites who have borne this burden so long. Of course, we would not presume to doubt the general truth of their statements, but now and then there will cases arise which show either that there is some flaw in the case which they make, or that some one has neglected his individual duty toward has own darkeys, and has failed to keep them from some degree of idleness, of which Satan aforesaid was not slow to take advantage. Here, for instance, is ROBERT SMALL, pilot of the Planter, who, with his companions, ran that steamer out from Charleston, under the guns of Fort Sumter. They must have been allowed to be very "idle hands" to have perpetrated such a piece of mischief as that. It would have required no small amount of skill and courage, even in white men, to have planned and carried out such an undertaking, whose only chance of success was its boldness, and where failure would have made death, and that in its most horrible shapes, the inevitable lot of all. And yet these eight colored men ran such a risk as that for the purpose of escaping from this patriarchal institution -- of running away from the ranks of those happiest of laborers -- away from all the blessings of being "taken care of."

abstract: Lewisburgh is the capital of Greenbrier County, Western Virginia, 214 miles west of Richmond ; is situated about three miles from the Greenbrier River, occupying the site of the old Savannah fort, and is a loan of 1,000 inhabitants.
lead_paragraph: Lewisburgh is the capital of Greenbrier County, Western Virginia, 214 miles west of Richmond ; is situated about three miles from the Greenbrier River, occupying the site of the old Savannah fort, and is a loan of 1,000 inhabitants. It is nine miles west of the celebrated White Sulphur Springs, where the thief FLOYD rejuvenated himself and his forces last Summer. It is in the department of Gen. FREMONT. This detachment of FREMONT's column, it is believed, is making its way to the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad -- from the line of which Lewisburgh is about fifty miles distant.

abstract: Editorial sees recent change in Confederates tactics
snippet: Editorial sees recent change in Confederates tactics
lead_paragraph: The rebel movements for the last few weeks, many of them inexplicable, when considered alone, yet, as a whole, indicate a sudden and decided change of policy. The nature of this change is such as might inspire the movements of a cause driven to the last extreme of desperation, and yet cherishing such deadly and vindictive determination of success, as to supply, in a great measure, the lack of reasonable hope.

abstract: BROOKLYN ORPHAN ASYLUM. -- By the annual report of this Society, just made, it appears that there are 99 children in the Institution, between the ages of 3 and 12 years. Received since May, 1861, 60; dismissed, 41; adopted, 1; died, 1. The children are taught the common branches of an English education, and singing. They attend divine worship every Sunday, and connected with the Institution is a flourishing Sabbath-school. The girls are taught plain needle-work, and light household duties. This Institution has been in successful operation for many years, and scores of children who received its fostering care are now good members of society, and many are wealthy, and occupy high social positions. The expenses of the school during the last year amounted to about $6,600, and the receipts exceeded that amount nearly $500. At the Anniversary meeting, held on Thursday evening, a collection was taken up, when $76 was received into the treasury. The following are the officers for the ensuing year:

abstract: The Mount St. Vincent's Buildings in the Central Park are to be turned into a temporary home for disabled soldiers, and will most probably be ready for use by the early part of next week. Alderman FARLEY and Councilmen KEECH and [???], who have had the matter in hand on behalf of the Common Council, have been indefatigable in trying to find a suitable place for the purpose, and in their endeavors to get it speedily fitted up. [???] have been warmly seconded by the Board of Park Commissioners. Sufficient ground will be incaused with the building to make a garden and lawn, in which the convalescent of those who seek refuge in the "Home" can find plenty of fresh air and opportunity for invigorating exercise. It is inteaded to transform the "Home," when ready, over to the regular State authorities.

abstract: A new claimant, not so much for the charity as for the interest of philanthropists, has arisen in the infant institution of a "Girl's Lodging-House;" a place which is intended to invite to a decent bed and satisfactory meal, she of the unsuccessful search after a situation, or the little pilgrim through the busy streets, attracting purchasers for her basket variety of temptingly arranged wares in the shoe-string, peanut, matches and button line. The enterprise was put forth and is under the direction of the Children's Aid Society, and the idea is to make it self-supporting, by levying a nominal sum upon lodgers, who are thus induced to cultivate a feeling above pauperism, and to feel at once an interest in a refuge so peculiarly their own.
lead_paragraph: A new claimant, not so much for the charity as for the interest of philanthropists, has arisen in the infant institution of a "Girl's Lodging-House;" a place which is intended to invite to a decent bed and satisfactory meal, she of the unsuccessful search after a situation, or the little pilgrim through the busy streets, attracting purchasers for her basket variety of temptingly arranged wares in the shoe-string, peanut, matches and button line. abstract: Editorial on Canada's future as independent nation; Editorial on cotton shortage in Great Britain
snippet: Editorial on Canada's future as independent nation; Editorial on cotton shortage in Great Britain
lead_paragraph: The immediate events of the civil war now waging, so entirely absorb public attention, that subjects which at any other time would possess the highest interest are altogether neglected. The supremacy and security of the American Union upon this continent is, of course, the main desire of all its citizens, and, in that point of view, the condition and prospects of the nearest adjacent States become of importance to to us. Some months ago, when a collision with Great Britain was momentarily expected, we devoted a portion of our space to a consideration of the probable situation of Canada in case of a war between the United States and England. The inquiries then started by the American Press gave the clue to the journals of France, which, from time to time, have taken up the topic. The Paris Journal Des Debats enters more fully and thoroughly into the discussion than any of its cotemporaries, and has recently furnished an article which, apart from its intrinsic value, is the more significant when the peculiar opinions of the writer from whom it emanates are remembered.
headline: {'main': 'The Future of Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Future of Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have advices from Gen. MCCLELLAN's headquarters to yesterday afternoon, at which time matters were progressing favorably. Our troops crossed the Chickahominy on Friday, both at Bottom's Bridge and the Railroad Bridge, and the advance in that direction was a mile and a half beyond the river. The enemy had not been encountered in any force, and the impression was that they had taken up a position for defence between three and four miles from Richmond. A large number of our men had been detailed to build bridges, and a number were to be erected at different points. Our forces at New Bridge, yesterday, shelled out the rebels on the opposite side, in fine style. They made no response, but suddenly broke camp and left with their baggage trains. We have nothing later from our gunboats on the James River.

abstract: The United States vs. Pedro Astorga. -- This man was one of the crew of the ship Pleiades, and was indicted for an assault with a dangerous weapon upon one James Walker, the second mate of the ship. A plea of not guilty was put in, and the trial was to have taken place this morning, but the defendant concluded to withdraw his plea and plead guilty. The facts of the case as they appeared on the examination before the Commissioner were laid before the Judge, who thereupon, inasmuch as the defendant was one of the ringleaders in the affray in which the second mate was stabbed, and in which also the first mate was killed, sentenced the defendant to imprisonment for three years at hard labor, that being the extreme limit of the law.

abstract: The throng of our best citizens who attended the Reception of the Art Department of the Cooper Institute last Wednesday evening, as well as the merit of the pictures exhibited, attested how much New-York is indebted to the noble founder of this institution.
lead_paragraph: The throng of our best citizens who attended the Reception of the Art Department of the Cooper Institute last Wednesday evening, as well as the merit of the pictures exhibited, attested how much New-York is indebted to the noble founder of this institution. About a thousand such pictures in every style of art, and a thousand more of excellent judges to view them, is a sight worthy of honorable mention. The School of Design for Women, under the superintendence of Mrs. H.M. Field, assisted by Messrs. Ehninger, McIntee and Farrar, the Mechanical Drawing Class under Messrs. Babcock and Fuchs, the Architectural Drawing under Mr. Derrick, and the Free Hand under Messrs. Hertshung and Myer, and the Wood Engraving under Mr. O'Brien, were all most excellently represented.

abstract: Editorial says West Indies trade with Charleston Harbor continues despite stone blockade
snippet: Editorial says West Indies trade with Charleston Harbor continues despite stone blockade
lead_paragraph: BRISK TIMES. -- Trade between the West Indies and the port of Charleston is at present very active. All the measures adopted to prevent contraband traffic have failed. The ship blockade and the stone blockade are alike ineffective. The rebel craft run through the one and over the other, bearing cotton out, and arms, powder and supplies in, apparently with safety and comfort. Steamers, schooners, barks, brigs, and ships of every size and shape, daily crowd the waters of Charleston Bay, paying no attention whatever to President LINCOLN's prohibitory proclamation, nor to Secretary WELLES' polite and easy cruisers. Our Nassau (N.P.) correspondent sends us a list of twenty-one vessels which have run from that port mostly to and from Charleston, from the 1st to the 18th inst. During these thirteen days there were thirteen vessels (one for each day) arrived from Charleston Iaden with cotton, and eight left Nassau, nominally for other ports, but really for a rebel market, as the nature of their car-goes will show. All this brisk commercial intercourse was between Charleston and one West India shipping port -- which, though the most convenient and most irequented, is not the only port which enjoys the benefit of the flourishing commerce of South Carolina.

abstract: Thursday, May 15, this brigade took up the line of march from Williamsburgh at 7 o'clock A.M., leaving the town under a cavalry guard. The troops were all in fine order and spirits.

abstract: - A telegram from San Francisco, dated Friday last, informs us that the Third Regiment of California Infantry, five companies of the Second Cavalry, and a field battery, will start from Benicia (Cal.) for Salt Lake on Monday (this morning.) What are these troops needed for in Utah? There are no rebels there; the Indians are no more cantankerous than usual; and BRIGHAM YOUNG and all the Mormons swear their unflinching fealty to the National Government. There is, we know, a little cloud of mischief in the fact that the followers of the Prophet have established for themselves a State Government without authority from Congress, and without having gone through the ordinary formalities. But that is a matter very easily settled by legislation -- easily settled, perhaps, with the consent and cooperation of the Mormons; but if not, easy to be peacefully settled without their cooperation. The Mormons desire a State Government, and have organized one; but so have other Territories organized State Governments, which were subsequently squelched by Congress. If they do not peaceably assent to this, the Territory of Utah can be very conveniently cut up, and divided between the adjacent Gentile Territories, when the political power of the Mormons with be completely annihilated, and their united action be rendered impossible. This has nothing to do with the question of altering the boundaries of States or destroying State Governments. The boundaries of Territories are altered by Congress every year. It is much more likely that these Gentile soldiers from California will create difficulties in Utah than that they will ever settle them. If the troops are designed to operate against the fragments of dying savages west of the Rocky Mountains, we are likely to have an Indian was on our hands this Summer, which, though barren enough of value, will be fertile enough of expenses. The Mormons and Indians are, as things go, doing respectably well at present; and it would not be bad policy to let well enough alone.

abstract: One sad reflection mingles with the whirl and excitement of our modern life the old-time depth and heartiness which gave color and tone to existence seems to be, day by day, departing. Old customs, quaint legends, odd usages connecting the acts of each time and season of our existence with homestead, family memories of the past, and thereby giving richness and depth to the sensations of the present, seem, among us, to be dying out.
lead_paragraph: One sad reflection mingles with the whirl and excitement of our modern life -- the old-time depth and heartiness which gave color and tone to existence seems to be, day by day, departing. Old customs, quaint legends, odd usages connecting the acts of each time and season of our existence with homestead, family memories of the past, and thereby giving richness and depth to the sensations of the present, seem, among us, to be dying out. Everything is sheer and new; fresh cut edges, blank upright outlines brilliant fresh plastering, and paint yet odorous of the raw material, have greatly replaced the rounded shapes, the mellow tints, the "dim religious light" of the mansions, and the fanes of other days. We seem to live in a daytime that has no yesterday and no to-morrow. The German idea of "Das Jetzt," -- the Now -- is fully realized as all in all; the whistle of the locomotive and the rattle of the car pervade all solitudes even to the cot of the recluse, and the cloister of the priest, and the newsboy sells his Sunday extra at the Cathedral door, shrilly mingling the announcement of battles won and cities captured with the chaunt of the "Miserere," or the wail of the "Dies Irae." Yet, the human heart is so constituted that it tires at length of all this glare and freshness, this "spektakel" or hurly-burly of progress, in certain moments. It longs for the Past; for old associations; for the simulacra of the hours and friends departed. Manhood turns often wearily from its mad struggle of ambition to weep in dreams of childhood near the father's hearthstone, beside the mother's knee. NAPOLEON, Emperor and arbiter of Europe, melted to tears in the village garden beneath the fruit-tree that had been the sole witness of his boyish vows to beauty perished. Thus do even nations go back from the stifling pressure of existing trials and pursuits to the contemplation of its earlier and quainter history. This sentiment, much hidden in our brand-new Republic, is yet felt by vast classes of our people, and, from time to time, some one among us desperately strives to give it utterance. WASHINGTON IRVING was the creature of this taste, and we all love him best among the old Knickerbockers of colonial legend, or in the quaint and drowsy shades of Sleepy Hollow. Others in different paths have endeavored to invest our scenery and social life with ripe associations. COOPER has done much, and HAWTHORNE and LONGFELLOW, too, have dipped their pens in Autumn dew, Revolutionary diaries, memoirs of early settlers, and what not, have been added to the shelves, but still we have felt the newness of our history to be an almost hopeless obstacle. Nothing is left for us, in this respect, but the common fund of antique usages, sayings, personages, deeds and things that belong to all who are of the same race and Christian faith. Here it is, precisely, that our new friend, the Book of Days, steps in, a literary Rip Van Winkle, but wide-awake and all in fresh attire. We welcome him thus fully, because we hail with real pleasure the prospect of good influences opened by the publication to the entire public. HONE's Day-Book and Year-Book were of a similar cast, and what scholar's library, in their time, lacked their presence? But CHAMBERS, with his well-known thoroughness and comprehensiveness, covers a range of thought and information far wider than the sphere of both these famous repertories. This is just what thousands of us have been waiting for and wishing that some one, with the material at hand, would give. Here it is, at last -- a gathering of "old fireside ideas in general," and "a means of improving the fireside wisdom of the present day" -- a book of Festivals and Saints' days, of Seasons and their Phenomena, of Folk Lore, of Notable Events, Biographies and Anecdotes for every setting of the Sun, of Popular Archaeology, of Curious Fugitive and Inedited Pieces -- in fine, an "Old Curiosity Shop" of everything quaint and queer, antique and racy under the firmament. Beautifully printed by LIPPINCOTT, it is copiously illustrated with real merit, and commends itself monthly to the million for a price less than that of any other periodical in any walk approaching its own. Parts I, and II, are already issued. The yearly volume will be an elegant ornament, as well as a most useful and entertaining companion.

abstract: For so late a period in the season the past week has been unusually plentiful in musical entertainments. The Boughton Family Opera at the Academy of Music, which we spoke of upon Friday last, was, as we understand, repeated upon Saturday in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For so late a period in the season the past week has been unusually plentiful in musical entertainments. The Boughton Family Opera at the Academy of Music, which we spoke of upon Friday last, was, as we understand, repeated upon Saturday in Brooklyn. On Thursday evening a grand concert was given at Irving Hall, by the New-York Catholic Library Association. We allude to it for the purpose of remarking that Mrs. MOZART sung charmingly, while we have to compliment Mrs. GEARY upon the progress she has made as a concert singer, and which entitles her to warm and favorable mention whenever she appears in public. The Miss GELLIES, who are well and most agreeably known among our resident vocalists, also announced a concert at Niblo's Saloon for the same evening. They were supported by Signor ARDAVANI and Messrs. WERNER and SCHREIBER, as instrumentalists. However, the next sensation to the Boughton Family Opera, although critically far pleasanter, was the matinee at Niblo's Saloon, on Saturday, given by the Associated Artists. This drew a large audience, and was, we believe, the first appearance in public of Signor BRIGNOLI in the part of a manager. As we have previously spoken of Miss KELLOGG, with himself and SUSINI, in La Figlia del Reggimento, it will be unnecessary to repeat our criticism, it we mention that Signor SUSINI was it better voice than usual, and state that the opera was gracefully and ungraciously sandwiched into small slices, amongst which GOTTSCHALK was ingeniously dove-tailed. He played an etude and valse by CHOPIN it is rare to find the exquisite musical fancies of that delightful genius rendered by a living pianist. His fantasia on the Ballo in Maschera was subsequently given by him for the first time. It is as sparkling and as winning as his other fantasias, and was received with undivided delight by his hearers.

abstract: Baltimore has always been a faithful barometer of the ups and downs of the rebel cause. Though the essential loyalty of the city has been long ago well assured, there has always been a large Secessionist element -- mainly women, snobs and rowdies -- ready at every rebel success to show its "sympathy" with rebellion. Of late such opportunities have been very rare, indeed, and these sympathizers have found it prudent to lie perdu. But the repulse of BANKS has given a sudden and extraordinary fillip to their hopes. Wild visions of a Northward-marching Confederate army, that shall seize Washington by a sudden coup, and realize the darling and oft-promised policy of carrying the war into Northern soil, float before their minds. The intoxication of this unwonted success appears to have stimulated them to a bolder and more open demonstration than they have long dared to make, and their insolent and indecent exultation produced yesterday a counter-action of loyal indignation, in which several of these blatant traitors received bloody noses, knock-downs, and other rough though not fatal responses. We prefer that Southern society shall have the monopoly of such manifestations; but certainly, if ever the toleration and long suffering of men were tried, it was in the case of those loyal Baltimoreans whose friends and relatives composed the regiment which is reported to have suffered the most severely in the rumored repulse, and who were compelled to listen to the malignant exultation of the rebel sympathizers over the slaughter of those they love. This is a situation to try men's patience, and it is easy to understand, without commending, the spirit that led to the violences that are reported. Happily it was but a momentary effervescence, and order again reigns in Baltimore. What is chiefly noteworthy in the affair is the evidence it affords of the strength of the Union sentiment in that city, whose streets were a year ago reddened with the blood of Union soldiers. Silently, a lukewarm neutrality has given place to a positive, staunch, determined loyalty. It is very evident that Baltimore can now take care of herself, and though it has happened that the evidence has not come in the most pleasing form, it is, nevertheless, at bottom, a gratifying manifestation of the solid heart-felt patriotism of her people.

It is very evident that Baltimore can now take care of herself, and though it has happened that the evidence has not come in the most pleasing form, it is, nevertheless, at bottom, a gratifying manifestation of the solid heart-felt patriotism of her people.

abstract: THE FUNERAL OF LIEUT. PROSS. The funeral of Lieut. PROSS was attended yesterday by a large number of the members of the police and military of this City. The body was taken to St. Marcus' Church  Rev. Dr. ROEGNEL'S where the funeral services...
lead_paragraph: THE FUNERAL OF LIEUT. PROSS. -- The funeral of Lieut. PROSS was attended yesterday by a large number of the members of the police and military of this City. The body was taken to St. Marcus' Church -- Rev. Dr. ROEGNEL's -- where the funeral services were performed at 2 o'clock. The military was then formed in First-avenue, the right resting on Sixth-street. The line of march was through Eighth-street to Broadway, and down Broadway to South Ferry. The Police were out in large numbers, and made a very creditable appearance as they marched down Broadway. There were twenty-five patrolmen, two sergeants and the Captain, from each Precinct in the City. The flags upon all the Station-houses and upon some of the other public buildings were at half mast, and the City Hall and other bells were tolled during the whole time the procession was passing down to the ferry. Lieut. PROSS had a large circle of very warm friends, especially in the Seventeenth Precinct, where he was a well known and respected member of the Police Department. At an early period of the war, he resigned his position on the force, and volunteered in the Thirty-first Regiment, N.Y.S.V. He was killed by a rifle ball, which passed through his head, while fighting at the head of his Company, at the battle of West Point.

abstract: -- The evidences of the growing loyalty of North Carolina accumulate. The latest cheering sign is that the citizens of Raleigh have raised the Stars and Stripes! If this be so, it is a bad prospect for JEFF. DAVIS, who had that particular spot in his eye as the next Capital of the nomadic Confederate Government. It would not be at all surprising if Gov. STANLY should be able to set up the Provisional Government in the proper Capital of the State, instead of at Newbern. This Union reaction, whose reality is now proven by numerous evidences, is the more remarkable, seeing that North Carolina is still wedged in between seceded States. The movement assumes the character, therefore, of a spontaneous and genuine growth of loyalty. We look with hope to this rising tide in the Old North State. More than all the successes of our arms, it points the way to a reconstruction of the Union.

abstract: In the Senate on Saturday, a petition signed by nearly eight thousand women, for emancipation, was presented by Mr. SUMNER. A petition to the same effect was presented from the Women's Society of Friends. A bill to legalize and confirm the act of the President in accepting volunteers under the act of the 22d of July, 1861, and to authorize the acceptance of 200,000 additional to those raised under that act, was referred to the Military Committee. A bill to amend the Fugitive Slave law was presented by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts. The bill donating lands to Agricultural Colleges was briefly considered, but gave way for the Tax bill, which occupied attention until the adjournment. The 108th section was reached.

abstract: The Kennebec from Yorktown arrived on Saturday night, with 230 sick and wounded New-York and New-England soldiers. Cols. BLISS, HOWE and ALMY took on board hot coffee and food for the men, and the ladies of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association went down to render all the aid they could. Col. BURGESS, of Gov. SPRAGUE's Staff, wounded in the advance of Gen. STONEMAN, was removed from the Kennebec to the Astor House, where he is doing well.
lead_paragraph: The Kennebec from Yorktown arrived on Saturday night, with 230 sick and wounded New-York and New-England soldiers. Cols. BLISS, HOWE and ALMY took on board hot coffee and food for the men, and the ladies of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association went down to render all the aid they could. Col. BURGESS, of Gov. abstract: CONDITION OF THE WOUNDED MAN, &c. -- There is a very great amount of speculation and rumor afloat, in respect to the causes which led to the unfortunate shooting affray in Prince-street, on Thursday evening last. The respective friends of both parties are very busy in endeavoring to influence public opinion, and to create a feeling in the minds of others similar to that which they themselves entertain in regard to the occurrence. Whatever may have been the motive which induced CARSON to attempt to take the life of WATROUS, it is now quite probable that the act will not result so seriously as it was at first believed by his attending physicians. The wounded man was yesterday comparatively comfortable, and he informed the reporter, who called for the purpose of learning his true condition, that "he was not going to die of this wound, but, on the contrary, he would be around again in a few days." His physicians also had, yesterday, strong hopes of his recovery. A very favorable change took place during the latter part of Saturday night, and the early part of yesterday. Under these circumstances WATROUS declines to say much with reference to the difficulty between himself and CARSON. He, however, denied most emphatically, that he owes his assailant any such sum of money as is stated in some of the papers. He says be never borrowed of him more than $100 or $200 at a time, and does not now owe him but a very small amount. He also stated to the reporter yesterday that there was not a word of truth in the story that a woman was connected with the affair. He pronounces it a base fabrication, got up by the friends of CARSON, for the purpose of shielding him from punishment for the deadly assault. WATROUS is a man of fine conversational powers, and evidently one who well understands the world, and human nature generally. On the other hand, it is proper to say, that the most intimate friends of CARSON confidently state, that the only motive the latter had, when he shot WATROUS, was to punish the man who had violated the sanctity of his domestic life. The counsel for CARSON, Messrs. GRAHAM & AVERILL, say, that instead of the shot having been fired suddenly and unexpectedly at WATROUS, as is stated in the deposition of the latter, taken before the Coroner on the night of the occurrence, the whole affair was talked over that afternoon, that CARSON made distinct charges against WATROUS of having seduced his wife, and told him that he (CARSON) knew well of an arrangement having been made the night previous, between WATROUS and his wife, whereby they were to go to the Central Park together, when he (CARSON) should be away from home. They state, further, that WATROUS admitted all this, and went down upon his knees before CARSON, and begged for his life, even before the pistol was drawn to shoot him. This is given as CARSON's version of the difficulty, communicated to his counsel since the night of the occurrence. Mr. CARSON appears to have very many warm and closely-attached friends in this City.

abstract: June
snippet: June
lead_paragraph: Harper comes out with remarkable spirit for the approaching month. The number is a magazine of June sunshine, and, by one of those delightful coincidences that sometimes occur in the fortunes of book, as well as of men and nations, all the bright things, and the brightest parts of everything, are grouped together. The "selection" of articles, or the "turn" of the wheel in favor of the chances of this or that article, has been peculiarly felicitous.

abstract: BUENOS AYRES, S.A., Saturday, March 29, 1862. The Argentine Confederation, as you know,  lately fell to atoms, partly under the stroke of the sword and partly by its inherent weakness. The Provinces reassumed their independency, and almost simultaneously have called on Gov. MITRE to issue a proclamation for a National Convention to reorganize de novo. This call was dated March 15, and it convenes the Convention on the 25th of May prox.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AYRES, S.A., Saturday, March 29, 1862.

abstract: editorial on Andrew reply
snippet: editorial on Andrew reply
lead_paragraph: We wish it could be found compatible with courtesy to the State of Massachusetts, and with the profound admiration which the whole country must feel for the heroic courage and loyalty of her sons, to excuse Gov. ANDREW from raising any more volunteers to aid in preserving the Union and putting down the rebellion. His letter responding to the President's call is in the worst possible taste, and indicates anything but a just and proper spirit.

abstract: Editorial expresses concern for Lincoln in his visits to front lines in Virginia
snippet: Editorial expresses concern for Lincoln in his visits to front lines in Virginia
lead_paragraph: The retreat of Gen. BANKS, and the pursuit of his force by the rebel JACKSON, seems to have created more of a panic here and at Washington than the occasion calls for. At the Capital, at all events, the incident is one which ought to have been foreseen, as the steps taken at the War Department were such as to render it perfectly natural, if not inevitable. The whole movement, which has had this untoward termination was dictated by the Secretary of War for reasons which we are bound to presume sufficient, and which, possibly, future events may vindicate.

abstract: Among the many works which have been devoted to a description of that wonderful American imperium in imperio which is rapidly laying the foundations of a new and powerful social system on the vast middle ground between the Atlantic and Pacific States, there has appeared none that conveys such an abundance of living facts, in language so sprightly, and with an interest so well sustained, as this book before us.
lead_paragraph: Among the many works which have been devoted to a description of that wonderful American imperium in imperio which is rapidly laying the foundations of a new and powerful social system on the vast middle ground between the Atlantic and Pacific States, there has appeared none that conveys such an abundance of living facts, in language so sprightly, and with an interest so well sustained, as this book before us. The writer -- a genial Englishman -- of great experience as a traveler, but to whom everything in America was entirely fresh and unexplored, determined to penetrate the Far West in the eventful Summer of 1860, at a time when the United States forces were occupying the Salt Lake Valley, and there was every prospect of a general frontier war, in which the forces of the Union would be battling against the Mormons in their mountain fastnesses, backed by the wild tribes of the interior. The moment was well chosen for the bold seeker after excitement and adventure, and our jovial Briton seems to have made the most of all his opportunities. His life on the wilderness pathway to the Mormon Capital; his residence of some weeks there: his intercoursse with the quaint inhabitants, and their ways, customs, and pursuits; his excursions through adjacent regions, and among the Dakotahs and other Indian tribes; his journeyings to Carson and Ruby valleys, and then the incidents of his returning travel -- are all told in a chatty, cheerful vein that, combining instruction with amusement, makes the work a delightful and interesting friend. Notwithstanding its considerable length, it never flags or wearies, and the reader, at the close, regrets the parting with his traveling mate. It is profusely and handsomely illustrated, and neatly, but substantially bound in Harper's style.
