abstract: We cannot help think-  ing that Gen. WOOL makes a mistake in refusing trade of all kinds to the people of Norfolk, so long as the city authorities refuse to take the oath of allegiance. The common people of Norfolk, like those of all that section of Virginia, are in the utmost need of...
lead_paragraph: -- We cannot help thinking that Gen. WOOL makes a mistake in refusing trade of all kinds to the people of Norfolk, so long as the city authorities refuse to take the oath of allegiance. The common people of Norfolk, like those of all that section of Virginia, are in the utmost need of even the common necessaries of life. They are almost destitute of food, and, in many cases, are on the very verge of starvation. The richer classes have provided against such contingencies, and therefore suffer much less from the deprivation of trade.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial was presented from citizens of Southwest Missouri, asking protection from guerrilla bands. The bill legalizing the acceptance of 200,000 more troops was reported back from the Military Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial was presented from citizens of Southwest Missouri, asking protection from guerrilla bands. The bill legalizing the acceptance of 200,000 more troops was reported back from the Military Committee. A resolution was offered by Mr. SUMNER, and laid over, asking the Secretary of War for copies of all instructions to Generals, in pursuance of the Act of August, 1861, freeing slaves employed against the United States. Another resolution, presented by Mr. SUMNER, declaring that the Government should call upon all, without distinction of color, to help put down the rebellion, was also laid over. Mr. SUMNER also introduced a bill to relieve the National Government from all obligation to support Slavery. It is intended as amendatory of the Fugitive Slave law. A bill was introduced to aid in restoring order and to preserve the public peace in insurrectionary districts. It was referred. In response to a remark of Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, deprecating the policy of weakening Gen. BANKS, so as to leave him to be whipped by the rebels, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, said the President was entirely responsible for all orders for the arrest of Gen. MCDOWELL's progress toward Richmond, and for the withdrawal of troops from Gen. BANKS. He stated further, that it was done in anticipation of just such a movement as had taken place, and that the President's policy was completely vindicated. The Tax bill was then taken up and debated until the adjournment.

abstract: Two inquests were held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at Bellevue Hospital -- one upon the body of Mrs. LYDIA PHILLIPIE, and the other upon the body of her daughter JULIETTE, aged 5 1/2 years, both of whom died under the following circumstances: Mrs. PHILLIPIE is a native of Switzerland, and about 26 years of age. In the early part of the present year her husband enlisted in one of the regiments of the Sickles Brigade, and was killed at the battle of Williamsburgh. When the news of this battle arrived here, and the wife found the name of her husband among the list of the killed in that action, she became almost frantic with grief, and notwithstanding the efforts of many kind friends to console her, she made known to several that she had no longer any object worth living for, and was therefore determined to die. Shortly after this, while crossing the ferry from Brooklyn to this City, she made an attempt to throw both herself and child -- the one above-mentioned -- into the river. The child, however, held her back, and screamed for aid just as she was about to take the leap into the water.
lead_paragraph: Two inquests were held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at Bellevue Hospital -- one upon the body of Mrs. LYDIA PHILLIPIE, and the other upon the body of her daughter JULIETTE, aged 5 1/2 years, both of whom died under the following circumstances: Mrs. PHILLIPIE is a native of Switzerland, and about 26 years of age. In the early part of the present year her husband enlisted in one of the regiments of the Sickles Brigade, and was killed at the battle of Williamsburgh. When the news of this battle arrived here, and the wife found the name of her husband among the list of the killed in that action, she became almost frantic with grief, and notwithstanding the efforts of many kind friends to console her, she made known to several that she had no longer any object worth living for, and was therefore determined to die. Shortly after this, while crossing the ferry from Brooklyn to this City, she made an attempt to throw both herself and child -- the one above-mentioned -- into the river. The child, however, held her back, and screamed for aid just as she was about to take the leap into the water.

abstract: Editorial on business Congress must complete before it recesses
snippet: Editorial on business Congress must complete before it recesses
lead_paragraph: Congress has taken to those premonitions of early dissolution, evening sessions and short speeches. The modern method of compensating (as far as a mere mercenary return can repay) the inestimable services of these National lawgivers, by a fixed salary, instead of by a per diem, has this effect, that the business of governing the country never lags; nor is the Annual Session extended a day beyond the earliest feasible for an adjourment. To such extent, indeed, is this alacrity carried, that measures of the highest public moment are too apt to be scantily and only partially considered, in the haste of the Members to reach their homes and enjoy the well-earned laudations of an admiring constituency. It was different, indeed, under the old system. The Thirty-First Congress had in its hands the Compromise measures of 1850, and receiving eight dollars a-day per head, never thought of adjourning until September 30 -- two months before the commencement of the short Session. But the present Congress, with tenfold more business upon its calendar, business, the importance of which has no parallel in the antecedent history of the Nation, is quite willing to be released by the middle of June, whatever at that time may be the requirements of public welfare. Such, at least, appears to be its present temper. We shall be happy to note any proof of amendment.

abstract: At ten o'clock last night the Seventh Regiment marched down Broadway, and took its departure for Washington. The same patriotic alacrity that placed that pet New-York corps in the van of the great movement which, a year ago, poured to the defence of the Capital, makes it once more first to respond to the summons for the services of our State militia.

abstract: We have advises four days later from Europe, by steamship Kangaroo, which passed Cape Race late on Saturday night. The news of the capture of New-Orleans had been received in England by the Canada, and confirmed by the City of New-York, which arrived at Liverpool shortly before the Kangaroo left. It occasioned much surprise, and at first was received with considerable doubt. It seems to have had very little effect on the cotton market, though the impression in Manchester was that it would cause the staple to come forward more freely, under the previous assurance of our Government that measures would be taken to mitigate the blockade. The London Times considers the capture a hard blow for the South, and a great triumph for the North, and says it is vain to deny the importance of the event -- at the same time still doubting the ability of the Government to conquer the rebellion. Even the London Herald, though at first doubting the truth of the report taken over by the Canada, admits it to be a signal triumph; while the Ministerial Post, admitting a serious loss to the South, professes to think it will not seriously affect the fortunes of either party. Speculations relative to the visit of Count MERCIER to Richmond continued, but nothing reliable had transpired. Parliamentary proceedings had been generally unimportant. There is nothing of interest from the Continent. The Liverpool Cotton Market was irregular, and prices were 1/4d. lower for American breadstuffs, and provisions were dull. Consols, 93 1/4 for money. Advices one day later than by the Kangaroo are received by the Hibernian, which passed Cape Race on Sunday morning, on her way to Quebec. There is nothing by this arrival of special importance. The Government had been defeated in the House of Commons, on the proposition to abolish the Church rates, by a decided majority. A still further decline had taken place in American cotton, and breadstuffs and provisions continued dull. Consols had advanced to 93 1/2.

abstract: Baltimore will have the effect to allay something of the Tribune's apprehensions of a "rising of the rebel symphatizers" in that city. So long as any of that species of its population ventured to show themselves in the street, they had frequent occasion for "rising" -- being pretty uniformly knocked down as soon as they made their appearance. According to the latest advices they have resorted to a discreet concealment, from which they will have no occasion very speedily to emerge. Even the venomous agent of secession, the News Sheet, has hosted the Stars and Stripes.

abstract: "What excites this animosity against French intervention, is not that it is needless; the contrary is but too well understood. It is because as a consequence of it, the reorganization of Mexico upon firm and independent basis is foreseen, and with it the establishment of the Republic beyond the reach of that covetousness which has already robbed it for the advantage of the United States. While affecting to...
lead_paragraph: "What excites this animosity against French intervention, is not that it is needless; the contrary is but too well understood. It is because as a consequence of it, the reorganization of Mexico upon firm and independent basis is foreseen, and with it the establishment of the Republic beyond the reach of that covetousness which has already robbed it for the advantage of the United States. While affecting to bemoan that Government so often declared the disgrace of the republican principle, an eye has rather been had to the easy prey which was thought to be already within practicable grasp. This is the whole secret of the outburst of generous indignation which has carried away the TIMES and its cotemporaries. But their crocodile tears deceive nobody. Their lamentations to-day over the Mexican nationality, which no one threatens, conflict with their efforts of yesterday to destroy that very nationality."

abstract: To the fact of the tidings from Gen. BANKS reaching the country on Sunday, we doubtless owe an escape from the wild panic the first impression of such a disaster was calculated to excite. Time was given for a second thought;...
lead_paragraph: To the fact of the tidings from Gen. BANKS reaching the country on Sunday, we doubtless owe an escape from the wild panic the first impression of such a disaster was calculated to excite. Time was given for a second thought; and reflection soon showed that the effort of the enemy was simply a throe of dissolution -- a spasm preceding that final collapse which must certainly render further movement impossible. Some demonstration was needed to restore the shattered morale of the forces before Richmond and Corinth. The gloom resulting from constant defeat and reverse was to be for an instant dissipated by a gleam of success. It was not impossible that, under the excitement of a reported victory, the army of JOHNSTON might be encouraged to give Gen. MCCLELLAN battle in front of Richmond, and so save the mortification of losing the Confederate capital without a blow. BANKS was known to have only a handful of men in his command. To make a dash at his enfeebled column, pursue it up the valley, drive it into Maryland, and then retire before MCDOWELL, or SHIELDS or FREMONT could close in behind them and cut off their retreat, was doubtless the rebel policy. An impression of this sort became general in this City as soon as the news had been fairly digested. It was seen that no material advantage was lost. The rebels gained nothing but the fame of a barren victory. The pieces on the National chess-board held their squares -- only the pawns had moved. Washington was not endangered. An invasion of Maryland was out of the question. And so public apprehension passed away; that acute index of popular opinion, the Stock Market, wavered only momentarily, and then recovered its tone. Whatever abatement there was of the general confidence, had reference to the War Department alone.

abstract: Sketch of Banks 3-mos. campaign in Shenandoah Valley
snippet: Sketch of Banks 3-mos. campaign in Shenandoah Valley
lead_paragraph: Precisely three months ago, on the 26th of February last, the army of Maj.-Gen. BANKS crossed the Potomac at Harper's Ferry, and took up its line of march along the valley of the Shenandoah. The column numbered some thirty thousand men, finely drilled and well equipped; and was composed of regiments from almost every loyal State in the Union -- from New-England, from New-York, Pennsylvania and Maryland, and from the Northwestern tier of States as far as Wisconsin. Its work was to destroy or drive from the valley the rebel force under Gen. THOS. J. JACKSON, (commonly called "Stonewall" Jackson,) who had, during the Winter, held possession of that section of Virginia extending from the Blue Ridge to the hills in Berkeley County, and from the Potomac on the northeast to the Southwestern limit of the State. Gen. BANKS' column set out in high spirits, anxious to measure swords with the rebel fee, and with a perfect confidence in the accomplished soldier and statesman who was in command. The day after reaching the soil of Virginia, the advance began. The enemy was driven from Charlestown, discomfited in innumerable cavalry skirmishes, his whole army was defeated at Winchester, he was pursued to Strasburgh, from thence to Mount Jackson, the terminus of the Valley Railroad; from thence to New-Market, to Harrisburgh, and to Staunton -- a distance of over a hundred miles from where he started; while a harrassing series of cavalry and infantry skirmishes was kept up along the whole line. Gen. BANKS' work, so far as his own Department was concerned, was now nearly completed. He had only to advance upon Staunton, defeat or drive away the rebels there, hold the railroad running across the Blue Ridge, and then his fine army would be ready for further operations wherever it might be needed. Suddenly, and while near this point, it was darkly given out from Washington that BANKS' army was on the retreat -- why, no common mortal could divine. It was reported early in the present month to be back at New-Market, back to Woodstock, back to Strasburgh, where it temporarily made a halt, and it leaked out from the telegraph that one-half of the column (SHIELDS' division) was on the wing over the Manassas Gap Railroad to Fredericksburgh -- for what purpose nobody but the war-gods at Washington could tell. The rebels, in the meantime, came up with the remnant of BANKS' army at Strasburgh, defeated a part of it at Front Royal, drove the remainder back from Strasburgh to Winchester, defeated it there, with great loss; drove it back in haste from Winchester to the Potomac; and there, on yesterday, it effected a crossing into Maryland -- after a retreat of a hundred miles -- precisely three months to a day, as we have said, from the time it set out. The advance, so gloriously and hopefully made in February, after all but accomplishing its object, ended in disaster and disgrace to the National arms in May. For which, whoever may be responsible, Gen. BANKS is not.

abstract: The rumor, quite current on Sunday, that a requisition had been made upon the State of New-York for a militia force to proceed to the seat of war, created quite an excitement among the military of this city. Military men assembled in their usual place of resort, and discussed all the probabilities about the case, and at a late hour, having received no definite intelligence, they returned to their homes to await some definite action by the proper authorities. Yesterday, Maj.-Gen. DURYEA received an order from Gov. MORGAN to call out all his available force for three months' service at the seat of war. A meeting of Commanders of Regiments was at once convened at the Commanding-General's headquarters. Col. BENNETT, of the Twenty-eighth Regiment, reported that he could start with 500 men by Wednesday, provided arms and accoutrements were promptly furnished. Col. CLARK, of the Thirteenth Regiment, thought he could have 600 men ready by Wednesday. The officer representing the Forty-seventh, (new regiment,) estimated his force at 500 men. The Twenty-third (new regiment) reported 250 men -- four companies organized, ready for service. The Second Regiment artillery, Col. GRAHAM, has been in marching order for the last three months, and numbers about 1,000 men. This corps was to leave last night for Washington.

abstract: Once more, the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, has left this City for the defence of Washington. As soon as it was known that more troops were ...
lead_paragraph: Once more, the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, has left this City for the defence of Washington. As soon as it was known that more troops were needed, Col. LEFFERTS issued an order for the members of the corps to meet at the armory, in citizens' dress, yesterday morning at 9 o'clok. As early as 8 o'clock the spacious drill-room was crowded by the brave and gallant soldiers, anxious to be the first to answer to the call of Secretary STANTON. Shortly after, Col. LEFFERTS arrived, and his appearance was hailed with every manifestation of delight by his command.

abstract: While the chief European journals do little else than pour out vitriol and vinegar in regard to American affairs, it is gratifying to find occasional instances of a truly liberal and appreciative spirit. We find a marked exam
lead_paragraph: -- While the chief European journals do little else than pour out vitriol and vinegar in regard to American affairs, it is gratifying to find occasional instances of a truly liberal and appreciative spirit. We find a marked example of the kind in the Paris Presse of the 7th inst., one of the ablest of the Parisian journals, and since M. GIRARDIN assumed its editorship, conspicuous for its just and intelligent judgments on American affairs. It thus takes to task those French and English journals whose secessionist sympathies blind them to the broadest and most palpable facts:

abstract: The response to the new and unexpected call for troops has been all that the Government could require, and more than is could have foreseen. In
lead_paragraph: The response to the new and unexpected call for troops has been all that the Government could require, and more than is could have foreseen. In answer to a dispatch from Secretary STANTON. the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, Col. LEFFERTS, left for Washington last evening. Never was so much enthusiasm shown at the departure of any regiment. The march down Broadway was a complete triumph, and must have gladdened the hearts of the brave fellows as they passed. The Second Regiment of artillery. Col. GRAHAM, also left yesterday for Washington, amidst the cheering of the people. Still other regiments are to follow to-day and to-morrow, including the gallant Sixty-ninth, already celebrated in the annals of the war. Some right or ten regiments will probably leave this City and Brooklyn in the course of the week. The response from other States is no less gratifying, as will be seen from our dispatcher this morning.

abstract: A meeting of the Sixty-ninth Regiment was held at their Armory, Essex Market, last evening, Maj. BAGLEY in the Chair, to determine what action the Regiment would take in reference to the call for more troops. Quartermaster TULLY moved that the services of the Regiment be tendered to the Governor, which was seconded by Lieutenant COONAN, and unanimously passed. Recruits will be received at the several company headquarters, commencing today. The regiment at present numbers 600 men, rank and file.

abstract: We have no very definite information concerning the military action of the Government. Rumors which seem to be well founded, however, confirm the view which we took yesterday of recent events in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: We have no very definite information concerning the military action of the Government. Rumors which seem to be well founded, however, confirm the view which we took yesterday of recent events in Virginia. One dispatch states that "the officers of the Government were not unprepared for the advance of JACKSON upon BANKS, and have taken steps accordingly." As a matter of course, they must have known, when they took away from BANKS 15,000 men, leaving him less than half that number, that they exposed him to attack and defeat from the enemy in his front. We can only hope that the country is to have compensation for this disaster in something brilliant and effective to be done by MCDOWELL. It is reported that it was upon his express demand that BANKS' troops were sent to him, and that his reason for asking them was the fear that he was to be at once attacked by the forces in front of him. If this was so, it only proves that he was mistaken as to the point of the rebel assault. Generals who simply lie still and await an attack, at the discretion of the enemy, are quite liable to these minor mistakes of judgment.

abstract: For once those London  and Paris journals that have been persistently unfriendly toward the United States, are brought up by a Union success, which they can neither dodge nor discredit.
lead_paragraph: -- For once those London and Paris journals that have been persistently unfriendly toward the United States, are brought up by a Union success, which they can neither dodge nor discredit. The capture of New-Orleans is a broad and palpable victory for the National arms, which no ingenuity of sophism can belittle, and no audacity of logic can explain into a Confederate triumph. The extracts from our London files, and our translated excerpts from the Paris journals, brought by the New-York yesterday, and published in to-day's TIMES, give a good representation of the impression produced by the first tidings of the capture.

lead_paragraph: Already have we evidence that the irrepressible energies of our people will create anew, if they cannot restore the Southern trade which has been so suddenly cut off by the civil strife that rages throughout the county. Having obtained possession of several important Southern ports, and among them New-Orleans, the President, but little more than two weeks since, issued his proclamation that the several Southern ports then held by the National forces would be opened for trade, and commence on the 1st of June proximo.

abstract: The Tax bill has now been under consideration of Congress nearly three months, having been first reported to the House of Representatives March 3, when it was committed to the Committee of the Whole.
lead_paragraph: The Tax bill has now been under consideration of Congress nearly three months, having been first reported to the House of Representatives March 3, when it was committed to the Committee of the Whole. House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed. After a consideration of just one month in Committee of the Whole, the bill as amended was passed by the House April 8. On the 10th of April the bill was presented to the Senate, and referred to the Committee on Finance. After considering the different sections of the act as referred, the Committee on Finance, of which Senator FESSENDEN is Chairman, reported it back to the Senate on the 6th of May. Several attempts have since been made to reach the Tax bill, and to press it or a substitute to its passage, but other acts have been deemed of sufficient importance to take precedence, in consequence of which the bill was only on Wednesday brought under the consideration of the Senate. It was considered advisable to dispose of the Confiscation bill, determining the status of the property of rebels, before taking up the bill which imposes taxes on the property of loyal citizens. The former bill has been under discussion some days; but no action having been taken on it, it has been laid aside for the present, and the Tax bill taken up.

abstract: A regular weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held on Monday evening, Alderman VAN BRUNT in the chair. A communication was received from Mayor KALBFLEISCH vetoing a resolution ...
lead_paragraph: A regular weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held on Monday evening, Alderman VAN BRUNT in the chair. A communication was received from Mayor KALBFLEISCH vetoing a resolution adopted on the 12th inst., providing for the presentation of a stand of colors to the Jackson Artillery, (Second Regiment New-York State Heavy Artillery,) Col. SAMUEL GRAHAM, as under the amended Charter no money can be paid out of the City Treasury for any object whatever unless the money has first been raised and in the Treasury. The communication was laid on the table and ordered printed. The Mayor sent in a communication nominating J.H. Hutchins as a member of the Board of Education, vice Thomas H. Rodman, resigned. The nomination was laid upon the table. Under the special order, majority and minority reports of the Gas Committee were presented on the application of the Citizens' Gas Company to furnish a portion of the gas used in lighting the public lamps and buildings. The minority report, signed by Alderman MALONEY, is against the prayer of the petitioner. The fact is recounted that the appropriation, as the gas is now used, will not last the year, and a reduction in the number of hours in which gas is used is recommended, and that no part of the present appropriation, under the new charter, can be legally diverted from the old to the new Company. The majority report, signed by Aldermen STRONG and GREEN, is in favor of directing the Board of Contracts to enter into a contract with the Citizens' Company for supplying the city at $1 80 per 1,000 cubic feet, provided the Company agrees to extend the contract for five years, furnish good gas, and supply private consumers at $2 per 1,000 cubic feet. The reports were laid upon the table, to enable the Aldermen to canvass the subject. The Constructing Board of Water Commissioners officially notified the city authorities that the engine at Mount Prospect Engine House has been tested, and is in condition to be turned over to the Permanent Board. Placed on file. A resolution was adopted declaring that the streets shall be repaired by contract until the 1st of January, 1863. Each ward to be advertised for separately, and the work to be done under the direction of the inspectors of Pavements, and subject to the approval of the Alderman of each Ward. The Counselor sent in a communication giving it as his opinion that the law of 1859 (chap, 160) does not apply to the case of the owners of lands and buildings on Flatbush-avenue. The awards to be made to such owners for damages sustained inconsequence of the improvement, (regarding Flatbush-avenue,) do not constitute any indebtedness against the City of Brooklyn, so as to authorize their payment by the issue of city bonds. These awards are to be paid out of the assessment to be laid by the Commissioners within the district fixed by the Board of Aldermen.

abstract: The Message of Mr. LINCOLN, presented to Congress yesterday, illustrates the most engaging traits of the President's character. He is unwilling to take the noble installment of credit which the people accord him for his conduct of public affairs through this ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Message of Mr. LINCOLN, presented to Congress yesterday, illustrates the most engaging traits of the President's character. He is unwilling to take the noble installment of credit which the people accord him for his conduct of public affairs through this tremendous crisis, without also taking upon his broad shoulders the blame popularly accorded his Ministers. His generous intervention will scarcely alter the general verdict. The nation will not venerate President LINCOLN the less, or respect CAMERON, MORGAN and the rest an atom the more.

abstract: GRADING, PAVING, , FOR NEW CHAMBERSSTREET. Bids were opened yesterday for the construction of the necessary culverts and receiving basins to connect the sewers of the old and new Chambers ...
lead_paragraph: GRADING, PAVING, &c., FOR NEW CHAMBERS-STREET. -- Bids were opened yesterday for the construction of the necessary culverts and receiving basins to connect the sewers of the old and new Chambers streets, the award being made in favor of ROBERT CUNNINGHAM at $1,752, the work to be commenced on Monday. In connection with this street, a state of facts exists which demand the immediate attention and action of the authorities. Under an ordinance passed by the Common Council some weeks ago, the work of grading the street is rapidly progressing, the various owners, after a long delay, during which the street became not only impassable, but a nuisance, agreed upon a grade. That portion of the work is being pushed forward, and, meantime, an ordinance lies on the table of the Common Council for paving the street with Belgian pavement, which should be commenced immediately; the grading is finished. If this is not attended to, and acted on at once, and authority given the Croton Department to pave the street at once, it will become again a common dumping ground, and another year may elapse before the street can be used by the community. It is a valuable thoroughfare, and public convenience demands that no unnecessary delay should occur in putting it in proper condition.

abstract: Advices received last evening at the War Department from Gen. McCLELLAN announce that he has captured Hanover Court-house, a town on the railroad between Richmond and Fredericksburgh, about thirty miles north of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Advices received last evening at the War Department from Gen. McCLELLAN announce that he has captured Hanover Court-house, a town on the railroad between Richmond and Fredericksburgh, about thirty miles north of Richmond. No particulars are received, further than that our loss is small, while that of the rebels is considerable, in killed, wounded and prisoners. One of the enemy's cannon was also captured.

abstract: report on nation-wide response to call for volunteers
snippet: report on nation-wide response to call for volunteers
lead_paragraph: In response to the call for Militia regiments, to report immediately at Washington, the armories of the Seventy-first, Eighth, Twenty-second, Thirtyseventh and other City regiments were crowded, yesterday, with members and proffered recruits, anxious to meet the requirements of the Government in its hour of need. At least the four regiments named could have left for the seat of war last night, had not red tape intervened. The State authorities had done all in their power, and in connection with the United States officials, had issued the necessary arms, ammunition, equipments and rations, but the uniforms and clothing which had been promised were not forthcoming. In vain did the State authorities and the commandants of the several regiments represent what had been done, and their readiness to go immediately upon being uniformed. U.S. Assistant Quartermaster-General VINTON was inexorable. He stated that his orders were positive to issue no uniforms until all those receiving them had been mustered into the service of the United States. He could not recognize even the order of his superior officer, Major-Gen. MORGAN, commanding this Department. Even if the enemy were within five miles of Washington, and the troops could succor the Capital, and could not do it without these uniforms, he could not furnish them. He peremptorily refused to disobey instructions.

abstract: The preliminary exercises of their twenty-fifth anniversary were held by this Society on Sunday evening, in the church of Rev. Dr. DUNBAR, on Lexingtonavenue, and closed with a business meeting on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The preliminary exercises of their twenty-fifth anniversary were held by this Society on Sunday evening, in the church of Rev. Dr. DUNBAR, on Lexingtonavenue, and closed with a business meeting on Monday. The Rev. Dr. WELCH, President of the Society, conducted the exercises. The annual sermon was preached by Rev. JOHN NEWTON BROWN, of Philadelphia, and his remarks, which were a most profound and elaborate vindication of the divine authority of the Holy Scriptures, were listened to with deep interest by a very large and intelligent audience. Earnest prayers were offered for the success of our arms, and the triumph of Union principles. There were many ministers, representatives of the Baptist denomination, present, but the usual addresses were omitted, owing to the occurrence of the Bible Society anniversaries in other localities -- a large number being obliged to leave in the afternoon boat, in order to be present at that of Providence, R.I., which is in session to-day.

abstract: A large assemblage collected yesterday afternoon, in spite of the very discouraging showers, to witness the exhibition of the Orphan Asylum, at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Fifty-first-street.
lead_paragraph: A large assemblage collected yesterday afternoon, in spite of the very discouraging showers, to witness the exhibition of the Orphan Asylum, at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Fifty-first-street. Five hundred and thirty boys were upon the stage, (this being an exclusively male department,) and passed their examination in arithmetic, algebra, elements of science and geography, orthography, &c, &c, without an error. After these drier proceedings came declamation and music. The well-organized band of the Asylum, comprising sixty pieces of brass and stringed instruments, performed upon by the pupils, leading off by playing some patriotic aims, and afterward accompanying the vocalization.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a resolution was adopted asking information of the Secretary of War as to how many officers and men belonging to the regular or volunteer forces are now in the ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a resolution was adopted asking information of the Secretary of War as to how many officers and men belonging to the regular or volunteer forces are now in the Penitentiary of the District of Columbia, together with other information in relating to them. The Post-route bill was passed. The resolution to suspend payments under the act providing for the payment of troops in the Department of the West was considered and amended so as to provide that the Commissioners shall report within sixty days. It was then laid aside for the Tax bill, which was considered until the adjournment.

abstract: editorial on McDowell movements; Editorial on campaign in Virginia
snippet: editorial on McDowell movements; Editorial on campaign in Virginia
lead_paragraph: Events are rapidly furnishing the explanation of recent military movements at Washington which the authorities have not vouchsafed us. As we anticipated, moreover, they are vindicating the action of the Government. It was announced in Congress on Monday that every event which has occurred in the Valley of the Shenandoah was foreseen and provided for. When Gen BANKS was suddenly arrested in his victorious march and deprived of three-fourths of his army, it was known that he could no longer hold his ground, and he was therefore ordered to retreat. Contrary, we suspect, to anticipation, he was pursued by both JACKSON and EWELL, but the masterly manner in which he conducted that most difficult of military manoeuvres, a rapid retreat in presence of an overwhelming force, has reflected the highest possible credit on his military capacity and energy.

abstract: The latter part of the present month is recognized by the authorities connected with the Eastern Dispensary as their "busy season;" for it seems as if chosen by common consent as the annual period for ...
lead_paragraph: The latter part of the present month is recognized by the authorities connected with the Eastern Dispensary as their "busy season;" for it seems as if chosen by common consent as the annual period for mothers to convey their young infants, and make a general turn-out of the family to share in the privileges of vaccination, or such other blessings of prevention and cure as are to be had for the asking, in the District Dispensary. The process of vaccination has been brought to such perfection that a sleeping infant is not aroused while undergoing it. Some young ladies, however, who having been escorted hither by half dozen or more sympathetic friends, and having made up their minds to scream, arc loth to relinquish that effective design, are astonished to find the operation all over befere they have arrived at a becoming state of nervousness. Babies look over their plump little shoulders and laugh at the doctor as he passes rapidly around with his beautifully-adapted instrument, dispatching a case at every two seconds. The philosophy of scabs, or vaccine lymph, is very interesting as observed in this institution, which is renowned for the purity of its virus. The specimens of perfect extraction are carefully preserved air tight, between glass plates, and can be sent by avail to any part of the world. Many thousand of our State troops received the benefit of this genuine matter before exposing their persons to the infection of camps. When the volunteering excitement of one year ago was at its height, an order emanated from the Surgeon-General's office at Albany that every regiment should be vaccinated before leaving the State. This order was so promptly and efficiently carried out, not only by the giving out of virus, but by the personal attendance of the medical staff of the Eastern Dispensary, that a letter of grateful acknowledgment has been received from the State Department. The charitable dispensations of the present year have exceeded those of any previous one since the existence of the institution.

abstract: The Ministry of Lord PALMERSTON threatens to be to Young England what the Long Parliament was to the Great Rebellion. It utterly declines to die.
lead_paragraph: -- The Ministry of Lord PALMERSTON threatens to be to Young England what the Long Parliament was to the Great Rebellion. It utterly declines to die. Time was that when the Government was beaten upon one of its measures, Ministers would either appeal to the country by a dissolution or resign. The Whigs do neither. With that happy nonchalance which is the Premier's peculiarity, he laughs at defeat, and scorns resignation. If he cannot bring the Houses to his support on one measure he can upon another. If he break down on domestic questions be brings up in the Foreign. If the Budget meet with a reverse, the Navy Estimates fetch up the leeway. And the unanimous support of the House upon the Trent settlement compensates for utter discomfiture on the Church Rates, or marriage affinities. The latest misadventure of the Ministry was in this business of Church Rates abolition -- a measure which the Cabinet has advocated for two sessions vainly. Not only was there a majority of one against the Government upon the direct question; but when a resolution denouncing the Government view was put, it was carried by an unmistakable majority. What hope can the Tories have of power, if even this blow fail to induce upon the Whigs a spirit of resignation?

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a Message was presented from the President, stating that it was not compatible with the public interests to furnish information relative to arrests in Kentucky at present.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a Message was presented from the President, stating that it was not compatible with the public interests to furnish information relative to arrests in Kentucky at present. The bill making an appropriation for certain bounties was taken up and passed. A memorial was presented from the Legislature of Western Virginia, in reference to the division of that State. The bill donating lands for the benefit of Agricultural Colleges, &c., was debated, but not acted upon. The Tax bill was then considered. An amendment, proposed by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, to strike out the section recognizing licenses to retail liquor, was rejected. Mr. SUMNER proposed an amendment virtually laying a tax on slaves, which was discussed until the adjournment.

abstract: Throughout the day, and during the evening of yesterday, the armory of the Seventy-first Regiment, over Centre Market, and vicinity, was crowded. The Quartermaster's Department was busily engaged all day in receiving and assorting the uniforms, clothing and equipments supplied tardily by the United States authorities, but distributed with astonishing celerity.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the day, and during the evening of yesterday, the armory of the Seventy-first Regiment, over Centre Market, and vicinity, was crowded. The Quartermaster's Department was busily engaged all day in receiving and assorting the uniforms, clothing and equipments supplied tardily by the United States authorities, but distributed with astonishing celerity. The moment a box was received on the sidewalk, it was seized by a hundred willing hands, and swiftly transferred to the armory room. In another moment the box was opened, and in almost less time than it takes to relate it, each company would be supplied with its quota. So far as the regiment was concerned there was no blame for the delay in embarkation for the seat of war. The spirit of the regiment was astonishing. The ranks were filled with some of our wealthiest and best citizens, who sacrificed business, home interests of all kinds, to join in the march of their favorite corps a second time to the defence of their country. The scarred and disfigured faces of many denoted the terrible experience of the regiment on the bloody field of Bull Run. Here was a man whose face was a series of frightful scars; there another whose nose was nearly gone. No less than thirty-seven were for months prisoners in the horrible tobacco warehouses of Richmond, previous to the arrangement for the interchange of prisoners. All went willingly to the work again. As an instance of the wonderful esprit du corps that characterized the members, we may state that there were in the ranks one who had resigned a position as First Lieutenant in the Navy, another who had relinquished a Lieutenant-Colonelcy of volunteers, four Captains of volunteers, eight First and Second Lieutenants of volunteers, three Sergeants of Police, eleven policemen and scores of others who gave up pecuniarily better positions in order to go with the regiment. All were not only willing but anxious to go, and joyously awaited the hour of departure. It was not the mere excitement of the moment, for many had tasted the stern realities of war. It was the calm, determined, patriotic resolve of good and loyal citizens. Col. MARTIN was everywhere among the then, calmly giving orders, unexcited, answering the thousand calls upon him with urbanity and promptness worthy a veteran soldier.

abstract: The bark Palles, (British, of Balize, Hond., [???], from Balize, Hond.,) May 10, with logwood and cotton to JOSIAH JEX, arrived yesterday. She reports that on May 16, at 8 A.M., lat. 23° 50', lon. 85°, she was boarded by the United States bark Pursuit who reported that the day previous the United States steamer R.R. Cuyler captured an iron steamer loaded with cotton, and sent her to New-York. She did not learn the name of the captured steamer.

abstract: The zeal with which Gen. DIX applies martial law to the malcontents of Maryland might be advantageously imitated in one or two other quarters, where leniency is working mischief. At Easton, the other day, a State Judge, backed by the County Prosecuting Attorney, exposed himself to the penalties of sedition. The population thereabouts was unfortunately sympathetic with the brace of legal luminaries. It was necessary to make an example; and the Provost-Marshal was dispatched to arrest the Judge and his fellow, and carry them to Baltimore. Strong doctrinaires of the State Rights school, the two culprits offered resistance, and reinforced by the mob, resisted the military officials even to blows, and might have triumphed had not a column of infantry, opportunely arriving, aided in the capture and safe convoy of the recusants out of the infected district. They now lie in a Baltimore jail.

abstract: The new steam sloop-of-war Adirondack, has just been completed at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and the Navy Department have been informed that she is ready for her armament, and for being put in commission if need be. Her rigging and external decoration were finished last week, and she now lies in the stream, a perfectly beautiful model of naval architecture.

abstract: R. MORRIS COPELAND, Assistant Adjutant-General to Major-Gen. BANKS, has issued an address to the people of Massachusetts which may very well convey the idea that the rebels are on the eve of overwhelming our armies and encamping on Boston Common. "Men of Massachusetts," he says, "have you heard the news? Have you heard that a Massachusetts General and the Sons of Massachusetts have been driven out of Virginia by an enemy that only ten days ago was nearly prostrate before us?" This is scarcely a correct statement of the facts. Gen. BANKS was not driven back by the enemy, -- he was ordered back by his own Government. For good and sufficient reasons, we have no doubt, he was directed to withdraw, and did so. This cannot be called a defeat, nor does the fact that he was pursued and suffered some loss, change the character of the movement. Maj. COPELAND says, furthermore, that "the rebels will cross the Potomac River, exultant and reckless of all consequences." We rather think not. They show no such intention. Adjutant COPELAND means well in his appeal to the patriotism of Massachusetts, -- but it does not need the stimulus of such exaggerations as these.

abstract: -- Gen. Robert Bentley died recently in Mansfield, Ohio, in the 79th year of his age. He removed from Allegheny County, Penn., to Ohio, in 1812, and settled in the wilderness of Richland County. After HULL's surrender at Detroit. Mr. Bentley shouldered his musket, and in the militia service of Ohio filled every office from Corporal to Major-General. His field of operations extended from Richland County to Lake Eric, and he was a very efficient officer. At the close of the war, in 1815, he opened an extensive farm in Richland, and during twenty years of his life, he was a large dealer in cattle, having driven nine droves from Ohio over the Mountains to Philadelphia. M. Bentley did much to build up the Baptist churches in Richland County, in early times; was Judge of the Court of Common Pleas for seven years, and served several terms in the House and Senate of Ohio.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. Robert Bentley died recently in Mansfield, Ohio, in the 79th year of his age. abstract: Editorial favors J Robb for Military Gov. of Louisiana
snippet: Editorial favors J Robb for Military Gov. of Louisiana
lead_paragraph: The name, of JAMES ROBB has been favorably mentioned in high official circles as a proper person to perform the important and delicate duties of Military Governor of New-Orleans. The gentlemen prominent in this movement include the strongest in the country. Among them are JOHN JACOB ASTOR, MOSES GRINNELL, MOSES TAYLOR, BROWN BROTHERS & Co., W.H. ASPINWALL, CHARLES H. MARSHALL, MATTHEW MORGAN, and others, who have spontaneously united in the request that Mr. ROBB be awarded the position. Mr. ROBB more than twenty-five years ago settled in New-Orleans, and as a banker soon acquired not only large wealth, but the still greater distinction of an honest and public-spirited citizen. To him is the South largely indebted for its railroads. Probably no gentleman in private life stands higher, and no one in the country has a larger share of practical wisdom -- no one living knows more of the material interests and public men of New-Orleans and Louisiana. Mr. ROBB is a thorough Union man; his sagacity long since anticipated the ruin that has overtaken the South from the rebellion, and his knowledge of commercial matters, North and South, his fine personal manners, his popularity, his determination, all point to him as a fit person for the position.

abstract: The Eleventh Regiment Washington Rifles, composed mainly of Germans, was busy all day at the armory corner of Chrystle and Delancey streets, preparing for departure, undaunted by the refusal of the U.S. Quartermaster to furnish uniforms.
lead_paragraph: The Eleventh Regiment Washington Rifles, composed mainly of Germans, was busy all day at the armory corner of Chrystle and Delancey streets, preparing for departure, undaunted by the refusal of the U.S. Quartermaster to furnish uniforms. They determined to go in their own private uniforms, taking recruits ununiformed, and relying upon being properly supplied in Washington. At about noon, Col. BLISS expressed a willingness to supply a requisition for United States uniforms, but it was too late for distribution yesterday, and Col. MAIDHOF, having been once foiled, determined to go anyhow. The ranks were filled to about nine hundred men, and as they formed about 5 P.M., and marched down Broadway, en route, were most cordially greeted. The following is the list of officers:

abstract: CLAD VESSELS. -- We have received a superb lithograph, with the above title, representing the memorable battle between the Monitor and the Merrimac, in Hampton Roads, March 9, 1862. In order to group all the incidents of that famous two days' combat together, the designer, by a pardonable anachronism, represents the Cumberland sinking, the Congress on fire, and the rebels Yorktown and Jamestown, with their tugs, and the United States steamer Minnesota, hotly engaged in the distance. The batteries at Sewall's Point and Newport's News are descried in dim outline at the extreme left and right of the scene.
lead_paragraph: CLAD VESSELS. -- We have received a superb lithograph, with the above title, representing the memorable battle between the Monitor and the Merrimac, in Hampton Roads, March 9, 1862. In order to group all the incidents of that famous two days' combat together, the designer, by a pardonable anachronism, represents the Cumberland sinking, the Congress on fire, and the rebels Yorktown and Jamestown, with their tugs, and the United States steamer Minnesota, hotly engaged in the distance. The batteries at Sewall's Point and Newport's News are descried in dim outline at the extreme left and right of the scene.

abstract: The House of Representatives has passed a bill confiscating all the property of men who shall hereafter hold office under the rebel Government, and of all who, being engaged in the rebellion, shall not lay down their arms within sixty days after proclamation duly made by the President of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives has passed a bill confiscating all the property of men who shall hereafter hold office under the rebel Government, -- and of all who, being engaged in the rebellion, shall not lay down their arms within sixty days after proclamation duly made by the President of the United States. The act will be found at length in another column. It is precise and well-guarded in its language, and prescibes the proceedings by which its penalties are to be enforced.

abstract: A depot has been opened by Col. BLISS for recruiting volunteers for the war under the new call, and thus far applications have been received from more than a dozen commandants of companies, representing about 1,100 men. By the 30th of June it is thought there will be 6,000 recruits from this City. Volunteers must be offered by companies which will be formed into regiments by the Governor, and the officers appointed from headquarters -- thus thwarting all schemes of ambitious but incapable would be Colonels, Majors, &.c, and securing efficient officers for the service. Had this plan been adopted last year it might have been better for the country.

abstract: We have at last Com. TATNALL's official report of the destruction of the Merrimac. It is a curious and interesting document. It shows that the burning of the iron-clad vessel was not in pursuance of any general conference of rebel officers, but that it was the sudden resolution of TATNALL himself, on hearing that our troops had marched upon Norfolk, that the rebel batteries on Craney Island and Sewall's Point had been abandoned, that his pilots deceived him as to their ability to take the vessel up the James River, and that the enemy were present in overwhelming force. He was quite confident the vessel could not stand so unequal a contest, and as he wished to preserve her sailors for the Confederate service, he determined to blow her up. He asks for a Court of Inquiry. We hardly think his explanation will satisfy the rebels.
lead_paragraph: We have at last Com. TATNALL's official report of the destruction of the Merrimac. It is a curious and interesting document. He was quite confident the vessel could not stand so unequal a contest, and as he wished to preserve her sailors for the Confederate service, he determined to blow her up. He asks for a Court of Inquiry. We hardly think his explanation will satisfy the rebels.

abstract: THE ALLEGHANIANS AT THE STUYVESANT INSTITUTE. -- This company of vocalists, under the management of Mr. BOULARD, have been giving a very pleasant evening entertainment in the shape of a bell-ringing and vocal concert, at the Stuyvesant, during the last week. We can honestly recommend them, for the excellence of their entertainment, to our readers, and would more especially praise the vocalism of Miss HIFFERT, which; of not great, is specially pleasing. With the bells they probably exceed any and every other congregation of tintinnabulary executants we have yet had in this City.

abstract: MR. RAREY'S ENTERTAINMENT. At the Cooper Institute, on Tuesday evening, Mr. RAREY, the celebrated horse-tamer, gave an exhibition. He experimented on three horses, one of which was a most vicious brute, that, just before being brought upon the stage, kicked the groom in attendance, and completely demolished a glass door.
lead_paragraph: MR. RAREY's ENTERTAINMENT. -- At the Cooper Institute, on Tuesday evening, Mr. RAREY, the celebrated horse-tamer, gave an exhibition. He experimented on three horses, one of which was a most vicious brute, that, just before being brought upon the stage, kicked the groom in attendance, and completely demolished a glass door. The poor fellow was much hurt, and was conveyed to his home on a litter. Of course, when Mr. RAREY took the animal it was soon subdued, at least comparatively speaking, soon, but not without a severe struggle. Two other horses were also introduced, and soon tamed. Mr. RAREY gives another exhibition this evening, when it is promised that a horse almost as unruly and vicious as the celebrated Cruiser will be introduced to the audience, and thoroughly subjugated.

abstract: -- The rumors that we have been receiving for a week past that BEAUREGARD had left Corinth for Richmond, are confirmed by one of our correspondents this morning, who writes that that personage arrived in the rebel capital last Thursday. BEAUREGARD's popularity is with the rebel army of the East; with that of the West he has never been popular. It was in Virginia that he achieved success -- such as it was; whereas in the West he has uniformly been associated with defeats or retreats. It was he (if not Gen. [???]) who induced SIDNEY JOHNSTON to evacuate Bowling Green, it was he who ordered the evacuation of Columbus; it was he who selected No. 10 as an impregnable position, though it was the most unfortunate position for the rebels; it was he who, after his superior officer, SIDNEY JOHNSTON, had won the day at Pittsburgh and had fallen, feebly attempted to carry out JOHNSTON's tactics on the second day, and failed. On these grounds, he is disliked in the West; whereas BRAGG and PRICE, both at Corinth, are immensely popular. The clamor of the Eastern army for its old leader has no doubt induced JEFF. DAVIS to recall BEAUREGARD from Corinth, to try his skill at the defence of the rebel Capital. Having been used to retreats of late, he may now again be of service in that line.

abstract: One of our correspondents with  the army before Richmond informs us that the rebel army, which has of late been drawn close to and immediately around Richmond, is now being rapidly thrown forward from the rebel Capital toward the Chickahominy River, and directly in front of the main body of our army.
lead_paragraph: -- One of our correspondents with the army before Richmond informs us that the rebel army, which has of late been drawn close to and immediately around Richmond, is now being rapidly thrown forward from the rebel Capital toward the Chickahominy River, and directly in front of the main body of our army. This, it is thought, is a positive indication that the rebel Generals are going to contest, with their whole force, the occupancy of Richmond. Though MCCLELLAN is pressing close upon the city from two directions, and MCDOWELL is menacing it from Fredericksburgh, and the gunboats are but a short distance below it in front, there is no indication that the rebel host is preparing to evacuate. The retreat of such an army is not a thing that can be effected in a day, nor in two days; and, as our forces must now be within cannon shot of it, it would be impossible for it to make good its retreat at all, if the pursuit were pressed with vigor. These things certainly all look as if there was to be a desperate struggle for Richmond. The view would seem to be confirmed, too, by the late demonstrations of the political chiefs of the South against a peaceful surrender. The Legislature of Virginia has resolved that the "capital of the State must be defended to the last extremity;" Gov. LETCHER declares that the "capital of Virginia must not be surrendered;" the Mayor of Richmond says he "would sooner die than surrender the city;" JEFF. DAVIS says that he "does not see or anticipate the necessity that the capital should fall;" and the Press talks of a general slaughter before such an event shall take place. It maybe that these demonstrations have forced the rebel authorities to do their utmost to save the city from a surrender.

abstract: The steamer S.R. Spaulding arrived here yesterday morning with 330 sick and wounded soldiers from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army.
lead_paragraph: The steamer S.R. Spaulding arrived here yesterday morning with 330 sick and wounded soldiers from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army. The Spaulding left White River Point, Pamunkey River, at noon on Monday. The soldiers were taken from the General Hospital at that place and from the receiving-ship Elm City. Most of them are sick, but few dangerously so. There are about 1,000 patients remaining in the hospital at White River Point. Of those that arrived in the Spaulding, about 100 will be sent to David's Island, 66 to the New-York Hospital, and the remainder to their homes. The following is a list of their names:

abstract: SABBATH-SCHOOL ANNIVERSARY. The annual celebration of the Brooklyn Sabbath-school, postponed from Tuesday on account of the inclement weather, took place yesterday. The ringing of the bells at 11 o'clock A.M. the signal to be made in case the parade was to come off made the hearts of not less than twenty-five thousand children thrill with pleasure, and promptly the members of each school proceeded to the appointed rendezvous.
lead_paragraph: SABBATH-SCHOOL ANNIVERSARY. -- The annual celebration of the Brooklyn Sabbath-school, postponed from Tuesday on account of the inclement weather, took place yesterday. The ringing of the bells at 11 o'clock A.M. -- the signal to be made in case the parade was to come off -- made the hearts of not less than twenty-five thousand children thrill with pleasure, and promptly the members of each school proceeded to the appointed rendezvous. While waiting to join in the division processions, their spirits were considerably dampened by a drizzling rain, which now commenced falling. But they did not long let this disappointment cloud their brows. The time was passed very pleasantly in listening to appropriate and considerately short speeches, singing, and partaking of the good things the partiality of friends had provided for them. Though thwarted by the elements in regard to a parade in force, they were determined not to forego the anticipated pleasures in the churches, so at 2 o'clock -- the time named in the programme -- each school marched, with banners and flags flying, and accompanied by music, to the particular churches set apart for their use respectively, and there the order of exercises, consisting of speaking, singing and partaking of refreshments, was carried out to the letter, and much to the satisfaction of all concerned. At the close of these proceedings, some of the schools, still bent upon having a procession of some kind, formed and marched several squares, honoring sister schools, prominent citizens and others, occasionally, as they passed along, with rounds of cheers. It is estimated that not less than 25,000 children were present at the different churches, and not an accident of any kind occurred to mar the occasion.

abstract: Editorial discusses conquering the South
snippet: Editorial discusses conquering the South
lead_paragraph: The rebels are very fond of saying that they may be beaten, but they cannot be subjugated. They may lose all their cities, have all their armies defeated, and be driven from every important military position, -- and yet, they say, no progress will have been made toward the conquest of the South. They can retire to the mountains, and there protract the contest indefinitely. Their foreign agents and allies deal extensively in this language, which produces, without doubt, considerable effect upon a large portion of the public.

abstract: The libel in the case of HAMILTON E. TOWLE against the Great Eastern was filed yesterday. The libelant, who is an American, and a civil engineer by profession, was a passenger on board the Great Eastern on her attempted voyage from Liverpool to NewYork, in September, 1861.
lead_paragraph: The libel in the case of HAMILTON E. TOWLE against the Great Eastern was filed yesterday. The libelant, who is an American, and a civil engineer by profession, was a passenger on board the Great Eastern on her attempted voyage from Liverpool to NewYork, in September, 1861. The libel states that on the 12th day of September, the ship being then about three hundred miles west of Cape Clear, she was overtaken by a violent storm, which carried away the side-wheels, disabled the rudder, and did other serious damage. That the officers of the ship endeavored, by means of various devices, to steer the ship, but failed, and she remained from the afternoon of Thursday, the 12th, until the evening of Sunday, the 15th of September, in the trough of the sea, entirely at the mercy of the storm. That on Friday the libelant devised a temporary steering apparatus, and asked permission of the Captain to apply it to the broken rudder, which request was declined. That, on Saturday evening, at the solicitation of the passengers, the captain consented to allow the libelant to construct his steering apparatus, and placed men and material at his disposal, to enable him to complete his design. That on Sunday evening the temporary apparatus was completed, and was found to be sufficient to steer the ship, and with it she was brought safely to a harbor, reaching the Cove of Cork on Tuesday, Sept. 17. The libelant claims for services in the nature of salvage one hundred thousand dollars. HOWLAND & ASPINWALL, consignees of the ship, having become sureties for the claim, the ship is released, and will sail for Liverpool, as previously appointed, on Saturday.

abstract: Unless we have been misinformed, the Ordnance Department is practicing a piece of very cruel economy. We have been informed that the troops now so gallantly rushing to the field in response to the call of the President, are being armed with the guns purchased in Austria and palmed off on our Government, and which may be found condemned in the report upon contracts from the Ordnance Department, recently published. If this is so, the matter should have the immediate attention of the President and the Secretary of War. That report discloses the fact that a large number of old guns, nearly worn out, originally smooth bore, but rifled and "fixed up" to give them a modern appearance, which were condemned by some of the officers of the Ordnance Department, as both inefficent and unsafe, were purchased under a careless contract, from which the Government could not honorably escape. To put these guns in the hands of the noble fellows who hazard their lives in defence of the country, is both wretched policy and outrageous cruelty. It should not be tolerated for a moment, merely because it will cost a few thousand dollars to procure better guns. We certainly hope the President will give the matter his attention.

abstract: Our advices from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, received from one of our special correspondents, are of importance. They seem to indicate that whatever the rebels might have intended to do a week since, they now mean to fight for the possession of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, received from one of our special correspondents, are of importance. They seem to indicate that whatever the rebels might have intended to do a week since, they now mean to fight for the possession of Richmond. Reconnoissances, by balloon and otherwise, had established the fact that the line of the Chickahominy was almost entirely deserted, and that between it and Richmond were but a comparatively small body of men. Now, however, it is different. The rebels have reoccupied the space in heavy force, and have again approached the Chickahominy in great numbers, apparently with the intention of disputing the way to the rebel Capital inch by inch. Our correspondent mentions the fact that BEAUREGARD has arrived, and evidently thinks that this new movement on the part of the rebels is due to his counsel.

abstract: The consideration of the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs was, when the bill was reported by the Committee of Commerce, postponed until the 29th inst. An inspection of the bill which they have reported shows that the Committee now propose not to give the Solicitor any assistant, thus saving that additional salary. But they have reincorporated in the bill a provision for the settlement, outside of the Courts, of cases involving less than $1,000. Such a provision was in the bill when it was first proposed, but on discussion it was amended by leaving this new feature out. For some reason the Committee have put it into the bill again, but their report does not enlighten us as to what the reason was.
lead_paragraph: The consideration of the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs was, when the bill was reported by the Committee of Commerce, postponed until the 29th inst. An inspection of the bill which they have reported shows that the Committee now propose not to give the Solicitor any assistant, thus saving that additional salary. But they have reincorporated in the bill a provision for the settlement, outside of the Courts, of cases involving less than $1,000. Such a provision was in the bill when it was first proposed, but on discussion it was amended by leaving this new feature out. For some reason the Committee have put it into the bill again, but their report does not enlighten us as to what the reason was.

abstract: Within the past three days the disposition of the whole rebel army before Richmond seems to have been changed. Instead of the rebels retreating, with all their supplies and camp equipage toward the city, they are coming from it in large numbers, and are evidently determined to make a stand between it and the Chickahominy River.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRIDGE, CHICKAHOMINY RIVER, Va., Monday Evening, May 26, 1862.

abstract: Your readers know that Boston is a moral town. They have doubtless heard how once each year the vital piety, of which its atmosphere is redolent, attracts the gentle shepherd from all the eccleslastical folds of New-England, who, after enjoying a six days' hospitality, return to recount to their accustomed charges the wonders they have seen, and the thoughts which those wonders excite in their minds. We are at this moment under that annual visitation.

abstract: The second battalions of all the regular regiments of the United States Army, now in process of organization, are to be filled up at once.
lead_paragraph: The second battalions of all the regular regiments of the United States Army, now in process of organization, are to be filled up at once. The Twelfth and Fourteenth regiments of foot, having a considerable number of their second battalions enlisted, have already sent officers to recruit for the remainder. Meantime all the soldiers at present attached to the second battalions of these two regiments, have been ordered, and have gone to the National Capital. Six captains of the Twelfth have been sent out for men, and whoever does not complete his company before the battalion is filled, must wait for the third. The Government has expressed a strong desire to fill up these regiments.

abstract: The City of Natchez, of whose (virtual though not nominal) surrender to our gunboats we now learn, is 300 miles above New-Orleans, by the course of the river, 540 below Memphis, 100 Southwest of Jackson, the capital of the State; and is the largest city in Mississippi -- its population, by last census, being 13,550. It is situated on the left bank of the river, mostly on a high bluff, near 200 feet above the river level. That portion of the city on the margin of the river is termed "Natchez under the Hill;" and most of the heavy mercantile business is done in this part of the town, and most of the gamblers, robbers, cyprians, and bowie-knife chivalry, for which Natchez was erst so famous, had here their headquarters. The upper town -- "Natchez over the Hill" -- stands on the bluff, and is an elegant and salubrious spot -- the thermometer here seldom rising above 90 degrees. From this point, as far as the eye can reach along the margin of the river, is seen rich and well-cultivated cotton plantations, and the seats of many wealthy families, [see diagram,] while beyond this is a boundless waste of deep and impenetrable swamps. The city is one of the principal cotton ports on the Mississippi; the streets are often rendered impassable by the piles of cotton bales waiting to be shipped; but since the rebellion all this has passed away. Natchez carries on (in the past tense) an extensive inland and foreign trade; many large vessels come up to the town, receive their freight, and sail to foreign ports. There are several large foundries here for making engines, which have been of use to the rebels. The cotton plantations in the vicinity, with the names of their owners, and other interesting local details, will be found accurately set forth in our diagram.

abstract: The President directs that the New-York regiments be uniformed before being mustered into the service. Such was the peremptory manner in which the President cut the coils of red tape that bound our City regiments, and prevented their promptdeparture for the seat of war in response to the call of the Government.
lead_paragraph: The President directs that the New-York regiments be uniformed before being mustered into the service. Such was the peremptory manner in which the President cut the coils of red tape that bound our City regiments, and prevented their promptdeparture for the seat of war in response to the call of the Government. Consequently, at an early hour yesterday morning, the distribution of uniforms renewed the bustle and excitement at the various armories of our City militia. Each locality was the duplicate of the others, for in all there was the same crowd of half-equipped soldiers. The same bustle of assorting and distributing uniforms, arms and equipments, the same throng of friends and relatives attendant upon those who so nobly and so promptly responded to the call of the Republic. Indeed, the scene throughout the city was a repetition of that which succeeded the fall of Fort Sumter, and the first call for volunteer soldiers. Everywhere the national bunting was hung to the breeze; everywhere there were knots of soldiers of varied uniforms; everywhere friends of the various regiments patiently awaiting the departure of their favorite corps. Nor was the proportion of the fair sex that usually adorns such occasions, in any way diminished. In all the thoroughfares there were dashing officers or sombre privates escorting fair friends on the final promenade, discussing the chances of war, the possibility of a triumphant return, or a glorious death.

abstract: It seems that the order  imputed to Gen. BUTLER, concerning ladies who make up faces at the Union soldiers, was genuine.
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that the order imputed to Gen. BUTLER, concerning ladies who make up faces at the Union soldiers, was genuine. He did actually issue it, though there comes with it from New-Orleans an explanatory paragraph, which somewhat modifies its effect. It seems that by a municipal regulation in New-Orleans, "women of the town practicing their avocation" are liable to be imprisoned in the Calaboose; and Gen. BUTLER merely intends to say by his order, that women who insult or express contempt, by word or gesture, for any officer or soldier of the United States, shall be subject to the same punishment. We regret that he did not say so in distinct terms, if that was his meaning. Besides the coarse and needless vulgarity of the language of his order, it was obnoxious to the very serious misconstruction which was put upon it by Gen. BEAUREGARD, and by nearly all who read it, without the comment by which it has now been followed. Our troops have probably had more severe trials to encounter than the scowls and grimaces of the female department of Secession; but if they cannot sustain these afflictions, they should have some regard to decency and their own dignity in their mode of inflicting punishment.

abstract: Pursuant to an order published in yesterday's Times, the Eighth Regiment N.Y.S.M. left for Washington last evening.
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to an order published in yesterday's Times, the Eighth Regiment N.Y.S.M. left for Washington last evening. Regimental line was commenced to be formed on Lafayette-place at 4 o'clock, and the men, shortly after 5, were marched to TIFFANY & Co.'s store, on Broadway, where they were drawn up in line, in order, to have a handsome stand of colors presented to them. Col. VARIAN advanced to the front, and his field, staff and line officers gathered around him. Gen. ANTHON, accompanied by Gen. HALL, Col. BLISS, Hon. B.F. PINCKNEY, and other well-known gentlemen, then came forward, and made the presentation on behalf of the friends of the regiment. In doing so, he said:

abstract: Gen. BUTLER's orders, which fall thick as Autumn leaves around the cars of the Secessionists of New-Orleans, are about the spiciest specimens of Southern literature which reach us now-a-days. The General governs all departments of his new realm with most commendable vigor and vigilance. We see he has taken charge of the Delta. If its articles are as sharp as his orders, we trust he will put the TIMES on his exchange list.

abstract: The British steamship Stellin, of London, in charge of Acting-Master T.D. BARCLAY, from Charleston bar, May 24, arrived at this port last evening.
lead_paragraph: The British steamship Stellin, of London, in charge of Acting-Master T.D. BARCLAY, from Charleston bar, May 24, arrived at this port last evening. The Stettin was captured off Cape Romain on the morning of May 24, while attempting to run the blockade at Charleston. She has a cargo of brandy, wines, saltpetre, &c., which, with the vessel, is valued at half a million of dollars.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning the armory of this regiment was crowded with the friends of the members, who expected that the corps would leave by noon.  The armory of the Sixty-ninth presented a busy scene all day yesterday, the bustle and confusion of which was materially heightened by the crooked and narrow staircase, which some stupid architect constructed.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning the armory of this regiment was crowded with the friends of the members, who expected that the corps would leave by noon. The armory of the Sixty-ninth presented a busy scene all day yesterday, the bustle and confusion of which was materially heightened by the crooked and narrow staircase, which some stupid architect constructed. They were disappointed, it not leaving till nearly 9 o'clock. During the greater part of the day, the officers were busily employed in distributing uniforms, knapsacks, canteens, arms, &c., to the men. All were in the highest spirits, and when it was known, positively, that regimental line would be formed at 6 o'clock, intense enthusiasm and every feeling of delight were manifested. The regiment has not been organized quite a year, and the young men who compose it have great satisfaction in the fact that it was among the first that offered on the reception of the President's last call. They will be armed with the Enfield rifle, some, it is said, of the lot taken from the enemy at Fort Donelson.

abstract: Editorial questions activities of iron-clad ships on James River
snippet: Editorial questions activities of iron-clad ships on James River
lead_paragraph: -- It seems, as matters now stand, that our fleet of iron-clad gunboats on the James River is destined to have no part in the operations against Richmond. Ever since their repulse from Fort Darling, a fortnight ago, they have been, and are still, lying idle, fifteen or twenty miles below City Point.
