abstract: Since Tuesday last, every succeeding hour witnesses increased exertions to put the new regular regiments on a war footing. Being enlisted for four years, and for general service, they are found to be availlable for all duties, no matter where to be performed. These new regiments are eleven in number, have, or are to have, three battalions of 800 men, giving each regiment when full 2,400 men. All have their first battalion filled, and serving at the seat of war. Several have their second nearly organized, and the Eighteenth, the headquarters of which is at Columbus, Ohio, has its three battalions, or the entire 2,400 men enrolled. Yesterday recruiting was commenced at several new stations, and there is hardly a town of any importance in the States of Maine. Ohio, Connecticut, New-Hampshire, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, that representatives of the above troops are not enlisting men. Lieut. MORGAN, Twelfth Foot, has been dispatched to Pottsville, Penn., for the purpose of opening a recruiting office there. He is to send on to Fort Hamilton all the men obtained, who will be supplied with requisites and drilled for duty. The Fourteenth Regiment, now numbering over 1,200 rank and file, has opened offices to fill up is ranks, and all the troops enlisted for its second battalion were sent to Washington on Tuesday. Over 800 members of this regiment are in the advance, with Gen. MCCLELLAN's army. An officer engaged on the Medical Staff in this City -- Mr. CHARLES F. HOWARD -- left yesterday to report for duty to the War Department. Soldiers enlisted for the old regiments of the army, or for "general service," are to be forwarded to the headquarters of the recruiting service for the Department of the East.

abstract: THE  REBEL ACCOUNT. Gen. BEAUREGARD'S Report of the Battle of Shiloh must have been more to the taste of President DAVIS than that of Bull Run, as it has seen the light within two months after the conflict.
lead_paragraph: -- THE REBEL ACCOUNT. -- Gen. BEAUREGARD's Report of the Battle of Shiloh must have been more to the taste of President DAVIS than that of Bull Run, as it has seen the light within two months after the conflict. There are reasons indeed why it should be satisfactory. BEAUREGARD is shrewd and plausible. He knows how to put a bad picture in an advantageous light; and doubtless, nine out of ten of his dull rebel readers fancy the narrative to be one of a victory, attended by inestimable strategic consequences. The odds are all placed on the side of GRANT's army. Its numbers, position, and the presence of the gunboats, are represented at full value; and the daring plans of the rebel leader became really meritorious, considering the magnitude of the task he had set for himself. It was simply to rout GRANT at all points, under the very guns of the flotilla, drive his forces into the river, and return to Corinth, carrying back untold booty in great guns, small arms and equipage. The plan, he alleges, failed only because of the unexpected arrival of BUELL; but so admirably conducted was the retreat, that the rebels reached the lines of Corinth without the Nationals venturing to harass them. They found it inconvenient, however, to take with them anything but such better weapons as the rebels picked up on the field, as the relics of runaway Yankees. The losses in general officers, and rank and file, on the rebel side, are admitted to be great; but newspaper reports are relied upon to prove the loss on the side of the North to be yet greater.

abstract: Everybody appears  to be delighted with the comprehensiveness, energy and humanity of the new SurgeonGeneral, Dr. HAMMOND.
lead_paragraph: -- Everybody appears to be delighted with the comprehensiveness, energy and humanity of the new SurgeonGeneral, Dr. HAMMOND. But everybody is asking, what has become of that corps of Inspectors, which, by the provisions of the bill under which Dr. HAMMOND was appointed, were immediately to be selected by the President and Senate out of the whole medical corps, and the Brigade Surgeons, with sole reference to qualifications, for the purpose of carrying out necessary reforms and animating a new medical regime. Notwithstanding the well-known sufferings of the army -- requiring an immense amount of volunteer aid in the Medical Department; notwithstanding the necessity of superseding the inefficiency of the old grade by men of talent and zeal raised to higher rank, and thus able to overrule them; notwithstanding the cry of the army, East and West, for additional medical men, -- six weeks have passed by and no action has been taken to supply the only instruments by which any reform can be carried into the Medical Department. Dr. HAMMOND must be as helpless as a man without limbs in his present position. He might have the energies of a giant, and yet, in the exhausted receiver in which he is left, perish.

abstract: Notwithstanding all that has been said in certain of the public prints, as to the escape of JAMES CARSON from the City, the Police authorities have been all the time aware of the fact that he was secreted somewhere in New-York.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding all that has been said in certain of the public prints, as to the escape of JAMES CARSON from the City, the Police authorities have been all the time aware of the fact that he was secreted somewhere in New-York. The officers having the case in charge have been very vigilant in their efforts to ascertain the whereabouts of CARSON, and it was doubtless owing to their watchfulness, aided by the advice of Messrs. GRAHAM & AVERHILL counsel for CARSON, -- that the latter was yesterday induced to surrender himself to the officers. On Wednesday last Justice QUACKENBUSH, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, issued a warrant for CARSON's arrest, upon the application of Officer WILLIAM WARREN, of the Eighth Precinct, who represented to the Justice that he had reliable information that CARSON was still in the City, and that he believed he could be arrested if proper and timely action were taken. The result of this step was that CARSON yesterday afternoon delivered himself up to Policeman WARREN. He was immediately taken before the Justice, who issued the warrant, and after an examination, he was held to bail in the sum of $5,000 for his appearance to answer any indictment which may be found against him by the Grand Jury. In answer to the usual questions put to him by the Justice, CARSON stated that he was 32 years of age; that he was born in Philadelphia, and that his residence was Ontonagon, in the State of Michigan. His occupation, he says, is that of a general dealer in real estate, and in the mining business. In answer to the question if he had anything to say as to the charge preferred against him, he made the following statement under oath, taken verbatim as it was uttered by him:

abstract: Yesterday was an auspicious day for the opening of the season at the Union Course on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was an auspicious day for the opening of the season at the Union Course on Long Island. A trot for a purse and stake of $800 was advertised, in which the gray gelding Ed Eddy, the black mare Sunnyside, and the sorrel mare Widow Machree were to engage before wagons, mile heats, and the best three in five. The Widow was withdrawn for some sufficient reason, leaving the Course open to Eddy and Sunny side, the former to be driven by MCMANN and the latter by PFIFER.

abstract: Editorial holds war now at dead halt
snippet: Editorial holds war now at dead halt
lead_paragraph: To the public, at the present moment, military and naval operations seem everywhere to have come almost to a dead halt. The main body of our Eastern Army is, and has been since the early part of the month, in front of the rebel Capital, and of the main body of the Eastern rebel army; but nothing more decisive than a few skirmishes have yet taken place. The main body of the Army of the West has been planted before Corinth ever since the battle of Pittsburgh; a period of now three months; but of its doings we know nothing excepting the fact that it has not yet fought a battle or moved upon the enemy's works. These two mighty armies -- jointly numbering over two hundred thousand men -- have certainly not been inactive during their respective brief periods of pause; but neither have they dazzled the public with any of those grand actions which have been by it daily expected.

abstract: Orders having been received from the Commander-in-Chief countermanding those directing this regiment "to get ready for three months' service, to proceed to Washington at once," the recruiting offices are for the present closed, and enlistments for such service canceled. At a meeting held on Monday, it was unanimously agreed to go, and strenuous exertions were being made to complete the organization preparatory to an early departure. Two more companies only are wanting to put the Twenty-third on a proper footing for its early acceptance into active service. An opportunity is thus offered to the young men of Brooklyn for joining a regiment which, in material and military efficiency, promises to rival the best in the State. Headquarters, Arsenal Portland-avenue, every Monday evening. The officers, as far as appointed, are W. EVERDELL, Jr., Colonel; Edwin Beers, Lieutenant-Colonel; J.R. Elwell, Major.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the memorial presented by Mr. WILLEY, of Virginia, in reference to the separation of that State, was referred to the Committee on Territories. The Tax bill was then again considered, the question being on the proposition to tax slave property. Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, offered an amendment to reduce the proposed tax from $5 to $2 each, which was adopted, after considerable debate. The proposition, as thus amended, was finally defeated, 22 to 14. The Senate adjourned, after holding an Executive Session.

abstract: Editorial on Jackson activities in Shenandoah Valley
snippet: Editorial on Jackson activities in Shenandoah Valley
lead_paragraph: The raid of the rebel JACKSON down the Shenandoah Valley, has not been without its most salutary fruits. In this case, as in so many others during the progress of the unholy rebellion against our Government, our reverses have seemed designed by Providence to strengthen and glorify our cause. In the very first act of the drama -- the fall of Sumter -- there was disaster in a military sense; but no other event could have proved so precious and priceless to the flag that was there humbled and insulted. Again, the Baltimore riots on the 19th April, were a most terrible and momentous development, and for a time the nation seemed appalled by the deep-seated and wide-spread disaffection that was revealed. But what other event could have so aroused the loyal energies of the people and the Government, or led to such perfect defences against a similar future outbreak, which might have been at another time far more damaging to the National cause.

abstract: At about 2 1/2 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a fire broke out in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, near the foot of North Second-street, which, owing to the combustible nature of the material it had to feed upon, rapidly extended along the river front, nearly to North Fourth-street, and back one square to Water-street, where its further progress was stayed, through the almost superhuman exertion of the firemen, who were materially aided in their labors by the River Police.

abstract: On an  other page we publish a dressing of the first iron-clad vessel, or rather plan of an iron-clad vessel, for it never came to material realization.
lead_paragraph: -- On another page we publish a dressing of the first iron-clad vessel, or rather plan of an iron-clad vessel, for it never came to material realization. The drawings of this ship, for which letters patent were taken out by THOMAS GREGG, of Pennsylvania, in 1814, are copied from the originals deposited in the Patent-office in Washington, and are accompanied by the inventor's specifications. We give it, of course, simply for its historical interest, without expecting that the model will be immediately adopted by our naval architects: though, for that matter, our modern Monitors and Merrimacs are quite as grotesque in shape as this original father of the pachyderms. Mr. GREGG's ship embraces many if not all the features of iron-clad vessels of to-day, and is a new illustration of that law of anticipation so common in science and art.

abstract: John A. Cantor, Plaintiff in Error, vs. The People, Defendants in Error. The defendant was indicted,tried and convicted in the New-York General Sessions for having in his possession, with intent to ...
lead_paragraph: John A. Cantor, Plaintiff in Error, vs. The People, Defendants in Error. -- The defendant was indicted,tried and convicted in the New-York General Sessions for having in his possession, with intent to pass, and passing counterfeit money. He was sentenced to ten years and five months in the State Prison. The case comes before this Court on writ of error. Various exceptions to decisions of the Court below on points of law, having been taken on the trial by the prisoner's counsel, this Court reversed the judgment and granted a new trial.

abstract: MR. RAREY's ENTERTAINMENT. -- Mr. RAREY gave his second entertainment at the Cooper Institute, last evening. His theory of horse-taming was illustrated with three extremely ungentle animals, the first of which was owned by Mr. THOMAS ROBSON. This was a young sorrel colt, which was entirely wild and ungoverned at the time of his introduction to the audience. The second horse belonged to Mr. KRALES; the third, and last, which was the longest and strongest of all, to Mr. BELLOWS Mr. RAREY stated it to be his belief that the most important lesson to teach the horse is that of standing still; and encouraged his maternal hearers by assuring them that colts were more easily governed than children. The lecture was extremely entertaining, and was concluded by a general invitation to those of his audience who owned horses to commit them to his teachings. He announced another lecture for tomorrow evening and one for Saturday afternoon.

abstract: This regiment, Col. WARD, will leave the City to-day for Washington. Since the last call for troops the officers have been most active in endeavoring to raise it to the full standard. Now it is nearly full: a few more only are wanted; good, active men should apply early this morning at the Mercer House, in Broome-street, or at headquarters over Jefferson Market. This morning at 9 o'clock all the members are ordered to report themselves at the drill-rooms of their respective armories, in order to be inspected and sworn in.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, passed a resolution making the New-York Staats Zeitung a Corporation paper. The resolution appropriating $12,000 for the completion of the Fourthavenue Park, after some discussion was laid over.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, passed a resolution making the New-York Staats Zeitung a Corporation paper. The resolution appropriating $12,000 for the completion of the Fourthavenue Park, after some discussion was laid over. The Chairman of the Committee on National Affairs announced in answer to an inquiry, that the building in the Central Park, formerly known as the Mount St. Vincent Academy, had been secured for the accommodation of convalescent soldiers, and would be ready for occupation next week. The Board of Councilmen was not in session.

abstract: Judge ROST'S letter to his rebel brother YANCEY, which Gen. BUTLER has exhuined and published in the New-Orleans papers, gives us a glimpse into the domestic councils of the Confederates.
lead_paragraph: -- Judge ROST's letter to his rebel brother YANCEY, which Gen. BUTLER has exhuined and published in the New-Orleans papers, gives us a glimpse into the domestic councils of the Confederates. He writes from Spain, whither he had gone in pursuit of recognition. He was told at Paris, both by the Spanish Legation and by the French Minister, that he couldn't get it, and he discovers, to his sorrow, that it is even so. But, worse than all this, he is compelled to abandon the hope that any European Power will break the blockade. "This," he confesses, "destroys the last hope" of receiving the slightest aid from any of the leading Powers of Europe.

abstract: It is  fortunate, in view of the late symptoms of returning loyalty in North Carolina, that there are able men in that Commonwealth both competent and willing to direct this movement.
lead_paragraph: -- It is fortunate, in view of the late symptoms of returning loyalty in North Carolina, that there are able men in that Commonwealth both competent and willing to direct this movement. Unlike most of the seceded States, the leaders of opinion and politics, the influential and representative men of North Carolina, are in many cases loyal. The Old North State does not breed that type of fiery Southern Secessionist aristocracy common both to the State that lies North and that which lies South of her. Not that the men referred to have been, or are now, actively loyal; no doubt they have acquiesced in the secession rule -- quietly biding their time. But all their instincts, habitudes and sympathies incline them to the side of the Union, and just as soon as they can safely do so, they will doubtless come forward and give voice and form to the popular sentiment in favor of a return to it.

abstract: THE PRIZE STEAMER CONSTITUTION -- By Statements made in City Journals it would be construed that the above-named vessel, which arrived last night, was another valuable prize, but in justice to parties concerned, we wish to make a correction, us follows. The Constitution was formerly the George Washington, of Albany, and plied between Newburgh and Troy, and at the time of her capture was under United States Government charter, having a cargo of 500 bushels of oats and a few sutler's stores, for Port Royal. She is only 175 tons burden. When off Lockwood's Folly Inlet, which to 15 miles from Wilmington ton River. N.C., she was hailed by U.S. gunboat Penobscot, and ordered off that port; the pilot, not knowing his course, became confused; she was again hailed, by the Monticello and gunboat Victoria, when the became suspicious, and was taken in charge by Executive Officer Alfred Emerson.
lead_paragraph: THE PRIZE STEAMER CONSTITUTION -- By Statements made in City Journals it would be construed that the above-named vessel, which arrived last night, was another valuable prize, but in justice to parties concerned, we wish to make a correction, us follows. abstract: Gen. HALLECK'S combinations against the rebels at Corinth have proved too much for them, and they have evacuated the position last ditch and all.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK's combinations against the rebels at Corinth have proved too much for them, and they have evacuated the position -- last ditch and all. The dispatches published by us yesterday announced that three strong reconnoitering columns of our army advanced on Wednesday morning from the right, centre and left, to "feel" the enemy, and to unmask his batteries. The enemy, it appears, hotly contested our advance at each point, but was driven back with considerable loss. Gen. POPE's column, on the left, encountered the strongest opposition, and our loss there was twenty-five killed and wounded, while the enemy left thirty dead on the field. The fighting was renewed on Thursday morning, Gen. POPE's heavy batteries opening upon the enemy's works, from the advanced batteries of which he soon drove the rebels. Gen. SHERMAN in the course of the day also established a heavy battery at only one thousand yards' distance; and early yesterday morning skirmishing parties were advanced in all directions. Three of our divisions soon occupied the enemy's intrenchments, about a mile from Corinth, which was soon discovered to be in flames, and the enemy falling back. Our troops immediately pushed forward, and Gen. POPE's advance, the Thirty-ninth Ohio, occupied the town, and planted the "Old Glory" on the Court-house. The enemy, it appears, evacuated the place during Thursday night, and retreated down the railroad toward Mobile -- one report states, to take up a new position at Okolona, about sixty miles below on the railroad. Gen. HALLECK seems to be in doubt about the enemy's movements, accounts being, he says, conflicting. He is of opinion that the rebels are in strong force on our left flank, some four or five miles south of Corinth, but of course on the railroad. He has doubtless taken measures to ascertain the truth, which we shall all learn in good time.

abstract: Yesterday a motion was mad; before Judge BETTS, at Chambers, by HOWLAND & ASPINWALL, consignees of the Great Eastern, through their counsel, WM. M. EVARTS, to reduce the amount of security required to insure the release of the vessel, and enable her to proceed on her voyage, or to dismiss the case entirely. In support of the latter proposition, the Chief Engineer and other officers of the vessel testified that the services of Mr. TOWLE were of no such value as alleged. Judge BETTS was to decide the motion at 10 o'clock last night. The motion was opposed by Judge BIRDSEYE.

abstract: There is to be an anniversary reception, at Union Hall, Cooper Institute, this evening, for Col. W.A. BARTLETT and any of his Naval Brigade who may now be in the City. Yesterday, May 30, was the anniversary of the landing of the corps at Fortress Monroe, over 900 strong. Col. BARTLETT had the misfortune to be severely wounded, on the 2d of June, while mounting a Sawyer rifled gun on the Rip Raps. He has now quite recovered his health and has succeed in clearing the docket of all the bills for the equipment of the corps, and himself and his friends will only look to the Government for reimbursement. Col. BARTLETT proposes now to raise a second brigade of 1,200 on the same plan.

abstract: It is safe to say the news of the rebels having evacuated Corinth was as little expected as was that of the evacuation of Yorktown. At Corinth had been located one of the very last ditches of the insurrection.
lead_paragraph: It is safe to say the news of the rebels having evacuated Corinth was as little expected as was that of the evacuation of Yorktown. At Corinth had been located one of the very last ditches of the insurrection. There, with as numerous a throng of traitors as could ever be brought together, in a position possessing every natural advantage in addition to the most elaborate defensive works, and surrounded by approaches of peculiar difficulty, it was reckoned confidently, North and South, that one of the two decisive battles of the war would have to be fought, and that doubts as to the relative force and martial characteristics of the antagonists would require no further solution. The force under Gen. BEAUREGARD has been rated at various figures. A moderate estimate derived from others of much larger proportions, would seem to justify a belief that at least one hundred and thirty thousand men were behind the lines of Corinth. The ablest Generals in the rebel service -- BEAUREGARD, BRAGG, HARDEE, POLK, and VAN DORN, to say nothing of BRECKINRIDGE -- were at the head of the several divisions; men who, beyond mere military skill and experience, possessed the entire confidence of their soldiers. All these conditions turned the odds of the apparently impending conflict in favor of the rebels, who had an additional incentive to desperate resistance in the circumstance that the fate of Memphis and the Mississippi River was dependent on the result. Yet all these arguments for a great fight have been spoiled by the event. The rebels have retired, not in the direction of Memphis, or to a position where the possession of the river might still be disputed, but to a point at the Southeast, which is simply a step in the direction of further retreat. The war in the West is ended. The Mississippi Valley is in possession of the Union. The entire region to the west, from Texas northward, can offer no further resistance to the National arms. Forts Wright and Randolph must fall with the fall of Corinth. The theatre of war is narrowed to the southeastern angle of the Republic. And it is almost certain that, in thus abandoning the Southwestern States, all of the rebel army which was drafted from that section will abandon the flag of BEAUREGARD in a body.

abstract: The trot announced to take place on this course yesterday afternoon for a purse of $100, mile heats, and for which there were five horses entered, did not come off. The weather about mid-day was heavy and threatening, and the fall of a smart shower of rain about the usual hour of departure for the track from the City, caused many of the regular frequenters of the course to absent themselves. The attendance was, consequently, very limited, but the manager, determined to keep faith with the public and the owners of horses, hung up the purse in the judge's stand. The rain having somewhat cleared off, the horses were called upon to come up to start, when it appeared that out of the five horses entered, one only, the Lady Emma, put in an appearance.
lead_paragraph: The trot announced to take place on this course yesterday afternoon for a purse of $100, mile heats, and for which there were five horses entered, did not come off. abstract: The organization of the Stanton Legion is rapidly progressing by companies. The general details are very nearly completed for the entire command, but will not be made public for a few days. If required, he will leave with part of the regiment, but the full command will be recruited.

abstract: By orders issued on Thursday evening, it was supposed that this regiment would leave for Washington last evening. Owing to the fact of the men not having been sworn or mustered in, Col. WARD thought it best to defer the distribution of uniforms until that had taken place. The ceremony will be performance to-day. As soon after as possible the order for march will be issued, and on Sunday, it is presumed, the Twelfth will leave for Washington.

abstract: Berry vs. Kelly, Sheriff, Ketchum et al. -- Ketchum & Son, on the 6th of February, 1861, as creditors of Carroll & Mead, who had suspended payment, caused an attachment to be issued against that firm, consisting of three persons, upon the ground that the members thereof were all non-residents. On the same day the Sheriff levied the attachment on the partnership stock. On the 7th of February the plaintiff bought all of the stock of Carroll & Mead, the sellers agreeing to deduct from the purchase price whatever might be necessary to discharge the lien of the attachment, which they intended to contest. On the 16th of March the attachment was set aside as to one of the defendants, but the Sheriff retained his levy on the partnership stock. Judgment was perfected against all of the defendants, and the Sheriff sold the attached property in parcels to different purchasers. The plaintiff, on the issues coming on for trial, claims that after the attachment was set aside as to one of the partners, it could only hold the individual interest of the other two partners, and as the firm was insolvent, he is entitled to the value of the property as to the whole of the proceeds of the Sheriff's sale. The defendants contend that the principle involved by the plaintiff does not apply when the attachment is issued against one partner for the partnership debt. The case was recently before Chief-Justice Bosworth on a motion for a receiver of the fund pending the action; the motion was denied upon the ground that there was no allegation that the fund was in danger, but the Chief Justice, in his opinion, remarked that "the property being actually attached upon a partnership debt, and sold to satisfy it, it makes a case within the equity of the statute as to executions on a judgment in an action against partners when only a part of them are served with process." The question, in view of the distinction contended for, is a new one, and important to partnerships having a non-resident copartner, as well as to their creditors. Decision reserved.

abstract: To Maj.-Gen. M. Lovell:  The following dispatch was sent to you on the 25th ult. A.T. BLEDSOE, Assistant Secretary of War.  It has been determined to burn all the cotton and tobacco, whether foreign or our own, to prevent it from falling into the hands of the enemy.  You will therefore destroy it all, if necessary, to prevent them from getting it.
lead_paragraph: From the Richmond Examiner.

abstract: Lumber has come in pretty freely, though boats are taking more time than usual on their trips. The reported shipments from Buffalo, Oswego, , are large, so that receipts during the coming week will be large. The assortment in market is good, and the supply increasing every day. A fair business has been done during the week, but buyers purchase mostly in small lots at the advanced prices.

abstract: Three Yankee prisoners, says the Examiner, were brought to this city, yesterday, from the neighborhood of Fredericksburgh. They claim to have belonged to Gen. SHIELDS' Division. This is the first intimation we have had of this General's being in that section of Virginia. When last heard from he was near Winchester. One of the prisoners gave as his opinion that the Yankee army would never get to Richmond. This is the first instance of a Yankee expressing a doubt on the subject. They have universally boasted from first to last that the grand army of the Union was irresistible, and could not be checked in its onward march to this capital.

abstract: Editorial on Confederacy financing war by using cotton as security for bonds; Editorial on Confederate financing of war by using cotton as security for bonds
snippet: Editorial on Confederacy financing war by using cotton as security for bonds; Editorial on Confederate financing of war by using cotton as security for bonds
lead_paragraph: It has been about one year since Mr. MEMMINGER, of South Carolina, who was intrusted with the management of the Confederate finances, presented to the world his first scheme for a war loan. The amount called for was not great, the interest offered was liberal, and the security regarded, by Confederates, at least, as most ample -- being nothing less than a tax on all the cotton to be shipped from the prolific South to all parts of the cotton-consuming world. It occurred to us at the time, and probably to many other much brighter financiers, that it was not wise to pledge all of the money that the Confederate Government expected to raise from the cotton monopoly, to sustain the credit of their first loan, and that by no means a large loan. It was possible that other loans would be needed, and further securities wanted. Would the cotton tax be pledged again? Second mortgages are never as good as first mortgages. At least such has been the estimation of financiers heretofore. It may have been, perhaps it was, reserved to Mr. MEMMINGER to establish the contrary principle. It must be granted he has come amazingly near it, in his treatment of cotton as the security of his Confederate bonds.
headline: {'main': 'Cotton and Confederate Bonds Rebel Financiering.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cotton and Confederate Bonds Rebel Financiering.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Only one branch of Congress was in session yesterday -- the Senate. In that body, after the presentation of various petitions, the bill for the better organization of the Adjutant-General's Department was reported from the Military Committee, but was not acted upon. The Secretary of War was asked to communicate to the Senate a copy of the official report of Gen. HOOKER, relating to the late battle of Williamsburgh. A copy of the correspondence with the War Department, on the subject of the imprisonment of soldiers in the Penitentiary of the District, was called for. The Tax bill was again taken up, at 1 o'clock, and debated until the adjournment. Very little progress was made upon the bill.

abstract: MISS MADELINE HENRIQUES' BENEFIT. -- One of the most popular and charming actresses on the New-York stage takes her first benefit on any stage this evening, at Wallack's Theatre. DOUGLAS JERROLD's comedy of "Time Works Wonders," will be produced for the occasion. This play has not been produced in this City for some time, and is almost as good as new. Independent of this, Miss HENRIQUES' popularity will inevitably attract, as she deserves, a crowded house.

abstract: The release of fourteen hundred Union prisoners, many of them after a confinement of over six months in loathsome Southern prisons, constitutes the chief item of interest and rejoicing for the current week. The event will make glad the hearts in many hitherto desolate homes, and extract one of the bitterest fangs which war has planted in the National bosom.
lead_paragraph: NEWBERN, N.C., Tuesday, May 27, 1862.

abstract: OTTO STIETZ. an artist residing in Chicago, has made for the LaCrosse and Milwaukee Packet Line, and the Buffalo and Milwaukee Propeiler Line, a couple of glass embossings, which exceed in beauty and perfection of portraiture anything of the kind ever seen.
lead_paragraph: OTTO STIETZ. an artist residing in Chicago, has made for the LaCrosse and Milwaukee Packet Line, and the Buffalo and Milwaukee Propeiler Line, a couple of glass embossings, which exceed in beauty and perfection of portraiture anything of the kind ever seen. One is a picture of the propeller Charles Ensign, the other of the steamboat W.F. Davidson. They are etched upon plate-glass with acid, into which is put gold and silver bullion, presenting, when finished, in the case of the propeller, a fac simile of a first-class lake-boat, with sails and spars, ropes and windows, planks and naii-heads, smoke and water, to the very life; while in the other is seen the picture of a regular Mississippi steamboat, low cut, cotton laden, darkies, widows, smoke-pipe and wheel, as in the thing itself. He has also made for the La Crosse, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road, a train of cars, with engine, tender, freight and express cars, which seem us if cut out of solid gold and placed upon the surface of the glass.

abstract: THE ITALIAN INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL AND THE GIRLS' LODGING HOUSE JOLLIFICATION, GINGER SNAPS, ,  The children of the Italian Industrial School under the superintendence of Mr. AGOSTINO E. CERQUA, paid their compliments to the newly-established Girls' Lodging House, on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: THE ITALIAN INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL AND THE GIRLS' LODGING HOUSE -- JOLLIFICATION, GINGER SNAPS, &c., &c. -- The children of the Italian Industrial School under the superintendence of Mr. AGOSTINO E. CERQUA, paid their compliments to the newly-established Girls' Lodging House, on Thursday evening. A magic-lantern exhibition added to the pleasures of the evening, and such hearty laughter was induced by the merry show that appetites were fairly set on edge for the rare feast of cakes and iced lemonade which ensued. The members of the Children's Aid Society, who were present, saw to it that none lacked in participation of these delicacies, which, as a general thing, constituted unattainable temptations upon on corner fruit-stands, and never to be indulged in at the individual expense of those who now, with unrestrained sociability, luxuriated thereupon. After each had partaken to their heart's content, and to a colic-threatening extent, three times; three were given for the Loding-house, and for the considerate friends who had planned this pleasant entertainment for them. A circle of interested observers was present, and appropriate remarks were made by Mr. MACY and others. Some first-rate music formed a main attraction of the evening, and the manner in which these Italian-born children rendered the "Garibaldi March" and other national airs was inspiriting to the fullest degree. By invitation of Mr. and Mrs. TROTT. Superintendents of the Lodging-house, a most satisfactory reconnoissance of the premises, dormitories, &c., took place, the children moving in an orderly manner through each apartment. After this all re-gathered in the spacious reception room, where a song of congratulation from the little Italians was responded to by the transient dwellers in the Lodging-house with the beautiful and suggestive parting hymn, "Heaven is our Home."

abstract: To-morrow bring the 1st of June, from which date the President's proclamation opening the ports of New-Orleans, Beaufort, N.C., and Port Royal, S.C., takes effect, the blockade which has been established at those ports for the past twelvemonth ceases with to-day, and they stand open henceforth for free commercial intercourse with the world  contraband of war excepted.
lead_paragraph: To-morrow bring the 1st of June, from which date the President's proclamation opening the ports of New-Orleans, Beaufort, N.C., and Port Royal, S.C., takes effect, the blockade which has been established at those ports for the past twelvemonth ceases with to-day, and they stand open henceforth for free commercial intercourse with the world -- contraband of war excepted. A number of enterprising shippers and merchants have already put up cargoes and taken out licenses, under the regulations prescribed by Secretary CHASE in his Circular; and Uncle Sam's war-dogs will hardly be withdrawn from their long watch ere argosies freighted with articles of use, of medicine, and of luxury, to which Southern eyes have for months been strangers, will sail into those harbors and take in exchange cargoes of those staples for which our European friends do so pine. Our late files of the French and English journals are filled with speculations as to a possible relaxation of the blockade, which appears to have been diplomatically forthshadowed in London and Paris; and the capture of New-Orleans was chiefly interesting to them as bearing upon this all-important question. The President's proclamation, which has now been received at the other side of the Atlantic, has, however, decided the matter, and without doubt the intelligence has been received with the liveliest satisfaction. It only remains now that the vessels that go in search of the new golden fleece shall be successful in obtaining their cargoes. And for this it is necessary, first, that the cotton shall not have been destroyed, and secondly, that the planters shall be willing to sell. We have very little doubt that both the fact and the disposition will prove satisfactory. Wild fictions have reached us of the burning of cotton along the Mississippi as our flotilla pushed up. Doubtless a certain quantity has been consumed, but it has been the work of Confederate soldiery specially charged with this "patriotic" task, and we have yet to receive evidence that a single planter has either burned his cotton or suffered it to be burned, if he could help it. Already cotton begins to reach New-Orleans from Plaquemine, and our latest advices report the arrival of more from up river. New that the blockade is raised, we shall [???] what the effect [???] our merchants may take down will be in inducing the forthcoming of the floculent fiber.

abstract: The Vicksburgh Whig reports that "prudential preparations are being made by the Government to save the valuable stores which have accumulated at Memphis. Everything that could be of service to the army in the whole city have been turned over to the officials by the business men, and this, too, was done with the utmost cheerfulness in almost every instance. The supplies thus secured are enormous in quantity, and the soldiers will have reason to thank the generous and patriotic citizens of the Bluff City for a long time. Of course this was not done without sacrifices being made in a few instances, but the general verdict is -- better thus than that they should fall into the hands of the enemy."

abstract: editorials on re-opening of trade
snippet: editorials on re-opening of trade
lead_paragraph: We have received by the Urania, which arrived at this port last night, files of Buenos Ayres papers to the 10th of April, but they contain no news not already published. The first news of probable war between England and the United States caused great depression of business among American and British shipping. The latter was not more able to obtain freights than American; and the Swedish, Danish, French and other vessels in Montevideo, were taken up at high rates for Europe and elsewhere, as soon as they arrived in port, -- in some instances before they had commenced to discharge their inward cargoes. Mr. HELPER, the Buenos Ayres Consul appointed by President LINCOLN, was reported to have arrived at Montevideo when the Urania left. Several American vessels had changed owners at ports on the River Plate, and were loading under Buenos Ayrean and Montevidean colors.

abstract: Although Major BAGLEY ordered the Sixty-ninth to form line yesterday morning on Great Jones-street, at 9 o'clock precisely, that famous corps could not be collected at the time designated. The Armory was the scene of the same bustle and confusion that has prevailed during the last few days, and it was late in the afternoon before the distribution of clothing, equipments, &c., was entirely completed. Meanwhile the members of the regiment became somewhat scattered. An impression partially prevailed that there was to be a delay of another day. About 4 o'clock, however, the line was formed, and, attended by a large deputation of what is known as the "Sidewalk Committee," the regiment marched down Broadway to its point of embarkation. It seemed as if each member was attended by his relatives and friends of the family. So dense was the crowd of admirers that it was difficult to tell where the regiment was located, so nearly was it lost in the crowd. Certainly no regiment has been more cordially greeted on its way to the war. The route was thronged with citizens of all classes, not the least prominent among whom were the ladies, whose waving handkerchiefs were uniformly hailed with hearty cheers by the companies as they passed. The personal popularity of Major BAGLEY, Quartermaster TULLY, Adjt. MURPHY, Capts. LYNCH, KIRKER, and others among the officers, was manifested by the frequent hand-shakings to which they were periodically subjected on the match down Broadway. When the regiment reached Fulton-street, the accession of friends of the members was so great, that, though marching by the flank, the continuity of the corps was frequently broken. Many of the privates were forcibly carried to the sidewalk by their friends, and marched in triumphal procession. Indeed, for half a mile behind the main body the stragglers might be seen. So far as we learned, however, all reached the steamer of the New-Jersey Central Railroad in safety, and were soon on their way to the seat of war. May they return with fresh laurels, and with a less sad record than that which they brought from the bloody held of Bull Run.

abstract: Hon. J.E. BOULINGNEY, Member of Congress from New-Orleans, left the Fifth-avenue Hotel, yesterday, for Washington. He was tendered a serenade at his hotel on Thursday evening, but was obliged to decline on account of ill health and the necessity of an early departure for Washington.
lead_paragraph: Hon. J.E. BOULINGNEY, Member of Congress from New-Orleans, left the Fifth-avenue Hotel, yesterday, for Washington. He was tendered a serenade at his hotel on Thursday evening, but was obliged to decline on account of ill health and the necessity of an early departure for Washington.

abstract: Since the commencement of the rebellion, recruiting in this City, or the State, has not been so brisk as it is at the present time. The General Order No. 31, issued by the Governor May 23, immensely facilitates it. Though no official report has been made, it is stated that the recruiting officers now in various parts of the State are very successful, volunteers flocking in upon them so readily that it is the general impression that no difficulty will be experienced in raising the new levy. It was also stated that the Twelfth Regiment enrolled yesterday as many as five hundred men. And the officers of the Sixty-ninth declared that, if it were needed, they could raise a brigade in eight hours.
lead_paragraph: Since the commencement of the rebellion, recruiting in this City, or the State, has not been so brisk as it is at the present time. And the officers of the Sixty-ninth declared that, if it were needed, they could raise a brigade in eight hours.
